description: The Google Apps for Work Certified Administrator certification is designed to cover the day-to-day skills required to manage Google Apps in a business environment. Testers are expected to be proficient in managing the cloud-based software suite via the centrally managed web-based portal. Topics covered include user and identity management, access control, data storage management and many others. The typical viewer would be anyone responsible for the deployment and maintenance of Google Apps for Work.
name: Google Apps for Work
subtitle: Certified Administrator

episodes.title: Overview of Google for Work
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:08,071
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08,071 --> 00:00:13,095
For many organizations setting up
collaboration software, document editing,

3
00:00:13,095 --> 00:00:18,950
spreadsheet software, and online storage
is a really very difficult undertaking.

4
00:00:18,950 --> 00:00:22,370
And that's where organizations like Google
have stepped in to provide products like

5
00:00:22,370 --> 00:00:26,470
Google Apps that make you not
have to reinvent the wheel.

6
00:00:26,470 --> 00:00:29,250
Google Apps is a well-rounded
suite of software and

7
00:00:29,250 --> 00:00:33,550
online services that provides the needs
for most small and medium organizations.

8
00:00:33,550 --> 00:00:37,190
I say, small and medium,
really large and enterprise too.

9
00:00:37,190 --> 00:00:41,190
There are enterprise customers with
Google that have hundreds of thousands of

10
00:00:41,190 --> 00:00:46,510
employees all using solely Google Apps
accounts, it's really impressive.

11
00:00:46,510 --> 00:00:50,090
With Google Apps,
you get a full office suite,

12
00:00:50,090 --> 00:00:54,390
you get the ability to do spreadsheets,
documents,

13
00:00:54,390 --> 00:00:59,150
slide presentations, all within an online
hosted application environment,

14
00:00:59,150 --> 00:01:02,240
which means no software needs
to be installed on the client.

15
00:01:02,240 --> 00:01:05,393
In addition to that, you get shared
storage through Google Drive,

16
00:01:05,393 --> 00:01:09,449
you get group mailing lists, calendaring,
all sorts of additional functionality.

17
00:01:09,449 --> 00:01:13,808
And really the best part of it is that it
is all hosted on Google state of the art

18
00:01:13,808 --> 00:01:18,713
data centers, so you don't have to back it
up, you don't have to pay the power bill,

19
00:01:18,713 --> 00:01:21,890
you don't have to manage the resources for
that.

20
00:01:21,890 --> 00:01:27,370
It's all done for you at a per user
license fee that you can adapt as

21
00:01:27,370 --> 00:01:31,910
your company shrinks and grows, so it is
a great solution for a lot of companies.

22
00:01:31,910 --> 00:01:35,460
The challenge though, is getting it
set up, and getting your feet wet.

23
00:01:35,460 --> 00:01:37,540
For a lot of people this
is a new way to think.

24
00:01:37,540 --> 00:01:40,570
A lot of us are stuck in the old
paradigm of you buy a desktop,

25
00:01:40,570 --> 00:01:43,160
you install your software right there,
and you're done.

26
00:01:43,160 --> 00:01:46,680
Now, we're transitioning it off, so
that the desktop doesn't matter anymore.

27
00:01:46,680 --> 00:01:50,590
You could be on your laptop, your cell
phone, your desktop PC, your desktop Mac,

28
00:01:50,590 --> 00:01:54,690
a Linux machine, doesn't matter, and you
can access the same exact software, and

29
00:01:54,690 --> 00:01:57,280
the same exact resources
without installing anything

30
00:01:57,280 --> 00:01:59,860
aside from a web browser
on your workstation.

31
00:01:59,860 --> 00:02:02,127
So, really handy, really neat technology,

32
00:02:02,127 --> 00:02:04,400
and a lot of organizations
are going that way.

33
00:02:04,400 --> 00:02:09,981
ITProTV, when we first started to form our
company, Edutainment Live, we decided,

34
00:02:09,981 --> 00:02:14,723
let's go with Google Apps,
because we don't need the infrastructure,

35
00:02:14,723 --> 00:02:20,730
we need to focus on creating shows, not
focus on managing our own document system.

36
00:02:20,730 --> 00:02:24,100
So, that's a great solution for
a lot of organizations, and

37
00:02:24,100 --> 00:02:26,470
that's what we're gonna
be covering in this show.

38
00:02:26,470 --> 00:02:29,650
Now, when we set out to do this show,
it was just gonna be a skills show.

39
00:02:29,650 --> 00:02:34,120
A how to use Google Apps in your
organization, but during the planning

40
00:02:34,120 --> 00:02:37,690
process of our show, we were talking to
some of the guys that are at Google, and

41
00:02:37,690 --> 00:02:40,730
they informed us of a new
certification they were releasing.

42
00:02:40,730 --> 00:02:44,230
Which is the Google Apps
certified administrator, so

43
00:02:44,230 --> 00:02:48,560
they now have an administrator
certification that's available.

44
00:02:48,560 --> 00:02:51,605
You can go and show your knowledge
of working with Google Apps,

45
00:02:51,605 --> 00:02:54,708
it's supposed to be the equivalent
of working, they say here,

46
00:02:54,708 --> 00:02:57,479
six months of experience managing 50,
or more users.

47
00:02:57,479 --> 00:03:01,654
It's kind of a what the certification
shows, and you can take their exam, and

48
00:03:01,654 --> 00:03:05,150
when you pass, you're a Google Apps
certified administrator.

49
00:03:05,150 --> 00:03:07,960
You can show people that
you have that knowledge, so

50
00:03:07,960 --> 00:03:10,010
it was really excellent timing.

51
00:03:10,010 --> 00:03:13,490
We got a chance to see the exam
while it was in beta, and

52
00:03:13,490 --> 00:03:15,820
now we're gonna produce
the show built around it.

53
00:03:15,820 --> 00:03:19,510
So, our general skill show has
actually become a certification show,

54
00:03:19,510 --> 00:03:22,800
it's kinda neat that happened and
all, it kinda just fell into place.

55
00:03:24,290 --> 00:03:27,560
I'll post the link to this website with
the show notes, you get a chance to see

56
00:03:27,560 --> 00:03:30,560
those, but basically, what it is
is a certification that just shows

57
00:03:30,560 --> 00:03:35,090
you have the know how to setup, and
operate a Google Apps environment.

58
00:03:35,090 --> 00:03:38,420
The things that a company is going
to need to know, things like

59
00:03:38,420 --> 00:03:42,390
adding user accounts and removing
user accounts, managing Google Drive,

60
00:03:42,390 --> 00:03:46,090
managing security, all the other
pieces inside of Google Apps.

61
00:03:46,090 --> 00:03:47,610
It's important stuff to know, and

62
00:03:47,610 --> 00:03:50,820
if you've not worked with this environment
before, it's a great way to learn.

63
00:03:51,900 --> 00:03:54,070
Now, if you wanna get the certification,
some of you don't,

64
00:03:54,070 --> 00:03:57,270
some of you just wanna learn how to
use Google apps, and that's great.

65
00:03:57,270 --> 00:03:58,980
But if you wanna get the certification,

66
00:03:58,980 --> 00:04:02,910
it's a pretty straight forward process,
the test itself costs $100.

67
00:04:02,910 --> 00:04:06,800
So, it's not as high priced as some of
the other exams that are out there, but

68
00:04:06,800 --> 00:04:11,150
the part that I like best is that
it's not a multiple choice exam.

69
00:04:11,150 --> 00:04:15,414
Instead, it's a hands on practical exam,
when you sign up for this,

70
00:04:15,414 --> 00:04:19,625
you're gonna be logging into
a temporary Google Apps environment.

71
00:04:19,625 --> 00:04:23,773
An account they've set up just for
you, and they'll give you a series of

72
00:04:23,773 --> 00:04:28,669
scenario-based statements, not questions,
really like config documentation,

73
00:04:28,669 --> 00:04:33,021
saying we need you to set up this
organization and these sub organizations,

74
00:04:33,021 --> 00:04:37,610
and make sure you set this password
policy for this organization.

75
00:04:37,610 --> 00:04:42,100
So, they're telling you what to do,
and then you do it, you log in and

76
00:04:42,100 --> 00:04:43,280
you actually get in there and

77
00:04:43,280 --> 00:04:45,870
work with the software to put
the configuration in place.

78
00:04:45,870 --> 00:04:50,230
Now, they don't care how you do it,
when you're done, when you submit that

79
00:04:50,230 --> 00:04:55,240
exam to be graded, they run some scripts
to look at what's the final product.

80
00:04:55,240 --> 00:04:59,330
They don't care, which way you achieved
your goal, they just care about the goal.

81
00:04:59,330 --> 00:05:03,170
If they ask you to set a password policy,
and you use the GUI to do it, wonderful,

82
00:05:03,170 --> 00:05:06,450
if you used an API call to do it,
wonderful, they don't care.

83
00:05:06,450 --> 00:05:09,639
But a check to make sure that the end
result is what was right, and

84
00:05:09,639 --> 00:05:11,308
then if it is, you pass the exam.

85
00:05:11,308 --> 00:05:15,470
So, I really enjoyed that, that was
a breath of fresh air compared to other

86
00:05:15,470 --> 00:05:19,780
exams that are multiple choice, or
drag and drop, or fake user interfaces.

87
00:05:19,780 --> 00:05:23,130
I hate those, when they give you some
kind of like flash animation, and

88
00:05:23,130 --> 00:05:25,850
you pretend like you're in the UI.

89
00:05:25,850 --> 00:05:28,390
Here it's the actual product, really cool.

90
00:05:28,390 --> 00:05:30,840
A little bit more about the exam,
I said it's $100, and

91
00:05:30,840 --> 00:05:35,900
it's a practical exam, you can take
it from anywhere in the world.

92
00:05:35,900 --> 00:05:39,150
You don't have to go to testing center to
do it, you can take it from your own desk.

93
00:05:39,150 --> 00:05:43,160
You'll log in to an actual Google Apps
environment that they built custom,

94
00:05:43,160 --> 00:05:44,750
just for you.

95
00:05:44,750 --> 00:05:47,790
It's a two hour exam, so
when you start the exam,

96
00:05:47,790 --> 00:05:50,230
you've got two hours to get it completed.

97
00:05:50,230 --> 00:05:52,320
And when you're exam timer starts,

98
00:05:52,320 --> 00:05:56,960
when you hit that Start button,
you'll get access to a Google Drive share

99
00:05:56,960 --> 00:05:59,880
that has a couple of documents in
it that are telling you what to do.

100
00:05:59,880 --> 00:06:02,695
All the different actions
that you need to perform, and

101
00:06:02,695 --> 00:06:04,990
they're broken up into sections.

102
00:06:04,990 --> 00:06:08,160
They start with activities that
might take a long time to implement

103
00:06:08,160 --> 00:06:11,380
because you've only got two hours, and
you need to get started on those first.

104
00:06:11,380 --> 00:06:14,630
And then they break it up by section for
other one's, so if you get hung up on

105
00:06:14,630 --> 00:06:19,370
something and you can't do it, you can
skip past it and work on other things.

106
00:06:19,370 --> 00:06:23,490
Some of them are interrelated, but most of
them aren't, that way if you're stuck at

107
00:06:23,490 --> 00:06:26,340
one point, you don't just have to
give up on the rest of the exam and

108
00:06:26,340 --> 00:06:30,720
fail, you can skip over it, work on
the other things, and come back later, and

109
00:06:30,720 --> 00:06:32,800
try and
fix that part that you were stuck on.

110
00:06:32,800 --> 00:06:36,170
So, that's kind of a nice thing too,
but you work on the environment and

111
00:06:36,170 --> 00:06:39,150
when your two hours are up,
you lose access to your documents, and

112
00:06:39,150 --> 00:06:41,060
you lose access to the environment.

113
00:06:41,060 --> 00:06:44,050
They'll grade your exam right then,
and you'll find out,

114
00:06:44,050 --> 00:06:47,350
it's almost instantaneous that you'll
find out whether you passed or failed.

115
00:06:47,350 --> 00:06:50,089
It only takes a moment for
their scripts to run to grade it.

116
00:06:50,089 --> 00:06:54,339
Now, because the exam is done in
an actual Google Apps environment,

117
00:06:54,339 --> 00:06:57,400
it takes a little while
to get that set up.

118
00:06:57,400 --> 00:07:00,750
So, when you register for
the exam, and you pay for it, and

119
00:07:00,750 --> 00:07:03,970
you schedule to take it,
you'll get a notice saying, hey,

120
00:07:03,970 --> 00:07:08,530
it could take up to 48 hours to build
the environment, and get it ready for you.

121
00:07:08,530 --> 00:07:11,580
So, if you're planning on
taking the test tomorrow,

122
00:07:11,580 --> 00:07:14,270
you really should have signed up for
it yesterday.

123
00:07:14,270 --> 00:07:17,600
So, don't expect to be able to take
the test the same day that you

124
00:07:17,600 --> 00:07:18,720
register for it.

125
00:07:18,720 --> 00:07:20,220
It could take up to 48 hours now,

126
00:07:20,220 --> 00:07:22,870
I'll tell you from my experience,
it's usually much less.

127
00:07:22,870 --> 00:07:26,280
I think it took about four hours for
me, so it was ready pretty quickly, but

128
00:07:26,280 --> 00:07:28,650
don't bank on that,
it depends on how busy they are and

129
00:07:28,650 --> 00:07:30,590
how much activity is in the system.

130
00:07:30,590 --> 00:07:34,320
So, if you wanna take the exam on Monday,
you should probably register for

131
00:07:34,320 --> 00:07:36,690
it on a Saturday,
that way you know it'll be ready.

132
00:07:36,690 --> 00:07:39,140
Now, once it's ready,
you have a window of time,

133
00:07:39,140 --> 00:07:42,660
I believe it's seven days or,
do I have that written down?

134
00:07:42,660 --> 00:07:44,930
I don't.
I believe it's seven days to actually take

135
00:07:44,930 --> 00:07:46,020
the exam, and

136
00:07:46,020 --> 00:07:51,140
when you click the start button,
that's when your two hour window starts.

137
00:07:51,140 --> 00:07:53,980
Now, you might get disconnected,
during my exam I actually did

138
00:07:53,980 --> 00:07:57,200
get disconnected at one point,
my user credentials stopped working.

139
00:07:57,200 --> 00:08:00,910
I had to just log out and log back in,
and it remembers exactly where you were.

140
00:08:00,910 --> 00:08:01,940
It's Google Apps,

141
00:08:01,940 --> 00:08:04,800
you don't lose your settings just
because you got disconnected.

142
00:08:04,800 --> 00:08:08,060
So, don't worry about that, but
if you do get disconnected,

143
00:08:08,060 --> 00:08:10,300
you still have that two hour
window that you're operating in.

144
00:08:10,300 --> 00:08:13,820
So, just because you got disconnected,
doesn't mean the timer has stopped

145
00:08:13,820 --> 00:08:18,395
running, you need to get back in there as
quickly as you can, and continue working.

146
00:08:19,905 --> 00:08:23,228
Now, during the exam, you have all
the tools that you would normally have

147
00:08:23,228 --> 00:08:25,277
at your disposal, you're in a web browser.

148
00:08:25,277 --> 00:08:28,749
So, if you forget how to do something
you can pull the documentation up, and

149
00:08:28,749 --> 00:08:29,410
find out how.

150
00:08:29,410 --> 00:08:32,971
That sounds great, the easiest exam ever,
it's open book, but

151
00:08:32,971 --> 00:08:35,885
the amount of time you spend searching for
an answer,

152
00:08:35,885 --> 00:08:39,420
could be the difference between
you passing in failing.

153
00:08:39,420 --> 00:08:43,010
If you know how to do something, you can
jump right to it, and answer it, and

154
00:08:43,010 --> 00:08:44,020
you're in business.

155
00:08:44,020 --> 00:08:45,920
If you're looking in
the help documentation,

156
00:08:45,920 --> 00:08:49,410
you'll likely run out of time, so
don't rely on that as a crutch,

157
00:08:49,410 --> 00:08:51,340
you wanna make sure you're ready for
the topics.

158
00:08:52,850 --> 00:08:56,620
The only real requirement for your PC,
because you can be on a Mac, or

159
00:08:56,620 --> 00:09:00,850
a Windows machine, or whatever,
they do require you to have a web camera.

160
00:09:00,850 --> 00:09:02,940
During the exam it'll take your picture,

161
00:09:02,940 --> 00:09:06,390
right at the beginning of the exam,
and throughout the exam it'll take

162
00:09:06,390 --> 00:09:10,620
random pictures to ensure that
you're the person taking the test.

163
00:09:10,620 --> 00:09:12,320
So, you do need a web camera to take it,

164
00:09:12,320 --> 00:09:16,290
but other than that you just need a web
browser, preferably Google Chrome, and

165
00:09:16,290 --> 00:09:18,720
you can log in, take the exam,
and do everything that you need.

166
00:09:20,260 --> 00:09:24,101
So, that's a little bit about the exam,
once you've signed up and you take it,

167
00:09:24,101 --> 00:09:27,546
you pass, and you'll get certificates
in the mail a few days later, but

168
00:09:27,546 --> 00:09:30,963
you get immediate notification that
you pass, so really nice to have.

169
00:09:30,963 --> 00:09:34,124
If for some reason you don't
pass on the first attempt,

170
00:09:34,124 --> 00:09:38,629
then you have to wait 14 days in between
attempts, so basically, two weeks,

171
00:09:38,629 --> 00:09:42,690
if you fail, you've got to wait two
weeks to be able to repeat the exam.

172
00:09:44,530 --> 00:09:45,660
That's really about it for

173
00:09:45,660 --> 00:09:49,490
requirements on the exam,
it does cover a wide breadth of topics.

174
00:09:49,490 --> 00:09:52,790
You'll see they have the Administrator
Exam FAQ right here, where they layout

175
00:09:52,790 --> 00:09:56,980
some basic information here, which is
basically what I was just talking about.

176
00:09:56,980 --> 00:10:01,030
But there's also
the Administrator Study Guide, and

177
00:10:01,030 --> 00:10:04,180
this shows you everything
that's on the exam.

178
00:10:04,180 --> 00:10:09,820
It starts out with managing user accounts,
that accounts for 23% of the exam.

179
00:10:09,820 --> 00:10:14,020
You'll see organizational units,
which are only about 10% of the exam.

180
00:10:14,020 --> 00:10:16,960
Google App service and
organizational access,

181
00:10:16,960 --> 00:10:21,700
so which services you allow to be
used by your users, that's 14%.

182
00:10:21,700 --> 00:10:25,649
Mail delivery routing and filtering,
you'll learn about spam filtering, and

183
00:10:25,649 --> 00:10:28,504
e-mail domain attachment,
and so on, that's 18%.

184
00:10:28,504 --> 00:10:30,850
Calendar setting are 7%.

185
00:10:30,850 --> 00:10:35,508
Mobile policies, that's getting to be
a real important thing for businesses,

186
00:10:35,508 --> 00:10:36,430
that's 8%.

187
00:10:36,430 --> 00:10:38,260
And then lastly, sorry not lastly.

188
00:10:38,260 --> 00:10:41,390
Then we've got security,
which is 10% and groups.

189
00:10:41,390 --> 00:10:44,170
I said lastly cuz I always think
of groups as part of security.

190
00:10:44,170 --> 00:10:48,790
But security and groups are the remaining
10% there, is what the exam covers.

191
00:10:48,790 --> 00:10:50,410
They are very open about this.

192
00:10:50,410 --> 00:10:53,890
This exam study guide is
really all you need to study.

193
00:10:53,890 --> 00:10:54,740
Every question,

194
00:10:54,740 --> 00:10:58,508
everything that they ask you to do on
the exam is right here in the guide.

195
00:10:58,508 --> 00:11:01,840
If you wanna learn about deploying users,
you can come in, and pull this up, and

196
00:11:01,840 --> 00:11:04,570
it will show all the different
ways that we can add users, and

197
00:11:04,570 --> 00:11:06,570
you can read through that documentation.

198
00:11:06,570 --> 00:11:10,270
Here on the show what we're doing is that
we're turning that into a concise format,

199
00:11:10,270 --> 00:11:13,520
so you can watch instead of having
to read through page after page.

200
00:11:13,520 --> 00:11:17,310
And so during the course of the show I'll
demonstrate how to do all these things.

201
00:11:17,310 --> 00:11:19,930
I'll show you where to go in Google apps,
and how to configure and

202
00:11:19,930 --> 00:11:21,280
modify these settings, and

203
00:11:21,280 --> 00:11:25,790
how to get them put in place in different
scenarios, but it's all right here.

204
00:11:25,790 --> 00:11:31,510
So, this is really a nice certification in
that the material right here is available,

205
00:11:31,510 --> 00:11:34,860
they're very honest about what's gonna
be on the exam, it's all right here.

206
00:11:34,860 --> 00:11:37,784
It's pretty pleasant experience compared
to some of the other vendors that

207
00:11:37,784 --> 00:11:38,385
are out there.

208
00:11:38,385 --> 00:11:41,224
Now, if you wanna practice
to get ready for this exam,

209
00:11:41,224 --> 00:11:45,300
you know from the administrator guide
the topics that are gonna be on there, so

210
00:11:45,300 --> 00:11:47,870
you know the type of stuff
you need to be aware of.

211
00:11:47,870 --> 00:11:51,796
These maybe things that you're not used
to, you haven't worked with before,

212
00:11:51,796 --> 00:11:55,898
maybe you haven't worked with Google Apps
before, or maybe you have Google Apps in

213
00:11:55,898 --> 00:12:00,390
your company but you haven't used some
of the features they're talking about.

episodes.title: Create New Users
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,008 --> 00:00:05,184
[SOUND] Objective 1.1 covers how

2
00:00:05,184 --> 00:00:13,579
to create new users inside
of your Google Apps account.

3
00:00:13,579 --> 00:00:14,955
When you setup your initial account,

4
00:00:14,955 --> 00:00:17,330
it is not incredibly useful until
you get some users put in there.

5
00:00:17,330 --> 00:00:19,800
So this is a pretty important step for us.

6
00:00:19,800 --> 00:00:22,840
There's three different way to
create new users in Google App but

7
00:00:22,840 --> 00:00:24,770
it's all done through the same system.

8
00:00:24,770 --> 00:00:26,440
In fact, here let me just show you.

9
00:00:26,440 --> 00:00:32,050
When I log in to my admin console, one of
my admin console icons is to create users.

10
00:00:32,050 --> 00:00:34,560
And on a new account
when you go in to users,

11
00:00:34,560 --> 00:00:37,630
it's going to be mostly empty,
you'll see yourself in there,

12
00:00:37,630 --> 00:00:40,350
you've got an account as
the administrator that set it up.

13
00:00:40,350 --> 00:00:41,520
But that's it.

14
00:00:41,520 --> 00:00:43,530
Now we need to get other users in there.

15
00:00:43,530 --> 00:00:46,480
You've got the add user icon
up top which is a little

16
00:00:46,480 --> 00:00:48,980
person with a plus symbol by their head,
that's the icon.

17
00:00:48,980 --> 00:00:51,790
And when we click on
that it's going to ask us

18
00:00:51,790 --> 00:00:55,060
which of the three ways we want
to use to create the user's.

19
00:00:55,060 --> 00:00:58,590
The most common method is the first
one which is to add a user manually.

20
00:00:59,640 --> 00:01:02,120
We just choose that option and
hit Continue.

21
00:01:02,120 --> 00:01:04,930
And we'll provide
information about the user.

22
00:01:04,930 --> 00:01:08,830
To create a user account, Google Apps
needs four pieces of information.

23
00:01:08,830 --> 00:01:13,620
They need a first name, a last name,
an email address, and a password.

24
00:01:13,620 --> 00:01:15,430
And we'll see that over and over again.

25
00:01:15,430 --> 00:01:17,010
No matter which way you
create the account,

26
00:01:17,010 --> 00:01:18,890
those are the four pieces
of information you need.

27
00:01:18,890 --> 00:01:21,820
First name, last name,
email address, password.

28
00:01:21,820 --> 00:01:23,890
So I can just punch that in here.

29
00:01:23,890 --> 00:01:25,760
I'll create an account for
one of our other show hosts.

30
00:01:25,760 --> 00:01:27,100
I'll do Ronnie Wong.

31
00:01:27,100 --> 00:01:30,490
All right, and
I'll need to give him an email address, so

32
00:01:30,490 --> 00:01:35,550
maybe I'll do rwong@itpro.tv.net,
so I'll punch that one in.

33
00:01:35,550 --> 00:01:39,548
And then for the password, the default
is to do a temporary password so

34
00:01:39,548 --> 00:01:41,840
we're just gonna automatically assign one.

35
00:01:41,840 --> 00:01:47,070
And then we can do the password reset
option to get a new password set on there,

36
00:01:47,070 --> 00:01:49,850
or alternatively I can go in and
set a password myself.

37
00:01:49,850 --> 00:01:51,420
I can click on set a password.

38
00:01:52,740 --> 00:01:54,050
And I can punch one in.

39
00:01:54,050 --> 00:01:57,400
Now it's going to gauge the strength
of that password to find out whether or

40
00:01:57,400 --> 00:01:59,610
not it's a strong password or a weak one.

41
00:01:59,610 --> 00:02:02,810
You can see I've typed in a weak password
here and it's not too happy about that.

42
00:02:02,810 --> 00:02:05,910
It will let you use it but
it's not too happy about it.

43
00:02:05,910 --> 00:02:07,480
It's only if it fails completely,

44
00:02:07,480 --> 00:02:10,130
if you get a red password that
it will actually stop you.

45
00:02:10,130 --> 00:02:14,200
So let me just punch in a stronger
password for this user account.

46
00:02:14,200 --> 00:02:17,520
And now you'll see as I use capital and
lower case letters and so

47
00:02:17,520 --> 00:02:22,270
on, that the strength meter goes to green,
letting me know that it is more secure.

48
00:02:22,270 --> 00:02:25,480
So we're kind of covered there, and
now I can take this password, and

49
00:02:25,480 --> 00:02:26,470
I give it to that user.

50
00:02:26,470 --> 00:02:29,330
They can log in, and
they're in business, right?

51
00:02:29,330 --> 00:02:32,950
We can auto generate the password
again if we want to switch back, but

52
00:02:32,950 --> 00:02:34,400
here we at least know it.

53
00:02:34,400 --> 00:02:36,890
Now technically that's all I need,
I can hit Create User and

54
00:02:36,890 --> 00:02:40,080
I'm done, but you might have more
information for that user, and

55
00:02:40,080 --> 00:02:42,690
if you do,
you can just hit Additional Info, and

56
00:02:42,690 --> 00:02:46,810
you can provide all the optional
information that person might have.

57
00:02:46,810 --> 00:02:48,800
They might have more than
one email address, so

58
00:02:48,800 --> 00:02:51,250
you can list additional
email addresses here.

59
00:02:51,250 --> 00:02:54,270
You can enter in home phone numbers and
addresses.

60
00:02:54,270 --> 00:02:57,480
Work numbers and addresses,
and mobile phone numbers.

61
00:02:57,480 --> 00:03:00,270
Well I guess you wouldn't really have
a mobile address, that one's not there.

62
00:03:00,270 --> 00:03:02,080
But you can add in each of those, and

63
00:03:02,080 --> 00:03:03,950
you can do more than one by
using that add new button.

64
00:03:05,310 --> 00:03:07,720
On the last screen,
you've got employee details.

65
00:03:07,720 --> 00:03:11,390
Employee ID, type, title,
manager, and so on.

66
00:03:11,390 --> 00:03:13,220
This is all optional information.

67
00:03:13,220 --> 00:03:15,390
If you want to have it logged in, great.

68
00:03:15,390 --> 00:03:16,810
If you don't, you can leave it blank.

69
00:03:16,810 --> 00:03:20,050
You can always add it later,
it's entirely up to you.

70
00:03:20,050 --> 00:03:23,220
But when you create user, the user
account get created in our system,

71
00:03:23,220 --> 00:03:25,970
and then we'll see them
appear here in our list.

72
00:03:25,970 --> 00:03:29,440
So now it's telling me the username,
and what the new email address is.

73
00:03:29,440 --> 00:03:32,540
And it's giving me the URL to share
with that user so that they can come and

74
00:03:32,540 --> 00:03:34,460
log in, and access the system.

75
00:03:35,470 --> 00:03:38,350
All right, so,
that method works pretty well, right?

76
00:03:38,350 --> 00:03:39,870
But it's not perfect.

77
00:03:39,870 --> 00:03:43,330
And the main problem with it is if
I have to create a ton of users.

78
00:03:43,330 --> 00:03:45,690
What if I need to create
a hundred new user accounts?

79
00:03:45,690 --> 00:03:47,770
I could run through that
wizard a hundred times.

80
00:03:47,770 --> 00:03:49,280
I'd have to have a lot
of time on my hands, or

81
00:03:49,280 --> 00:03:51,380
be really bored, or
just love monotonous work.

82
00:03:51,380 --> 00:03:55,790
Some people do, but if we want to create
a large quantitative users at once

83
00:03:55,790 --> 00:03:57,850
that method's not too great for us.

84
00:03:57,850 --> 00:04:00,910
But when we hit that add user icon,
you'll see the other option.

85
00:04:00,910 --> 00:04:02,780
Add update several users at once.

86
00:04:04,010 --> 00:04:07,920
Google Docs or Google Apps
supports being updated via a CSV.

87
00:04:07,920 --> 00:04:10,020
A comma separative values sheet.

88
00:04:10,020 --> 00:04:15,770
It's basically a spreadsheet that
is a very plain text simple format.

89
00:04:15,770 --> 00:04:18,510
Almost every spreadsheet
software out there supports it.

90
00:04:18,510 --> 00:04:22,060
So you can use Google Sheets to
generate it right there inside of your

91
00:04:22,060 --> 00:04:23,210
Google Apps account.

92
00:04:23,210 --> 00:04:25,535
You can use Microsoft Excel.

93
00:04:25,535 --> 00:04:27,820
You can use Lotus 123 for
that matter, even old software.

94
00:04:27,820 --> 00:04:32,840
Almost all spreadsheet software
will generate a CSV file, and

95
00:04:32,840 --> 00:04:37,930
in that CSV file, you can list first name,
last name, email address and password.

96
00:04:37,930 --> 00:04:41,360
Those four pieces of information, that's
enough to get those accounts created.

97
00:04:41,360 --> 00:04:45,620
You can provide all the other information
too, if you've got it, mailing address,

98
00:04:45,620 --> 00:04:47,360
phone numbers, and so on.

99
00:04:47,360 --> 00:04:50,390
That CSV, you can make it yourself,
if you want.

100
00:04:50,390 --> 00:04:54,150
But what I normally do is, if you hit
Continue, it gives you the option to

101
00:04:54,150 --> 00:04:59,510
download a CSV that's already formatted
the way that Google wants it, all right.

102
00:04:59,510 --> 00:05:01,970
If you download that,
I'll go ahead and download this one.

103
00:05:03,150 --> 00:05:05,480
So I'm going to download that and
save it to my drive.

104
00:05:05,480 --> 00:05:10,030
When I open that up,
it's just a blank CSV, and it's got

105
00:05:10,030 --> 00:05:13,770
all the different fields that I need
right there across the top of the screen.

106
00:05:13,770 --> 00:05:16,480
Let me zoom on that so
we can actually see what's going on here.

107
00:05:16,480 --> 00:05:19,640
So I've got first name, last name,
email address, and so on.

108
00:05:19,640 --> 00:05:21,770
I just type all that in for my users.

109
00:05:21,770 --> 00:05:24,540
I might already have these employees
logged in another system and

110
00:05:24,540 --> 00:05:28,710
I can just export them and bring them
all right in here one fell swoop.

111
00:05:28,710 --> 00:05:30,800
You can also use this
to update your users.

112
00:05:30,800 --> 00:05:33,420
If you wanna change the users
that are already in the system.

113
00:05:33,420 --> 00:05:36,150
I had that check box back there,
I didn't hit it, but

114
00:05:36,150 --> 00:05:39,110
I had this pre populate
with existing users.

115
00:05:39,110 --> 00:05:41,720
If you check that it'll put
all your existing user data

116
00:05:41,720 --> 00:05:44,680
in there with the exception of passwords,
right, it leaves that blank.

117
00:05:44,680 --> 00:05:48,412
And then you can modify it,
and import it back in.

118
00:05:48,412 --> 00:05:51,400
Now you can make bulk changes to
your users and do it very rapidly.

119
00:05:51,400 --> 00:05:52,360
It's kinda a nice thing.

120
00:05:52,360 --> 00:05:55,700
I know a lot of people might want to add
a secondary email address after the fact,

121
00:05:55,700 --> 00:05:58,540
and if you've already got 100 users,
then you don't wanna have to go and

122
00:05:58,540 --> 00:05:59,930
edit each one individually.

123
00:05:59,930 --> 00:06:03,050
So you can use that pre-populate
option to take care of that.

124
00:06:03,050 --> 00:06:03,720
All right?

125
00:06:03,720 --> 00:06:08,510
Now I've got a CSV file sitting
over here called users.csv.

126
00:06:08,510 --> 00:06:12,370
I generated this before the show,
and it just has a handful of users.

127
00:06:12,370 --> 00:06:16,800
And so I've got their first name, last
name, email address, and passwords for

128
00:06:16,800 --> 00:06:17,790
the system.

129
00:06:17,790 --> 00:06:22,800
Now for the passwords I chose semi-random
passwords that mix capital letters,

130
00:06:22,800 --> 00:06:25,660
lowercase letters, and so
on to pre-populate that so

131
00:06:25,660 --> 00:06:27,180
I can load it in the system.

132
00:06:27,180 --> 00:06:31,350
A lot of people will pick one standard
password and give that to their users and

133
00:06:31,350 --> 00:06:34,160
say, hey when you log in you
need to reset your password.

134
00:06:34,160 --> 00:06:37,520
The problem with that is if one user sees,
hey my passwords 1234,

135
00:06:37,520 --> 00:06:39,850
I bet somebody else's is.

136
00:06:39,850 --> 00:06:43,020
And if they wanted they could start trying
to log in as other users until they find

137
00:06:43,020 --> 00:06:45,770
somebody who hasn't logged in yet
and take over that account.

138
00:06:45,770 --> 00:06:47,140
It's not a good idea.

139
00:06:47,140 --> 00:06:50,970
So it's better to generate dynamic
passwords like these, different for

140
00:06:50,970 --> 00:06:52,790
each user,
that you then distribute to the users.

141
00:06:52,790 --> 00:06:54,500
And you still make them
reset their password.

142
00:06:54,500 --> 00:06:56,990
Make them change their password
when they log in because

143
00:06:56,990 --> 00:07:00,950
if somebody gets a hold of this
spreadsheet you're in hot water, right?

144
00:07:00,950 --> 00:07:05,050
Now for those random passwords,
you can generate them any number of ways.

145
00:07:05,050 --> 00:07:10,800
The way that I like to use is if
you go to the website random.org,

146
00:07:10,800 --> 00:07:13,970
it's a website that specifies
in generating random data.

147
00:07:13,970 --> 00:07:20,660
And so they have got all sorta of junk in
here for games and lotteries and so on.

148
00:07:20,660 --> 00:07:21,690
But if you scroll down a bit,

149
00:07:21,690 --> 00:07:24,650
you'll find in here where
they've got one for passwords.

150
00:07:24,650 --> 00:07:26,400
I always miss it here on this screen.

151
00:07:26,400 --> 00:07:27,270
Let me just search for password.

152
00:07:27,270 --> 00:07:27,980
There it is.

153
00:07:27,980 --> 00:07:31,270
Under Lists and Strings,
we've got password generator.

154
00:07:31,270 --> 00:07:35,550
And so you can go in there and tell it hey
I need to generate 50 random passwords

155
00:07:35,550 --> 00:07:40,800
that are say ten characters each, and
hit Get, and it'll generate those and

156
00:07:40,800 --> 00:07:43,810
you can just copy and
paste this right into your spreadsheet and

157
00:07:43,810 --> 00:07:45,790
there's some dynamic password for
you to use.

158
00:07:45,790 --> 00:07:49,799
A great way to like seed a CSV file to
already have that information in there.

159
00:07:52,040 --> 00:07:54,020
All right, but
once we have got that CSV developed,

160
00:07:54,020 --> 00:07:58,030
all we have to do is go in here and choose
to attach a file, and notice this option.

161
00:07:58,030 --> 00:08:01,110
Require user to change
password at next sign-in.

162
00:08:01,110 --> 00:08:02,100
That is what we want.

163
00:08:02,100 --> 00:08:05,950
We'll give them this temporary password
that we set and the first time they login,

164
00:08:05,950 --> 00:08:08,530
they are going to have to
change their password.

165
00:08:08,530 --> 00:08:11,519
So I will go in and
attach that CSV that I made.

166
00:08:13,050 --> 00:08:16,820
Which I've got buried away in
here somewhere in my show notes.

167
00:08:16,820 --> 00:08:18,700
Let me just find that real quick.

168
00:08:18,700 --> 00:08:23,860
And we'll import it and it will create
all of those users in one big fell swoop

169
00:08:23,860 --> 00:08:27,110
which does make life a heck
of a lot easier on us.

170
00:08:27,110 --> 00:08:28,410
So I'll go ahead to
choose to bring that in.

171
00:08:28,410 --> 00:08:32,430
I'm going to leave the check mark to
require users to change their passwords.

172
00:08:32,430 --> 00:08:34,040
And we'll upload it.

173
00:08:34,040 --> 00:08:36,570
Now it says that it's adding six users.

174
00:08:36,570 --> 00:08:38,190
It's not actually done, right.

175
00:08:38,190 --> 00:08:41,720
So it's going to run and it says it
will email me when it's complete.

176
00:08:41,720 --> 00:08:44,930
I'll get an email at this address
letting me know the users are complete.

177
00:08:44,930 --> 00:08:48,430
It usually doesn't take very long, but
the more accounts you're importing,

178
00:08:48,430 --> 00:08:49,980
the longer this can take.

179
00:08:49,980 --> 00:08:54,110
So you can wait for that email or you can
just sit here and refresh this screen.

180
00:08:54,110 --> 00:08:57,170
And eventually you'll see all
the additional users start to appear.

181
00:08:57,170 --> 00:08:58,290
So there they go.

182
00:08:58,290 --> 00:09:01,060
I can see all the users that I just
imported in addition to myself.

183
00:09:01,060 --> 00:09:04,410
Now they all say never logged
in because they're new accounts.

184
00:09:04,410 --> 00:09:05,630
They haven't logged in.

185
00:09:05,630 --> 00:09:09,260
I need to go and give them their new user
name and password and the URL to go to.

186
00:09:09,260 --> 00:09:12,149
And the first time they log in,
they'll punch in that new password.

187
00:09:13,350 --> 00:09:17,060
All right, so we've seen manual creation
of user accounts, and we've seen creation

188
00:09:17,060 --> 00:09:20,460
of the user accounts using a CSV,
pretty straightforward, all right.

189
00:09:20,460 --> 00:09:24,890
There is a third method for creating user
account, and that's to send an invitation.

190
00:09:24,890 --> 00:09:28,830
If I hit the little plus
sign here on the user and

191
00:09:28,830 --> 00:09:32,430
choose invite users,
my third option, all right.

192
00:09:32,430 --> 00:09:36,640
This is useful if the users already
have an email address somewhere else.

193
00:09:36,640 --> 00:09:40,190
We can choose to send them an invite
at their current email address.

194
00:09:40,190 --> 00:09:45,210
And they can click on that invite and
it will let them pick their password,

195
00:09:45,210 --> 00:09:47,320
and put in their own information.

196
00:09:47,320 --> 00:09:51,350
So instead of having to know it
ahead of time and have us enter it,

197
00:09:51,350 --> 00:09:54,650
where we might make mistakes,
we can have them enter it themselves.

198
00:09:54,650 --> 00:09:55,320
All right?
So

199
00:09:55,320 --> 00:09:57,830
it definitely takes a little
bit of burden off of us.

200
00:09:57,830 --> 00:10:01,200
To invite a user, the only thing
you need is their email address.

201
00:10:01,200 --> 00:10:05,010
So you pick who it is that you want to
invite and you send them an invitation.

202
00:10:05,010 --> 00:10:06,910
So I could invite, here,

203
00:10:06,910 --> 00:10:10,460
I'll do nate@itpro.tv,
one of our other show hosts.

204
00:10:10,460 --> 00:10:14,030
So I'll invite him and
when I hit Continue,

205
00:10:14,030 --> 00:10:16,370
it's going to show me the invitation
that it's going to send him.

206
00:10:16,370 --> 00:10:17,880
Just a simple message saying,

207
00:10:17,880 --> 00:10:20,770
hey, I'm inviting you to use
the Google Apps one, right.

208
00:10:20,770 --> 00:10:25,850
So I'll just say here, oh, actually it

209
00:10:25,850 --> 00:10:29,540
won't let me modify it here, you have to
modify in your main applications settings.

210
00:10:29,540 --> 00:10:32,700
But basically, it's got this generic
little template here that it's gonna send,

211
00:10:32,700 --> 00:10:35,950
and I'll send that along, and
now Nate's gonna get an email.

212
00:10:35,950 --> 00:10:38,650
When he gets it,
he'll be able to click on a link and

213
00:10:38,650 --> 00:10:41,630
create his own account,
specifying his password at that time.

214
00:10:41,630 --> 00:10:45,194
So now there's no messing around with
temporary passwords, that's a good thing,

215
00:10:45,194 --> 00:10:47,070
that's a positive side of this.

216
00:10:47,070 --> 00:10:49,890
On a negative side he's got
to have an existing email

217
00:10:49,890 --> 00:10:52,950
account to be able to send to, but I think
most people have that at this point so

218
00:10:52,950 --> 00:10:55,660
that's probably something very doable.

219
00:10:55,660 --> 00:10:58,200
All right, so those are the three
methods for creating that account.

220
00:10:58,200 --> 00:11:01,940
We've got our manually creating
them individual user accounts,

221
00:11:01,940 --> 00:11:06,710
creating them with a CSV in bulk,
or sending an invitation.

222
00:11:06,710 --> 00:11:08,630
All right, so
that takes care of creating users.

223
00:11:08,630 --> 00:11:11,645
Stay tuned we've got more
topics coming up after this.

224
00:11:11,645 --> 00:11:18,364
[SOUND].

episodes.title: Modifying Users
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:08,033
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08,033 --> 00:00:11,232
Objective 1.2 covers managing our users.

3
00:00:11,232 --> 00:00:15,441
The official one is demonstrate how
to rename users, move users, add or

4
00:00:15,441 --> 00:00:18,360
remove nicknames, and suspend users.

5
00:00:18,360 --> 00:00:19,470
It's a lot, right?

6
00:00:19,470 --> 00:00:22,390
These are basically the day to day
activities that we'll have deal with as we

7
00:00:22,390 --> 00:00:25,320
work with our user accounts
once they've been created.

8
00:00:25,320 --> 00:00:27,250
So, let's just break
this down piece by piece.

9
00:00:27,250 --> 00:00:29,140
The first one is renaming a user.

10
00:00:29,140 --> 00:00:32,720
Now, there's a lot of different scenarios
where we might need to rename a user.

11
00:00:32,720 --> 00:00:35,780
Maybe there was a typo made
when the user was entered in.

12
00:00:35,780 --> 00:00:39,460
Maybe you have a person whose name has
changed, you have that through marriage or

13
00:00:39,460 --> 00:00:42,910
divorce, other things like that that
might result in user's name changing.

14
00:00:42,910 --> 00:00:45,780
So in those scenarios we need
to come in and modify it.

15
00:00:45,780 --> 00:00:48,507
The most common scenario for
me is where you hire somebody and

16
00:00:48,507 --> 00:00:49,694
you know their full name.

17
00:00:49,694 --> 00:00:52,192
But then you find out that
they usually use a nickname,

18
00:00:52,192 --> 00:00:54,852
a shortened version of their name and
so you want to go in and

19
00:00:54,852 --> 00:00:58,040
change their account to reflect
that shortened version.

20
00:00:58,040 --> 00:01:00,690
Whatever the reason it's
all done the same way.

21
00:01:00,690 --> 00:01:04,253
There's actually a couple of different
ways we could go about renaming a user.

22
00:01:04,253 --> 00:01:07,459
The most common way is if we
just go into our users list,

23
00:01:07,459 --> 00:01:11,363
we can pull up our list of users and
if you just float over somebody so

24
00:01:11,363 --> 00:01:15,500
if I float over like Chris Poland here,
I'll float over him.

25
00:01:15,500 --> 00:01:18,600
And when you float over the user name,
you'll see a window pop up

26
00:01:18,600 --> 00:01:22,730
that has their basic contact details and
includes a rename link.

27
00:01:22,730 --> 00:01:26,432
And I can choose Rename and
maybe I wanna make him Christopher.

28
00:01:26,432 --> 00:01:28,996
Right?
So I'll punch in Christopher as the name.

29
00:01:28,996 --> 00:01:32,760
You'll see where I can change
the primary email address also.

30
00:01:32,760 --> 00:01:34,830
You probably don't wanna change that.

31
00:01:34,830 --> 00:01:38,490
If they've been handing out their
email address to other people, well,

32
00:01:38,490 --> 00:01:40,260
you don't want their
email address to change.

33
00:01:40,260 --> 00:01:42,550
People are gonna have a bad
email in their contacts.

34
00:01:42,550 --> 00:01:46,380
So instead, if we wanna do additional
names there, we may want to attach

35
00:01:46,380 --> 00:01:49,390
an alias, which we'll take
a look at here in a few moments.

36
00:01:49,390 --> 00:01:51,170
But here, I can punch this in.

37
00:01:51,170 --> 00:01:54,420
I've got their full name in,
and I can hit rename user.

38
00:01:54,420 --> 00:01:57,210
So that's one way to go about it, right?

39
00:01:57,210 --> 00:02:00,646
Another way would be to actually click
on the user and, if we browse into

40
00:02:00,646 --> 00:02:03,870
the user page for Christopher Poland here,
I can see his account.

41
00:02:03,870 --> 00:02:07,755
I can see his basic information and
you can click on account and

42
00:02:07,755 --> 00:02:10,530
you'll see basic information right here.

43
00:02:10,530 --> 00:02:13,410
So I see the name and
email address and if you hit edit,

44
00:02:13,410 --> 00:02:16,806
the screen's a little bit different but
it's the same thing.

45
00:02:16,806 --> 00:02:18,804
It's using that rename
screen from earlier.

46
00:02:18,804 --> 00:02:21,300
So here, I could put him
back to being Chris Poland.

47
00:02:22,560 --> 00:02:23,390
There we go.

48
00:02:23,390 --> 00:02:25,776
And I can update that user,
and there it is.

49
00:02:25,776 --> 00:02:27,120
Now, they've got the new name.

50
00:02:28,460 --> 00:02:30,833
Notice how my screen hasn't
refreshed to show it.

51
00:02:30,833 --> 00:02:32,740
It does take a moment for
the screens to refresh.

52
00:02:32,740 --> 00:02:35,341
It's usually easier just to go
back out to our user list, and

53
00:02:35,341 --> 00:02:38,962
we'll see that it's already updated there,
and if I go back into the user account,

54
00:02:38,962 --> 00:02:40,049
it's updated, right?

55
00:02:40,049 --> 00:02:44,937
So, your screen might not refresh right
away, but the change did take effect.

56
00:02:44,937 --> 00:02:46,820
So, that's renaming a user.

57
00:02:46,820 --> 00:02:50,230
The next thing that they
call out is moving a user.

58
00:02:50,230 --> 00:02:54,610
I did a bulk import in an earlier import
to bring all of these user accounts in.

59
00:02:54,610 --> 00:02:58,980
When you import your users,
they all end up in your main organization.

60
00:02:58,980 --> 00:03:01,708
Now a lot of companies just
use one organization, so

61
00:03:01,708 --> 00:03:03,199
we don't worry about that.

62
00:03:03,199 --> 00:03:05,570
There's no need to move the users.

63
00:03:05,570 --> 00:03:07,807
But if you have more
than one organization,

64
00:03:07,807 --> 00:03:10,356
you might need to move
users to different places.

65
00:03:10,356 --> 00:03:13,412
Notice here in my company,
on the right side I've got,

66
00:03:13,412 --> 00:03:18,289
here, I'll just move this over a little
bit, I've got organization, itprotv.net,

67
00:03:18,289 --> 00:03:22,110
and underneath it,
I have a suborganization called Retired.

68
00:03:22,110 --> 00:03:25,724
This is where I move my employees that
have retired off to so they're not active

69
00:03:25,724 --> 00:03:29,523
in the company anymore but I still want to
keep their account for various reasons.

70
00:03:29,523 --> 00:03:32,350
Maybe I still provide email
service to them but nothing else.

71
00:03:32,350 --> 00:03:35,680
So I wanna move then to
that sub-organization.

72
00:03:35,680 --> 00:03:39,058
When you create user accounts like this,
especially with a bulk import,

73
00:03:39,058 --> 00:03:40,975
they just go into our main organization.

74
00:03:40,975 --> 00:03:42,160
That's where they are.

75
00:03:42,160 --> 00:03:45,060
Well, when you take a look at a user,
and you float over them,

76
00:03:45,060 --> 00:03:48,290
you don't really see any
option to move the user.

77
00:03:48,290 --> 00:03:51,743
It's a little bit strange but
if you click by user,

78
00:03:51,743 --> 00:03:55,132
you'll see some new buttons
appear up at the top.

79
00:03:55,132 --> 00:03:58,900
And that's where you start to see things
like move to another organization.

80
00:03:58,900 --> 00:04:01,640
It's a little picture of a person
with an arrow on it letting

81
00:04:01,640 --> 00:04:03,550
you know you're gonna
move them somewhere else.

82
00:04:03,550 --> 00:04:07,140
The nice part about this is you
can pick more than one user.

83
00:04:07,140 --> 00:04:10,200
And so we can just go down the list and
pick people that we want to move off.

84
00:04:10,200 --> 00:04:11,470
And you can hit move, and

85
00:04:11,470 --> 00:04:15,505
then it'll let you pick from the various
organizations and sub-organizations.

86
00:04:15,505 --> 00:04:18,420
Allright, if you didn't have any
sub-organizations you can actually see

87
00:04:18,420 --> 00:04:19,870
where you can create new ones right here,
but

88
00:04:19,870 --> 00:04:22,010
we'll talk about that in another segment.

89
00:04:22,010 --> 00:04:25,296
I'm gonna move them off to this
retired one, I'll hit OK, and

90
00:04:25,296 --> 00:04:26,973
that's gonna move them along.

91
00:04:26,973 --> 00:04:30,360
Moving users in bulk is really
easy from the user list.

92
00:04:30,360 --> 00:04:32,050
You can also do it from
the individual user.

93
00:04:32,050 --> 00:04:34,220
So if I pull up Ronnie's page,

94
00:04:34,220 --> 00:04:37,590
when I go in to Ronnie's account you'll
see I've got the move icon right there.

95
00:04:37,590 --> 00:04:41,039
So if I'm just moving one user, I can do
it right from inside of their account.

96
00:04:41,039 --> 00:04:44,980
Whatever works for you guys,
where you happen to be at that point.

97
00:04:44,980 --> 00:04:46,039
The end result is the same.

98
00:04:47,770 --> 00:04:51,330
All right the next little chore
in our list is a nickname.

99
00:04:51,330 --> 00:04:51,830
Right.

100
00:04:51,830 --> 00:04:53,650
We'll use Ronnie here as an example.

101
00:04:53,650 --> 00:04:57,440
So Ronnie is Ronnie Wong, but
his full name is actually Ronald.

102
00:04:57,440 --> 00:05:00,330
I don't think I've ever called
him Ronald in his entire life.

103
00:05:00,330 --> 00:05:02,660
Or in the time I've known him at least.

104
00:05:02,660 --> 00:05:04,570
But that is his full name.

105
00:05:04,570 --> 00:05:06,240
So he has two names.

106
00:05:06,240 --> 00:05:10,290
Ronnie, that he goes by and
Ronald, that is his actual name.

107
00:05:10,290 --> 00:05:13,400
I might want him to have more
than one name in my system.

108
00:05:13,400 --> 00:05:17,672
Now as far as what's displayed on the
screen, we don't normally worry too much

109
00:05:17,672 --> 00:05:21,200
about that, that's just his name and
it's what's shown here.

110
00:05:21,200 --> 00:05:24,275
But where it really becomes
a problem is with email addresses.

111
00:05:24,275 --> 00:05:27,247
Now here we're using first initial,
last name from the email address.

112
00:05:27,247 --> 00:05:32,065
Like rwong@itprotv.net, but
what if I was using first names?

113
00:05:32,065 --> 00:05:35,620
And so
everybody knows that I'm don@itprotv.net.

114
00:05:35,620 --> 00:05:39,936
And then they're like I want to email
Ronnie, I bet he's ronnie@itprotv.net.

115
00:05:39,936 --> 00:05:43,210
Or is he Ronald, I can't remember,
which one is it, right?

116
00:05:43,210 --> 00:05:45,660
So maybe I want him to have
more than one address, and

117
00:05:45,660 --> 00:05:47,610
we can do these through aliases.

118
00:05:47,610 --> 00:05:51,966
When you edit a user account like
this one, you can click on account.

119
00:05:51,966 --> 00:05:55,233
And under the account you'll see
a section called Aliases, and

120
00:05:55,233 --> 00:05:58,940
here's all the different email
addresses that are attached to Ronnie.

121
00:05:58,940 --> 00:06:02,520
He has only got one right
now rwong@itprotv.net.

122
00:06:02,520 --> 00:06:05,040
I can add in new ones.

123
00:06:05,040 --> 00:06:08,245
I'm gonna give him ronnie@itprotv.net.

124
00:06:08,245 --> 00:06:09,120
I'll just hit Save.

125
00:06:11,070 --> 00:06:12,970
And after a moment, that'll save.

126
00:06:12,970 --> 00:06:15,080
Oh shoot, I've already got that
attached to another account.

127
00:06:15,080 --> 00:06:18,413
Let me just do ron here and
I'll punch that one in.

128
00:06:18,413 --> 00:06:24,590
So now he's got rwong@itprotv.net and
then I just added ron.

129
00:06:24,590 --> 00:06:26,948
Now, it's not showing up
here on my screen and

130
00:06:26,948 --> 00:06:29,073
there's two things that can cause this.

131
00:06:29,073 --> 00:06:32,365
The most common just being the page
hasn't refreshed, all right.

132
00:06:32,365 --> 00:06:34,820
Now you might be asking yourself
why didn't we edit this out.

133
00:06:34,820 --> 00:06:38,050
And the reasons is this
happens on the exam too.

134
00:06:38,050 --> 00:06:41,060
So don't panic if you make a change
like that and it doesn't take effect.

135
00:06:41,060 --> 00:06:44,400
The temptation is to immediately try and
add another alias.

136
00:06:44,400 --> 00:06:46,753
But it might be that
the alias is already there.

137
00:06:46,753 --> 00:06:48,525
So a good idea to do is to go ahead and

138
00:06:48,525 --> 00:06:52,210
just hit the refresh button on your
web browser and let the page update.

139
00:06:52,210 --> 00:06:56,045
And that way you can find out whether or
not the alias actually took effect.

140
00:06:56,045 --> 00:06:57,645
Often times you'll find that it did,

141
00:06:57,645 --> 00:07:00,720
that the alias is there even
though the screen didn't show it.

142
00:07:00,720 --> 00:07:01,948
In my case it's not though.

143
00:07:01,948 --> 00:07:03,550
So, I'll need to go ahead and
add it again.

144
00:07:03,550 --> 00:07:05,480
So, I'm gonna go ahead and do that.

145
00:07:05,480 --> 00:07:09,620
Remember when they grade the exam they're
not grading how you did something,

146
00:07:09,620 --> 00:07:11,449
they're grading the end result.

147
00:07:11,449 --> 00:07:14,936
So even though I did it properly,
I typed in the name and I hit submit or

148
00:07:14,936 --> 00:07:18,303
save changes, I did it properly,
if the end result isn't there,

149
00:07:18,303 --> 00:07:20,005
I would get that question wrong.

150
00:07:20,005 --> 00:07:22,565
So it is important that you
make sure you do that properly.

151
00:07:22,565 --> 00:07:25,547
So I'll just re-add it, there we go and

152
00:07:25,547 --> 00:07:30,912
now I can see he's got rwong@itprotv and
ron@itprotv.net, right.

153
00:07:30,912 --> 00:07:33,913
So you can add in more,
it maxes out at 20, you can put up to

154
00:07:33,913 --> 00:07:38,150
20 aliases in there to give people all
the different addresses they need.

155
00:07:38,150 --> 00:07:39,388
You can do more than one domain.

156
00:07:39,388 --> 00:07:43,880
If you've got multiple email domains on
your account, you can punch those in too.

157
00:07:43,880 --> 00:07:47,581
All right, so those are our aliases.

158
00:07:47,581 --> 00:07:49,896
The last thing is suspending an account.

159
00:07:49,896 --> 00:07:53,235
If Ronnie's no longer gonna be working
with us, the temptation is to go and

160
00:07:53,235 --> 00:07:54,510
just delete their account.

161
00:07:55,810 --> 00:07:59,340
But, you may actually have need for some
of the resources attached to that account

162
00:07:59,340 --> 00:08:03,500
down the road, and so a better solution
might be to suspend the account.

163
00:08:03,500 --> 00:08:07,150
Suspending it disables the ability for
somebody to log in, so

164
00:08:07,150 --> 00:08:09,010
he won't be able to log in as his account.

165
00:08:09,010 --> 00:08:12,372
But he'll still receive email, his
documents will still be in Google Drive.

166
00:08:12,372 --> 00:08:14,560
They'll all be sitting there,
he just can't get at them.

167
00:08:14,560 --> 00:08:18,090
That's really useful if you still
need to keep that address valid or

168
00:08:18,090 --> 00:08:21,500
if you think you might
reactivate the user later.

169
00:08:21,500 --> 00:08:25,030
If you delete a user account you've
only got five days to bring them back,

170
00:08:25,030 --> 00:08:26,640
otherwise they lose all their data.

171
00:08:26,640 --> 00:08:30,353
But if you suspend them, you can leave
them suspended forever if you want and

172
00:08:30,353 --> 00:08:32,162
turn them back on whenever you need.

173
00:08:32,162 --> 00:08:33,848
So you might have a seasonal employee,

174
00:08:33,848 --> 00:08:36,670
somebody who just works during
the holiday or during the summer.

175
00:08:36,670 --> 00:08:40,990
And at the end of summer, you suspend them
but knowing that next summer you're going

176
00:08:40,990 --> 00:08:43,480
to turn that account back on and
activate it again.

177
00:08:43,480 --> 00:08:45,280
To suspend someone is really easy.

178
00:08:45,280 --> 00:08:48,620
When you edit their account right
here on their main account page,

179
00:08:48,620 --> 00:08:52,710
you'll see under their picture
is active user in the green bar.

180
00:08:52,710 --> 00:08:55,890
That's letting you know that they're
active, that they're a valid user account,

181
00:08:55,890 --> 00:08:58,180
they can login and do stuff.

182
00:08:58,180 --> 00:09:02,141
If we drop that down, you'll see
suspend user and I can choose that.

183
00:09:02,141 --> 00:09:05,560
It's gonna suspend the user and
it'll let you know they can't login.

184
00:09:05,560 --> 00:09:08,590
They won't be able to get in,
they won't be able to access services, and

185
00:09:08,590 --> 00:09:11,110
they won't receive Invites to Gmail and

186
00:09:11,110 --> 00:09:15,440
calendar, but that's okay they'll still
receive the emails just not invitations.

187
00:09:16,970 --> 00:09:20,260
So, I'll go ahead and hit suspend and
now that account is suspended.

188
00:09:20,260 --> 00:09:23,480
It's still there, but
it can't be logged in with.

189
00:09:23,480 --> 00:09:26,970
And you'll notice when you go
back out to your user screen

190
00:09:26,970 --> 00:09:28,970
that Ronnie no longer shows up here.

191
00:09:28,970 --> 00:09:32,750
So, I don't see Ronnie in my list and he's
not in my little sub-organization either.

192
00:09:32,750 --> 00:09:33,366
He's not in retired.

193
00:09:33,366 --> 00:09:35,293
He's just gone.

194
00:09:35,293 --> 00:09:39,984
Well the reason is the default filter
on the users account defaults to active

195
00:09:39,984 --> 00:09:41,250
users only.

196
00:09:41,250 --> 00:09:42,740
And if I change that and

197
00:09:42,740 --> 00:09:48,200
switch it to suspended users,
then there's Ronnie right there.

198
00:09:48,200 --> 00:09:49,870
So suspended users
are hidden from the view.

199
00:09:49,870 --> 00:09:51,250
Just keep that in mind.

200
00:09:51,250 --> 00:09:52,620
If you don't see your filters option,

201
00:09:52,620 --> 00:09:55,610
make sure you hit the little
funnel icon up here up at the top.

202
00:09:55,610 --> 00:09:59,370
I usually keep that expanded on mine,
and then you can switch back and

203
00:09:59,370 --> 00:10:02,490
forth between active and suspended and
see the different accounts.

204
00:10:04,640 --> 00:10:06,750
All right, so we covered quiet
a bit this segment, right?

205
00:10:06,750 --> 00:10:09,830
We got a chance to see
how to rename a user.

206
00:10:09,830 --> 00:10:12,513
We saw how to move a user
between organizations,

207
00:10:12,513 --> 00:10:16,709
we saw how to add aliases to a user
account if they've got more than one name.

208
00:10:16,709 --> 00:10:20,880
And then we finally wrapped up looking at
suspending a user if they no longer need

209
00:10:20,880 --> 00:10:22,160
access.

210
00:10:22,160 --> 00:10:25,230
So, quite a bit of stuff there, but
nothing too challenging, right?

211
00:10:25,230 --> 00:10:28,070
Pretty easy to do if we just remember
where to go to find the options

212
00:10:28,070 --> 00:10:29,300
we're looking for.

213
00:10:29,300 --> 00:10:30,672
Well I hope you guys enjoyed the segment.

214
00:10:30,672 --> 00:10:34,029
Stay tuned we've got more
Google Apps coming up next.

215
00:10:34,029 --> 00:10:39,262
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Deleting and Restoring Users
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,231 --> 00:00:08,260
[SOUND]

2
00:00:08,260 --> 00:00:11,242
>> Objective 1.3 is demonstrating how to

3
00:00:11,242 --> 00:00:16,270
delete user accounts,
retain data files for the deleted users.

4
00:00:16,270 --> 00:00:19,220
And restore recently
deleted user accounts.

5
00:00:19,220 --> 00:00:22,370
Basically these are the activities
that take place whenever we

6
00:00:22,370 --> 00:00:24,290
remove an employee from our organization.

7
00:00:24,290 --> 00:00:26,130
So important things to know.

8
00:00:26,130 --> 00:00:29,690
When we get rid of a user account well,
deleting them's the easy part.

9
00:00:29,690 --> 00:00:32,320
We can just float over their user account
and you'll see the delete option.

10
00:00:32,320 --> 00:00:34,700
Or we can check off more than one user and
delete them that way.

11
00:00:34,700 --> 00:00:36,710
It's pretty straightforward.

12
00:00:36,710 --> 00:00:41,490
The challenging part, though, is what
happens to their data when we delete them?

13
00:00:41,490 --> 00:00:44,650
If the user account has
data in Google Drive, and

14
00:00:44,650 --> 00:00:48,500
that shared storage across our company,
what happens to their data?

15
00:00:48,500 --> 00:00:53,180
They were the owner, and if I remove them,
who's the owner of the data?

16
00:00:53,180 --> 00:00:55,550
Well, we could just lose it,
then that's one option, right?

17
00:00:55,550 --> 00:00:57,370
But, it's not normally what we want.

18
00:00:57,370 --> 00:01:01,110
So when you go to delete a user, there's
a second activity that's really attached

19
00:01:01,110 --> 00:01:04,530
to it, which is transferring
ownership of their documents.

20
00:01:04,530 --> 00:01:07,470
We wanna make sure that we don't lose
all the documents that they worked on

21
00:01:07,470 --> 00:01:09,830
in the company that they just
didn't share out with other people.

22
00:01:09,830 --> 00:01:12,410
[LAUGH] And if it's an employee
that's being terminated,

23
00:01:12,410 --> 00:01:13,840
that usually happens quite a bit.

24
00:01:13,840 --> 00:01:16,350
So we need to have access to that data.

25
00:01:16,350 --> 00:01:17,490
But Google has got us covered.

26
00:01:17,490 --> 00:01:20,920
They kind of wrap all this
all together into one action.

27
00:01:20,920 --> 00:01:22,220
Let's take a look at it.

28
00:01:22,220 --> 00:01:25,820
Let's say that I have an employee,
like Christopher Walken, right here.

29
00:01:25,820 --> 00:01:27,810
And I'm going to be terminating him.

30
00:01:27,810 --> 00:01:29,370
So he's left the company.

31
00:01:29,370 --> 00:01:30,950
He no longer works for us.

32
00:01:30,950 --> 00:01:32,340
I don't need to suspend his account.

33
00:01:32,340 --> 00:01:34,340
He's quit, he's gone,
he's not coming back.

34
00:01:34,340 --> 00:01:36,060
So, I need to remove his account.

35
00:01:36,060 --> 00:01:40,220
I don't wanna pay the monthly fee to keep
his account here and active, all right?

36
00:01:40,220 --> 00:01:41,740
So I wanna get rid of him, and

37
00:01:41,740 --> 00:01:45,970
when I remove him, I wanna transfer
the ownership of his documents to me.

38
00:01:45,970 --> 00:01:48,930
Any document he had in Google Drive,
I want that assigned to my account so

39
00:01:48,930 --> 00:01:50,890
that I can then give that
out to whoever needs it.

40
00:01:50,890 --> 00:01:54,320
All right, well, if you float
over the user, so if I float over

41
00:01:54,320 --> 00:01:58,650
Christopher Walken, I'll see the delete
option right there, and I can choose that.

42
00:01:58,650 --> 00:02:02,920
Or, if I check him off,
I'll see the delete user icon there.

43
00:02:02,920 --> 00:02:05,770
A third way would be if I
actually go into his account,

44
00:02:05,770 --> 00:02:08,060
I'll see the delete user option there.

45
00:02:08,060 --> 00:02:12,100
All three of them do the exact same thing,
so it doesn't really matter which one we

46
00:02:12,100 --> 00:02:15,390
use, it's just whichever screen we
happen to be on when we're doing it.

47
00:02:15,390 --> 00:02:20,170
So I'll use the float method here and I'm
gonna choose to delete Christopher Walken.

48
00:02:20,170 --> 00:02:21,710
And when I delete them it's gonna warn me,

49
00:02:21,710 --> 00:02:25,970
it's gonna say hey this user has Google
Drive data, what do you wanna do with it?

50
00:02:25,970 --> 00:02:28,770
And the option is to assign
a new owner for that data,

51
00:02:28,770 --> 00:02:32,660
notice it's not gonna let me make
the mistake and wipe out the data.

52
00:02:32,660 --> 00:02:35,190
If I want to though,
if I just want to get rid of his data,

53
00:02:35,190 --> 00:02:39,930
I can just uncheck that and see how it
says delete account without data transfer?

54
00:02:39,930 --> 00:02:43,950
That's gonna get rid of the account and
wipe out the data that it left behind.

55
00:02:43,950 --> 00:02:47,150
Maybe he contributed absolutely
nothing to my company, and so

56
00:02:47,150 --> 00:02:48,920
I just wanna wipe out all his stuff.

57
00:02:48,920 --> 00:02:51,470
I've got that option right there,
I can do it.

58
00:02:51,470 --> 00:02:53,450
But normally we will transfer it off and

59
00:02:53,450 --> 00:02:57,820
you'll see this option to also include
data that is not shared with any one.

60
00:02:57,820 --> 00:03:01,790
When we do this its basically looking at
things he shared with other employees and

61
00:03:01,790 --> 00:03:04,130
that when hes going to
transfer ownership to me.

62
00:03:04,130 --> 00:03:08,060
But what about documents or private that
he didn't share with other employees,

63
00:03:08,060 --> 00:03:11,380
well I'll need to check that off
to make sure I get everything.

64
00:03:11,380 --> 00:03:13,122
All the documents that
he had in Google Drive.

65
00:03:13,122 --> 00:03:14,290
All right?

66
00:03:14,290 --> 00:03:17,360
So I'll check that off and
I'll choose to assign a new owner.

67
00:03:17,360 --> 00:03:19,440
Now we can assign anyone to be the owner.

68
00:03:19,440 --> 00:03:21,310
We just need to specify
their email address.

69
00:03:21,310 --> 00:03:22,760
So I'm going to specify myself.

70
00:03:23,770 --> 00:03:25,970
Right there.
So I'll be the new owner, all right?

71
00:03:25,970 --> 00:03:29,470
And I'll go ahead and
transfer data and delete account.

72
00:03:29,470 --> 00:03:33,510
That's gonna remove the user account and
transfer the data over, all right?

73
00:03:33,510 --> 00:03:35,180
So that's gonna take just a moment.

74
00:03:35,180 --> 00:03:38,280
The larger the amount of data,
the longer it'll take.

75
00:03:38,280 --> 00:03:39,390
So it actually tells you hey,

76
00:03:39,390 --> 00:03:42,600
it's started,
we're done here as far as the GUI.

77
00:03:42,600 --> 00:03:44,700
You'll get an email when
it's actually done.

78
00:03:44,700 --> 00:03:47,460
It'll email you to let you know that
that account has been wiped out and

79
00:03:47,460 --> 00:03:48,180
you're ready to rock.

80
00:03:49,850 --> 00:03:52,410
All right, now what if I want
to transfer the data but

81
00:03:52,410 --> 00:03:55,910
I don't want to delete the account, right?

82
00:03:55,910 --> 00:03:59,740
Remember in one of the earlier segments
we suspended Ronnie's account.

83
00:03:59,740 --> 00:04:03,810
So if I go into my suspended users,
I've got Ronnie sitting right there and

84
00:04:03,810 --> 00:04:06,990
maybe I wanna get Ronnie's data
transferred to somebody else.

85
00:04:06,990 --> 00:04:09,200
But I don't wanna delete his account.

86
00:04:09,200 --> 00:04:11,530
Well, the deletion was to
go transfer the stuff,

87
00:04:11,530 --> 00:04:13,830
but it'll delete his account, right?

88
00:04:13,830 --> 00:04:15,380
So I can't go that route.

89
00:04:15,380 --> 00:04:18,390
If I want to move data off of a user
without actually deleting them,

90
00:04:18,390 --> 00:04:21,802
I've gotta use my Google Drive settings,
all right?

91
00:04:21,802 --> 00:04:24,489
So to do that I need to go
back out to my Admin console.

92
00:04:25,660 --> 00:04:28,150
And inside of the Admin console
you can go to Google Apps.

93
00:04:29,310 --> 00:04:32,810
And inside of Google Apps
you'll find Google Drive.

94
00:04:32,810 --> 00:04:34,240
And there we go.

95
00:04:34,240 --> 00:04:35,960
So I can go into drive.

96
00:04:35,960 --> 00:04:37,230
And inside of Drive,

97
00:04:37,230 --> 00:04:40,650
they've got a nice little utility
right here, Transfer ownership.

98
00:04:40,650 --> 00:04:43,650
And so we can transfer file
ownership from a user without

99
00:04:43,650 --> 00:04:45,550
actually removing their account.

100
00:04:45,550 --> 00:04:48,450
And all you have to do is
specify their email address.

101
00:04:48,450 --> 00:04:53,550
And so I had rwong@ITProTV.net and
I'm going to transfer his documents

102
00:04:53,550 --> 00:04:58,760
over to me, dpezet and I'll hit
transfer and it's going to go ahead and

103
00:04:58,760 --> 00:05:01,710
queue that up so we've successfully
initiated file transfer.

104
00:05:01,710 --> 00:05:03,540
It will email me when it's done.

105
00:05:03,540 --> 00:05:06,870
The more data, the longer it will take,
but otherwise It's transferring over,

106
00:05:06,870 --> 00:05:07,740
all right?

107
00:05:07,740 --> 00:05:11,450
So that's how we can go about doing
it without deleting the user account.

108
00:05:11,450 --> 00:05:13,300
So it's just up to you which one you want.

109
00:05:13,300 --> 00:05:15,920
If you want to delete the user account and
wipe out their data,

110
00:05:15,920 --> 00:05:19,720
you just uncheck the drive boxes
during the deletion wizard.

111
00:05:19,720 --> 00:05:22,240
If you wanna delete the user in transfer,
you just use the wizard,

112
00:05:22,240 --> 00:05:23,360
it does it, right?

113
00:05:23,360 --> 00:05:26,730
But if you just wanna transfer data, you
go through the drive settings right here.

114
00:05:26,730 --> 00:05:28,089
Couple of different ways
to go through that.

115
00:05:29,480 --> 00:05:30,350
All right.

116
00:05:30,350 --> 00:05:32,400
Now, once a user has been deleted,
what if we made a mistake?

117
00:05:32,400 --> 00:05:36,870
What if we deleted the user and
all of a sudden, we get a call from

118
00:05:36,870 --> 00:05:40,770
human resources and they say you know
what, there was a big misunderstanding.

119
00:05:40,770 --> 00:05:44,490
The employee quit, but they were mad
about something and we talked to them and

120
00:05:44,490 --> 00:05:47,640
we all came to an agreement and
want to bring him back on.

121
00:05:47,640 --> 00:05:49,160
And all of a sudden,
you're sitting there and going great,

122
00:05:49,160 --> 00:05:50,640
I deleted his account, wonderful.

123
00:05:50,640 --> 00:05:52,530
Now, I gotta being them back.

124
00:05:52,530 --> 00:05:55,820
Well, Google has a little
safety net built in for you.

125
00:05:55,820 --> 00:05:59,710
When you delete an account,
it doesn't actually go away.

126
00:05:59,710 --> 00:06:03,130
It will hold onto the account for
five days, right?

127
00:06:03,130 --> 00:06:04,170
So you've got five days.

128
00:06:04,170 --> 00:06:06,650
If in five days,
you decide you need that employee back,

129
00:06:06,650 --> 00:06:09,420
you can restore them
back into your system.

130
00:06:09,420 --> 00:06:11,230
So that's kind of a nice feature, right?

131
00:06:11,230 --> 00:06:12,880
Being able to bring that right back in.

132
00:06:12,880 --> 00:06:14,470
And have them in your system.

133
00:06:14,470 --> 00:06:17,800
If you wait more than five days
though the account is gone and so

134
00:06:17,800 --> 00:06:19,500
you'll just have to create a new account.

135
00:06:19,500 --> 00:06:21,950
And the user will start over from scratch,
all right.

136
00:06:21,950 --> 00:06:25,790
To recover a deleted user,
you just go back to your user screen and

137
00:06:25,790 --> 00:06:28,330
you might have seen this in
one of the earlier segments.

138
00:06:28,330 --> 00:06:31,470
When we go into the user screen, we've
got these filters over on the right side.

139
00:06:31,470 --> 00:06:34,520
If you don't see them just
hit the funnel icon up there.

140
00:06:34,520 --> 00:06:38,480
And when you drop down the filters,
you'll see that there is a filter.

141
00:06:38,480 --> 00:06:40,630
I guess that my head is covering that,
let me move that.

142
00:06:40,630 --> 00:06:43,270
Called recently deleted users.

143
00:06:43,270 --> 00:06:45,130
And you can choose recently deleted users,
and

144
00:06:45,130 --> 00:06:49,330
it'll show anybody that's been deleted
in your company in the last five days.

145
00:06:49,330 --> 00:06:53,400
And I can see right there, cwalken,
there's that Christopher Walken account,

146
00:06:53,400 --> 00:06:55,150
and so I can take that and
I can restore it.

147
00:06:55,150 --> 00:06:57,380
You just check the users
you want to restore and

148
00:06:57,380 --> 00:07:01,830
then you hit that undelete user, and
that's gonna process the restore.

149
00:07:01,830 --> 00:07:05,590
Now, when you restore them,
if you have more than one organization,

150
00:07:05,590 --> 00:07:09,760
it'll ask which one you want to restore
to, I'll just send them to the main one.

151
00:07:09,760 --> 00:07:11,370
And then it's gonna queue it up.

152
00:07:11,370 --> 00:07:14,890
Now, it will give you a warning at some
point that'll tell you that it could take

153
00:07:14,890 --> 00:07:16,610
up to two hours to restore the user.

154
00:07:16,610 --> 00:07:17,220
There's the warning.

155
00:07:17,220 --> 00:07:21,710
All right, and the reason is when you
delete an account, Google actually moves

156
00:07:21,710 --> 00:07:27,160
their data off to lower end storage,
less sensitive storage on their system.

157
00:07:27,160 --> 00:07:29,150
Production accounts,
your active user accounts,

158
00:07:29,150 --> 00:07:33,470
they're stored on very fast expensive
storage, but these deleted users,

159
00:07:33,470 --> 00:07:36,480
Google knows that most companies
aren't gonna go and bring them back.

160
00:07:36,480 --> 00:07:38,810
So they move them off the less
expensive storage to make room for

161
00:07:38,810 --> 00:07:42,500
the important stuff, and that's why it can
take a little while to recover that data.

162
00:07:42,500 --> 00:07:45,050
This is not a priority activity for them.

163
00:07:45,050 --> 00:07:48,400
Your production users, your active users,
those are the priority.

164
00:07:48,400 --> 00:07:50,910
So you won't see that
user pop up right away.

165
00:07:50,910 --> 00:07:54,090
When I go into my user list,
I don't see Christopher Walken, but

166
00:07:54,090 --> 00:07:58,230
at some point in the next two hours,
that user account will magically reappear.

167
00:07:58,230 --> 00:08:00,340
It'll have the same password as before,
and

168
00:08:00,340 --> 00:08:02,630
you'll be able to log in,
and work with the system.

169
00:08:04,000 --> 00:08:05,320
All right so

170
00:08:05,320 --> 00:08:10,660
in this segment we got a chance to see
how to delete a user account, right?

171
00:08:10,660 --> 00:08:13,870
If we're terminating an employee or
just removing them from our system.

172
00:08:13,870 --> 00:08:17,390
We saw how to transfer the ownership
of their files to someone else,

173
00:08:17,390 --> 00:08:20,590
either through the wizard, or
manually through the drive settings.

174
00:08:20,590 --> 00:08:23,830
And lastly we got to see
how to restore a user

175
00:08:23,830 --> 00:08:26,612
if we're still in that five day window and
we need the account back.

176
00:08:26,612 --> 00:08:30,836
All right,
well I hope you enjoyed the segments,

177
00:08:30,836 --> 00:08:35,676
stay tuned,
we've got more Google apps coming up next.

178
00:08:35,676 --> 00:08:37,981
>> [SOUND]

episodes.title: Using System Roles
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:08,095
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08,095 --> 00:00:13,863
Objective 1.4 is Using System Roles
to Delegate Administrative Duties

3
00:00:13,863 --> 00:00:18,817
to Users in the Domain including
Custom Administration Roles.

4
00:00:18,817 --> 00:00:19,972
It's quite a mouthful.

5
00:00:19,972 --> 00:00:25,270
Basically, it's using permissions
groups inside of Google Apps.

6
00:00:25,270 --> 00:00:29,050
When we create a new user in Google Apps,
it is just a regular user and

7
00:00:29,050 --> 00:00:33,620
they will have access to email,
or YouTube, or Google Drive, or

8
00:00:33,620 --> 00:00:37,810
whatever other services I have enabled for
the standard user accounts in my system.

9
00:00:37,810 --> 00:00:42,220
But, what if I want to delegate some
administrative duties to those users.

10
00:00:42,220 --> 00:00:44,720
What if I want somebody else to
be able to create user accounts.

11
00:00:44,720 --> 00:00:46,010
It's a good idea.

12
00:00:46,010 --> 00:00:48,910
You don't want your company
to be contingent upon

13
00:00:48,910 --> 00:00:51,340
one particular employee performing tasks.

14
00:00:51,340 --> 00:00:54,490
Right, you should always
have duplication of duties.

15
00:00:54,490 --> 00:00:57,030
We don't want to have just one
person who's responsible for

16
00:00:57,030 --> 00:00:58,390
adding user accounts.

17
00:00:58,390 --> 00:01:01,730
Because if that person's out sick,
how are you gonna add new user accounts?

18
00:01:01,730 --> 00:01:03,760
Or, just one person who
can reset passwords.

19
00:01:03,760 --> 00:01:06,890
And that way, if you forget your password,
you can only go to this one person.

20
00:01:06,890 --> 00:01:08,830
You don't wanna be in that situation.

21
00:01:08,830 --> 00:01:12,220
So, in Google Apps,
we have what are called system roles, and

22
00:01:12,220 --> 00:01:16,290
the system roles allow us to assign
certain permissions to users.

23
00:01:16,290 --> 00:01:18,160
You can make them
full-blown administrators,

24
00:01:18,160 --> 00:01:19,670
they can do anything they want.

25
00:01:19,670 --> 00:01:21,200
If that's what you're looking for.

26
00:01:21,200 --> 00:01:25,310
But ideally, you have a subset of
permissions you want to give to users, and

27
00:01:25,310 --> 00:01:27,380
that's what you make use of.

28
00:01:27,380 --> 00:01:29,280
There's some that
are built in to the system,

29
00:01:29,280 --> 00:01:34,220
and then you can create your own custom
ones to meet your own needs, right.

30
00:01:34,220 --> 00:01:38,160
If we go into our admin console,
it might not show up here by default.

31
00:01:38,160 --> 00:01:40,870
If you don't see the roles,
you can go down to More Controls.

32
00:01:40,870 --> 00:01:44,750
And under More Controls,
you'll see admin roles right there.

33
00:01:44,750 --> 00:01:47,810
When you go in to admin
roles this will show the,

34
00:01:47,810 --> 00:01:50,170
well after I re-authenicate here,

35
00:01:50,170 --> 00:01:56,320
it'll the built in administrative roles
that Google has already created for you.

36
00:01:56,320 --> 00:01:59,100
So you'll see Super Admin, Groups Admin,

37
00:01:59,100 --> 00:02:02,530
User Management Admin,
Help Desk Admin, and Services Admin.

38
00:02:03,660 --> 00:02:08,740
These are all roles that Google feels
that most organizations need, right.

39
00:02:08,740 --> 00:02:12,000
If you want somebody else to be a full
blown administrator on the system,

40
00:02:12,000 --> 00:02:15,400
you've got the Super Admin role and
you can add them in there and

41
00:02:15,400 --> 00:02:18,130
now they'll have that
access on your system.

42
00:02:18,130 --> 00:02:20,780
You'll also see like Groups Admin or
