User Management,

43
00:02:20,780 --> 00:02:23,310
you know groups is to be able
to create and manage groups.

44
00:02:23,310 --> 00:02:26,600
Or user management to Control users,
right?

45
00:02:26,600 --> 00:02:29,480
Most of these are pretty self-explanatory.

46
00:02:29,480 --> 00:02:32,840
Google has a nice little web page that
I like to refer to, which is this one.

47
00:02:32,840 --> 00:02:35,600
And I'll post the link with
the episode on the website.

48
00:02:35,600 --> 00:02:40,610
But these are the pre-built administrator
roles and exactly what access they have.

49
00:02:40,610 --> 00:02:42,649
So you don't have to guess about
what you're giving somebody.

50
00:02:42,649 --> 00:02:45,670
This'll specifically tell
you what they've got.

51
00:02:45,670 --> 00:02:49,070
So if you give somebody Super Admin,
they can do everything.

52
00:02:49,070 --> 00:02:50,700
They can do everything on your account.

53
00:02:50,700 --> 00:02:54,120
So you'll see here's a list of
things that only they can do.

54
00:02:54,120 --> 00:02:58,222
They can create administrator roles,
they can reset administrator passwords,

55
00:02:58,222 --> 00:03:01,264
they can do all sorts of really
high level, powerful stuff.

56
00:03:01,264 --> 00:03:02,204
All right.

57
00:03:02,204 --> 00:03:05,020
But if we go down to something
like a user admin, right?

58
00:03:05,020 --> 00:03:08,640
User Management Admin,
they can view user profiles, create and

59
00:03:08,640 --> 00:03:11,270
delete user accounts, rename users, right.

60
00:03:11,270 --> 00:03:14,141
But not change the passwords for
administrator accounts.

61
00:03:14,141 --> 00:03:17,980
See how it says applies only for
users who aren't administrators.

62
00:03:17,980 --> 00:03:20,254
So there's boundaries on their power.

63
00:03:20,254 --> 00:03:22,698
One of my favorite is the Help Desk Admin.

64
00:03:22,698 --> 00:03:26,880
The Help Desk Admin, who can reset
passwords for users, but that's it.

65
00:03:26,880 --> 00:03:29,150
They can't create user accounts.

66
00:03:29,150 --> 00:03:31,166
You have these limitations in place so

67
00:03:31,166 --> 00:03:34,887
that you don't give somebody more
access than they absolutely need.

68
00:03:34,887 --> 00:03:38,060
It's called the principle
of least privilege.

69
00:03:38,060 --> 00:03:41,800
Now the roles that are in place,
they may work out fine for you and

70
00:03:41,800 --> 00:03:42,610
you can use them.

71
00:03:42,610 --> 00:03:47,530
So going to my environment,
if I go back to my user list,

72
00:03:47,530 --> 00:03:52,250
I can see my list of users so maybe I want
to take, I'll take Marty Freedmen here.

73
00:03:52,250 --> 00:03:55,230
I want Marty Freedman to
be a help desk manager, so

74
00:03:55,230 --> 00:03:57,760
I want him to be able to reset
passwords for other users.

75
00:03:57,760 --> 00:04:01,590
So I'm gonna go back here
to my Admin console, and

76
00:04:01,590 --> 00:04:04,050
I'll go to More Controls and Admin Roles.

77
00:04:05,140 --> 00:04:07,140
And I'll go to Help Desk Admin, and

78
00:04:07,140 --> 00:04:10,450
I can see a list of current
people that are Help Desk Admins.

79
00:04:10,450 --> 00:04:15,510
And I can choose to assign a new admin,
and I'm gonna put in Marty Freedman.

80
00:04:17,190 --> 00:04:17,690
There he is.

81
00:04:18,710 --> 00:04:20,763
So we got Marty in there and
I'm gonna give him rights.

82
00:04:20,763 --> 00:04:23,556
Now, when you give somebody
a role of permissions,

83
00:04:23,556 --> 00:04:26,611
you have to choose what
organization they're a part of.

84
00:04:26,611 --> 00:04:28,980
And if your company only has one
organization than that's fine,

85
00:04:28,980 --> 00:04:30,180
you ignore it.

86
00:04:30,180 --> 00:04:34,760
But if you have sub-organizations like
I do, I've got this one called retired.

87
00:04:34,760 --> 00:04:39,050
When you give him access over the parent,
the permissions trickle down.

88
00:04:39,050 --> 00:04:42,550
So, he'll have permissions over
the sub-organization also.

89
00:04:42,550 --> 00:04:45,153
Or, I can give him access to
just the sub-organization.

90
00:04:45,153 --> 00:04:49,300
So, you can pick and choose where they
get their permissions in the system.

91
00:04:49,300 --> 00:04:50,754
But, I'm gonna give him the whole thing,
right?

92
00:04:50,754 --> 00:04:55,870
So, I'll pick the ITProTV net organization
and I'll hit confirm assignment.

93
00:04:55,870 --> 00:04:58,900
And now he's in the list I've
got a new help desk manager.

94
00:04:58,900 --> 00:04:59,410
Alright?

95
00:04:59,410 --> 00:05:01,900
So real easy to give
these permissions out.

96
00:05:01,900 --> 00:05:04,930
Now Marty can start to do some
of the administrative duties and

97
00:05:04,930 --> 00:05:07,229
I'm not being overly burdened
with it in my system.

98
00:05:08,630 --> 00:05:13,280
Now it may be that there isn't
a role that suits your needs.

99
00:05:13,280 --> 00:05:15,173
And in that scenario,
you might need to create your own.

100
00:05:15,173 --> 00:05:18,480
So for example, you can see I've
already done one called Report Admin.

101
00:05:18,480 --> 00:05:22,490
I wanted to have users that can
generate reports in my system.

102
00:05:22,490 --> 00:05:26,350
Well a regular user can't do that by
default, they don't have that permission.

103
00:05:26,350 --> 00:05:30,103
So I created a custom role to meet my
need, one for being a Report Admin,

104
00:05:30,103 --> 00:05:33,496
all right, but you can create
whatever role it is that you need.

105
00:05:33,496 --> 00:05:36,922
When you hit, create a new role,
it's gonna ask you for a name, and

106
00:05:36,922 --> 00:05:38,979
you call it whatever it is that you want.

107
00:05:40,680 --> 00:05:45,537
And, then when you create it, it's gonna
ask what privileges these users will get.

108
00:05:45,537 --> 00:05:49,450
And you get to browse through here and
pick and choose exactly what they need.

109
00:05:49,450 --> 00:05:53,430
So you have got some particular
scenario that you wanna deal with.

110
00:05:53,430 --> 00:05:58,304
So maybe under services here, I want these
guys to be able to manage mobile devices,

111
00:05:58,304 --> 00:05:59,260
all right.

112
00:05:59,260 --> 00:06:01,500
So these are gonna be mobile device admin.

113
00:06:01,500 --> 00:06:02,960
So I'm just gonna check that off.

114
00:06:02,960 --> 00:06:05,331
I'm not gonna bother checking
off any of these other options.

115
00:06:05,331 --> 00:06:08,930
I want to keep it fairly limited,
just to dealing with mobile.

116
00:06:08,930 --> 00:06:13,850
So I'll go ahead and save changes and
so now I've got this custom role,

117
00:06:15,330 --> 00:06:18,980
that is going to provide
them with the mobile admin.

118
00:06:18,980 --> 00:06:20,971
That ability to control those devices.

119
00:06:20,971 --> 00:06:22,990
So create as many of those as you need.

120
00:06:22,990 --> 00:06:24,566
It's whatever is flexible for
your organization.

121
00:06:24,566 --> 00:06:28,340
You can always go back and edit them
if you want to change the permissions.

122
00:06:28,340 --> 00:06:30,704
Maybe you find out, oh,
having mobile isn't enough.

123
00:06:30,704 --> 00:06:33,800
I need to give them a little
bit more to control it.

124
00:06:33,800 --> 00:06:36,294
Now the permissions or the privileges,
it's a pretty big list.

125
00:06:36,294 --> 00:06:39,330
There's a lot of stuff in here and
you can pick and choose.

126
00:06:39,330 --> 00:06:42,896
A lot of them will expand out and
you'll have things like create, read,

127
00:06:42,896 --> 00:06:43,835
update, delete.

128
00:06:43,835 --> 00:06:47,320
So you might need to issue out read
permissions for certain things.

129
00:06:47,320 --> 00:06:48,870
If you're gonna manage
the mobile settings,

130
00:06:48,870 --> 00:06:51,380
maybe you need to allow them
to read on the user accounts.

131
00:06:51,380 --> 00:06:55,130
So you can pick and choose from there,
breaking each one down very,

132
00:06:55,130 --> 00:06:56,630
very granular.

133
00:06:56,630 --> 00:06:58,565
If you want a deeper explanation of these,

134
00:06:58,565 --> 00:07:01,565
there's a great article that Google
has posted and again I'll post

135
00:07:01,565 --> 00:07:05,895
the link with this episode called
Administrator privilege definitions.

136
00:07:05,895 --> 00:07:06,755
And it goes through and

137
00:07:06,755 --> 00:07:11,025
breaks down each one of those permissions
with exactly what we're giving out.

138
00:07:11,025 --> 00:07:14,635
And so when you look in here and
see like user security management,

139
00:07:14,635 --> 00:07:16,415
security settings and so on.

140
00:07:16,415 --> 00:07:18,624
This will have the breakdown
of what it is that they do and

141
00:07:18,624 --> 00:07:20,179
what permissions you're giving out.

142
00:07:20,179 --> 00:07:23,270
So when I gave out mobile
permissions you'll see here,

143
00:07:23,270 --> 00:07:27,160
allows full control over mobile
devices in the admin console.

144
00:07:27,160 --> 00:07:29,570
Administrators with this
privilege can activate, delete,

145
00:07:29,570 --> 00:07:32,800
wipe and
otherwise manage all mobile devices.

146
00:07:32,800 --> 00:07:36,150
The privilege is automatically
selected by the services privilege.

147
00:07:36,150 --> 00:07:39,290
So I just turn it on,
I give somebody the access and

148
00:07:39,290 --> 00:07:40,710
that's what they're gong to get.

149
00:07:40,710 --> 00:07:43,450
So you can look through here
to figure out what each one

150
00:07:43,450 --> 00:07:44,670
is really going to be giving out.

151
00:07:46,100 --> 00:07:49,950
All right, that is really handy as far
as delegating out those permissions and

152
00:07:49,950 --> 00:07:51,140
it saves you a lot of time.

153
00:07:52,290 --> 00:07:56,040
So in this segment we took a look at
using the pre-built security roles that

154
00:07:56,040 --> 00:07:58,728
are already a part of your
Google Apps installation.

155
00:07:58,728 --> 00:08:02,234
And then we got a chance to see
creating our own custom roles and

156
00:08:02,234 --> 00:08:03,730
assigning users to them.

157
00:08:03,730 --> 00:08:07,270
I guess I didn't really assign users to my
custom role, but it's done the same way.

158
00:08:07,270 --> 00:08:10,569
You just go to the admins tab,
add in whatever users you want,

159
00:08:10,569 --> 00:08:12,038
really straightforward.

160
00:08:12,038 --> 00:08:14,988
Keep in mind that a user can
have more than one role.

161
00:08:14,988 --> 00:08:18,741
So maybe Marty Freedman can be
in that Report Admin role, and

162
00:08:18,741 --> 00:08:21,621
in the custom Mobile Admin role,
that I made.

163
00:08:21,621 --> 00:08:25,056
He can be in more than one, whatever
permissions that particular user needs,

164
00:08:25,056 --> 00:08:27,922
you just assign the roles and
they'll have it.

165
00:08:27,922 --> 00:08:29,380
All right well I hope you
guys enjoyed the segment.

166
00:08:29,380 --> 00:08:32,624
Stay tuned,
we've got more Google Apps coming up next.

167
00:08:32,624 --> 00:08:34,150
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Managing Passwords
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:04,519
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08,118 --> 00:00:12,715
Objective 1.5 covers managing
passwords in your organization.

3
00:00:12,715 --> 00:00:16,541
Specifically it says demonstrating
how to reset a user password,

4
00:00:16,541 --> 00:00:19,000
force a user to change their password, and

5
00:00:19,000 --> 00:00:23,326
monitor the strength of the passwords
that your users currently have set.

6
00:00:23,326 --> 00:00:26,927
So this is an important thing for us to
be able to keep track of it just from

7
00:00:26,927 --> 00:00:30,362
a security perspective,
how are users managing their passwords?

8
00:00:30,362 --> 00:00:33,984
So real important thing and
not a terribly difficult thing to do.

9
00:00:33,984 --> 00:00:37,404
When we create our user accounts,
you might remember from an earlier episode

10
00:00:37,404 --> 00:00:41,360
where we imported our user accounts,
we have to pick passwords for them.

11
00:00:41,360 --> 00:00:44,300
But, at the end of the day the users
are gonna reset those passwords and

12
00:00:44,300 --> 00:00:46,250
pick something different.

13
00:00:46,250 --> 00:00:50,270
And when they do, they may pick
something that's nice and secure.

14
00:00:50,270 --> 00:00:54,360
They may pick something that's weak, that
doesn't meet our minimum requirements or

15
00:00:54,360 --> 00:00:57,200
that just isn't a good
password in general.

16
00:00:57,200 --> 00:00:59,490
So we need a way to be able to
keep track of that, all right?

17
00:00:59,490 --> 00:01:02,360
And that's what this objective is
all about, how we can handle that.

18
00:01:02,360 --> 00:01:06,360
The first thing is, what if we
want to reset a user's password?

19
00:01:06,360 --> 00:01:09,990
We've got a user and for whatever reason
we need to cause their password to reset.

20
00:01:09,990 --> 00:01:12,228
The most common cause for
this is they've forgotten their password.

21
00:01:12,228 --> 00:01:15,409
So user can't remember their password and
we need to reset them.

22
00:01:15,409 --> 00:01:16,198
All right.

23
00:01:16,198 --> 00:01:19,014
Well, we can do that pretty easily
right here from our admin console.

24
00:01:19,014 --> 00:01:22,698
If we go to our users screen and
we pick a particular user, so

25
00:01:22,698 --> 00:01:24,405
I'll take Dave Mustaine.

26
00:01:25,450 --> 00:01:28,250
All right, when I pick this user account,
here's his account.

27
00:01:28,250 --> 00:01:30,630
And we'll see some of the different
options that we've got in here for

28
00:01:30,630 --> 00:01:31,390
looking at his account.

29
00:01:31,390 --> 00:01:34,480
And there's an icon up here,

30
00:01:34,480 --> 00:01:37,740
which it's supposed to be
a padlock with an arrow on it.

31
00:01:37,740 --> 00:01:39,467
Kinda looks like a purse, though.

32
00:01:39,467 --> 00:01:43,483
[LAUGH] And we can choose to
reset the user's password.

33
00:01:43,483 --> 00:01:44,890
So I can click on that.

34
00:01:44,890 --> 00:01:47,980
And here's a chance to punch in
a password for that account.

35
00:01:47,980 --> 00:01:50,680
I can auto generate
a password if I want or

36
00:01:50,680 --> 00:01:52,660
I can manually set it to something I need.

37
00:01:53,750 --> 00:01:56,490
One example where we might do this is if
the user forgot their password, right.

38
00:01:56,490 --> 00:01:57,682
Here is one way to do it.

39
00:01:57,682 --> 00:01:59,596
You can set it to something temporary and

40
00:01:59,596 --> 00:02:02,814
choose to require a change of
password the next time they sign-in.

41
00:02:02,814 --> 00:02:04,829
So now I can call Dave on this phone and
say hey,

42
00:02:04,829 --> 00:02:06,700
next time you login here is your password.

43
00:02:06,700 --> 00:02:08,170
You will change it when you login.

44
00:02:09,550 --> 00:02:11,970
Or maybe this employee
has been terminated.

45
00:02:11,970 --> 00:02:15,700
And I wanna log in as this employee
to be able to see their email and

46
00:02:15,700 --> 00:02:18,670
Google Drive documents and
access their other resources.

47
00:02:18,670 --> 00:02:22,190
So I might just want to reset this
user to something that I know, so

48
00:02:22,190 --> 00:02:24,770
that I can log in and
control that account.

49
00:02:24,770 --> 00:02:25,950
So I can go in here and

50
00:02:25,950 --> 00:02:30,760
I can punch it in, and I get my normal
password strength monitor right there,

51
00:02:30,760 --> 00:02:33,879
it's letting me know that I'm typing in
a strong password or a weak password.

52
00:02:35,160 --> 00:02:36,390
And I can reset it.

53
00:02:36,390 --> 00:02:38,090
Since I manually set the password,

54
00:02:38,090 --> 00:02:41,620
I'm gonna uncheck that require
change of password at next login.

55
00:02:41,620 --> 00:02:43,270
So we'll go ahead and reset that.

56
00:02:43,270 --> 00:02:44,220
And that'll take care of that one.

57
00:02:45,940 --> 00:02:47,320
All right.

58
00:02:47,320 --> 00:02:50,460
What if I'm concerned that
a user has a weak password?

59
00:02:50,460 --> 00:02:53,070
And I just want them to have to
change it the next time they log in.

60
00:02:53,070 --> 00:02:56,572
So maybe I got reports that possibly
one of my employees shared their

61
00:02:56,572 --> 00:02:58,178
password with somebody else.

62
00:02:58,178 --> 00:03:01,250
Well, I might want to force
them to reset their password.

63
00:03:01,250 --> 00:03:02,520
I don't necessarily want
to know what it is.

64
00:03:02,520 --> 00:03:03,980
I don't wanna go in and
change the password myself.

65
00:03:03,980 --> 00:03:06,960
I just want them to have to change
it the next time they log in.

66
00:03:06,960 --> 00:03:08,760
Well, you can do that too.

67
00:03:08,760 --> 00:03:12,470
Right here from the user screen,
if you click on their account, so well,

68
00:03:12,470 --> 00:03:13,880
I'm already in their account, all right?

69
00:03:13,880 --> 00:03:15,970
But we've got this actual
account link here.

70
00:03:15,970 --> 00:03:20,420
And if we go into the account you'll
see information about the password.

71
00:03:20,420 --> 00:03:24,300
See it's telling me right now that
this password was set by the admin.

72
00:03:24,300 --> 00:03:27,510
Well the next time they log in,
if I check that option it would reset it.

73
00:03:27,510 --> 00:03:29,310
But I didn't check that option.

74
00:03:29,310 --> 00:03:33,450
So, Dave could keep using the password
that I set for as long as he wants.

75
00:03:33,450 --> 00:03:34,080
Right.

76
00:03:34,080 --> 00:03:36,030
But the problem is,
is that two people know the password and

77
00:03:36,030 --> 00:03:37,000
that's always a bad thing.

78
00:03:37,000 --> 00:03:40,060
He knows it because I told him and
I know it because I set it.

79
00:03:40,060 --> 00:03:44,220
So, I might want to force him to change
his password the next time he logs in.

80
00:03:44,220 --> 00:03:45,840
So you've got that option right here.

81
00:03:45,840 --> 00:03:48,120
We can check that little box that says,

82
00:03:48,120 --> 00:03:51,350
require user to change
password at next sign-in.

83
00:03:51,350 --> 00:03:54,420
Now the next time he signs in
he'll have to change the password.

84
00:03:54,420 --> 00:03:56,170
One slight program with this though,

85
00:03:56,170 --> 00:04:00,750
when you sign in an authentication
token is generated for your account.

86
00:04:00,750 --> 00:04:05,150
And that token can be good for
up to 24 hours in some scenarios.

87
00:04:05,150 --> 00:04:08,688
So that means he might not have
to log in again until tomorrow.

88
00:04:08,688 --> 00:04:12,225
If I'm in a hurry and I need him to
change that password right away,

89
00:04:12,225 --> 00:04:14,192
I know his account got compromised.

90
00:04:14,192 --> 00:04:16,630
I need him to change that password now.

91
00:04:16,630 --> 00:04:20,920
You'll notice this little option here that
says reset sign-in cookies, all right?

92
00:04:20,920 --> 00:04:25,110
That'll take any current session
he's got with Google and log it out.

93
00:04:25,110 --> 00:04:28,550
So, he'll be forced to change
his password right away.

94
00:04:28,550 --> 00:04:30,460
That's a great way to do it.

95
00:04:30,460 --> 00:04:34,640
I'm gonna go and hit that, and so
that's gonna reset the sign-in cookies.

96
00:04:34,640 --> 00:04:37,017
So, any current session
he has is now dead.

97
00:04:37,017 --> 00:04:41,760
I've checked require user change password
at next login and I'll hit Save changes.

98
00:04:41,760 --> 00:04:45,880
And now, the next time they log in, they
can punch in the password I gave them, but

99
00:04:45,880 --> 00:04:48,720
it'll force them to change their password.

100
00:04:48,720 --> 00:04:49,310
All right?

101
00:04:49,310 --> 00:04:52,992
So, pretty easy to do,
makes them change the password and

102
00:04:52,992 --> 00:04:56,238
they'll be able to get in and
work with the system.

103
00:04:56,238 --> 00:05:01,624
All right, now, if I suspect the user
has a weak password, how do I know?

104
00:05:01,624 --> 00:05:06,551
If I'm the one who set it, so if I take
this user and I go to reset password and

105
00:05:06,551 --> 00:05:11,560
I'm the one who sets it, I can
intentionally set it to something weak.

106
00:05:11,560 --> 00:05:15,360
So, this password that I'm typing in
right here, it's a dictionary word, and

107
00:05:15,360 --> 00:05:17,500
I'm just sticking the number
one on the end of it,

108
00:05:17,500 --> 00:05:21,060
so it's not a very strong password at all,
I'll go ahead and reset it.

109
00:05:21,060 --> 00:05:22,510
See, it let me do it.

110
00:05:22,510 --> 00:05:25,570
It let me set a somewhat weak password.

111
00:05:25,570 --> 00:05:30,460
So if your end-users are doing that,
your organization is at risk.

112
00:05:30,460 --> 00:05:34,560
So we may want to double check our users
to make sure that they're doing secure

113
00:05:34,560 --> 00:05:35,500
passwords.

114
00:05:35,500 --> 00:05:38,480
Well, there's a nice little
report we can use to view that.

115
00:05:38,480 --> 00:05:42,240
Most of my users were just imported so
the report's not gonna work for them.

116
00:05:42,240 --> 00:05:45,340
But for some of my other users,
like myself or Dave or

117
00:05:45,340 --> 00:05:47,200
somebody, these'll show up.

118
00:05:47,200 --> 00:05:49,530
Usually, the user has to
log in at least once.

119
00:05:49,530 --> 00:05:53,610
So, I guess I could log in as Dave real
quick and get a chance to see that.

120
00:05:53,610 --> 00:05:54,400
So, let's do that.

121
00:05:54,400 --> 00:05:55,470
I'm gonna sign out here.

122
00:05:56,950 --> 00:06:03,854
And I'm gonna sign in as
dmustaine@itprotv.net.

123
00:06:03,854 --> 00:06:07,105
All right, and I'll punch in that
password that I assigned for him.

124
00:06:07,105 --> 00:06:08,620
Oh, actually, I did a weak password.

125
00:06:08,620 --> 00:06:09,470
Let me type in the weak one.

126
00:06:10,700 --> 00:06:11,670
There we go.

127
00:06:11,670 --> 00:06:14,990
So I'm gonna sign in as him, and
see how it's saying it's a new account,

128
00:06:14,990 --> 00:06:16,720
I still have to accept the agreement.

129
00:06:16,720 --> 00:06:18,840
That's why the report won't work for
a new user.

130
00:06:18,840 --> 00:06:21,728
They haven't even accepted
a license agreement yet.

131
00:06:21,728 --> 00:06:25,536
So let's skip my verification and
there we go.

132
00:06:25,536 --> 00:06:29,970
So he's in and he can start to access his
resources, access his email and so on.

133
00:06:29,970 --> 00:06:32,160
All right, well he's in.

134
00:06:32,160 --> 00:06:34,340
He logged in with a weak password,
he hasn't changed it.

135
00:06:34,340 --> 00:06:37,210
So he still has that weak password.

136
00:06:37,210 --> 00:06:40,300
So I'm gonna go ahead and
log out and log back in as me.

137
00:06:42,980 --> 00:06:48,550
And when I log in, I'm gonna run
a quick report to show me my users and

138
00:06:48,550 --> 00:06:52,320
show me whether or
not they've got good passwords.

139
00:06:52,320 --> 00:06:56,430
Right, because they probably don't in
some cases, maybe some of them do.

140
00:06:56,430 --> 00:06:59,930
So let me just get to my Admin panel.

141
00:06:59,930 --> 00:07:04,040
I went to the wrong page there.

142
00:07:04,040 --> 00:07:07,370
So let me get back over to my Admin panel,
and we'll pull up that report.

143
00:07:07,370 --> 00:07:10,230
The report itself is kinda
buried away a little bit.

144
00:07:10,230 --> 00:07:11,990
It's in your Security tool,

145
00:07:11,990 --> 00:07:16,140
and I don't believe the Security
tool is displayed by default.

146
00:07:16,140 --> 00:07:20,080
So, if you don't see that one by default,
it might be buried under More Controls.

147
00:07:20,080 --> 00:07:24,060
So sometimes when you log in,
you may see less icons here than I do.

148
00:07:24,060 --> 00:07:27,060
So if it's buried under more controls,
you just click down here, and

149
00:07:27,060 --> 00:07:28,950
you go to Security.

150
00:07:28,950 --> 00:07:33,350
And once you go to Security, you'll see
Password monitoring, right there, and

151
00:07:33,350 --> 00:07:36,120
you can generate a Password
monitoring report.

152
00:07:36,120 --> 00:07:38,730
And when I look at my report I can see

153
00:07:38,730 --> 00:07:42,240
that I've got a ten character
password that's strong.

154
00:07:42,240 --> 00:07:44,030
I've got upper case and lower case.

155
00:07:44,030 --> 00:07:46,590
I've got letters and numbers,
I've got special characters right?

156
00:07:46,590 --> 00:07:51,227
It's a complex password, but Dave
Mustaine, his is just a dictionary word,

157
00:07:51,227 --> 00:07:54,410
all lowercase,
followed by a single number.

158
00:07:54,410 --> 00:07:57,990
That's not a complex password,
that's a weak password, and

159
00:07:57,990 --> 00:07:59,810
since it's weak, it's showing that.

160
00:07:59,810 --> 00:08:02,720
It's not telling me what his password is,
I dunno, but it's tell, well,

161
00:08:02,720 --> 00:08:04,110
I guess I do know, I set it, right?

162
00:08:04,110 --> 00:08:05,810
But normally I wouldn't know but

163
00:08:05,810 --> 00:08:09,960
I can see that it is weak, and
the password's ranked as a red, right.

164
00:08:09,960 --> 00:08:12,860
So this lets me quickly look
at my employees and say,

165
00:08:12,860 --> 00:08:16,780
man, Dave's gotta get a stronger password,
let me go force him to reset that.

166
00:08:16,780 --> 00:08:19,090
And let me reach out to him,
let me give him a little phone call and

167
00:08:19,090 --> 00:08:21,340
tell him like hey you need
to do a better password.

168
00:08:21,340 --> 00:08:24,600
We'll see in a later segment that we
can set policies that dictate this to

169
00:08:24,600 --> 00:08:26,720
prevent them from putting
a weak password in.

170
00:08:26,720 --> 00:08:29,060
But with the default
settings it is possible.

171
00:08:29,060 --> 00:08:31,291
They can enter a weak password and
there it'll be, and

172
00:08:31,291 --> 00:08:35,743
if you click on the user you'll be
able to jump right over to them And

173
00:08:35,743 --> 00:08:38,200
you'll be able to go in and
enforce that password reset right there.

174
00:08:38,200 --> 00:08:41,002
It's real easy to do and
get your system more secure.

175
00:08:41,002 --> 00:08:45,750
All right so in this segment we got
a chance to see how to force a user to

176
00:08:45,750 --> 00:08:49,220
reset their password,
we also saw how to reset it ourselves.

177
00:08:49,220 --> 00:08:53,575
And we got a chance to see how to monitor
the passwords that our users are choosing

178
00:08:53,575 --> 00:08:55,265
to make sure they're secure.

179
00:08:55,265 --> 00:08:57,519
That pretty much wraps up this one,
so stay tuned.

180
00:08:57,519 --> 00:08:59,747
We've got more Google Apps
coming up later.

181
00:08:59,747 --> 00:09:04,042
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Managing Organizational Units
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:08,299
[SOUND].

2
00:00:08,299 --> 00:00:13,086
Objective 2.1 covers using organizational
units to manage the user accounts inside

3
00:00:13,086 --> 00:00:14,000
of Google Apps.

4
00:00:14,000 --> 00:00:16,670
The full title is,
Demonstrate How To Create and

5
00:00:16,670 --> 00:00:22,010
Use Organizational Units to Manage Users,
Groups and Security Settings.

6
00:00:22,010 --> 00:00:24,980
Many companies aren't really
going to leverage this.

7
00:00:24,980 --> 00:00:27,230
In a small or medium company,

8
00:00:27,230 --> 00:00:31,240
your employees are usually part of
one big organization and that's it.

9
00:00:31,240 --> 00:00:34,970
But the larger your organization becomes,
the more separations and

10
00:00:34,970 --> 00:00:37,220
differences you have between employees,
and

11
00:00:37,220 --> 00:00:41,430
it becomes practical to divide your
company up into sub-organizations.

12
00:00:41,430 --> 00:00:44,240
Even if your company is
simply one big unit,

13
00:00:44,240 --> 00:00:46,350
there are still times you might use this.

14
00:00:46,350 --> 00:00:48,570
A great example is if you
deal with contractors,

15
00:00:48,570 --> 00:00:52,520
or third party companies that you have
temporary business relationships with.

16
00:00:52,520 --> 00:00:56,500
For them, you might want to bring them in
to your Google Apps environment to be able

17
00:00:56,500 --> 00:00:59,390
to give them email addresses and
allow them access to Google Drive and

18
00:00:59,390 --> 00:01:00,650
all that other good stuff.

19
00:01:00,650 --> 00:01:04,520
But you might want to a different
set of password restrictions or

20
00:01:04,520 --> 00:01:05,560
other security policies.

21
00:01:05,560 --> 00:01:08,150
You might not want to turn
on every feature, but

22
00:01:08,150 --> 00:01:10,910
just turn on certain features for
those users.

23
00:01:10,910 --> 00:01:14,161
Well that's really hard to do if you're
treating all of your users as one

24
00:01:14,161 --> 00:01:15,610
big organization.

25
00:01:15,610 --> 00:01:19,100
But if we divide our company
up into sub-organizations,

26
00:01:19,100 --> 00:01:21,710
then we can really have some power and
control over that.

27
00:01:21,710 --> 00:01:25,430
So, it really comes down
to security policies.

28
00:01:25,430 --> 00:01:28,450
If you need separate security policies and
configurations for

29
00:01:28,450 --> 00:01:32,030
your users, you'll need multiple
organizations, all right.

30
00:01:32,030 --> 00:01:34,880
Creating them is, fortunately,
really, really easy.

31
00:01:34,880 --> 00:01:37,450
Let me just bring up my admin panel here.

32
00:01:37,450 --> 00:01:41,280
Now when you first sign up for
Google Apps, you'll pick what your

33
00:01:41,280 --> 00:01:45,240
primary domain name is, and that will
become your default organization.

34
00:01:45,240 --> 00:01:48,160
So you'll always have one organization.

35
00:01:48,160 --> 00:01:52,200
And then after that,
you can create organizations at will.

36
00:01:52,200 --> 00:01:56,030
And they can be domain names, or they can
just be whatever you want to call them.

37
00:01:56,030 --> 00:01:59,870
You can call them whatever the heck you
want, based on the needs of your company.

38
00:01:59,870 --> 00:02:02,710
To create organizations,
you just go into your Users screen.

39
00:02:03,770 --> 00:02:07,170
And in your Users screen on the right
side, it'll show your Organization list.

40
00:02:07,170 --> 00:02:10,250
If it doesn't show up, you just need
to turn on your filter screen, and

41
00:02:10,250 --> 00:02:11,790
you'll see it right there.

42
00:02:11,790 --> 00:02:15,630
So you can see on mine, I've got
an organization called ITProTV.net.

43
00:02:15,630 --> 00:02:18,350
And I've created a child organization.

44
00:02:18,350 --> 00:02:21,010
See how it's nested under ITProTV.net?

45
00:02:21,010 --> 00:02:23,250
And I've got retired.

46
00:02:23,250 --> 00:02:26,360
And so I might have employees that
have retired from the company, but

47
00:02:26,360 --> 00:02:29,950
I still want them to have a user account,
still be able to log in and get to email.

48
00:02:29,950 --> 00:02:32,330
And so
I move them over to the retired one, and

49
00:02:32,330 --> 00:02:35,980
I can change the policies on that
organization to only allow email.

50
00:02:35,980 --> 00:02:40,380
Maybe they don't get Google Drive anymore
or all the other things, just email.

51
00:02:40,380 --> 00:02:44,060
I can do that because it's
a separate organization.

52
00:02:44,060 --> 00:02:46,590
You can create as many
organizations as you want.

53
00:02:46,590 --> 00:02:48,595
You just add them in based
on your company's needs.

54
00:02:48,595 --> 00:02:52,790
And you can nest them several
levels deep if you want.

55
00:02:52,790 --> 00:02:55,820
So for example, I might deal with
several different contractors.

56
00:02:55,820 --> 00:02:59,470
So I might want to create a new
organization called Contractors, and

57
00:02:59,470 --> 00:03:03,620
inside of it, I might create
different organizations for them.

58
00:03:03,620 --> 00:03:06,020
Creating an organization is pretty simple.

59
00:03:06,020 --> 00:03:10,380
You just float over an organization,
usually your parent one, the main one.

60
00:03:10,380 --> 00:03:14,470
And you hit the drop-down box to the right
side of that, and you'll see two options,

61
00:03:14,470 --> 00:03:18,220
Add a sub-organization or
Edit the current organization.

62
00:03:18,220 --> 00:03:21,620
There's not a lot to edit, you can change
the name and description, that's about it,

63
00:03:21,620 --> 00:03:23,430
so not terribly exciting.

64
00:03:23,430 --> 00:03:26,570
But, I might not wanna
call this ITProTV.net,

65
00:03:26,570 --> 00:03:29,105
I might wanna call it ITProTV, right?

66
00:03:29,105 --> 00:03:35,582
So this is my
Primary ITProTV Organization, right?

67
00:03:35,582 --> 00:03:39,220
So, something that makes a little more
sense to users that may see this.

68
00:03:39,220 --> 00:03:40,000
All right, so now I've got it.

69
00:03:40,000 --> 00:03:42,471
And my organization's just called ITProTV.

70
00:03:42,471 --> 00:03:44,850
I've got retired here,
which I did all lowercase.

71
00:03:44,850 --> 00:03:48,860
I must have been lazy when I typed that,
so I'll just rename that one Retired.

72
00:03:50,270 --> 00:03:51,350
Okay.

73
00:03:51,350 --> 00:03:54,360
Now if I want to create more I can
just float over that arrow and

74
00:03:54,360 --> 00:03:58,600
drop it down, and
I can choose to add a sub-organization.

75
00:03:58,600 --> 00:04:01,168
So I'm gonna add one called Contractors.

76
00:04:01,168 --> 00:04:05,762
All right, so here’s my Contractors, I
could type in a description if I want, and

77
00:04:05,762 --> 00:04:07,678
then who this is going to be under.

78
00:04:07,678 --> 00:04:10,162
Notice I can put it under Retired.

79
00:04:10,162 --> 00:04:15,062
You can nest these organizations
several levels deep if you need to.

80
00:04:15,062 --> 00:04:18,750
Well I want mine to be under the parent
organization so I'll create it there.

81
00:04:18,750 --> 00:04:22,400
And in just a second it'll refresh,
and there's Contractors.

82
00:04:22,400 --> 00:04:26,310
But maybe under Contractors, maybe I
deal with several other companies there.

83
00:04:26,310 --> 00:04:32,380
So I might come under Contractors and
choose to add other sub-organizations.

84
00:04:32,380 --> 00:04:34,290
So maybe I deal with Halliburton, right.

85
00:04:34,290 --> 00:04:35,940
So I'll punch in Halliburton here.

86
00:04:35,940 --> 00:04:38,210
I'm gonna put that under Contractors.

87
00:04:38,210 --> 00:04:39,910
There we go, so now I've got Halliburton.

88
00:04:39,910 --> 00:04:42,300
And I can continue to add more.

89
00:04:42,300 --> 00:04:45,710
Maybe I do EdutainmentLIVE, right.

90
00:04:45,710 --> 00:04:48,920
So I get some contractors from there.

91
00:04:48,920 --> 00:04:53,130
And so now I've got two different
classifications of Contractor,

92
00:04:53,130 --> 00:04:55,830
all underneath
the Contractor organization,

93
00:04:55,830 --> 00:04:59,390
which is all underneath my primary
organization of ITProTV, right?

94
00:04:59,390 --> 00:05:02,120
So you can break this
down however you need it.

95
00:05:02,120 --> 00:05:03,630
For the parent organization,

96
00:05:03,630 --> 00:05:06,010
this main one, there's not
a whole lot you can do with it.

97
00:05:06,010 --> 00:05:08,180
You can rename it and that's about it.

98
00:05:08,180 --> 00:05:09,670
But for the other guys,

99
00:05:09,670 --> 00:05:12,548
if you hit that drop-down arrow
you'll see a few different options.

100
00:05:12,548 --> 00:05:15,760
Add a sub-organization and
Edit, we've seen those.

101
00:05:15,760 --> 00:05:20,420
But Move and Delete, you can delete a
sub-organization if you don't need it, and

102
00:05:20,420 --> 00:05:23,830
you can move them if you wanna
change the organizational structure.

103
00:05:23,830 --> 00:05:25,460
So it's not all set in stone.

104
00:05:25,460 --> 00:05:27,240
The only one that's set in
stone is that parent one.

105
00:05:27,240 --> 00:05:28,840
You can't change it other than its name.

106
00:05:31,050 --> 00:05:35,580
Once I've created these organizations,
my next step is to put users in them.

107
00:05:35,580 --> 00:05:38,180
So I need to move my
user accounts around so

108
00:05:38,180 --> 00:05:40,570
that they're in
the appropriate organization.

109
00:05:40,570 --> 00:05:43,015
And so I would just go through and
check the users.

110
00:05:44,375 --> 00:05:47,625
And then once I've got them checked,
I've got this Move to another organization

111
00:05:47,625 --> 00:05:50,335
button I would hit to move them
to the particular location.

112
00:05:50,335 --> 00:05:52,255
I think I've already got some
people that are retired.

113
00:05:52,255 --> 00:05:53,077
Let's see, yeah.

114
00:05:53,077 --> 00:05:58,028
So I might wanna take Chris here, and I'll
move him to put him in EdutainmentLIVE,

115
00:05:58,028 --> 00:06:00,640
all right, so I'll move him off.

116
00:06:00,640 --> 00:06:05,370
And then I might take Chris, or
we just did Chris, I'll do Gar this time.

117
00:06:05,370 --> 00:06:10,710
So I'll take Gar Samuelson, and
I'll move him to Halliburton, all right?

118
00:06:10,710 --> 00:06:11,830
So we can just check right through,

119
00:06:11,830 --> 00:06:15,350
and hit that option, and I'm gonna move
them off to the appropriate location.

120
00:06:15,350 --> 00:06:18,270
If your screen doesn't refresh right away,
don't worry about it, right.

121
00:06:18,270 --> 00:06:20,960
You can usually just click around and
it'll update.

122
00:06:20,960 --> 00:06:24,060
And if I go into EdutainmentLIVE,
there's Chris.

123
00:06:24,060 --> 00:06:26,600
And if I go into Halliburton,
there's Gar Samuelson, right?

124
00:06:26,600 --> 00:06:29,117
Moved to the appropriate organizations.

125
00:06:29,117 --> 00:06:30,534
Now the policies that we set,

126
00:06:30,534 --> 00:06:33,598
all of the policies and
configurations that we've been doing so

127
00:06:33,598 --> 00:06:37,790
far have been right up here at the ITProTV
organization, at the top level.

128
00:06:37,790 --> 00:06:41,690
And those settings trickle
down to the sub-organizations.

129
00:06:41,690 --> 00:06:43,860
So, since everything was done here,

130
00:06:43,860 --> 00:06:47,580
it's all trickling down to these
other sub-organizations I've made.

131
00:06:47,580 --> 00:06:51,070
So when I move those users,
are they gonna notice any difference?

132
00:06:51,070 --> 00:06:53,640
No, everything is the same to them, right?

133
00:06:53,640 --> 00:06:59,260
But, now I have the power to go and
override settings at any of these levels,

134
00:06:59,260 --> 00:07:02,040
to change what the users see,
what they experience.

135
00:07:02,040 --> 00:07:04,545
And we'll notice throughout
the user interface here,

136
00:07:04,545 --> 00:07:08,930
that as we start to look at things like
our users, we'll be able to go into our

137
00:07:08,930 --> 00:07:14,310
user list in the admin panel and
filter based on organization.

138
00:07:14,310 --> 00:07:18,382
Or when we go to define policies
we'll define by organization.

139
00:07:18,382 --> 00:07:22,300
So we'll have a lot more control than
what we used to have, all right?

140
00:07:22,300 --> 00:07:23,910
Let me show you an example of a policy.

141
00:07:23,910 --> 00:07:28,020
I know this bleeds into the next objective
a little bit but I'll show you anyway.

142
00:07:28,020 --> 00:07:30,660
If I go back to my admin panel, and

143
00:07:30,660 --> 00:07:34,935
I go to More Controls, I'll see some
of my different controls that I've got.

144
00:07:34,935 --> 00:07:39,774
And I'm looking for my, let's see what
would be a good one to mess with?

145
00:07:39,774 --> 00:07:41,430
I don't want to mess anything up too much.

146
00:07:41,430 --> 00:07:44,420
Well, let's go to Admin Roles, right?

147
00:07:44,420 --> 00:07:48,524
When we create an admin role,
I can make somebody a group admin or

148
00:07:48,524 --> 00:07:49,746
a help desk admin.

149
00:07:49,746 --> 00:07:54,487
And normally, I'm making them a help desk
admin for the ITProTV organization, for

150
00:07:54,487 --> 00:07:56,990
the organization as a whole.

151
00:07:56,990 --> 00:08:00,340
But, now that I've got sub-organizations,
I can change that.

152
00:08:00,340 --> 00:08:05,240
Maybe I want Marty Friedman to be a help
desk admin, but just for the contractors.

153
00:08:05,240 --> 00:08:07,710
I want him to be the liaison for
the contractors, so

154
00:08:07,710 --> 00:08:09,460
I want him to manage those accounts.

155
00:08:09,460 --> 00:08:11,340
So I might take his account and

156
00:08:11,340 --> 00:08:15,160
modify it so that he's not
attached to all organizations, but

157
00:08:15,160 --> 00:08:20,650
is instead attached to just particular
organizations like Contractors.

158
00:08:20,650 --> 00:08:24,680
Or I might want to add somebody else in
here, I'll add in, who else do we have?

159
00:08:24,680 --> 00:08:26,230
We can do Nick Menza.

160
00:08:26,230 --> 00:08:26,870
So I'll bring in Nick.

161
00:08:26,870 --> 00:08:31,200
And I'm gonna give him admin
rights on Contractors.

162
00:08:31,200 --> 00:08:34,098
And when I choose that, it's gonna
automatically trickle down to include

163
00:08:34,098 --> 00:08:37,290
EdutainmentLIVE and Halliburton,
so I'll give him those.

164
00:08:37,290 --> 00:08:39,340
And now, he's a help desk admin.

165
00:08:39,340 --> 00:08:41,790
I see him right in the list, but

166
00:08:41,790 --> 00:08:44,320
I've limited the organizations
that he has attached.

167
00:08:46,720 --> 00:08:51,490
All right, so that's a neat way that we
can make a use of these organizations.

168
00:08:51,490 --> 00:08:52,760
We can do it for permissions.

169
00:08:52,760 --> 00:08:54,280
We can do it for other things too.

170
00:08:54,280 --> 00:08:56,880
When we get to the policy side,
we'll see that.

171
00:08:56,880 --> 00:09:02,760
And just to look at that real quick, if we
take a quick glance at something like our,

172
00:09:02,760 --> 00:09:05,201
what would be a good one to look at?

173
00:09:08,360 --> 00:09:10,132
Well, shoot,
I don't want to step on my toes for

174
00:09:10,132 --> 00:09:12,610
some of the other objectives
that we're gonna get into.

175
00:09:12,610 --> 00:09:15,960
But just something simple,
like turning on and off services.

176
00:09:15,960 --> 00:09:21,471
So if I go into Google Apps and
I take something like Mobile.

177
00:09:21,471 --> 00:09:23,480
So there's the Mobile I was
talking about right here.

178
00:09:23,480 --> 00:09:25,240
These are all my device
management settings.

179
00:09:25,240 --> 00:09:28,500
And we'll start to see the device
management settings in here.

180
00:09:28,500 --> 00:09:31,400
And notice on the left,
I can pick my organizations.

181
00:09:31,400 --> 00:09:35,610
So at the ITProTV level, this is where
these settings are locally applied.

182
00:09:35,610 --> 00:09:37,790
See how it says that right there,
locally applied?

183
00:09:37,790 --> 00:09:39,780
This is where the setting is put in place.

184
00:09:39,780 --> 00:09:43,477
But for all of those
sub-organizations like Contractors,

185
00:09:43,477 --> 00:09:45,152
see how it says inherited?

186
00:09:45,152 --> 00:09:48,904
That setting wasn't put right here on
Contractors, it was put on the parent and

187
00:09:48,904 --> 00:09:50,170
it trickled down.

188
00:09:50,170 --> 00:09:54,290
So if I wanna override that I, can come
in here and I can start to change it.

189
00:09:54,290 --> 00:09:58,440
And if I start to change these things,
see how it now says locally applied?

190
00:09:58,440 --> 00:09:59,970
It's not inherited anymore.

191
00:09:59,970 --> 00:10:04,740
I'm overriding that behavior right
here just for these particular users.

192
00:10:04,740 --> 00:10:07,428
If you don't have a need for this,
if you don't have a need for

193
00:10:07,428 --> 00:10:11,250
separate policies, then there's not
really a need for sub-organizations.

194
00:10:11,250 --> 00:10:13,280
So, not every company needs that.

195
00:10:13,280 --> 00:10:18,658
But if you want custom permissions, custom
roles, or custom policies like these,

196
00:10:18,658 --> 00:10:21,624
sub-organizations are the way
that we do it.

197
00:10:21,624 --> 00:10:22,708
All right, let's see,

198
00:10:22,708 --> 00:10:25,869
is there anything else that I wanna
do while I'm messing around in here?

199
00:10:27,650 --> 00:10:29,040
No that's about it, right.

200
00:10:29,040 --> 00:10:33,470
Feel like I'm missing something,
but [LAUGH] I think I got it all.

201
00:10:33,470 --> 00:10:36,590
Just be aware that once you start
to create sub-organizations,

202
00:10:36,590 --> 00:10:40,620
it becomes doubly important that every
time you go into configure something,

203
00:10:40,620 --> 00:10:43,750
look for
the organization's navigation, right?

204
00:10:43,750 --> 00:10:47,230
Because you might think you're making
a change for your whole organization, but

205
00:10:47,230 --> 00:10:49,260
you're actually just making it for a sub.

206
00:10:49,260 --> 00:10:51,890
Or you might think you're making
a change on a sub-organization, but

207
00:10:51,890 --> 00:10:54,390
you're actually changing it for
your whole company.

208
00:10:54,390 --> 00:10:55,900
Be careful about that.

209
00:10:55,900 --> 00:10:57,130
When you've got sub-organizations,

210
00:10:57,130 --> 00:11:00,470
you've gotta pay attention to this
navigation bar on the left side.

211
00:11:00,470 --> 00:11:03,160
When we start to make changes,
it's easy to overlook it.

212
00:11:03,160 --> 00:11:05,514
So see,
I was in that Contractors organization.

213
00:11:05,514 --> 00:11:08,440
And if I go all the way back
out to my admin console, and

214
00:11:08,440 --> 00:11:11,625
then I go back into Google Apps,
and I go back into Mobile,

215
00:11:11,625 --> 00:11:15,490
then I go in here to start
working with device management.

216
00:11:15,490 --> 00:11:19,270
When I go in here,
see how it remembers I was in Contractors?

217
00:11:19,270 --> 00:11:21,500
So it remembers that's
what I was working on.

218
00:11:21,500 --> 00:11:24,170
And I see locally applied right here,
so it might be easy for

219
00:11:24,170 --> 00:11:27,890
me to confuse them and think that I'm
working on the company, when I'm not.

220
00:11:27,890 --> 00:11:30,270
And I need to remember to go over here and
choose that.

221
00:11:30,270 --> 00:11:33,990
So just a caveat, a little word to
the wise, easy to make a mistake there.

222
00:11:33,990 --> 00:11:37,704
And when you make a change at the company
level, at the parent organization,

223
00:11:37,704 --> 00:11:39,420
it takes effect immediately.

224
00:11:39,420 --> 00:11:41,360
Your end users will get
affected right away, and

225
00:11:41,360 --> 00:11:42,819
that's definitely something
you want to avoid.

226
00:11:44,224 --> 00:11:48,570
All right, so in this segment we got
a chance to see creating organizations and

227
00:11:48,570 --> 00:11:50,200
how we can move users in there.

228
00:11:50,200 --> 00:11:52,728
And some of the different cool
things we can do once we have

229
00:11:52,728 --> 00:11:54,860
sub-organizations in place.

230
00:11:54,860 --> 00:11:59,977
Be sure to stay tuned, we're gonna work
in organizations in the next segment.

231
00:11:59,977 --> 00:12:05,784
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Managing Services by OU
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:07,964
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07,964 --> 00:00:11,275
Objective 2.2 covers one of the neater
things that we can do when we

3
00:00:11,275 --> 00:00:14,830
have multiple organizations inside
of our Google apps account.

4
00:00:14,830 --> 00:00:18,900
The official title is demonstrate how
to manage Google apps services by

5
00:00:18,900 --> 00:00:20,195
organizational unit.

6
00:00:20,195 --> 00:00:24,100
And basically what they're saying is,
when you set up a Google apps account

7
00:00:24,100 --> 00:00:26,920
there are a number of services
that you're enabling, right.

8
00:00:26,920 --> 00:00:31,248
And we all think of Gmail and Drive
because those are the two big ones, right.

9
00:00:31,248 --> 00:00:35,490
But, there's plenty of other things like
Calendar and YouTube, and Blogger, and

10
00:00:35,490 --> 00:00:38,530
all these other different services
that are a part of Google apps.

11
00:00:39,580 --> 00:00:42,900
Well, when you have multiple
sub-organizations, you can turn these

12
00:00:42,900 --> 00:00:48,380
services on or off for different sets
of users, and that's really handy.

13
00:00:48,380 --> 00:00:51,530
If you don't use sub-organizations,
you just have one big organization,

14
00:00:51,530 --> 00:00:54,360
you can turn the apps on or
off for the entire company.

15
00:00:54,360 --> 00:00:57,330
But when you have sub-organizations,
you get a lot more control.

16
00:00:57,330 --> 00:00:59,160
Let me show you what I mean.

17
00:00:59,160 --> 00:01:02,640
Here in my admin panel if
I got into Google Apps,

18
00:01:02,640 --> 00:01:05,780
right in here I'll get a list of
the primary applications that pretty much

19
00:01:05,780 --> 00:01:07,790
every company's gonna take advantage of.

20
00:01:07,790 --> 00:01:10,440
And notice the status on the right side.

21
00:01:10,440 --> 00:01:13,050
You're normally gonna see
one of three statuses.

22
00:01:13,050 --> 00:01:16,050
On for everyone as the default for
the core services.

23
00:01:16,050 --> 00:01:18,170
That means everyone in your company and

24
00:01:18,170 --> 00:01:22,940
every sub-organization is allowed to
use this particular service, right.

25
00:01:22,940 --> 00:01:25,560
So Calendar, Contacts,
Drive, those are big ones,

26
00:01:25,560 --> 00:01:27,060
those are ones that we
want our company to use.

27
00:01:28,060 --> 00:01:31,757
You may see other ones that say on for
some organizations,

28
00:01:31,757 --> 00:01:35,919
and that means that we've done
a little pick and choose, right.

29
00:01:35,919 --> 00:01:40,980
We've picked some of our sub-organizations
to have it, and some not to have it.

30
00:01:40,980 --> 00:01:42,980
And then a third option is just off.

31
00:01:42,980 --> 00:01:45,040
We may have disabled it outright and

32
00:01:45,040 --> 00:01:47,510
nobody in the company is able to use it,
all right.

33
00:01:47,510 --> 00:01:49,600
So we can go through and
start to change that.

34
00:01:49,600 --> 00:01:53,050
Now, if you are not using organizations,
and you just have one,

35
00:01:53,050 --> 00:01:57,530
then there's really only two options
that matter, on for everyone, or off.

36
00:01:57,530 --> 00:02:00,820
But if you have some sub-organizations,
that's where the on for

37
00:02:00,820 --> 00:02:03,650
some organizations becomes really handy,
and we start to pick.

38
00:02:03,650 --> 00:02:07,470
So let's take, for example,
Google Hangouts right here.

39
00:02:07,470 --> 00:02:11,820
This allows employees to be able to chat,
as well as place video calls,

40
00:02:11,820 --> 00:02:13,070
a lot of powerful stuff.

41
00:02:13,070 --> 00:02:14,580
You can use it for group meetings.

42
00:02:14,580 --> 00:02:16,330
It's a wonderful collaborative tool.

43
00:02:16,330 --> 00:02:18,890
We use it here at ITProTV all the time.

44
00:02:18,890 --> 00:02:22,138
But maybe you're one of those companies
that's a little more Draconian, right.

45
00:02:22,138 --> 00:02:25,070
[LAUGH] And you don't want your
employees chatting or talking.

46
00:02:25,070 --> 00:02:26,590
Or maybe it's the contractors.

47
00:02:26,590 --> 00:02:29,640
You don't want the contractors
placing video calls, right.

48
00:02:29,640 --> 00:02:33,190
Well, we can go in and
either outright turn this off, or

49
00:02:33,190 --> 00:02:36,390
we could choose to make it where
the contractors aren't able to use it.

50
00:02:36,390 --> 00:02:40,690
If I click on Talk/Hangouts,
it'll pull up this list, and

51
00:02:40,690 --> 00:02:44,090
I can see right here under the picture,
where it says on for everyone.

52
00:02:44,090 --> 00:02:48,092
And if I drop that down,
here's my three choices, on for everyone,

53
00:02:48,092 --> 00:02:49,892
which is what's the default.

54
00:02:49,892 --> 00:02:54,371
Off, so just nobody's gonna be able to use
it, and you'll see here it's warning me

55
00:02:54,371 --> 00:02:58,680
that's gonna be a problem because of
how integrated it is with Google Plus.

56
00:02:58,680 --> 00:03:02,390
So it's telling me that if I turn this off
I may have some issues to deal with there.

57
00:03:02,390 --> 00:03:03,800
I'm gonna cancel that.

58
00:03:03,800 --> 00:03:07,600
The other option is,
on for some organizations.

59
00:03:07,600 --> 00:03:10,300
And now it's gonna give
me the chance to choose.

60
00:03:10,300 --> 00:03:15,720
And I'll see that ITProTV has my master
setting and the master setting is on.

61
00:03:15,720 --> 00:03:21,770
And the other guys, contractors,
retired, these guys are all inheriting,

62
00:03:21,770 --> 00:03:26,430
and so I can go through and start to
change that if I want, wherever I choose.

63
00:03:26,430 --> 00:03:31,570
Maybe I want the Halliburton guys not to
be able to use it, so I'll go up here and

64
00:03:31,570 --> 00:03:35,900
I'm gonna choose to override it, and

65
00:03:35,900 --> 00:03:40,550
then once we've chosen to override it,
we'll be able to flip that to off.

66
00:03:40,550 --> 00:03:46,560
So see a Halliburton is set to override,
and now I can flip it to off, all right.

67
00:03:46,560 --> 00:03:48,990
And it takes just a second
to recognize what I've done.

68
00:03:48,990 --> 00:03:51,290
It's giving me that Google Plus
warning again, but it's just for

69
00:03:51,290 --> 00:03:53,790
the Halliburton guy, so
what do I care there?

70
00:03:53,790 --> 00:03:55,770
And so I've got it set, all right.

71
00:03:55,770 --> 00:04:00,360
So I had to block the inheritants first,
and then I was able to turn it off.

72
00:04:00,360 --> 00:04:03,310
Notice that Entertainment Live
still has it,

73
00:04:03,310 --> 00:04:07,350
because it's inheriting it from
contractors, which inherits from ITProTV.

74
00:04:07,350 --> 00:04:09,590
If I wanted to turn it off for
all of my contractors,

75
00:04:09,590 --> 00:04:11,740
I'd need to do it here at this level.

76
00:04:11,740 --> 00:04:17,310
And notice how I can't turn it off
until I do that override, so I've gotta

77
00:04:17,310 --> 00:04:23,032
override it first, and apply that, and
then I can turn it off right there.

78
00:04:23,032 --> 00:04:27,210
All right, so now with that being
turned off I'll see that it's off for

79
00:04:27,210 --> 00:04:32,120
the contractors and Entertainment Live
says inherited still, right.

80
00:04:32,120 --> 00:04:34,820
But if I click on them I'll see
it's inheriting that it's off.

81
00:04:34,820 --> 00:04:38,260
I could actually turn it back on on
Entertainment Live if I went and

82
00:04:38,260 --> 00:04:42,060
overrode its inheritance, and
turned it back on right there.

83
00:04:42,060 --> 00:04:44,670
So you've really got a lot of flexibility.

84
00:04:44,670 --> 00:04:48,880
By doing this,
my ITProTV organization still has it,

85
00:04:48,880 --> 00:04:53,050
my retired personnel still have it,
but my contractors and

86
00:04:53,050 --> 00:04:55,680
each of the organizations inside of it,
don't have it.

87
00:04:55,680 --> 00:05:01,210
So, this situation is what we call,
on for some organizations.

88
00:05:01,210 --> 00:05:03,040
Some have it, some don't, all right.

89
00:05:03,040 --> 00:05:05,950
Now they can't display that in
a nice little green bar here so

90
00:05:05,950 --> 00:05:08,710
you'll see the link that appeared,
view the status for each org,

91
00:05:08,710 --> 00:05:12,710
and if you click on that you'll just get
that management screen where you can see

92
00:05:12,710 --> 00:05:14,600
whether it's turned on or
off for each one.

93
00:05:14,600 --> 00:05:18,490
So pretty straightforward,
really neat way to handle that and

94
00:05:18,490 --> 00:05:22,400
if I go back out to my Google Apps
Service Screen, we can do that for

95
00:05:22,400 --> 00:05:25,010
anyone of these and
you'll see it change, right.

96
00:05:25,010 --> 00:05:26,660
So like Talk/Hangouts.

97
00:05:26,660 --> 00:05:29,520
On for selected orgs right there,
and we can modify it.

98
00:05:29,520 --> 00:05:32,150
Now, these are the core services.

99
00:05:32,150 --> 00:05:36,050
Don't forget all of the other services
that are just not considered core.

100
00:05:36,050 --> 00:05:41,555
If I go back to my admin console and
I go to to more controls.

101
00:05:41,555 --> 00:05:44,805
In here you'll see more Google apps.

102
00:05:44,805 --> 00:05:46,265
These are the non-core ones.

103
00:05:46,265 --> 00:05:49,267
So here's Blogger, Google Ad Sense,
Ad Words, Analytics,

104
00:05:49,267 --> 00:05:51,830
all these other guys Google Plus,
YouTube, right.

105
00:05:51,830 --> 00:05:55,927
And we can do the exact same thing for
these guys.

106
00:05:55,927 --> 00:05:57,715
We can turn them on or off.

107
00:05:57,715 --> 00:06:01,128
So, those contractors,
I don't want them to go to YouTube.

108
00:06:01,128 --> 00:06:05,974
So I can go to YouTube and I can
choose on for some organizations, and

109
00:06:05,974 --> 00:06:09,970
I can kind of repeat the process here,
overriding it for

110
00:06:09,970 --> 00:06:13,553
contractors and
then turning it off, all right.

111
00:06:13,553 --> 00:06:16,700
So it's just letting me know
it's gonna turn it off, and

112
00:06:16,700 --> 00:06:18,744
it may take up to 24 hours to apply.

113
00:06:18,744 --> 00:06:22,260
Be aware of that, there's a lot of cookies
and sessions that are already in place.

114
00:06:22,260 --> 00:06:26,390
And Google, you might not know this but
they've got a lot of servers, they've got

115
00:06:26,390 --> 00:06:30,000
thousands of servers all across the world,
you guys already know that.

116
00:06:30,000 --> 00:06:33,370
So it takes awhile to get that
synchronized across all of their systems.

117
00:06:33,370 --> 00:06:35,660
That's why I warned you that
it may take up to 24 hours.

118
00:06:35,660 --> 00:06:38,880
It's normally much faster but
just plan on 24 hours and

119
00:06:38,880 --> 00:06:40,190
you'll never be disappointed, right.

120
00:06:40,190 --> 00:06:43,090
So that's our goal there but
now I've got that overridden and

121
00:06:43,090 --> 00:06:45,920
my contractors won't be
able to use YouTube.

122
00:06:45,920 --> 00:06:49,770
They might still be able to browse to the
YouTube website and watch stuff, but they

123
00:06:49,770 --> 00:06:53,360
won't be able to log in with their account
that's created through our Google apps.

124
00:06:53,360 --> 00:06:55,020
Now you might ask yourself well,

125
00:06:55,020 --> 00:06:57,650
what's the point there if you're
not going to block the access?

126
00:06:57,650 --> 00:07:01,450
Well, what your preventing is, your
preventing them from logging in with their

127
00:07:01,450 --> 00:07:05,690
company account and posting videos or
doing inappropriate things, commenting, or

128
00:07:05,690 --> 00:07:07,470
whatever with a company account.

129
00:07:07,470 --> 00:07:08,770
They won't be able to do that.

130
00:07:08,770 --> 00:07:10,450
They can log out and
log in with their personal account,

131
00:07:10,450 --> 00:07:13,450
do whatever the heck they want,
that's their own problem, right.

132
00:07:13,450 --> 00:07:16,870
Well, from the company side, we've
isolated ourselves from their activities.

133
00:07:16,870 --> 00:07:18,970
So, that's really
the whole purpose of this.

134
00:07:18,970 --> 00:07:21,540
You can put other
controls in place to stop

135
00:07:21,540 --> 00:07:23,392
them from even getting to the website,
if you want.

136
00:07:23,392 --> 00:07:28,530
All right, so, in this segment, we got
a chance to see how we can use those

137
00:07:28,530 --> 00:07:33,680
organizational units to manage the access
for an individual organizational unit.

138
00:07:33,680 --> 00:07:36,220
We saw some of the services that
we can turn on and off, and

139
00:07:36,220 --> 00:07:39,110
the different options that
are available for each.

140
00:07:39,110 --> 00:07:40,650
All right I hope you guys
enjoyed that segment.

141
00:07:40,650 --> 00:07:45,413
Stay tuned, we've got more Google
app segments coming up after this.

142
00:07:45,413 --> 00:07:48,753
[MUSIC]

143
00:07:48,753 --> 00:07:51,761
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Managing Google Apps Services
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:07,930
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07,930 --> 00:00:11,981
Objective 3.3 is demonstrating
how to manage domain and

3
00:00:11,981 --> 00:00:16,110
organizational level settings for
Google Apps services.

4
00:00:16,110 --> 00:00:16,990
That's quite a mouthful.

5
00:00:16,990 --> 00:00:20,290
What they're actually saying there is
how to turn on various services, or

6
00:00:20,290 --> 00:00:22,990
turn off various services,
within our organization.

7
00:00:22,990 --> 00:00:24,810
And we've kind of already seen that,
right?

8
00:00:24,810 --> 00:00:28,400
We had a segment where we covered
how to turn those things on and off.

9
00:00:28,400 --> 00:00:31,880
So what we really need to
focus here is on how to

10
00:00:31,880 --> 00:00:33,790
add new services to our environment.

11
00:00:33,790 --> 00:00:35,180
Now what do I mean by that?

12
00:00:35,180 --> 00:00:38,418
Well, Google is constantly
developing new solutions, right?

13
00:00:38,418 --> 00:00:40,990
New things come out and
sometimes old things go away.

14
00:00:40,990 --> 00:00:46,000
There might be a Google Wave that
came out and you could choose

15
00:00:46,000 --> 00:00:50,080
to add that to your Google Apps if you
wanted or not and then it went away.

16
00:00:50,080 --> 00:00:53,935
So new services come out, how do we
attach those to our organization and

17
00:00:53,935 --> 00:00:55,871
our sub-organizations and so on?

18
00:00:55,871 --> 00:00:59,506
Right, well the first thing we need to
do is we need to determine how we wanna

19
00:00:59,506 --> 00:01:01,880
handle this from a general perspective.

20
00:01:01,880 --> 00:01:03,157
And then we can go in and

21
00:01:03,157 --> 00:01:06,874
deal with it from a individual app
setting level if we want right.

22
00:01:06,874 --> 00:01:08,840
So let's just start from the big picture.

23
00:01:08,840 --> 00:01:13,410
When you log in to your admin console
you can go into your company profile.

24
00:01:13,410 --> 00:01:19,100
And inside of your company profile there's
two settings we wanna look for, all right.

25
00:01:19,100 --> 00:01:21,651
As we start to peek in here you'll see
some information about your company.

26
00:01:21,651 --> 00:01:23,880
Just your real general information.

27
00:01:23,880 --> 00:01:28,060
But as we scroll down you'll find
this section here, New user features.

28
00:01:29,220 --> 00:01:31,830
And under New user features we've
got some radio buttons here.

29
00:01:31,830 --> 00:01:34,810
We can pick between two
different release schedules.

30
00:01:34,810 --> 00:01:38,890
When new updates come out when
there's a new feature in Gmail or

31
00:01:38,890 --> 00:01:40,890
a new feature in Google Calendar or

32
00:01:40,890 --> 00:01:46,080
whatever, do you wanna get it right away,
the day it becomes available?

33
00:01:46,080 --> 00:01:47,150
Or do you wanna wait a little bit?

34
00:01:47,150 --> 00:01:49,060
Do you wanna slowly go into it?

35
00:01:49,060 --> 00:01:52,960
Now, this is not a new service altogether,
this is just like a new feature.

36
00:01:52,960 --> 00:01:56,880
So if some new feature comes out in Gmail,
right?

37
00:01:56,880 --> 00:02:02,260
A great example would be a few months ago
when Google release the new tabbed inbox.

38
00:02:02,260 --> 00:02:04,049
Used to be that you had one inbox and

39
00:02:04,049 --> 00:02:06,710
all of your new email was
right there in your inbox.

40
00:02:06,710 --> 00:02:12,139
Now you have tabs so you have bulk mail or
advertising, marketing you know those

41
00:02:12,139 --> 00:02:17,450
kind of tabs in addition to your higher
priority email or the priority inbox.

42
00:02:17,450 --> 00:02:21,429
That was another example of a new
feature that Google rolled out.

43
00:02:21,429 --> 00:02:25,100
Gmail was an existing service,
but these were new features.

44
00:02:25,100 --> 00:02:26,652
If you choose Rapid release,

45
00:02:26,652 --> 00:02:30,882
the moment a new feature is released it
will be activated for your organization.

46
00:02:30,882 --> 00:02:33,325
Your people will have that feature,
all right.

47
00:02:33,325 --> 00:02:36,517
But if you choose Scheduled release,
what that does is,

48
00:02:36,517 --> 00:02:38,720
it doesn't let you pick the schedule.

49
00:02:38,720 --> 00:02:39,900
Google picks it.

50
00:02:39,900 --> 00:02:41,860
But, it'll wait a few weeks.

51
00:02:41,860 --> 00:02:43,880
A new feature will come out and
then one or

52
00:02:43,880 --> 00:02:47,500
two weeks will pass before it
enables it for your organization.

53
00:02:47,500 --> 00:02:48,620
That's the default.

54
00:02:48,620 --> 00:02:52,813
And the idea is that you have a great
big public release across the world,

55
00:02:52,813 --> 00:02:57,573
and any little quirks or bugs kind of work
themselves out in that first week or two.

56
00:02:57,573 --> 00:03:01,392
And then it rolls out to environments like
yours that are business related where

57
00:03:01,392 --> 00:03:04,590
they're a little more sensitive
to change like that, all right.

58
00:03:04,590 --> 00:03:10,910
Now that's just features, if we keep
scrolling down you'll find New products.

59
00:03:10,910 --> 00:03:15,085
This is when the add an entirely new
service, so something like Google Wave.

60
00:03:15,085 --> 00:03:19,662
That was a new product that got added,
that was brought in, and you could choose

61
00:03:19,662 --> 00:03:23,980
whether you wanted to make that
available to your accounts or not.

62
00:03:23,980 --> 00:03:24,520
Right?

63
00:03:24,520 --> 00:03:26,040
The default is automatic.

64
00:03:26,040 --> 00:03:30,120
And that means when a new service is
released, it'll be enabled for your users.

65
00:03:30,120 --> 00:03:31,660
But you might not want that.

66
00:03:31,660 --> 00:03:35,060
You might want to pre-approve these
services cuz if it's a new service,

67
00:03:35,060 --> 00:03:36,860
it's something you're
gonna have to manage.

68
00:03:36,860 --> 00:03:39,570
And so you wanna make sure that you've
got the infrastructure in place.

69
00:03:39,570 --> 00:03:41,880
That you've adjusted
permissions as necessary.

70
00:03:41,880 --> 00:03:44,420
You've done your security
review to determine whether or

71
00:03:44,420 --> 00:03:46,150
not you have any compliance or

72
00:03:46,150 --> 00:03:49,820
regulation type issues that might
interfere with you using that service.

73
00:03:49,820 --> 00:03:53,580
So if that's your scenario,
you wanna go Manual.

74
00:03:53,580 --> 00:03:57,091
When you choose Manual that says,
great, Google released a new service.

75
00:03:57,091 --> 00:03:59,090
That's wonderful, but don't turn it on.

76
00:03:59,090 --> 00:04:00,430
Just leave it turned off.

77
00:04:00,430 --> 00:04:02,390
We'll do our research,
find out if we're ready for

78
00:04:02,390 --> 00:04:04,480
it, and then we'll manually
add it when we're ready.

79
00:04:05,710 --> 00:04:08,960
If you choose Automatic,
the services automatically be added,

80
00:04:08,960 --> 00:04:10,650
you don't have to do anything, right?

81
00:04:10,650 --> 00:04:11,819
That's why they call it Automatic, right?

82
00:04:11,819 --> 00:04:14,890
It just happens, it's done, and that's it.

83
00:04:14,890 --> 00:04:18,343
If you choose Manual, though,
when you choose that, I'll go ahead and

84
00:04:18,343 --> 00:04:20,841
put my name in the Manual and
I'll hit save changes.

85
00:04:20,841 --> 00:04:27,390
Now if Google releases some great new
service, well, I'm not gonna have it.

86
00:04:27,390 --> 00:04:32,081
When I go under my Google Apps core
services here I'm not gonna have whatever

87
00:04:32,081 --> 00:04:35,450
this new service is, or
if I go down to More controls and

88
00:04:35,450 --> 00:04:38,635
More Google Apps that I
won't have it here either.

89
00:04:38,635 --> 00:04:42,616
It's new, it's out but I don't have it.

90
00:04:42,616 --> 00:04:46,940
So, if that's the case,
I can manually add it in.

91
00:04:46,940 --> 00:04:50,430
The way you do that is with this little
square button up here that has a plus sign

92
00:04:50,430 --> 00:04:52,400
beside it, it's the Add services button.

93
00:04:52,400 --> 00:04:56,400
And you'll see I have it here under
the more Google Apps screen, but

94
00:04:56,400 --> 00:05:01,080
if I go back to just the regular
Google Apps screen, I've got it there too.

95
00:05:01,080 --> 00:05:02,330
It's the same thing.

96
00:05:02,330 --> 00:05:04,360
We're gonna add that service in.

97
00:05:04,360 --> 00:05:07,799
So if you chose Manual,
this is how you do it.

98
00:05:07,799 --> 00:05:08,423
You never know,

99
00:05:08,423 --> 00:05:11,641
there might already be some services that
are outstanding that you're not aware of.

100
00:05:11,641 --> 00:05:15,554
You can hit that, and it'll take you to
a screen where you can see the different

101
00:05:15,554 --> 00:05:17,460
services that are available.

102
00:05:17,460 --> 00:05:20,450
One of the big ones is Groups for
Business.

103
00:05:20,450 --> 00:05:23,260
We're gonna take a look at that
one in another segment where we

104
00:05:23,260 --> 00:05:24,960
tackle that specifically.

105
00:05:24,960 --> 00:05:27,900
That's one that I almost always go in and
add.

106
00:05:27,900 --> 00:05:30,460
And so if we wanna add Groups for
Business, we can hit Add it now.

107
00:05:30,460 --> 00:05:32,670
And now that service will be available.

108
00:05:32,670 --> 00:05:36,195
I can still go back and turn it on and
off from my organization and

109
00:05:36,195 --> 00:05:39,140
sub-organizations like we
saw in that earlier segment,

110
00:05:39,140 --> 00:05:44,310
but it's just added to my organization
then I can go and customize it.

111
00:05:44,310 --> 00:05:47,227
You'll see some other things,
like these are paid services down here.

112
00:05:47,227 --> 00:05:52,071
Google My Maps Pro, additional Google
Drive storage, if your end users need

113
00:05:52,071 --> 00:05:56,960
more storage than what they've got,
the Google Apps for Work unlimited.

114
00:05:56,960 --> 00:05:58,682
I know I mentioned that
in another segment.

115
00:05:58,682 --> 00:05:59,889
We can turn that feature on.

116
00:05:59,889 --> 00:06:02,730
And you'll see it's got a free
trial you can do if you want.

117
00:06:02,730 --> 00:06:07,610
And then Google Vault, and Google Vault
is really cool if you have any kind

118
00:06:07,610 --> 00:06:11,560
of regulatory or compliance requirements
that make you do e-discovery.

119
00:06:11,560 --> 00:06:14,790
If you need to be able to search across
all of your documents and e-mail and

120
00:06:14,790 --> 00:06:17,750
pull data out of it and make sure you
retain it for certain periods of time.

121
00:06:17,750 --> 00:06:20,908
They have that functionality and
you can add that in and turn it on.

122
00:06:20,908 --> 00:06:22,266
Not everybody has a need for that.

123
00:06:22,266 --> 00:06:23,516
So it's not turned on by default.

124
00:06:23,516 --> 00:06:26,750
It's just sitting here
on the side all right.

125
00:06:26,750 --> 00:06:28,560
And then down on here at the bottom
you'll see where you can

126
00:06:28,560 --> 00:06:31,320
enable the Google Apps Marketplace
where you can go and

127
00:06:31,320 --> 00:06:34,920
have access to tons of
other Google Apps services.

128
00:06:34,920 --> 00:06:36,580
That aren't from Google, but

129
00:06:36,580 --> 00:06:39,870
by independent third parties that
have written these applications.

130
00:06:39,870 --> 00:06:41,980
And there's a ton of cool stuff in there.

131
00:06:41,980 --> 00:06:45,181
Things like project management
software and task management,

132
00:06:45,181 --> 00:06:46,907
all sorts of workflow type stuff.

133
00:06:46,907 --> 00:06:49,532
Really, really neat, but
it's not Google, and so

134
00:06:49,532 --> 00:06:51,873
that's why they don't
turn it on by default.

135
00:06:51,873 --> 00:06:55,025
You can go and turn it on and
go find those different items.

136
00:06:55,025 --> 00:06:57,105
And then if you're using
Google App Engine,

137
00:06:57,105 --> 00:07:00,375
where you develop your
own Google Apps services,

138
00:07:00,375 --> 00:07:04,495
you can add those right here by
entering in your Google App ID.

139
00:07:04,495 --> 00:07:07,355
You punch that in and it'll be
attached to your Google Apps account.

140
00:07:07,355 --> 00:07:10,345
And because it's a published app you could
actually make it available to other people

141
00:07:10,345 --> 00:07:13,190
if you wanted In
the Google App Marketplace or

142
00:07:13,190 --> 00:07:16,100
you can do it manually through the app ID,
either way.

143
00:07:16,100 --> 00:07:19,110
But these are the ways
that we add new services.

144
00:07:19,110 --> 00:07:22,203
Now if you didn't see the other segment
where we covered how to turn them on and

145
00:07:22,203 --> 00:07:23,927
off, let me just recap that real quickly.

146
00:07:23,927 --> 00:07:27,000
If you did see the other segment,
you can stop here.

147
00:07:27,000 --> 00:07:31,320
But once we have a service enabled
you can go into Google Apps and

148
00:07:31,320 --> 00:07:33,450
find the service that
you want to work with.

149
00:07:33,450 --> 00:07:35,640
And so I'll go into like Calendar.

150
00:07:35,640 --> 00:07:38,410
And inside of the Calendar
is where we can adjust.

151
00:07:38,410 --> 00:07:44,080
Here it's on for everyone and we can
change that to on for some organizations.

152
00:07:44,080 --> 00:07:48,360
So when I add a new service, I can go and
adjust the settings right here,

153
00:07:48,360 --> 00:07:52,830
to turn it on or off for my main
organization and the child organizations,

154
00:07:52,830 --> 00:07:54,730
the sub orgs that we have throughout.

155
00:07:54,730 --> 00:07:59,213
So, easy enough to tweak
that to meet our needs.

156
00:07:59,213 --> 00:08:03,630
All right, so in this segment we got to
take a look at how we can automatically

157
00:08:03,630 --> 00:08:05,847
deploy new services and Google Apps.

158
00:08:05,847 --> 00:08:09,893
And how we can manually deploy them if we
choose to just want to have that time to

159
00:08:09,893 --> 00:08:12,670
evaluate the service
before we roll it out.

160
00:08:12,670 --> 00:08:17,280
We also saw to automatically

161
00:08:17,280 --> 00:08:21,580
right away deploy new features or to do a
little delay, a one or two week delay when

162
00:08:21,580 --> 00:08:24,670
a new feature is released before
rolling it out in our environment.

163
00:08:24,670 --> 00:08:28,660
All good stuff to help ensure that you
have a smooth roll-out of services

164
00:08:28,660 --> 00:08:30,370
to your end users.

165
00:08:30,370 --> 00:08:31,860
All right,
well I hope you guys enjoyed this segment.

166
00:08:31,860 --> 00:08:34,964
Stay tuned,
we've got more Google Apps coming up.

167
00:08:34,964 --> 00:08:40,229
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Chrome Policies
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:07,250
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08,543 --> 00:00:13,060
Objective 3.2 covers Chrome policies for
devices and users.

3
00:00:13,060 --> 00:00:14,770
In fact that's kind of the official title.

4
00:00:14,770 --> 00:00:18,990
Demonstrate how to use Chrome policies for
devices and users.

5
00:00:18,990 --> 00:00:21,590
Now, what the heck are Chrome policies?

6
00:00:21,590 --> 00:00:24,800
Well, I know I've mentioned policies in
some of the other segments, but if you

7
00:00:24,800 --> 00:00:28,860
haven't seen those, basically policies
are just a collection of settings.

8
00:00:28,860 --> 00:00:33,330
Settings that we push upon a user to
change their experience when they're in

9
00:00:33,330 --> 00:00:36,310
Google Chrome and
when they're using Google Apps.

10
00:00:36,310 --> 00:00:38,650
Now there's really two
different sides to this.

11
00:00:38,650 --> 00:00:43,210
There's one set of policies that we
apply with in our Google Apps account.

12
00:00:43,210 --> 00:00:47,060
And when a user logs in to Google Apps,
these policies will apply to them.

13
00:00:47,060 --> 00:00:49,370
That's the online policy processing and

14
00:00:49,370 --> 00:00:52,790
it's all pooled live from
the internet via their account.

15
00:00:52,790 --> 00:00:54,040
These are pretty awesome.

16
00:00:54,040 --> 00:00:56,743
Because the changes we make there,
can take effect and

17
00:00:56,743 --> 00:00:58,750
cross to all our users across the world.

18
00:00:58,750 --> 00:01:01,375
They don't have to physically come
to us to get these new settings.

19
00:01:01,375 --> 00:01:04,667
All right but
there's also the offline side of things.

20
00:01:04,667 --> 00:01:07,355
We might have policies that we
want to apply to people that

21
00:01:07,355 --> 00:01:09,375
don't have a connection to the Internet.

22
00:01:09,375 --> 00:01:11,574
And for those people,
they're not gonna be able to reach out and

23
00:01:11,574 --> 00:01:12,840
get your Google app server.

24
00:01:12,840 --> 00:01:14,730
They're not gonna be able
to get those settings.

25
00:01:14,730 --> 00:01:18,050
We need to be able to see this from both,
the online and the offline perspective.

26
00:01:18,050 --> 00:01:21,870
For the exam, they're gonna focus
on the online perspectives.

27
00:01:21,870 --> 00:01:23,640
That's what you really need to know.

28
00:01:23,640 --> 00:01:25,420
But I want to make sure
I show you guys both,

29
00:01:25,420 --> 00:01:28,200
because in real life land you
might see either way all right.

30
00:01:28,200 --> 00:01:30,120
So let's start with the online side.

31
00:01:30,120 --> 00:01:33,100
Fortunately the online
side is really easy.

32
00:01:33,100 --> 00:01:35,080
We go into our policy settings here.

33
00:01:35,080 --> 00:01:37,750
And the next time users
login they take effect.

34
00:01:37,750 --> 00:01:41,746
All right so to see those, what we need
to do is we start your admin console and

35
00:01:41,746 --> 00:01:45,182
we need to go down to More Controls
because what we're looking for

36
00:01:45,182 --> 00:01:46,870
is Chrome Management.

37
00:01:46,870 --> 00:01:49,560
And Chrome Management doesn't
show up here by default.

38
00:01:49,560 --> 00:01:53,238
In fact, you'll find a lot of instructions
that will refer to it as going under

39
00:01:53,238 --> 00:01:55,708
Google Apps and
finding Chrome Management in here.

40
00:01:55,708 --> 00:01:58,980
Well notice I don't
have Chrome Management.

41
00:01:58,980 --> 00:02:00,640
Well, you can add it to this screen.

42
00:02:00,640 --> 00:02:03,833
But I don't usually mess with
that because I like consistency.

43
00:02:03,833 --> 00:02:06,740
So I've just kind of gotten used
to going down to more controls.

44
00:02:06,740 --> 00:02:11,310
And under more controls,
you can go to More Google Apps and

45
00:02:11,310 --> 00:02:16,040
you'll get the full list in here, which
includes Chrome Management right there.

46
00:02:16,040 --> 00:02:18,090
So I'll go to Chrome Management and

47
00:02:18,090 --> 00:02:21,860
