here's where I can get into start
dealing with my policy settings.

48
00:02:21,860 --> 00:02:24,450
Now there's two main
pieces that we deal with.

49
00:02:24,450 --> 00:02:27,510
User Settings and Device Settings.

50
00:02:27,510 --> 00:02:30,810
The User Settings, like the name implies,
applies to your user account.

51
00:02:30,810 --> 00:02:34,670
And these will affect the user account
regardless of what device they use.

52
00:02:34,670 --> 00:02:38,370
So if they're on an Android phone,
or a Chromebook,

53
00:02:38,370 --> 00:02:42,610
if they're on their Mac laptop,
or their Windows desktop.

54
00:02:42,610 --> 00:02:45,760
When they fire up Chrome and
connect up to their Google Apps account,

55
00:02:45,760 --> 00:02:47,940
these policies will apply to them,
all right?

56
00:02:47,940 --> 00:02:51,940
So these settings follow the user,
not the device.

57
00:02:51,940 --> 00:02:53,940
A device policy is the opposite.

58
00:02:53,940 --> 00:02:57,850
A device policy applies to
the physical device, not the user.

59
00:02:57,850 --> 00:03:03,320
So if I have a Android tablet that's
being managed by my Google Apps account,

60
00:03:03,320 --> 00:03:06,990
I can create device policy settings here
that will affect that tablet regardless of

61
00:03:06,990 --> 00:03:10,580
whether it's me using it or one of
the other members of my organization.

62
00:03:11,690 --> 00:03:13,630
Typically we use both.

63
00:03:13,630 --> 00:03:16,920
Because there are some things that apply
to devices and some that apply to users,

64
00:03:16,920 --> 00:03:17,860
and they're a little bit different.

65
00:03:18,880 --> 00:03:23,240
Now when we configure settings here,
these are called policies.

66
00:03:23,240 --> 00:03:26,760
And if you read through the documentation,
you'll see people refer to policies and

67
00:03:26,760 --> 00:03:27,900
preferences.

68
00:03:27,900 --> 00:03:29,970
Policies are the things
that we enforce and

69
00:03:29,970 --> 00:03:32,880
the users can't typically override them.

70
00:03:32,880 --> 00:03:35,440
A preference is something that we
set that's more like a default.

71
00:03:35,440 --> 00:03:37,690
This is their default
configuration in the beginning.

72
00:03:37,690 --> 00:03:40,870
And if they want, they can override
it if they choose, all right?

73
00:03:40,870 --> 00:03:44,625
But you'll see that kind of language
as we go through and look at these.

74
00:03:44,625 --> 00:03:46,220
Let's take a quick look at user settings.

75
00:03:47,240 --> 00:03:51,451
So inside the user settings you'll see
a whole laundry list of configuration

76
00:03:51,451 --> 00:03:52,043
options.

77
00:03:52,043 --> 00:03:54,899
And just like we saw in
some of the other segments,

78
00:03:54,899 --> 00:03:58,060
we can customize these
based on sub-organizations.

79
00:03:58,060 --> 00:04:01,890
So I might have really strict policies for
my contractors and

80
00:04:01,890 --> 00:04:05,240
more relaxed policies for
my ITProTV employees.

81
00:04:05,240 --> 00:04:07,670
So you can kind of pick and
choose how you want to go about that.

82
00:04:07,670 --> 00:04:10,250
I'm looking at my organization
as a whole right now.

83
00:04:10,250 --> 00:04:15,087
And you'll see settings like whether
we want these settings to apply just to

84
00:04:15,087 --> 00:04:19,333
Chrome on Android or if we want it
to do Chrome on iOS also, or both.

85
00:04:19,333 --> 00:04:22,757
You'll see whether we wanna do
custom wallpaper on the devices,

86
00:04:22,757 --> 00:04:26,927
how often the policy refreshes, right,
the default there is every six hours,

87
00:04:26,927 --> 00:04:29,251
that might not, I'm sorry, every three.

88
00:04:29,251 --> 00:04:30,042
Wait.

89
00:04:30,042 --> 00:04:32,920
[LAUGH] Yeah, every three hours, sorry.

90
00:04:32,920 --> 00:04:35,300
So we can specify how often
we want that to happen.

91
00:04:35,300 --> 00:04:36,980
My horrible math skills.

92
00:04:36,980 --> 00:04:42,050
But you'll see a lot of options in here
that tailor how the devices function and

93
00:04:42,050 --> 00:04:47,030
work, whether you wanna pre-install
certain apps on Android or pre-install

94
00:04:47,030 --> 00:04:52,370
certain extensions on Chromebooks or
the Chrome web browser itself.

95
00:04:52,370 --> 00:04:56,201
We can completely customize this behavior,
turning features on,

96
00:04:56,201 --> 00:04:58,833
turning features off,
based on what we need.

97
00:04:58,833 --> 00:05:02,390
Maybe you don't want to allow
people to use Incognito Mode.

98
00:05:02,390 --> 00:05:03,880
So we can go in and turn that off.

99
00:05:03,880 --> 00:05:07,320
And now anyone this policy applies to
will no longer have the option to use

100
00:05:07,320 --> 00:05:08,180
Incognito.

101
00:05:08,180 --> 00:05:12,249
Well, they might have Incognito Mode right
now, but because my refresh interval was

102
00:05:12,249 --> 00:05:15,708
set to three hours, sometime in
the next three hours they'll refresh.

103
00:05:15,708 --> 00:05:17,862
And the Incognito menu
option will go away and

104
00:05:17,862 --> 00:05:21,930
they'll no longer be able to use that
while they're logged into Google Apps.

105
00:05:21,930 --> 00:05:24,830
If they remove themselves from Google
Apps, well then that's a different story,

106
00:05:24,830 --> 00:05:26,020
now they're on their own.

107
00:05:26,020 --> 00:05:31,083
But while they're under our control,
they won't have access to that.

108
00:05:31,083 --> 00:05:33,129
The ability to clear browser history,

109
00:05:33,129 --> 00:05:37,418
all of these different things that you may
want to tweak and modify for your users.

110
00:05:37,418 --> 00:05:40,335
There's not really anything in here
that an user couldn't change themselves

111
00:05:40,335 --> 00:05:40,960
already right?

112
00:05:40,960 --> 00:05:45,010
By going into their settings inside
of Chrome and using the under

113
00:05:45,010 --> 00:05:49,920
the hood option, to go in deeper in there,
but by setting it here we enforce it.

114
00:05:49,920 --> 00:05:52,930
These are policy settings that
are being forced on our user and

115
00:05:52,930 --> 00:05:54,270
they can't overwrite it.

116
00:05:54,270 --> 00:05:57,900
If we disable Incognito Mode,
that was that option up here.

117
00:05:57,900 --> 00:06:01,333
If I disable Incognito Mode,
they can't just go and turn it back on.

118
00:06:01,333 --> 00:06:02,710
The policy's enforced.

119
00:06:02,710 --> 00:06:03,680
They can't do it.

120
00:06:03,680 --> 00:06:06,030
They can't launch that setting.

121
00:06:06,030 --> 00:06:09,300
Really handy if we're employing
large quantities of Chromebooks or

122
00:06:09,300 --> 00:06:11,300
laptops that are running Google Chrome.

123
00:06:11,300 --> 00:06:15,583
You can customize this stuff and get a
consistent configuration across the board.

124
00:06:15,583 --> 00:06:18,470
And you can kinda see where we might
have more restrictive settings.

125
00:06:18,470 --> 00:06:22,200
Maybe I'm a school, and so I have
a sub-organization for my students and

126
00:06:22,200 --> 00:06:24,380
another sub-organization for my staff.

127
00:06:24,380 --> 00:06:27,980
I might want the staff to have
the access to be able to do things,

128
00:06:27,980 --> 00:06:31,460
maybe Incognito Mode or whatever, but
I don't want the students doing that.

129
00:06:31,460 --> 00:06:33,370
I need to keep track of what they did.

130
00:06:33,370 --> 00:06:35,610
And so
I might have a separate policy for them.

131
00:06:36,870 --> 00:06:38,910
These are the User Settings.

132
00:06:38,910 --> 00:06:41,010
And they're pretty straightforward.

133
00:06:41,010 --> 00:06:43,070
Device Settings are basically the same.

134
00:06:43,070 --> 00:06:46,839
If I go back up to my Chrome Management
and I go to Device Settings,

135
00:06:47,850 --> 00:06:51,120
when I go in here, I'll see options
that pertain to the device.

136
00:06:51,120 --> 00:06:55,030
And so, you'll see things in here
like Verified Access and so on.

137
00:06:55,030 --> 00:06:57,040
Notice that this is a licensed feature and

138
00:06:57,040 --> 00:07:01,220
it's telling me that I must purchase at
least one Chrome device license to use it.

139
00:07:01,220 --> 00:07:03,370
This is a demo account for
me so I haven't purchased any.

140
00:07:03,370 --> 00:07:05,270
I'll do the demo though.

141
00:07:05,270 --> 00:07:07,630
And oh no,
they're going to make me contact Sales.

142
00:07:07,630 --> 00:07:10,120
Well anyhow,
you can see some of the options here for

143
00:07:10,120 --> 00:07:14,210
some of the ones that are not completely
grayed out or we will in a second.

144
00:07:14,210 --> 00:07:16,580
But you'll see settings
that pertain to the device.

145
00:07:16,580 --> 00:07:21,220
This is really handy if you're got
computer labs or shared computers.

146
00:07:21,220 --> 00:07:23,700
For example,
you might be a real estate agency.

147
00:07:23,700 --> 00:07:26,760
With real estate, your real estate agents,
they're out in the field.

148
00:07:26,760 --> 00:07:27,720
They're out showing houses.

149
00:07:27,720 --> 00:07:28,800
That's how you make money.

150
00:07:28,800 --> 00:07:31,570
When they come back to the office,
they don't need a desk that they sit at

151
00:07:31,570 --> 00:07:33,640
everyday, because they're
supposed to be out in the field.

152
00:07:33,640 --> 00:07:37,400
So they may use shared computers, or
in a school you might have a computer lab.

153
00:07:37,400 --> 00:07:40,250
You don't know which computer
a particular student is gonna sit on.

154
00:07:40,250 --> 00:07:42,520
They can sit on any of them, right?

155
00:07:42,520 --> 00:07:46,270
You create a device setting policy and
that will control that.

156
00:07:46,270 --> 00:07:50,460
You can turn things on and off, like cloud
printing settings, guest mode and so on.

157
00:07:50,460 --> 00:07:53,050
And you have a suite of
configuration options in there

158
00:07:53,050 --> 00:07:55,520
just like he User Settings, all right.

159
00:07:55,520 --> 00:07:57,650
For you,
maybe User Settings are all you need,

160
00:07:57,650 --> 00:07:59,660
and you don't worry about
the Device Settings.

161
00:07:59,660 --> 00:08:03,710
But you may have where you wanna restrict
users when they're using particular

162
00:08:03,710 --> 00:08:07,170
computers, and not restrict them when
they're using other computers, and

163
00:08:07,170 --> 00:08:09,430
you can't achieve that
with just a user policy.

164
00:08:09,430 --> 00:08:12,333
That's where Device Settings
come in handy.

165
00:08:12,333 --> 00:08:17,660
Now, both of the ones I just showed you,
those are for online policy management.

166
00:08:17,660 --> 00:08:21,294
If you want to preconfigure
a machine to have a policy,

167
00:08:21,294 --> 00:08:24,459
or have offline policy application,
you can.

168
00:08:24,459 --> 00:08:25,960
You can still do it, alright?

169
00:08:25,960 --> 00:08:29,360
The exam will really dive into it,
but in real life then, you can do it.

170
00:08:29,360 --> 00:08:32,790
We have, what's called, Chrome for Work.

171
00:08:32,790 --> 00:08:36,800
Chrome for Work is Google Chrome
you can deploy on machines and

172
00:08:36,800 --> 00:08:39,070
that you can manage with policies.

173
00:08:39,070 --> 00:08:43,370
In a Windows environment you're going to
use the Microsoft active directory group

174
00:08:43,370 --> 00:08:47,500
policy objects or local group policy
objects on a Windows machine to manage it.

175
00:08:47,500 --> 00:08:50,601
On a Mac, you actually have a plist,
a preference list file,

176
00:08:50,601 --> 00:08:54,130
that you can define that
contains these service settings.

177
00:08:54,130 --> 00:08:56,542
And so
we can push those out to the machines.

178
00:08:56,542 --> 00:09:00,486
I'll post a couple of links with
the show notes for this episode, but

179
00:09:00,486 --> 00:09:04,500
basically it's just kind of indicating
how to set up Chrome for Work.

180
00:09:04,500 --> 00:09:10,130
The main things to remember is for Windows
you can't just do a normal Chrome install.

181
00:09:10,130 --> 00:09:15,240
If you go to Google's website and install
Chrome by going to like google.com/chrome.

182
00:09:15,240 --> 00:09:17,900
It installs in that user's profile.

183
00:09:17,900 --> 00:09:20,520
It doesn't install for
all the users on the computer.

184
00:09:20,520 --> 00:09:24,500
So they actually have a special MSI
file that you can use to download it.

185
00:09:24,500 --> 00:09:25,770
That's a Microsoft installer.

186
00:09:25,770 --> 00:09:27,040
See how it's got that right here.

187
00:09:27,040 --> 00:09:28,700
Install the MSI.

188
00:09:28,700 --> 00:09:30,700
And so,
there's a link to download that MSI,

189
00:09:30,700 --> 00:09:34,800
and when it installs,
it will install for all of your users.

190
00:09:34,800 --> 00:09:37,420
So that's requirement
number one on Windows.

191
00:09:37,420 --> 00:09:39,250
Linux and Mac, they aren't like that.

192
00:09:39,250 --> 00:09:42,290
With Linux and Mac, when you install
it it is installed for all users, so

193
00:09:42,290 --> 00:09:44,480
it's fine for them, all right?

194
00:09:44,480 --> 00:09:46,980
The next piece is the policies themselves.

195
00:09:46,980 --> 00:09:52,220
And for Chrome for Work,
Google actually has device and

196
00:09:52,220 --> 00:09:54,640
user based policies that you
can download right here.

197
00:09:54,640 --> 00:10:00,880
Group policies for windows and master
preference files for Mac OS and Cromebook.

198
00:10:00,880 --> 00:10:04,370
For Windows you download these ADM and
ADMX files.

199
00:10:04,370 --> 00:10:07,060
I don't wanna get too deep in to it cuz
this isn't like an active directory

200
00:10:07,060 --> 00:10:08,550
segment or whatever.

201
00:10:08,550 --> 00:10:11,120
But they provide those policy settings so

202
00:10:11,120 --> 00:10:14,400
that you can apply them in the Windows
environment, either as preferences so

203
00:10:14,400 --> 00:10:18,860
that users can override them, or
as policies so that they are enforced.

204
00:10:18,860 --> 00:10:22,000
On the Mac side, you just craft
a little master_preferences file.

205
00:10:22,000 --> 00:10:23,458
Let me show you an example of that.

206
00:10:23,458 --> 00:10:25,500
I wrote one up, let's see,
around here somewhere.

207
00:10:25,500 --> 00:10:26,370
Here we go.

208
00:10:26,370 --> 00:10:29,760
This is an example of what
a master_preferences file might look like.

209
00:10:29,760 --> 00:10:34,300
It's just written in a simple notation
that says what the settings are.

210
00:10:34,300 --> 00:10:39,210
So here I'm setting a homepage to
ITProTV and I'm setting the browser

211
00:10:39,210 --> 00:10:43,300
to show the home button up in
the title bar instead of hiding it.

212
00:10:43,300 --> 00:10:47,000
So you can start to put those and
you just set it up as a little text file.

213
00:10:47,000 --> 00:10:49,395
And you stuff it away with the browser,

214
00:10:49,395 --> 00:10:54,114
either in the folder the browser installed
into for Windows, or in a plist for

215
00:10:54,114 --> 00:10:57,540
a MAC file,
right in that little preference list file.

216
00:10:59,100 --> 00:11:02,010
All right, I’ll post these notes,
again you won’t see it on the exam, but

217
00:11:02,010 --> 00:11:04,210
in real life land you might
have a need for this.

218
00:11:04,210 --> 00:11:08,634
The policies, doing them online is really
ideal, because we set them right there,

219
00:11:08,634 --> 00:11:10,458
in our Google Apps admin console.

220
00:11:10,458 --> 00:11:12,810
And it makes life a lot easier.

221
00:11:12,810 --> 00:11:15,050
But if we can't,
if we have to do it offline,

222
00:11:15,050 --> 00:11:17,205
these are the other tools
that are available for us.

223
00:11:18,415 --> 00:11:22,395
All right, I think that's
pretty much it for that one.

224
00:11:22,395 --> 00:11:27,130
Before you take the exam make sure you
browse through the policy settings to get

225
00:11:27,130 --> 00:11:29,292
familiar with what all is in there.

226
00:11:29,292 --> 00:11:32,125
If we go under user settings,
you'll see all those different options.

227
00:11:32,125 --> 00:11:33,382
Just kind of read through it.

228
00:11:33,382 --> 00:11:35,902
Read through it at least once so
you're familiar with the options.

229
00:11:35,902 --> 00:11:37,167
There's a lot of stuff in there.

230
00:11:37,167 --> 00:11:42,039
It's really cool, and it's nice to be able
to create that consistent configuration

231
00:11:42,039 --> 00:11:43,333
across your devices.

232
00:11:43,333 --> 00:11:45,731
So that users know what to
expect when they log in.

233
00:11:45,731 --> 00:11:47,958
It is a nice feature to have.

234
00:11:47,958 --> 00:11:48,583
All right.

235
00:11:48,583 --> 00:11:52,411
So in this segment we got a chance
to take a look at user policy and

236
00:11:52,411 --> 00:11:56,021
device policy settings in Google Apps for
online use.

237
00:11:56,021 --> 00:11:58,911
And we talked a little bit about
offline policy generation and

238
00:11:58,911 --> 00:12:00,450
some of the features that are there.

239
00:12:00,450 --> 00:12:01,108
Just remember,

240
00:12:01,108 --> 00:12:04,125
I am gonna post some links to articles
along with the show notes for this one.

241
00:12:04,125 --> 00:12:07,250
They're a good read to take a look at
if you're deploying this in production.

242
00:12:07,250 --> 00:12:07,935
But for the exam,

243
00:12:07,935 --> 00:12:10,875
we've pretty much covered pretty much
everything you could expect to see.

244
00:12:10,875 --> 00:12:12,600
All right, I hope you guys enjoyed it.

245
00:12:12,600 --> 00:12:13,500
Be sure to stick with us.

246
00:12:13,500 --> 00:12:16,833
We've got more Google Apps
segments coming up.

247
00:12:16,833 --> 00:12:23,030
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Managing Google Drive Storage
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,346 --> 00:00:08,190
[SOUND]
For

2
00:00:08,190 --> 00:00:12,737
Objective 3.1, we're gonna take our first
look at Google Drive Storage inside of our

3
00:00:12,737 --> 00:00:14,200
Google Apps account.

4
00:00:14,200 --> 00:00:18,210
The official objective is, demonstrate
how to configure sharing settings.

5
00:00:18,210 --> 00:00:21,670
And the storage requirements [LAUGH] for
a Drive.

6
00:00:21,670 --> 00:00:24,660
So Google Drive,
it's a core service of Google Apps.

7
00:00:24,660 --> 00:00:26,410
When you sign up for Google Apps,

8
00:00:26,410 --> 00:00:32,470
each of your users will get a minimum
of 30 gigabytes of storage each.

9
00:00:32,470 --> 00:00:36,300
I say minimum because there are different
tiers of service with Google.

10
00:00:36,300 --> 00:00:39,020
Most of us when we sign up,
we're just gonna go on that normal tier,

11
00:00:39,020 --> 00:00:40,310
and you get 30 gigs.

12
00:00:40,310 --> 00:00:44,630
But they do have
the Google Unlimited licenses now.

13
00:00:44,630 --> 00:00:47,880
And with those, they're a little,
I'm gonna say it's strange.

14
00:00:47,880 --> 00:00:49,180
Not strange in a bad way.

15
00:00:49,180 --> 00:00:52,580
But if you have a small organization,
just one to four users, and

16
00:00:52,580 --> 00:00:57,180
you go Google Unlimited, you actually get
one terabyte of storage for each user.

17
00:00:57,180 --> 00:01:01,190
So up to four users,
you just get this one terabyte per user.

18
00:01:01,190 --> 00:01:03,790
After that though,
when you get to five users, and more,

19
00:01:03,790 --> 00:01:06,512
under Google Unlimited plan,
it becomes truly unlimited.

20
00:01:06,512 --> 00:01:08,115
You can have all
the storage that you want.

21
00:01:08,115 --> 00:01:13,400
So, when you're leveraging Google drive,
you can have a ton of data up there.

22
00:01:14,420 --> 00:01:16,370
We need to be able to
keep a handle on that.

23
00:01:16,370 --> 00:01:19,364
And so, there's a few little settings
that we need to be aware of,

24
00:01:19,364 --> 00:01:21,780
to tailor the way that our
company uses Google Drive.

25
00:01:23,400 --> 00:01:27,200
First off, Google Drive itself
it's a great Cloud solution.

26
00:01:27,200 --> 00:01:31,044
You can store your data up on Google
servers, it's securely transmitted, and

27
00:01:31,044 --> 00:01:34,610
encrypted it as it crosses the network,
so you know your data is safe up there.

28
00:01:34,610 --> 00:01:37,790
You don't have to worry about backing
it up, Google takes care of that.

29
00:01:37,790 --> 00:01:41,020
And regardless, of what computer you're
at, you'll have access to your files, so

30
00:01:41,020 --> 00:01:42,720
you definitely wanna use it.

31
00:01:42,720 --> 00:01:44,370
But, there are some little problems.

32
00:01:45,960 --> 00:01:48,470
Not problems,
they're opportunities for improvement.

33
00:01:48,470 --> 00:01:51,410
So, [LAUGH] you got to use
our right terminology.

34
00:01:51,410 --> 00:01:55,280
So, if you have a bunch of documents
inside of Google Drive, and

35
00:01:55,280 --> 00:01:59,860
you hire some contractors that are gonna
be working your organization temporarily.

36
00:01:59,860 --> 00:02:02,650
And you share documents
with those contractors.

37
00:02:02,650 --> 00:02:03,870
What can they do?

38
00:02:03,870 --> 00:02:07,680
They can turn around, and share those
documents outside of the company,

39
00:02:07,680 --> 00:02:08,860
if they wanted.

40
00:02:08,860 --> 00:02:11,850
That's what Google Drive is all about,
easy collaboration.

41
00:02:11,850 --> 00:02:14,760
So, they can share documents to
people that you haven't approved.

42
00:02:14,760 --> 00:02:16,960
And that can be a problem.

43
00:02:16,960 --> 00:02:20,570
So, one of the common settings
we adjust in Google Drive, is to

44
00:02:20,570 --> 00:02:24,600
change the way that sharing happens, to
modify who you're allowed to share with.

45
00:02:24,600 --> 00:02:26,480
Let me show you, what I mean.

46
00:02:26,480 --> 00:02:29,830
If we go into our Admin console,
and we go under Google Apps.

47
00:02:31,200 --> 00:02:34,750
You can go under Drive,
well after I re-authenticate here,

48
00:02:34,750 --> 00:02:38,480
we can go under Drive, and in the Drive
settings we'll see where we can modify

49
00:02:38,480 --> 00:02:39,850
the default sharing preferences.

50
00:02:39,850 --> 00:02:43,900
So I'll just go under Drive,
and then Sharing settings.

51
00:02:45,030 --> 00:02:49,050
So right in here, we see a handful of
options that pertain to how devices, or

52
00:02:49,050 --> 00:02:51,080
how files get shared out.

53
00:02:51,080 --> 00:02:53,980
There's two radio buttons right here,
that are primary options.

54
00:02:53,980 --> 00:02:58,300
The first one is, users cannot share
files outside of this organization.

55
00:02:58,300 --> 00:03:03,070
If we choose that, our employees will be
able to share stuff with each other, but

56
00:03:03,070 --> 00:03:03,900
that's it.

57
00:03:03,900 --> 00:03:06,560
They won't be able to share to
anybody outside of the organization.

58
00:03:06,560 --> 00:03:11,090
Now, they could download the file, and
email it to somebody as an attachment.

59
00:03:11,090 --> 00:03:12,670
This doesn't solve that problem.

60
00:03:12,670 --> 00:03:16,100
But it stops them from direct link
sharing it, right out of Google Drive.

61
00:03:16,100 --> 00:03:17,610
So, it'll stop that from happening.

62
00:03:17,610 --> 00:03:20,109
They'll only be able to share with
people inside the organization.

63
00:03:21,630 --> 00:03:24,750
When you do that,
by default they won't be able to

64
00:03:24,750 --> 00:03:27,610
receive shares from outside
of the organization either.

65
00:03:27,610 --> 00:03:30,310
So, you can check this option
to say let them do that.

66
00:03:30,310 --> 00:03:32,590
They can't share themselves.

67
00:03:32,590 --> 00:03:34,770
They can't originate the file themselves,
but

68
00:03:34,770 --> 00:03:36,980
they can receive somebody
else's share from the outside.

69
00:03:38,510 --> 00:03:43,500
The default, though, is users can share
files outside of the organization.

70
00:03:43,500 --> 00:03:44,610
And we do normally want that.

71
00:03:44,610 --> 00:03:47,620
We want people to be able to share
documents outside the organization.

72
00:03:47,620 --> 00:03:51,090
But we want them to understand the risk,
the risk that we have of

73
00:03:51,090 --> 00:03:54,560
disseminating information that
the outsider shouldn't have access to.

74
00:03:54,560 --> 00:03:57,620
So, you've got the ability
to turn on a warning.

75
00:03:57,620 --> 00:04:00,560
Warn users when sharing
outside this organization.

76
00:04:00,560 --> 00:04:02,830
That is a great thing to have turned on.

77
00:04:02,830 --> 00:04:06,160
When they share it, they'll see a message
warning them about the risks of sharing

78
00:04:06,160 --> 00:04:10,380
data outside of the company, and how that
data might not be cleared for release.

79
00:04:10,380 --> 00:04:12,150
So, they just need to be aware of that.

80
00:04:12,150 --> 00:04:14,190
If you don't want that,
you can remove the checkmark, and

81
00:04:14,190 --> 00:04:15,440
they won't get that warning anymore.

82
00:04:15,440 --> 00:04:17,470
So, that's completely customizable to you.

83
00:04:18,720 --> 00:04:19,910
You'll also see,

84
00:04:19,910 --> 00:04:24,690
allow users to share outside the domain to
people who are not using a Google account.

85
00:04:24,690 --> 00:04:26,780
Now, that's not turned on by default.

86
00:04:26,780 --> 00:04:30,790
If you share something, we expect
the other person to have a Google account.

87
00:04:30,790 --> 00:04:34,210
But if you check that, it'll actually
allow you to share to people that don't.

88
00:04:34,210 --> 00:04:37,970
They'll be able to view the document, even
though they don't have a Google account.

89
00:04:37,970 --> 00:04:41,240
And you'll see here, allow users
to publish files on the web, or

90
00:04:41,240 --> 00:04:43,150
make them visible to the world.

91
00:04:43,150 --> 00:04:45,190
That means make them completely public.

92
00:04:45,190 --> 00:04:47,610
And again,
that's something you might not want, but

93
00:04:47,610 --> 00:04:50,520
you can turn on the option right there,
if you choose.

94
00:04:50,520 --> 00:04:52,179
So, you've got the ability to control

95
00:04:53,200 --> 00:04:55,830
how people share things
out of your organization.

96
00:04:55,830 --> 00:04:57,470
Who's allowed to do what.

97
00:04:57,470 --> 00:05:00,040
Remember, that an administration
can override this stuff.

98
00:05:00,040 --> 00:05:02,910
So, this is really applying
to our regular user accounts.

99
00:05:04,700 --> 00:05:06,060
There are other settings in here.

100
00:05:06,060 --> 00:05:08,500
If you scroll down a bit,
you'll see File Visibility.

101
00:05:08,500 --> 00:05:12,600
So when files are created,
what's their default Sharing setting?

102
00:05:12,600 --> 00:05:14,210
The default is they're Private.

103
00:05:14,210 --> 00:05:17,730
If I go, and create a file,
only my account can see it.

104
00:05:17,730 --> 00:05:21,010
And then I can choose to share it
if I want to, but I don't have too.

105
00:05:22,650 --> 00:05:26,650
But you might have a central repository
that you want everybody to see.

106
00:05:26,650 --> 00:05:29,325
In that scenario you might choose,
this organization.

107
00:05:29,325 --> 00:05:33,000
When you create files by default,
everybody can see them.

108
00:05:33,000 --> 00:05:35,150
And if you wanna make it private,
you'll have to override that, and

109
00:05:35,150 --> 00:05:36,640
make that file Private.

110
00:05:36,640 --> 00:05:37,920
So, the default is everybody can see it.

111
00:05:37,920 --> 00:05:40,140
That gives full visibility
across all your employees.

112
00:05:41,160 --> 00:05:43,250
The middle option is
kind of an in between.

113
00:05:45,080 --> 00:05:47,370
When you create a document,
it's automatically shared, but

114
00:05:47,370 --> 00:05:48,890
other people don't know about it.

115
00:05:48,890 --> 00:05:49,960
We have to send them the link.

116
00:05:49,960 --> 00:05:52,270
And when they get the link,
they can browse to it, and see it.

117
00:05:52,270 --> 00:05:55,870
So, any employee in the organization
that has the link can access it.

118
00:05:55,870 --> 00:05:58,590
But they can't just browse, and
find the documents on there.

119
00:05:58,590 --> 00:05:59,710
They can't discover it.

120
00:05:59,710 --> 00:06:03,380
We have to tell them about the document,
and then they'll be able to get to it.

121
00:06:03,380 --> 00:06:04,350
So those are our choices.

122
00:06:04,350 --> 00:06:05,320
The default is private though.

123
00:06:05,320 --> 00:06:07,525
You may choose to override
that in your organization.

124
00:06:10,565 --> 00:06:15,230
Now, when I led this segment in,
I mentioned about storage limits.

125
00:06:15,230 --> 00:06:16,840
Let's say that you're like us.

126
00:06:16,840 --> 00:06:19,570
Well, at ITProTV we use regular accounts,
and so

127
00:06:19,570 --> 00:06:21,881
our users each get 30 gigs of storage.

128
00:06:22,890 --> 00:06:25,990
How do I know how much of
that storage I've used?

129
00:06:25,990 --> 00:06:28,460
Do I have users that
are coming up on their limits?

130
00:06:28,460 --> 00:06:32,050
Well, there's some reports that
are built-in to help us to see that.

131
00:06:32,050 --> 00:06:36,960
If you go back to your Admin console,
I've made changes without saving them,

132
00:06:36,960 --> 00:06:37,670
but I'm okay with that.

133
00:06:38,880 --> 00:06:40,990
It's gonna make me discard, there we go.

134
00:06:40,990 --> 00:06:44,720
So, let me go back to my Admin console,
and if we go into a Reporting screen,

135
00:06:44,720 --> 00:06:48,459
which is down here under More Controls,
and Reports.

136
00:06:49,840 --> 00:06:52,670
There's a couple of reports that
are really useful with storage.

137
00:06:52,670 --> 00:06:56,200
The first one is the Highlights,
and this is my demo account, so

138
00:06:56,200 --> 00:06:57,220
it doesn't have anything exciting.

139
00:06:57,220 --> 00:06:59,620
Let me switch over to
a Production account.

140
00:06:59,620 --> 00:07:00,120
Here we go.

141
00:07:01,420 --> 00:07:04,075
So, here's our production account
that actually has real-users in it,

142
00:07:04,075 --> 00:07:05,220
doing a real stuff.

143
00:07:05,220 --> 00:07:09,150
And so, we get this Highlight screen,
and one of the most useful parts of

144
00:07:09,150 --> 00:07:15,060
the Highlights screen is over here on the
right side, you get this Storage section.

145
00:07:15,060 --> 00:07:18,660
And it'll show users
nearing storage limit.

146
00:07:18,660 --> 00:07:22,160
And I can see that none of my
users are at 80% of the limit,

147
00:07:22,160 --> 00:07:24,370
none of my users are at 50% of the limit.

148
00:07:24,370 --> 00:07:28,410
But 12 of my users,
we just have 12, are less than 50%.

149
00:07:28,410 --> 00:07:31,680
So, 12 of my users haven't even
used half their storage yet, so

150
00:07:31,680 --> 00:07:34,470
I've got plenty of room to grow.

151
00:07:34,470 --> 00:07:35,580
Good to know.

152
00:07:35,580 --> 00:07:37,712
But how much storage am I using?

153
00:07:37,712 --> 00:07:42,360
Well, on the left side,
if you go to Apps Usage Activity,

154
00:07:42,360 --> 00:07:46,950
this will show you how much storage
people have been generating.

155
00:07:46,950 --> 00:07:49,480
And I can see it trended over time.

156
00:07:49,480 --> 00:07:51,060
Look at my growth numbers here.

157
00:07:51,060 --> 00:07:54,130
I can start to evaluate how
rapidly I'm growing, and

158
00:07:54,130 --> 00:07:55,896
when I'm gonna run out of space.

159
00:07:55,896 --> 00:07:59,390
And not only that, I can see down here
who is this consuming the most space,

160
00:07:59,390 --> 00:08:02,980
who owns the most files, or
is generating the most emails.

161
00:08:02,980 --> 00:08:05,300
You've got a little
date dropdown box here.

162
00:08:05,300 --> 00:08:08,030
I'm viewing everything as of October 1st.

163
00:08:08,030 --> 00:08:15,200
So, on October 1st, I had 3,900 files,

164
00:08:15,200 --> 00:08:18,610
most of which were
miscellaneous files apparently.

165
00:08:18,610 --> 00:08:24,311
And that's where I was at, but just a few
months before, I was down at 2,600 files,

166
00:08:24,311 --> 00:08:28,290
or 1,900 files,
you can see that growth over time.

167
00:08:28,290 --> 00:08:31,860
We must have hired somebody new here,
and they brought a bunch of files in.

168
00:08:31,860 --> 00:08:34,910
So I got a couple of jumps,
as people transferred stuff in.

169
00:08:34,910 --> 00:08:38,340
Now this is Files Owned,
what if I want this in megabytes?

170
00:08:38,340 --> 00:08:42,240
Well, I can drop Files Owned down,
and choose Total Storage Used (MB).

171
00:08:42,240 --> 00:08:47,840
And now, I can start to see that
big jump that happened right there.

172
00:08:47,840 --> 00:08:53,550
As I jump from about 19, and a half gigs,

173
00:08:53,550 --> 00:08:58,550
and I jump to about 25 gigs, so I added
about 5 gigs of storage right there.

174
00:08:58,550 --> 00:09:04,030
As of October first,
I'm sitting at about 26 gigs total.

175
00:09:04,030 --> 00:09:06,330
That's total my entire company.

176
00:09:06,330 --> 00:09:09,410
Any one user has 30 gigs
of storage themselves,

177
00:09:09,410 --> 00:09:11,500
this is the whole company
sitting at 26 gigs.

178
00:09:11,500 --> 00:09:16,300
And I can start to look down here, and
see information based on the users and,

179
00:09:16,300 --> 00:09:18,000
kind of customize that,
and look at it here.

180
00:09:18,000 --> 00:09:20,130
You can also see email volume.

181
00:09:20,130 --> 00:09:25,100
So like on October first,
I received 165 emails, but

182
00:09:25,100 --> 00:09:27,070
Denise, she only got 59 emails.

183
00:09:27,070 --> 00:09:30,670
So, you can look and start to see the
email volume that your users are handling.

184
00:09:30,670 --> 00:09:34,182
That's October 1st,
I can jump over to October 2nd, and

185
00:09:34,182 --> 00:09:36,090
it should look mostly the same.

186
00:09:36,090 --> 00:09:37,623
On October 2nd, I got 108 emails.

187
00:09:37,623 --> 00:09:39,200
It was a slower day.

188
00:09:39,200 --> 00:09:40,350
And then Denise got 46.

189
00:09:40,350 --> 00:09:43,600
So, we can start to see exactly,
how much traffic these users got.

190
00:09:45,420 --> 00:09:47,807
So, good information.
One thing to note about these reports, and

191
00:09:47,807 --> 00:09:50,111
I'll talk about these in
another segment later.

192
00:09:50,111 --> 00:09:52,060
But just one thing to note.

193
00:09:52,060 --> 00:09:54,510
When you see a cool report like this,

194
00:09:54,510 --> 00:09:57,930
there's always more information on
the backend that you don't see.

195
00:09:59,010 --> 00:10:00,800
So, just because there's this.

196
00:10:00,800 --> 00:10:04,320
I don't get a break down like per user,
so I showed you guys when

197
00:10:04,320 --> 00:10:09,500
I went to Total Storage, that our company
is sitting in about 26 gigs in storage.

198
00:10:09,500 --> 00:10:10,700
Who's using that?

199
00:10:10,700 --> 00:10:13,100
I don't know, it doesn't show me that.

200
00:10:13,100 --> 00:10:14,990
But it doesn't mean the data isn't there.

201
00:10:14,990 --> 00:10:17,080
It is, we just don't see it.

202
00:10:17,080 --> 00:10:21,709
You can use this Download button up here,
and you can Export this as a CSV,

203
00:10:21,709 --> 00:10:23,210
or into Google Sheets.

204
00:10:23,210 --> 00:10:27,276
And when you get the raw data,
you'll see all the extra stuff,

205
00:10:27,276 --> 00:10:29,676
like how big that actual mailbox is.

206
00:10:29,676 --> 00:10:33,550
Or how big that drive storage is,
per user.

207
00:10:33,550 --> 00:10:34,830
The data is there.

208
00:10:34,830 --> 00:10:36,520
It's just not rendered in this graph.

209
00:10:36,520 --> 00:10:38,290
There's only so much,
they can show here in the graph.

210
00:10:39,580 --> 00:10:44,980
And that's the real power of the reporting
system, is that the data is all there.

211
00:10:44,980 --> 00:10:46,510
You can do whatever you want with it,

212
00:10:46,510 --> 00:10:50,220
once you get it loaded into your
spreadsheet program, and have at it.

213
00:10:50,220 --> 00:10:51,609
So, a lot of power to be found there.

214
00:10:53,530 --> 00:10:56,060
We've just got 12 people, so
it's easy for me to browse, and pick.

215
00:10:56,060 --> 00:10:59,340
But in a larger organization, you might
need to go over here, and filter by

216
00:10:59,340 --> 00:11:03,210
username to find the people you're looking
for, and generate more filtered results.

217
00:11:03,210 --> 00:11:06,993
So, if I just wanted to
pull up information on me,

218
00:11:06,993 --> 00:11:11,766
I can filter that down, and
I can see my information down here,

219
00:11:11,766 --> 00:11:15,685
and start to look at it
from that perspective.

220
00:11:15,685 --> 00:11:19,380
But again, this is still total
company storage up here, and

221
00:11:19,380 --> 00:11:21,150
so its kind of broken down a little weird.

222
00:11:21,150 --> 00:11:24,405
But you go into the spreadsheet data's
there, you pull out whatever you need.

223
00:11:24,405 --> 00:11:27,640
Now, let's see, am I missing anything?

224
00:11:27,640 --> 00:11:29,030
I think that's basically it.

225
00:11:29,030 --> 00:11:31,980
Don't forget that Highlight screen
because that is really handy.

226
00:11:31,980 --> 00:11:34,110
Just to get that simple
information right there,

227
00:11:34,110 --> 00:11:36,640
about users nearing their storage limit.

228
00:11:36,640 --> 00:11:38,350
Real handy to just quickly pull that data.

229
00:11:40,130 --> 00:11:43,960
So in this segment, we got a chance to
look at the default Sharing settings, and

230
00:11:43,960 --> 00:11:47,620
the overall Google Drive settings for
our Google Apps account.

231
00:11:47,620 --> 00:11:49,470
And we got a chance to look
at some of the reporting,

232
00:11:49,470 --> 00:11:51,990
to see how our storage is being used.

233
00:11:51,990 --> 00:11:52,550
Hope you guys enjoyed this segment.

234
00:11:52,550 --> 00:11:54,952
Stay tuned,
we've got more of Google Apps coming up.

235
00:11:54,952 --> 00:12:02,304
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Using Reports
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,008 --> 00:00:05,735
[SOUND] Objective 3.4 focuses

2
00:00:05,735 --> 00:00:13,375
on using reporting inside of Google Apps.

3
00:00:13,375 --> 00:00:17,676
The full title is demonstrate how to
use reports to determine service's use,

4
00:00:17,676 --> 00:00:21,630
troubleshoot system issues and
to improve domain security.

5
00:00:21,630 --> 00:00:27,450
We've got a lot of reporting built into
our Google App service, and for a lot of

6
00:00:27,450 --> 00:00:32,070
us as an administrator, it is our insight
into how our service is being used.

7
00:00:32,070 --> 00:00:37,590
Many companies will deploy Google Apps and
assume that their employees are using

8
00:00:37,590 --> 00:00:41,850
every aspect of it, and then you find that
certain pieces are just not being used.

9
00:00:41,850 --> 00:00:45,700
Well, there's also some other neat things
we can do with reporting just to find out.

10
00:00:45,700 --> 00:00:47,110
For trouble shooting purposes.

11
00:00:47,110 --> 00:00:50,230
Whether certain things are working
the way that we anticipate them to.

12
00:00:50,230 --> 00:00:52,830
So, let's take a look at
some of the reporting.

13
00:00:52,830 --> 00:00:54,180
Now some of this we've already seen.

14
00:00:55,390 --> 00:00:58,190
First off, I'm gonna have to
bounce between two organizations.

15
00:00:58,190 --> 00:01:02,990
My demo account here that I'm using for
the shows is basically empty.

16
00:01:02,990 --> 00:01:06,610
So it doesn't really have any exciting
reporting information to give.

17
00:01:06,610 --> 00:01:09,420
So I'm gonna bounce between
a production environment and my demo.

18
00:01:09,420 --> 00:01:12,430
But to get to the reporting piece
there's a few different ways.

19
00:01:12,430 --> 00:01:14,300
Right here in your admin console,

20
00:01:14,300 --> 00:01:18,085
you more that likely have a view
reports link on the right side.

21
00:01:18,085 --> 00:01:21,070
Sometimes this panel is hidden so
you might not see it,

22
00:01:21,070 --> 00:01:24,530
in which case you might not have that but
otherwise you'll see view reports there.

23
00:01:24,530 --> 00:01:27,910
If you don't have that link,
you can just go down to more controls and

24
00:01:27,910 --> 00:01:30,820
you'll find reports right there,
all right.

25
00:01:30,820 --> 00:01:34,430
And you can use the little plus symbol
to pin that up here into your admin

26
00:01:34,430 --> 00:01:35,820
console if you want.

27
00:01:35,820 --> 00:01:37,280
But they both go to the same place.

28
00:01:37,280 --> 00:01:39,460
They take you to this screen, right here.

29
00:01:39,460 --> 00:01:42,180
If you have a brand new Google Apps
account, or this one isn't brand new,

30
00:01:42,180 --> 00:01:45,320
its been around a few days,
but it hasn't seen much usage.

31
00:01:45,320 --> 00:01:47,020
I'm the only one who has
ever logged into it.

32
00:01:47,020 --> 00:01:50,270
So you'll see a message like this,
that says, looks like your account is so

33
00:01:50,270 --> 00:01:53,960
brand new that we don't have any
data on usage to show you yet.

34
00:01:53,960 --> 00:01:56,292
You can expect that on a new deployment.

35
00:01:56,292 --> 00:01:58,193
But once your deployment has
been around a little while,

36
00:01:58,193 --> 00:01:59,690
that window will look different.

37
00:01:59,690 --> 00:02:00,990
It'll look like this.

38
00:02:00,990 --> 00:02:03,800
And what you're gonna see
is app usage activity, and

39
00:02:03,800 --> 00:02:08,070
it's breaking down exactly how
people are using your system.

40
00:02:08,070 --> 00:02:12,160
And you'll see Gmail,
Google Drive Calendar and Google+.

41
00:02:12,160 --> 00:02:16,940
And it's showing on a daily
basis how this was used,

42
00:02:16,940 --> 00:02:20,260
and breaking it kinda down based on
whatever it is that we're specifying.

43
00:02:20,260 --> 00:02:22,780
So as we look across here,
on each of these days,

44
00:02:22,780 --> 00:02:28,310
I can see on most days I've
got ten Gmail accounts set up.

45
00:02:28,310 --> 00:02:30,500
I've got seven people using Google Drive,

46
00:02:30,500 --> 00:02:33,240
six people using Calendar and
four people using Google+.

47
00:02:33,240 --> 00:02:37,330
These are how many of my employees or the
accounts that I have that are using it.

48
00:02:37,330 --> 00:02:41,630
Now I can see on the right side on
user status I have a total of 12.

49
00:02:41,630 --> 00:02:47,120
I have 12 people that I'm paying for
every month to be able to use Google apps.

50
00:02:47,120 --> 00:02:51,090
And of those 12,
10 of them are actually using it.

51
00:02:51,090 --> 00:02:54,690
I can see ten people have logged
into g-mail, or drive, or whatever.

52
00:02:54,690 --> 00:02:57,690
So that means I've got two
people that I'm paying for,

53
00:02:57,690 --> 00:03:01,110
that aren't logging into this system and
using it.

54
00:03:01,110 --> 00:03:04,450
And so I need to go and evaluate whether
I should keep those two accounts or not.

55
00:03:04,450 --> 00:03:06,980
I might be paying for
people that I don't necessarily need.

56
00:03:06,980 --> 00:03:08,270
Or there might be a reason for that.

57
00:03:08,270 --> 00:03:12,840
They might be contractors, or I might be
forwarding their email to somewhere else

58
00:03:12,840 --> 00:03:15,760
so they don't have to actually log
into their Google Apps account.

59
00:03:15,760 --> 00:03:18,860
So there can be extenuating circumstances,
always keep that in mind.

60
00:03:18,860 --> 00:03:21,960
Everybody has a different usage scenario.

61
00:03:21,960 --> 00:03:26,490
And this report right here is really just
based on how people are accessing and

62
00:03:26,490 --> 00:03:27,880
logging into the system.

63
00:03:27,880 --> 00:03:31,600
You can change these reports to
show all sorts of other things.

64
00:03:31,600 --> 00:03:34,500
You'll see over here
the apps usage activity.

65
00:03:34,500 --> 00:03:37,010
And in here's where it'll break down

66
00:03:37,010 --> 00:03:42,500
how many files we've got that
are loaded into Google Drive and Docs.

67
00:03:42,500 --> 00:03:46,000
So I can see how I've got
a really big jump right there,

68
00:03:46,000 --> 00:03:48,230
sometime around August 17th or so.

69
00:03:48,230 --> 00:03:51,120
Where it looks like somebody must
have imported their documents.

70
00:03:51,120 --> 00:03:53,600
So I've got almost 1,000 new documents.

71
00:03:53,600 --> 00:03:56,810
Actually, just a handful shy of 1,000 new

72
00:03:56,810 --> 00:03:59,600
documents right there
in a single day period.

73
00:03:59,600 --> 00:04:02,190
So somebody uploaded a bunch of
data into their Google Drive.

74
00:04:02,190 --> 00:04:03,320
And that's fine.

75
00:04:03,320 --> 00:04:06,810
Because if it's within the capacity of
the drive, right, that's why we have it.

76
00:04:06,810 --> 00:04:09,630
So I can start to monitor that and
see yeah, we're really using this.

77
00:04:09,630 --> 00:04:11,390
We got a lot of documents going in here.

78
00:04:11,390 --> 00:04:15,410
And each day it's growing, and so
that means that we're putting new stuff

79
00:04:15,410 --> 00:04:19,730
in there each day, and
I can see some of these are Google Sheets.

80
00:04:19,730 --> 00:04:23,170
Some of these are Google Docs and
those numbers are increasing.

81
00:04:23,170 --> 00:04:25,110
Actually that's some big
increases right there, so

82
00:04:25,110 --> 00:04:27,180
I know that people are using
the system the way that we want.

83
00:04:27,180 --> 00:04:31,220
And we can kind of break it down here
seeing how many files people own and

84
00:04:31,220 --> 00:04:34,110
how many emails they received
in a particular period.

85
00:04:34,110 --> 00:04:36,240
I'm looking at October 5,

86
00:04:36,240 --> 00:04:40,930
2014 and I can see on October
5th I received 59 emails, right.

87
00:04:40,930 --> 00:04:43,260
But I have busier days and slower days.

88
00:04:43,260 --> 00:04:45,740
And so you can see some days,
like this one.

89
00:04:45,740 --> 00:04:50,355
It says that I received
1,583 emails on August 8th,

90
00:04:50,355 --> 00:04:53,000
which is awesome and I sent 29.

91
00:04:53,000 --> 00:04:54,800
Or i'm sorry these are the totals,
this is not me.

92
00:04:54,800 --> 00:04:57,083
So my company,
I thought that number was a little high.

93
00:04:57,083 --> 00:05:01,095
My company received 1,583 emails,
but we only sent 29 or

94
00:05:01,095 --> 00:05:04,660
at least we sent 29
through Google's servers.

95
00:05:04,660 --> 00:05:07,380
So you can start to get
an idea of the capacities.

96
00:05:07,380 --> 00:05:08,740
How much data is coming and

97
00:05:08,740 --> 00:05:12,670
going through your organization and
start to measure that.

98
00:05:12,670 --> 00:05:14,480
Really good information
to be broken down there.

99
00:05:15,590 --> 00:05:20,100
Some of the other things we can view are
things like account activity and so on.

100
00:05:20,100 --> 00:05:22,620
Let's take a look at that back
here in my demo environment.

101
00:05:22,620 --> 00:05:24,510
Account activity is a nice one.

102
00:05:24,510 --> 00:05:26,170
Because, well,
I guess you can't really see it there.

103
00:05:26,170 --> 00:05:27,900
Let me go back to production here.

104
00:05:27,900 --> 00:05:33,290
If we go into account activity, you can
start to see things like people's access,

105
00:05:33,290 --> 00:05:36,360
their user account status,
whether they're admins, and

106
00:05:36,360 --> 00:05:37,770
you can see how many people you have.

107
00:05:37,770 --> 00:05:41,370
You'll see here, back in May,
I had 14 accounts.

108
00:05:41,370 --> 00:05:44,510
And then we removed 2 of them so
now I have 12 accounts.

109
00:05:44,510 --> 00:05:47,220
So here's how many
licenses I'm paying for.

110
00:05:47,220 --> 00:05:50,610
This is my active users
that I'm paying money for.

111
00:05:50,610 --> 00:05:52,160
I can see my suspended users and

112
00:05:52,160 --> 00:05:56,150
my blocked users also, and I can switch
these around to show different things like

113
00:05:56,150 --> 00:05:59,700
who's got two step there for enrollment
verification turned on, and all of that.

114
00:06:02,150 --> 00:06:05,560
Some of the other things that we can
verify are a little more security related.

115
00:06:05,560 --> 00:06:08,180
So see how I've got my
security report here, and

116
00:06:08,180 --> 00:06:11,880
I don't have a whole ton to show on this
one, but if we go down into our audit,

117
00:06:11,880 --> 00:06:15,820
we can see some really good things here,
like our login status.

118
00:06:15,820 --> 00:06:18,090
I wanna see who's been logging in today.

119
00:06:18,090 --> 00:06:20,000
So here in my little demo environment,

120
00:06:20,000 --> 00:06:22,670
I can see where I've been logging in,
Don Pezet.

121
00:06:22,670 --> 00:06:25,960
And I can see where Dave Mustaine
is logged in and other users.

122
00:06:25,960 --> 00:06:27,230
Well, as soon as it refreshes.

123
00:06:27,230 --> 00:06:28,417
Let me get back to my reports.

124
00:06:30,917 --> 00:06:33,530
And we'll see each of the users and
their login activity.

125
00:06:33,530 --> 00:06:37,220
That's another way to gauge whether or
not people are actually using the system.

126
00:06:37,220 --> 00:06:39,250
If I don't see that user logging in.

127
00:06:39,250 --> 00:06:41,080
Then I know there's a problem.

128
00:06:41,080 --> 00:06:43,260
And I might want to gauge
this by a single user.

129
00:06:43,260 --> 00:06:46,530
So if I want to know just what
Dave Mustaine has been doing,

130
00:06:46,530 --> 00:06:51,280
right, I can go over here and I can pick
a username and I can punch that in, and so

131
00:06:51,280 --> 00:06:53,180
I'll pick Dave Mustaine.

132
00:06:53,180 --> 00:06:55,710
And now it's gonna filter it
down to just his activity.

133
00:06:55,710 --> 00:06:57,240
So is he actually using the system?

134
00:06:57,240 --> 00:06:58,610
Well I can see he logged in.

135
00:06:58,610 --> 00:07:01,680
He logged in from this IP address,
which is our studio, right.

136
00:07:01,680 --> 00:07:04,280
So apparently he was right here
in the studio and logged in, but

137
00:07:04,280 --> 00:07:07,230
he's not logging in from home, or probably
not logging in from his cell phone.

138
00:07:08,320 --> 00:07:11,160
You can also choose other events,
not just login success,

139
00:07:11,160 --> 00:07:14,530
but login failure, logout,
suspicious logins.

140
00:07:14,530 --> 00:07:16,850
That's always a nice one,
suspicious logins.

141
00:07:16,850 --> 00:07:20,880
Because you can evaluate whether there's
new IP addresses that are showing up,

142
00:07:20,880 --> 00:07:24,220
usually it's IP's from other countries,
that always makes them suspicious.

143
00:07:24,220 --> 00:07:27,250
And you can get an idea if somebody is
trying to pull an attack on your systems.

144
00:07:30,125 --> 00:07:33,860
All right, some of the other
things that we can look at.

145
00:07:33,860 --> 00:07:37,520
The admit audit, right,
this is a nice one.

146
00:07:37,520 --> 00:07:40,260
You can see who's made
changes to your account.

147
00:07:40,260 --> 00:07:43,000
So any time somebody did
a new service update,

148
00:07:43,000 --> 00:07:46,580
I did one in the last segment,
you can see any change they made.

149
00:07:46,580 --> 00:07:50,000
You can see who did it,
when they did it, and what they did.

150
00:07:50,000 --> 00:07:53,300
So I made some Chrome OS User Setting
Changes in the previous segment.

151
00:07:53,300 --> 00:07:56,560
That's logged right here,
and I can see it, right.

152
00:07:56,560 --> 00:07:58,550
Also an email log search.

153
00:07:58,550 --> 00:08:02,160
You can see that I performed
an email log search this morning.

154
00:08:02,160 --> 00:08:04,450
Looking for my own emails.

155
00:08:04,450 --> 00:08:06,130
Well, what's an email log search?

156
00:08:06,130 --> 00:08:10,540
Well, email log searches are not really
for security, they're for troubleshooting.

157
00:08:10,540 --> 00:08:15,176
If you have a user that says, hey,
I was supposed to get an email from so and

158
00:08:15,176 --> 00:08:17,180
so and I never got it.

159
00:08:17,180 --> 00:08:18,450
What's going on?

160
00:08:18,450 --> 00:08:21,980
Well, we can go in and
do an email log search.

161
00:08:21,980 --> 00:08:26,740
It's a great way to see whether the email
ever even made it to Google Apps.

162
00:08:26,740 --> 00:08:31,720
So if they're saying, hey Don at ITProTV,
he sent me an email and I never got it.

163
00:08:31,720 --> 00:08:33,410
Well, I can go in here and
I can say, you know what?

164
00:08:33,410 --> 00:08:36,913
Let me pull up email from
the last seven days, and

165
00:08:36,913 --> 00:08:41,792
show me any email where the sender
was don@itpro.tv, all right.

166
00:08:41,792 --> 00:08:44,910
I wanna see if Don emailed
anybody in my organization.

167
00:08:44,910 --> 00:08:49,410
And I can hit search, and it's gonna
look to see if we can find any emails.

168
00:08:49,410 --> 00:08:52,250
Now the searches can take a little while,
so we have to be patient.

169
00:08:52,250 --> 00:08:55,950
The more email you have and
the bigger window of time you choose,

170
00:08:55,950 --> 00:08:57,640
the longer it's going to take.

171
00:08:57,640 --> 00:08:59,840
So we do have to be a little bit patient.

172
00:08:59,840 --> 00:09:02,260
But it's gonna search and find the email.

173
00:09:02,260 --> 00:09:06,660
Now, I was searching by a sender, who sent
the email and I didn't find any emails.

174
00:09:07,860 --> 00:09:13,510
So this user is saying, hey I was sent
an email by don@itpro.tv, I didn't get it.

175
00:09:13,510 --> 00:09:16,340
Well, it never even
made it to Google Apps.

176
00:09:16,340 --> 00:09:17,610
So if there was a problem,

177
00:09:17,610 --> 00:09:20,880
it must have happened prior to
even getting to our account.

178
00:09:20,880 --> 00:09:24,819
So it could've been blocked by some kind
of spam filtering system, it could've been

179
00:09:24,819 --> 00:09:28,100
blocked at the senders side, right,
it may have just not got in there,

180
00:09:28,100 --> 00:09:31,458
well I could switch and say all right,
well let me look at the recipient.

181
00:09:31,458 --> 00:09:36,080
Let me look at all the email
that my user has received.

182
00:09:36,080 --> 00:09:42,042
So I'll punch in what am I,
Dpezet@itprotv.net, all right.

183
00:09:42,042 --> 00:09:45,670
So I'm gonna punch in that recipient
this time and I'll search based on that.

184
00:09:45,670 --> 00:09:48,240
And I'll say show me all
the email that this user got.

185
00:09:48,240 --> 00:09:51,265
And then we can look and see and
maybe they were expecting email from

186
00:09:51,265 --> 00:09:54,550
don@itpro.tv that actually
came from a different address.

187
00:09:54,550 --> 00:09:56,490
So here we'll be able to spot that.

188
00:09:56,490 --> 00:09:59,558
I can see they've received
some different emails and

189
00:09:59,558 --> 00:10:02,420
as I look down the list,
If I look at these sender,

190
00:10:02,420 --> 00:10:06,875
here we go, they got an email from
Don@edutainmentlive.com, all right.

191
00:10:06,875 --> 00:10:09,938
So it didn't come from
don@itpro.tv like they thought,

192
00:10:09,938 --> 00:10:14,536
it came from Don@edutainmentlive.com, and
I can see it right there it was delivered,

193
00:10:14,536 --> 00:10:18,667
they got a copy of it right the status
over here shows as delivered and received.

194
00:10:18,667 --> 00:10:21,492
So it made it to the mailbox it
might have been delivered and

195
00:10:21,492 --> 00:10:25,182
then blocked by our spam filter, it
would show up here as being blocked, but

196
00:10:25,182 --> 00:10:27,333
in this case it was delivered and
received.

197
00:10:27,333 --> 00:10:29,700
It actually made it into their mailbox.

198
00:10:29,700 --> 00:10:31,020
I can see it happened.

199
00:10:31,020 --> 00:10:33,690
Here's the subject line,
so I can see that.

200
00:10:33,690 --> 00:10:35,300
I can see the date and time.

201
00:10:35,300 --> 00:10:39,200
If you click on the subject line,
you'll get some more detailed information.

202
00:10:39,200 --> 00:10:40,910
But cannot see the message body.

203
00:10:40,910 --> 00:10:43,690
This is not a way to read
other people's email.

204
00:10:43,690 --> 00:10:46,820
You use it for troubleshooting to
find out whether the email made it to

205
00:10:46,820 --> 00:10:47,520
the person or not.

206
00:10:47,520 --> 00:10:50,540
And if it didn't, you can find out why.

207
00:10:50,540 --> 00:10:52,510
But in this case,
I can just look at it and see.

208
00:10:52,510 --> 00:10:55,960
One of the really useful things
is we can expand this out and

209
00:10:55,960 --> 00:10:58,860
see where the email came from.

210
00:10:58,860 --> 00:11:02,150
I can see the IP address of
the server that sent the email.

211
00:11:02,150 --> 00:11:05,990
If these are being blocked by a spam
filter, I might wanna create a white

212
00:11:05,990 --> 00:11:08,870
list entry for this, and
I'll need the IP address to that server.

213
00:11:08,870 --> 00:11:10,470
So I can see it right there and

214
00:11:10,470 --> 00:11:12,990
that's the IP address I might
wanna put a white list on.

215
00:11:12,990 --> 00:11:15,265
Or I might just wanna white
list this email address,

216
00:11:15,265 --> 00:11:16,980
don@edutainmentlive.com, right.

217
00:11:16,980 --> 00:11:18,887
That's information we'll need and

218
00:11:18,887 --> 00:11:21,417
we can find it right here
in our email log search.

219
00:11:23,083 --> 00:11:23,990
All right.

220
00:11:23,990 --> 00:11:28,330
So a lot of really cool stuff, if you need
to be able to read other people's mail,

221
00:11:28,330 --> 00:11:31,460
if you need to be able to read the message
bodies, you can't do it with this tool.

222
00:11:31,460 --> 00:11:36,180
All right, instead you can use the vault
service, which is an add on for

223
00:11:36,180 --> 00:11:37,160
Google Apps.

224
00:11:37,160 --> 00:11:41,190
If you go under the more Google Services,
you can add it in there.

225
00:11:41,190 --> 00:11:43,050
And that'll allow you to do eDiscovery,
and

226
00:11:43,050 --> 00:11:47,190
you will be able to search by message body
and contents to find emails that way.

227
00:11:47,190 --> 00:11:50,420
But with the email log search,
it's really just based on a few things.

228
00:11:50,420 --> 00:11:52,160
Notice my search criteria.

229
00:11:52,160 --> 00:11:54,380
Send and recipient email address.

230
00:11:54,380 --> 00:11:56,570
Send and recipient IP address.

231
00:11:56,570 --> 00:11:58,480
Or message ID.

232
00:11:58,480 --> 00:12:02,310
And the message ID,
that's a long letter and

233
00:12:02,310 --> 00:12:05,290
number string that identifies
that message specifically.

234
00:12:05,290 --> 00:12:08,290
We're not normally gonna
search by message ID unless we

235
00:12:08,290 --> 00:12:10,390
happen to have a copy of
the email that didn't make it.

236
00:12:10,390 --> 00:12:13,610
And if we have a copy of
the email that didn't make it,

237
00:12:13,610 --> 00:12:14,630
it probably did make it, right.

238
00:12:14,630 --> 00:12:15,682
We got a copy some task.

239
00:12:15,682 --> 00:12:18,330
[LAUGH] So
that one's not the most terribly useful.

240
00:12:18,330 --> 00:12:21,620
But those are the things we can
search by to find those email.

241
00:12:23,130 --> 00:12:26,190
All right.
So that's a highlight of the reporting

242
00:12:26,190 --> 00:12:27,880
features and how we can use them.

243
00:12:27,880 --> 00:12:30,990
A lot of them are just useful for
monitoring usage.

244
00:12:30,990 --> 00:12:32,530
Whether people are actually
using our service.

245
00:12:32,530 --> 00:12:34,230
So we got a chance to see that.

246
00:12:34,230 --> 00:12:36,190
We got a chance to see
the security side of things.

247
00:12:36,190 --> 00:12:39,950
Monitoring whether people have been
logging into their accounts or not.

248
00:12:39,950 --> 00:12:43,160
And then lastly, we've gotta take
a look at the email log search,

249
00:12:43,160 --> 00:12:47,530
where we can verify email delivery,
a wonderful troubleshooting utility.

250
00:12:47,530 --> 00:12:50,268
So those are the different
use scenarios for

251
00:12:50,268 --> 00:12:53,083
the reporting system
inside of Google Apps.

252
00:12:53,083 --> 00:12:54,360
All right,
well I hope you guys enjoyed it.

253
00:12:54,360 --> 00:12:57,625
Stay tuned,
we've got more Google Apps coming up.

254
00:12:57,625 --> 00:13:03,529
[SOUND]

topics.title: Google Apps services and organizational access

episodes.title: Manage Mail Routing
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,008 --> 00:00:04,804
[SOUND] Objective 4.1 is

2
00:00:04,804 --> 00:00:10,036
how to configure Google apps

3
00:00:10,036 --> 00:00:14,836
to manage email routing.

4
00:00:14,836 --> 00:00:17,464
And what they are talking
about on this one is how to

5
00:00:17,464 --> 00:00:21,281
control the flow of e-mail as it enters
into your Google apps account and

6
00:00:21,281 --> 00:00:24,050
how it exits from your
Google apps account.

7
00:00:24,050 --> 00:00:27,646
Now, you might ask yourself,
what's the route?

8
00:00:27,646 --> 00:00:28,880
E-mail comes in, e-mail goes out.

9
00:00:28,880 --> 00:00:31,130
We're done.
There is not really much to mess with.

10
00:00:31,130 --> 00:00:33,930
And you'd be right for most organizations.

11
00:00:33,930 --> 00:00:36,940
But there are times where
we want to influence e-mail

12
00:00:36,940 --> 00:00:39,310
as it passes through our organization.

13
00:00:39,310 --> 00:00:42,020
There's two different ways
that we influence e-mail.

14
00:00:42,020 --> 00:00:45,000
One way is where we change
where it's going to.

15
00:00:46,210 --> 00:00:48,950
You may have e-mail that's
coming into your account,

16
00:00:48,950 --> 00:00:51,370
into your Google apps organization.

17
00:00:51,370 --> 00:00:55,530
And it's destined for someone who's not
actually in your Google apps organization,

18
00:00:55,530 --> 00:00:58,560
maybe they have an email
account somewhere else.

19
00:00:58,560 --> 00:01:00,400
And so you want to receive that email for

20
00:01:00,400 --> 00:01:03,760
them and
forward it along to the destination.

21
00:01:04,830 --> 00:01:07,800
Well, you could do that if you had
a Google apps account for that person,

22
00:01:07,800 --> 00:01:09,880
they could set up
an email forwarder there.

23
00:01:09,880 --> 00:01:11,620
But when you do that you've
gotta pay a license right.

24
00:01:11,620 --> 00:01:13,870
That's an active account in Google Apps.

25
00:01:13,870 --> 00:01:16,930
And if this persons not using Google Apps,
it doesn't make sense to pay for

26
00:01:16,930 --> 00:01:19,370
an account just to have
a forwarder in place.

27
00:01:19,370 --> 00:01:21,830
So instead, we can use mail routing.

28
00:01:21,830 --> 00:01:24,760
We can say email Dustin for this address.

29
00:01:24,760 --> 00:01:28,370
Forward it along to this other
external address or this other person.

30
00:01:28,370 --> 00:01:32,460
So that's a great way to manipulate
an email that's coming in.

31
00:01:32,460 --> 00:01:33,650
On the way out.

32
00:01:33,650 --> 00:01:37,050
If you have an email that's leaving
Google apps, you're sending an email,

33
00:01:37,050 --> 00:01:42,230
if it's destined for some business partner
that you know has a secure SMTP server,

34
00:01:42,230 --> 00:01:45,450
you could tell it, hey, when you send
it out, send it to this server and

35
00:01:45,450 --> 00:01:48,120
make sure you use SSL or TLS, right.

36
00:01:48,120 --> 00:01:49,650
You can enforce security on a connection.

37
00:01:49,650 --> 00:01:52,930
So that's another way that we can
influence incoming and outgoing email.

38
00:01:52,930 --> 00:01:57,500
So that's the first idea behind mail
routing, is just changing the flow,

39
00:01:57,500 --> 00:01:59,540
changing the direction of that email.

40
00:01:59,540 --> 00:02:04,620
The second idea behind mail routing
is actually changing the email.

41
00:02:04,620 --> 00:02:07,960
As email passes through our
Google Apps account we can modify it.

42
00:02:07,960 --> 00:02:10,210
And there's a number of different
things that you can do.

43
00:02:10,210 --> 00:02:11,290
A great example, and

44
00:02:11,290 --> 00:02:15,240
you guys have probably seen this, Is you
might get an email every now and then.

45
00:02:15,240 --> 00:02:17,170
It's obvious that somebody wrote it.

46
00:02:17,170 --> 00:02:21,090
It's all written out in plain English,
or whatever language you speak natively.

47
00:02:21,090 --> 00:02:25,770
It's written by a person, but then at
the very bottom is a legal disclaimer.

48
00:02:25,770 --> 00:02:29,260
And you can tell this is not something
they just wrote, that attorneys wrote it

49
00:02:29,260 --> 00:02:33,610
and it says this email is destined for
the recipient only and blah, blah, blah.

50
00:02:33,610 --> 00:02:36,320
Unauthorized use prohibited and so on.

51
00:02:36,320 --> 00:02:40,890
Well, how did that legal disclaimer
get on the bottom of that email?

52
00:02:40,890 --> 00:02:42,950
They could've written it,
right, they probably didn't,

53
00:02:42,950 --> 00:02:46,340
they could've copied and pasted or
made it a part of their signature.

54
00:02:46,340 --> 00:02:51,130
But, with Google Apps mail routing, we can
actually insert that programmatically, so

55
00:02:51,130 --> 00:02:54,560
that every email leaving our organization.

56
00:02:54,560 --> 00:02:56,380
Gets this custom footer stuck on it.

57
00:02:56,380 --> 00:02:58,440
We're modifying the email.

58
00:02:58,440 --> 00:03:00,527
Or we could manipulate email addresses,

59
00:03:00,527 --> 00:03:03,270
we can add additional
people as recipients to it.

60
00:03:03,270 --> 00:03:05,840
So maybe you want to store a copy
of every email sent from our

61
00:03:05,840 --> 00:03:07,620
organization, you can do that.

62
00:03:07,620 --> 00:03:12,490
So these are ways that we can modify
an email in transit through the system and

63
00:03:12,490 --> 00:03:14,200
we use the mail routing system to do it.

64
00:03:15,310 --> 00:03:18,780
Now modifying mail routing
is really not that hard.

65
00:03:18,780 --> 00:03:21,231
It's challenging if you just try and
stumble through it,

66
00:03:21,231 --> 00:03:23,430
if you say I'm just going
to figure this out.

67
00:03:23,430 --> 00:03:26,350
The mail routing settings actually
show up in more than one place and so

68
00:03:26,350 --> 00:03:29,040
it gets really confusing to
figure out where to set it.

69
00:03:29,040 --> 00:03:32,150
But if you know what you're doing,
the system is actually really simple.

70
00:03:32,150 --> 00:03:34,520
It's just,
we have more than one way to get there.

71
00:03:34,520 --> 00:03:35,200
All right.

72
00:03:35,200 --> 00:03:38,000
The first thing we need to do is we
need to get into our Gmail preferences.

73
00:03:38,000 --> 00:03:41,130
So I'm here on my admin console,
and I'm going to go to Google apps.

74
00:03:42,380 --> 00:03:44,830
And from the app screen,
I'm going to go down here into Gmail.

75
00:03:44,830 --> 00:03:48,160
Now, we're going to see all
the different Gmail settings in here,

76
00:03:48,160 --> 00:03:50,870
as we start to see our
different categories.

77
00:03:50,870 --> 00:03:54,500
And you'll see default routing,
and you'll see hosts.

78
00:03:54,500 --> 00:03:57,690
These are the two pieces that
are involved with routing.

79
00:03:57,690 --> 00:03:59,520
And you might be tempted to go there,
but I'm actually going to

80
00:03:59,520 --> 00:04:02,690
show you a different place we can go
that's a little bit easier for us.

81
00:04:02,690 --> 00:04:04,810
When we define mail routing,
there's two pieces.

82
00:04:06,240 --> 00:04:10,380
If we're just modifying emails that
are passing through our system

83
00:04:10,380 --> 00:04:13,090
Then we just go into default routing and
we start to

84
00:04:13,090 --> 00:04:16,220
change the default routing email to
add the modifications that we want.

85
00:04:17,750 --> 00:04:20,510
But if we're changing the flow for emails,

86
00:04:20,510 --> 00:04:24,760
if we're changing where emails are going
to based on the server they came from, or

87
00:04:24,760 --> 00:04:28,710
the server they're going to We
need to define hosts first.

88
00:04:28,710 --> 00:04:34,080
The host is going to be that external
server whose emails we're manipulating.

89
00:04:34,080 --> 00:04:36,590
So, those are the two pieces
we need to specify, and

90
00:04:36,590 --> 00:04:38,490
you can do it from right here.

91
00:04:38,490 --> 00:04:43,320
But it's a little bit easier if we go up
to the top and we got to User Settings.

92
00:04:43,320 --> 00:04:47,120
I know that it doesn't sound right, like
well to User settings, but if you go to

93
00:04:47,120 --> 00:04:52,310
User settings it actually takes you
into the advanced settings for Gmail.

94
00:04:52,310 --> 00:04:56,940
See my little bread crumb trail up here
says Google Apps, Settings for Gmail.

95
00:04:56,940 --> 00:04:58,030
Advanced settings.

96
00:04:58,030 --> 00:05:00,040
It doesn't say user settings, right?

97
00:05:00,040 --> 00:05:01,610
So, it's kind of weird that it does that.

98
00:05:01,610 --> 00:05:03,610
There's actually another way to get here.

99
00:05:03,610 --> 00:05:06,380
Back on my settings for Gmail screen,
if I scroll all the way down,

100
00:05:06,380 --> 00:05:09,450
there's this little tiny link right
here that says advanced settings.

101
00:05:09,450 --> 00:05:11,170
It'll take you to the same place.

102
00:05:11,170 --> 00:05:12,790
They all go to the same place.

103
00:05:12,790 --> 00:05:16,677
So that's what I normally do,
is kind of browse in that way,

104
00:05:16,677 --> 00:05:19,030
is just go to user settings.

105
00:05:19,030 --> 00:05:24,840
And here, inside of user settings, if we
scroll down, we'll see all sorts of stuff.

106
00:05:24,840 --> 00:05:26,140
And here's the end user settings.

107
00:05:26,140 --> 00:05:28,040
That's why that link took us here.

108
00:05:28,040 --> 00:05:30,100
Because the end user
settings are right there.

109
00:05:30,100 --> 00:05:34,930
But if you keep scrolling down,
you'll find where end user access is.

110
00:05:34,930 --> 00:05:42,060
Spam settings, compliance settings,
and there it is, routing.

111
00:05:42,060 --> 00:05:44,380
So the routing settings
are right in here also.

112
00:05:44,380 --> 00:05:47,330
Whichever way we go to get here, if you go
to advanced settings, if you go to user

113
00:05:47,330 --> 00:05:50,970
settings whatever, you end up on this
screen and you can get down to routing.

114
00:05:50,970 --> 00:05:54,470
And when we set things up here
it's a little bit easier for

115
00:05:54,470 --> 00:06:00,560
us because it gives us a chance to define
the routing and the host at the same time.

116
00:06:00,560 --> 00:06:03,520
Those two separate pieces,
I can do them at the same time,

117
00:06:03,520 --> 00:06:05,840
and it does make life a little bit easier.

118
00:06:05,840 --> 00:06:08,320
You'll also notice,
if I scroll all the way back to the top,

119
00:06:11,430 --> 00:06:13,330
Actually we don't see it on this screen,
shoot.

120
00:06:13,330 --> 00:06:16,330
On some screens we'll actually see tabs
across the top and you'll see hosts and

121
00:06:16,330 --> 00:06:17,190
routing up there too.

122
00:06:17,190 --> 00:06:19,310
We'll see that a little bit later.

123
00:06:19,310 --> 00:06:24,120
Again it's the same screens, the same
settings Just different ways to get to it.

124
00:06:24,120 --> 00:06:26,610
This one doesn't have those tabs.

125
00:06:26,610 --> 00:06:29,730
If I look under routing,
I've got my email routing, and

126
00:06:29,730 --> 00:06:32,000
notice how it says locally applied.

127
00:06:32,000 --> 00:06:35,570
Remember, just like policies
in our Google Apps account,

128
00:06:35,570 --> 00:06:39,840
when we set up email routing,
it's done on a per organization basis.

129
00:06:39,840 --> 00:06:43,020
Right now,
I'm on my IT Pro TV organization.

130
00:06:43,020 --> 00:06:46,140
And these settings are locally applied
right here on that organization.

131
00:06:47,170 --> 00:06:51,120
Any change I make is going to trickle
down to affect my contractors and

132
00:06:51,120 --> 00:06:53,290
retired people also.

133
00:06:53,290 --> 00:06:57,960
But, if I go down to contractors,
maybe I want to have a different

134
00:06:57,960 --> 00:07:00,770
legal disclaimer at the bottom of
e-mails from the legal contractors, so

135
00:07:00,770 --> 00:07:03,980
I could choose that And
when I go in here to their routing.

136
00:07:05,080 --> 00:07:06,630
When I go down to their routing section.

137
00:07:06,630 --> 00:07:09,420
See how it says, not configured yet?

138
00:07:09,420 --> 00:07:13,270
I can configure that using my configure
button over here on the side.

139
00:07:13,270 --> 00:07:18,060
And we can go and start to modify those
settings just for this sub-organization.

140
00:07:18,060 --> 00:07:21,910
So you can have different email routing
policies for different tiers or

141
00:07:21,910 --> 00:07:25,250
different organizations in your company,
very, very flexible stuff.

142
00:07:27,690 --> 00:07:30,400
Let me get back to my
routing section here.

143
00:07:30,400 --> 00:07:33,800
Now inside of the routing there's
a handful of things that we can do,

144
00:07:33,800 --> 00:07:36,420
the first setting here is
kind of an important one.

145
00:07:36,420 --> 00:07:38,890
It's a catch all address.

146
00:07:38,890 --> 00:07:42,250
When somebody sends a email to an email
that's attached to your domain.

147
00:07:42,250 --> 00:07:44,660
So my domain here is IT Pro TV dot net.

148
00:07:44,660 --> 00:07:48,040
If you send an email to
D Pezet at IT Pro TV dot net,

149
00:07:48,040 --> 00:07:50,810
that's my test account, and I'll get it.

150
00:07:50,810 --> 00:07:51,680
I've got a valid account.

151
00:07:51,680 --> 00:07:55,882
But, what if you send it to
Don at IT Pro TV dot net?

152
00:07:55,882 --> 00:07:58,877
Well, I don't have that address,
so it's gonna fail.

153
00:07:58,877 --> 00:08:00,318
The server is actually gonna reject.

154
00:08:00,318 --> 00:08:03,079
The message, it won't accept the message
for an address that doesn't exist.

155
00:08:03,079 --> 00:08:06,680
The sending server will
get a rejection host.

156
00:08:06,680 --> 00:08:08,950
But what if you want those emails?

157
00:08:08,950 --> 00:08:11,870
What if you want to support
somebody sending an email to

158
00:08:11,870 --> 00:08:13,380
an address that doesn't exist?

159
00:08:13,380 --> 00:08:16,220
You can create a catch all address.

160
00:08:16,220 --> 00:08:18,840
A catch all address, so
I could create one, and

161
00:08:18,840 --> 00:08:23,300
maybe I'll make it dpezet@itprotv.net
which probably a phenomenally bad idea,

162
00:08:23,300 --> 00:08:24,970
but let's say we do it.

163
00:08:24,970 --> 00:08:28,650
Now if anybody sends an email to
an address that doesn't exist,

164
00:08:28,650 --> 00:08:30,530
the email will get delivered to me.

165
00:08:30,530 --> 00:08:32,140
I'll get a copy of it, all right?

166
00:08:32,140 --> 00:08:34,230
Now that might sound like a great idea.

167
00:08:34,230 --> 00:08:35,140
Hey that's wonderful!

168
00:08:35,140 --> 00:08:38,840
Now if somebody has a typo in their
email or whatever I'll get a copy of it,

169
00:08:38,840 --> 00:08:39,620
I can receive it.

170
00:08:39,620 --> 00:08:40,300
Wonderful.

171
00:08:40,300 --> 00:08:41,150
All right?

172
00:08:41,150 --> 00:08:44,070
But the problem is Internet spam.

173
00:08:44,070 --> 00:08:45,460
Internet spam agents, right?

174
00:08:45,460 --> 00:08:46,910
When they start relaying spam,

175
00:08:46,910 --> 00:08:48,740
a lot of times they're just
trying brute force names.

176
00:08:48,740 --> 00:08:53,340
And so they'll do things like
bob@itprotv.net or tom@itprotv.net.

177
00:08:53,340 --> 00:08:55,910
Just randomly picking names,
hoping to hit a person.

178
00:08:55,910 --> 00:08:59,040
Well, all of those random
names are gonna go to me.

179
00:08:59,040 --> 00:09:00,850
I'm gonna get that.

180
00:09:00,850 --> 00:09:05,300
So when you set up a catch all mailbox
you can expect its spam numbers

181
00:09:05,300 --> 00:09:07,610
to just explode astronomically.

182
00:09:07,610 --> 00:09:09,360
It'll get a ton of stuff.

183
00:09:09,360 --> 00:09:12,630
The other thing is your server is
no longer rejecting the messages.

184
00:09:12,630 --> 00:09:14,150
It's gonna accept them.

185
00:09:14,150 --> 00:09:18,315
So if somebody outside is trying to
send an email to me, Don Pezet, or

186
00:09:18,315 --> 00:09:24,620
dpezet@itprotv.net, one of the ones I get
all the time is where they'll type dperez.

187
00:09:24,620 --> 00:09:29,040
For some reason, my last name, Pezet,
in people minds they switch it to Perez,

188
00:09:29,040 --> 00:09:30,230
it just happens.

189
00:09:30,230 --> 00:09:33,330
So if they send to that,
it's a bad address, right?

190
00:09:33,330 --> 00:09:37,040
Normally they'd get a bounce message
saying, hey that's not a valid address,

191
00:09:37,040 --> 00:09:39,980
and they'd look at it and go, oh that's
right that's not how you spell his name or

192
00:09:39,980 --> 00:09:42,450
oh look I made a typo, and they'd fix it.

193
00:09:42,450 --> 00:09:45,030
But with a catch all,
the message delivers.

194
00:09:45,030 --> 00:09:46,840
They think that it successfully went.

195
00:09:46,840 --> 00:09:49,480
Now unless I'm checking
this catch all mail box,

196
00:09:49,480 --> 00:09:51,160
I'm probably not gonna notice that.

197
00:09:51,160 --> 00:09:53,000
And so these might go unlooked at.

198
00:09:53,000 --> 00:09:55,240
Whoever the sender was
thinks they were delivered.

199
00:09:55,240 --> 00:09:58,320
Whoever the recipient was
never actually got it.

200
00:09:58,320 --> 00:10:02,040
And so the catch all is not something
that most organizations want, so

201
00:10:02,040 --> 00:10:05,530
you may want to discard,
which is the default.

202
00:10:05,530 --> 00:10:07,420
Discard says if an email comes in for

203
00:10:07,420 --> 00:10:09,710
an address that doesn't exist,
we just toss it, throw it out.

204
00:10:13,000 --> 00:10:13,532
All right.

205
00:10:13,532 --> 00:10:15,895
Then we can specify things
like an outbound gateway.

206
00:10:15,895 --> 00:10:16,720
All right.

207
00:10:16,720 --> 00:10:20,880
Now an outbound gateway is
kind of a neat feature.

208
00:10:20,880 --> 00:10:25,321
When you send your email, the default
is they send from Google's servers.

209
00:10:25,321 --> 00:10:26,260
All right?

210
00:10:26,260 --> 00:10:30,820
But you might be paying for
some kind of email archiving service.

211
00:10:30,820 --> 00:10:35,650
So you wanna keep a record all emails
sent from or to your organization.

212
00:10:35,650 --> 00:10:39,000
Now, Google has the Google vault service,
so you could use that.

213
00:10:39,000 --> 00:10:42,740
But, maybe you gotta use a third party
solution because you're company's already

214
00:10:42,740 --> 00:10:43,390
paid for it or

215
00:10:43,390 --> 00:10:46,940
you have some legal compliance issue
that makes you use a third party.

216
