00:10:46,940 --> 00:10:49,140
You can specify an outbound gateway.

217
00:10:49,140 --> 00:10:53,200
And all email sent from
your Google Apps accounts,

218
00:10:53,200 --> 00:10:56,440
instead of just going straight out to
the Internet through Google servers,

219
00:10:56,440 --> 00:11:00,660
will instead be sent to
whoever you put in right here.

220
00:11:00,660 --> 00:11:04,640
So we can specify the SMTP server, and now
all of our outgoing email will flow there.

221
00:11:04,640 --> 00:11:07,940
Great way to do additional spam filtering.

222
00:11:07,940 --> 00:11:11,990
Or to do, you know, e-discovery,
collecting the data and storing it.

223
00:11:14,550 --> 00:11:18,250
We can also do other things like
recipient address mappings.

224
00:11:18,250 --> 00:11:23,010
You might have one recipient who you
want to get emails for other addresses.

225
00:11:23,010 --> 00:11:26,670
So for
example I've got dpezet@itprotv.net right?

226
00:11:26,670 --> 00:11:28,810
I might want to have
more than one address.

227
00:11:28,810 --> 00:11:31,420
Well, I saw a way we could
do aliases on an account.

228
00:11:31,420 --> 00:11:32,870
I think we covered that
in another segment.

229
00:11:32,870 --> 00:11:34,350
So you could edit the user.

230
00:11:34,350 --> 00:11:37,222
And go into their profile and
add in aliases, up to 20 of them.

231
00:11:37,222 --> 00:11:37,810
All right.

232
00:11:37,810 --> 00:11:39,840
What if you need more than 20,

233
00:11:39,840 --> 00:11:44,340
or what if you want the alias to actually
be something that we can easily move from

234
00:11:44,340 --> 00:11:47,130
account to account without
modifying individual user accounts?

235
00:11:47,130 --> 00:11:50,520
Well, we can come in here and
do a recipient address map.

236
00:11:50,520 --> 00:11:53,970
The cool thing about recipient
address maps is they

237
00:11:53,970 --> 00:11:55,640
aren't tied specifically to the user.

238
00:11:55,640 --> 00:11:59,270
They're set here in the admin panel so
we have a little more control over them.

239
00:11:59,270 --> 00:12:03,660
And when you go into the configuration
screen, you can punch in a short

240
00:12:03,660 --> 00:12:07,280
description of the mapping, and then
what it is you're doing the mapping for.

241
00:12:07,280 --> 00:12:11,320
All incoming messages or only incoming
messages from outside people.

242
00:12:11,320 --> 00:12:12,300
In other words, not.

243
00:12:12,300 --> 00:12:15,180
Emails between our company members.

244
00:12:15,180 --> 00:12:18,570
So I'll say these will
be like Don's aliases.

245
00:12:19,620 --> 00:12:22,990
And I'll say, all incoming messages,
for the above type of messages,

246
00:12:22,990 --> 00:12:24,530
rewrite the following recipients.

247
00:12:24,530 --> 00:12:29,190
And I'm just gonna add in who
it is that I want to rewrite.

248
00:12:29,190 --> 00:12:33,370
So it says, enter address mappings below
with each mapping on a single line.

249
00:12:33,370 --> 00:12:35,770
Two addresses separated by a comma.

250
00:12:35,770 --> 00:12:43,660
So I want don@ITProTV.net to be
mapped to dpezet@ITProTv.net.

251
00:12:43,660 --> 00:12:46,160
So, I'll just punch that in and hit add.

252
00:12:46,160 --> 00:12:50,300
And it's got this address being
mapped to this other address.

253
00:12:50,300 --> 00:12:51,860
And so I can start to punch in other ones.

254
00:12:51,860 --> 00:12:57,630
Maybe I'll get some generic
emails like info@ITProTV.net.

255
00:12:57,630 --> 00:12:58,800
If I can type it.

256
00:12:58,800 --> 00:13:01,090
Then I wanna map it to dpezet right?

257
00:13:01,090 --> 00:13:06,980
So we can start to punch in these other
emails and those are gonna get mapped in.

258
00:13:06,980 --> 00:13:10,300
Now when somebody sends
an email to don@ITPROTV.net,

259
00:13:10,300 --> 00:13:12,460
I'll still get a copy of it, right?

260
00:13:12,460 --> 00:13:16,520
But, if we do it as an alias,
when it makes it into our inbox,

261
00:13:16,520 --> 00:13:19,680
we'll see that it was actually
sent to don@itprotv.net.

262
00:13:19,680 --> 00:13:23,280
When we do an address map like this, when
we get it, it will actually show us having

263
00:13:23,280 --> 00:13:27,320
been sent to depezet@@itprotv.net.,
so it kind of masks that address.

264
00:13:27,320 --> 00:13:31,120
But we can go through and enter in
the various aliases that we want and

265
00:13:31,120 --> 00:13:33,120
then we can add that setting.

266
00:13:33,120 --> 00:13:35,690
Now, because the address
is being rewritten,

267
00:13:35,690 --> 00:13:37,940
how do we know that it was
sent to a different address?

268
00:13:37,940 --> 00:13:42,150
Well, you do have the option to add
an original tube to the header.

269
00:13:42,150 --> 00:13:44,320
An extra header entry so
that we can see that.

270
00:13:44,320 --> 00:13:47,240
The default is it overwrites it and
it disappears, all right?

271
00:13:47,240 --> 00:13:51,070
But if we want we can choose that and
it'll add that to the email header.

272
00:13:51,070 --> 00:13:54,690
I'll add that setting and
now I've got two address mappings.

273
00:13:54,690 --> 00:13:58,305
And I can go and continue to add more
mappings that are adjusting the emails as

274
00:13:58,305 --> 00:14:00,071
they pass through my organization.

275
00:14:02,640 --> 00:14:03,470
All right.

276
00:14:03,470 --> 00:14:07,216
So the first couple of examples there
are ways that we can manipulate the emails

277
00:14:07,216 --> 00:14:08,183
themselves.

278
00:14:08,183 --> 00:14:10,350
Right?
The outbound gateway,

279
00:14:10,350 --> 00:14:14,115
that was changing the outbound
routing of all of our email.

280
00:14:14,115 --> 00:14:17,885
But what if I want to change the outbound
routing of just some emails?

281
00:14:17,885 --> 00:14:19,445
Well this is all of them, right.

282
00:14:19,445 --> 00:14:23,865
So I need to be specific if I want to
hit individual servers or domains.

283
00:14:23,865 --> 00:14:26,045
And you'll see that options is next.

284
00:14:26,045 --> 00:14:29,345
We've got Receiving routing,
and Sending routing.

285
00:14:29,345 --> 00:14:33,465
So, how do I route incoming emails
from the outside world to me, and

286
00:14:33,465 --> 00:14:36,440
how do I route outgoing emails
from me to the outside world?

287
00:14:36,440 --> 00:14:37,000
All right?

288
00:14:37,000 --> 00:14:40,540
Now, if I want to just change
all of my outgoing email,

289
00:14:40,540 --> 00:14:42,900
that's where this Outbound
gateway comes in.

290
00:14:42,900 --> 00:14:45,730
But if I want to change
certain outbound emails or

291
00:14:45,730 --> 00:14:49,000
if I want to be specific,
that's where the send routing comes in.

292
00:14:49,000 --> 00:14:52,140
Now, receiving routing and sending routing
are actually configured the same way.

293
00:14:52,140 --> 00:14:54,630
The configuration screens are identical.

294
00:14:54,630 --> 00:14:58,170
It's just the direction of
the email that's different.

295
00:14:58,170 --> 00:15:01,700
So let's say for example,
on the receiving side,

296
00:15:01,700 --> 00:15:05,930
if I'm going to be receiving email for
a user, and I just want to turn around and

297
00:15:05,930 --> 00:15:09,325
forward it to somewhere else,
forward it to some external address.

298
00:15:09,325 --> 00:15:12,195
I can go into receiving routing,
and I can configure that.

299
00:15:12,195 --> 00:15:13,845
So, I'll hit my configure
button on the side.

300
00:15:13,845 --> 00:15:17,495
And it's gonna take me to
the receiving routing screen, right?

301
00:15:17,495 --> 00:15:19,585
We can give it a description.

302
00:15:21,155 --> 00:15:28,470
And I can call this incoming email for
Bob Smith.

303
00:15:28,470 --> 00:15:29,190
All right.

304
00:15:29,190 --> 00:15:32,690
And I can specify the emails to effect.

305
00:15:32,690 --> 00:15:36,420
Inbound, that means email
sent from the outside world,

306
00:15:36,420 --> 00:15:38,020
to Bob Smith inside my company.

307
00:15:39,560 --> 00:15:44,280
Internal, that means email sent from
someone in my company to Bob Smith,

308
00:15:44,280 --> 00:15:45,650
in my company also.

309
00:15:45,650 --> 00:15:51,350
Technically email between two
employees just go direct and

310
00:15:51,350 --> 00:15:52,690
the routing doesn't apply to them.

311
00:15:52,690 --> 00:15:58,639
So I'm specifying whether I want to effect
just inside or just outside or both.

312
00:15:58,639 --> 00:16:01,354
I want to effect every email
that's sent to Bob Smith.

313
00:16:01,354 --> 00:16:04,721
And then I can start to
pick what I want to do.

314
00:16:04,721 --> 00:16:10,130
If somebody's emailing Bob Smith,
what do I do?

315
00:16:10,130 --> 00:16:13,012
And now,
I can specify how I wanna handle that.

316
00:16:13,012 --> 00:16:18,050
I wanna take it and I wanna forward
this out to his external account.

317
00:16:18,050 --> 00:16:21,550
I'm not actually gonna have an account for
Bob Smith, I'm gonna forward this to

318
00:16:21,550 --> 00:16:24,705
an external account, so I can change
the route or change the recipient.

319
00:16:24,705 --> 00:16:27,540
And that's what I'm gonna do,
I'm gonna change the recipient.

320
00:16:27,540 --> 00:16:31,220
And I'm gonna replace the recipient
with whatever his address happens to be.

321
00:16:31,220 --> 00:16:34,160
So, maybe it's bob@aol.com.

322
00:16:34,160 --> 00:16:39,890
So, if you send an email to
bob@itprotv.net I'm gonna intercept it,

323
00:16:39,890 --> 00:16:43,550
change the destination to bob@aol.com and
send it along.

324
00:16:43,550 --> 00:16:46,830
So, we can modify that and manipulate it,
and send it to a different place.

325
00:16:46,830 --> 00:16:49,550
You'll see where you can
preserve the domain name or

326
00:16:49,550 --> 00:16:53,320
preserve the username, if you're
just changing part of the address.

327
00:16:53,320 --> 00:16:55,280
But I'm replacing the whole thing.

328
00:16:55,280 --> 00:16:57,240
I'll make it Bob.

329
00:16:57,240 --> 00:17:01,491
My apologies to you if that is
your email address [LAUGH].

330
00:17:01,491 --> 00:17:03,454
We won't relate too much to it.

331
00:17:03,454 --> 00:17:05,920
You'll see also where you
can bypass the spam filter.

332
00:17:05,920 --> 00:17:06,970
That's really useful.

333
00:17:06,970 --> 00:17:12,250
I know we've had a problem at ITProTV
where a lot of our receipts for

334
00:17:12,250 --> 00:17:17,070
people purchasing subscriptions and
so on, will get flagged as spam.

335
00:17:17,070 --> 00:17:20,950
And so, you can choose to bypass the spam
filter for those types of emails.

336
00:17:20,950 --> 00:17:24,700
You can also strip attachments if you
wanna get those off of the emails.

337
00:17:24,700 --> 00:17:27,660
And you can add more recipients.

338
00:17:27,660 --> 00:17:29,110
Now, why would you do that?

339
00:17:29,110 --> 00:17:34,300
Well, adding more recipients is a neat
way to do, I call it poor man's vault.

340
00:17:34,300 --> 00:17:39,422
If you want an email vault, like one
email account that has all of the emails

341
00:17:39,422 --> 00:17:44,330
from your entire organization,
you could add it as a recipient.

342
00:17:44,330 --> 00:17:46,510
You could punch that in
as something like a BCC,

343
00:17:46,510 --> 00:17:50,580
so that every time that somebody sent
an email out, or received an email in,

344
00:17:50,580 --> 00:17:52,750
that a copy of it was
sent to this one mailbox.

345
00:17:52,750 --> 00:17:54,880
And then you have this one
mailbox you could log into and

346
00:17:54,880 --> 00:17:56,800
search to find your data.

347
00:17:56,800 --> 00:18:00,664
The Google vault service is a little bit
better cuz it gives you better reporting,

348
00:18:00,664 --> 00:18:02,568
but this is an easy way to go about it,
and

349
00:18:02,568 --> 00:18:05,158
you have one mailbox that
has all of that information.

350
00:18:05,158 --> 00:18:06,878
But there might be other reasons.

351
00:18:06,878 --> 00:18:10,480
You might wanna copy in somebody's
manager when they receive emails, or

352
00:18:10,480 --> 00:18:13,130
certain types of emails
we add recipients to.

353
00:18:13,130 --> 00:18:13,630
Either way.

354
00:18:15,400 --> 00:18:18,850
Then, I can specify when
I want this to apply.

355
00:18:18,850 --> 00:18:21,570
Now, I don't want this to
apply to everybody's email,

356
00:18:21,570 --> 00:18:23,240
which is what's gonna happen right now.

357
00:18:23,240 --> 00:18:27,140
I wanna get just email
sent to bob@itprotv.net.

358
00:18:27,140 --> 00:18:32,610
So, down here, I can specify a sender
address, or a recipient address.

359
00:18:32,610 --> 00:18:35,200
The recipient address is
the one I wanna manipulate.

360
00:18:35,200 --> 00:18:38,000
I'm gonna put in here
an address that I wanna match.

361
00:18:38,000 --> 00:18:42,899
And so, I'm gonna say,
if somebody's emailing bob@itprotv.net.

362
00:18:42,899 --> 00:18:47,288
If they're emailing bob@itprotv.net,
I wanna catch that and

363
00:18:47,288 --> 00:18:49,880
change it to this other address.

364
00:18:49,880 --> 00:18:53,950
Now, it does use a regular
expression to do that search, and

365
00:18:53,950 --> 00:18:55,895
you've got to be careful
with regular expressions,

366
00:18:55,895 --> 00:19:00,400
cuz some characters like that dot
can be interpreted different ways.

367
00:19:00,400 --> 00:19:03,080
So, there is a little learn more
link you can click on here that

368
00:19:03,080 --> 00:19:06,080
talks about regular expressions and
their formats.

369
00:19:06,080 --> 00:19:08,710
And how you need to phrase
things to be able to identify

370
00:19:08,710 --> 00:19:11,970
particular parts of a string, and so on.

371
00:19:11,970 --> 00:19:14,430
So, you can check a lot of that stuff.

372
00:19:14,430 --> 00:19:17,970
And they've even got a little test
expression link here where you can test it

373
00:19:17,970 --> 00:19:19,650
to see if it matches.

374
00:19:19,650 --> 00:19:24,000
So, if I'm punching in that address,

375
00:19:24,000 --> 00:19:27,400
I can make sure that my regular
expression matches and that it shows it.

376
00:19:27,400 --> 00:19:31,665
So, for example,
if Bob had more than one email account,

377
00:19:31,665 --> 00:19:37,061
if he had Bob1, Bob2 and Bob3@itprotv.net,
I could come in here and

378
00:19:37,061 --> 00:19:41,345
say, Bob, and then in square brackets,
one dash three.

379
00:19:41,345 --> 00:19:45,950
And then, when I do an email address,
if it's Bob 1, see how I have a match?

380
00:19:45,950 --> 00:19:49,950
And if I change it to Bob 2,
I still have a match.

381
00:19:49,950 --> 00:19:52,240
If I change it to Bob 3,
I still have a match.

382
00:19:52,240 --> 00:19:55,570
If I change it to bob 4,
I no longer have a match.

383
00:19:55,570 --> 00:19:58,690
So, these regular expressions
give you a lot of flexibility for

384
00:19:58,690 --> 00:20:01,610
catching more than one address.

385
00:20:01,610 --> 00:20:04,279
I'm gonna leave it at just
his straight up address.

386
00:20:07,876 --> 00:20:09,780
And that should be all I need.

387
00:20:09,780 --> 00:20:11,580
And I'll go and add that routing.

388
00:20:12,852 --> 00:20:15,180
So, now, I'm gonna uncheck this,

389
00:20:15,180 --> 00:20:17,550
execute the setting only if
the envelope sender matches.

390
00:20:17,550 --> 00:20:20,110
I don't care who the sender is so
I'm gonna uncheck that.

391
00:20:20,110 --> 00:20:21,590
I just care about the recipient.

392
00:20:21,590 --> 00:20:24,505
If I get an email where
the recipient is bob@itprotv.net,

393
00:20:24,505 --> 00:20:26,500
then I'm gonna take this action.

394
00:20:26,500 --> 00:20:31,070
I'm gonna change
the recipient to bob@aol.com.

395
00:20:31,070 --> 00:20:32,810
So, that should be every
thing that we need.

396
00:20:32,810 --> 00:20:34,300
I'll go ahead and add the setting.

397
00:20:34,300 --> 00:20:36,810
And now, I've got a receive route put in.

398
00:20:38,240 --> 00:20:40,860
Now, that receive route is entered
right here, I can add more.

399
00:20:40,860 --> 00:20:44,160
I can go in and start to add other ones,
putting in additional settings.

400
00:20:45,160 --> 00:20:48,810
And in this scenario, I was just
taking it and over riding it for

401
00:20:48,810 --> 00:20:50,610
a particular email address.

402
00:20:50,610 --> 00:20:53,160
I might wanna overwrite things for
an entire domain and

403
00:20:53,160 --> 00:20:57,590
you can certainly do that based on
whatever your criteria happen to be.

404
00:20:57,590 --> 00:21:00,820
We normally see that with things
like sender routing or sending.

405
00:21:00,820 --> 00:21:02,660
When we're sending email out,

406
00:21:02,660 --> 00:21:04,926
if I have a business partner
that I do work with a lot,

407
00:21:04,926 --> 00:21:10,210
I might wanna send email for their domains
straight to a particular email server.

408
00:21:10,210 --> 00:21:13,670
They might have an email server that's
set up to allow me to relay for them.

409
00:21:13,670 --> 00:21:17,360
You see this a lot with bulk
email services like Mailgun or

410
00:21:17,360 --> 00:21:18,980
SendGrid or whatever.

411
00:21:18,980 --> 00:21:23,740
So, you might have send routing for your
marketing email to go out through them,

412
00:21:23,740 --> 00:21:26,070
instead of going straight
out to the internet.

413
00:21:26,070 --> 00:21:29,105
So, we can go to send routing and
start to manipulate that.

414
00:21:29,105 --> 00:21:34,060
When we go to configure it here,
I'll call this my marketing email reroute.

415
00:21:36,400 --> 00:21:39,360
And I'm gonna be rerouting
out bound emails.

416
00:21:39,360 --> 00:21:41,400
I don't care about internal emails,
this is just outbound.

417
00:21:41,400 --> 00:21:48,332
So, it's going out to the internet and
I'm gonna change my sender,

418
00:21:48,332 --> 00:21:52,910
I want that to be marketing@itprotv.net.

419
00:21:52,910 --> 00:21:57,430
So, any email being generated
by marketing@itprotv.net, so

420
00:21:57,430 --> 00:22:01,580
any outbound email from that address,
I wanna change where it goes.

421
00:22:01,580 --> 00:22:06,590
And up here, I'll do change route and
I'm gonna reroute it.

422
00:22:06,590 --> 00:22:09,200
Now, the default is normal routing,
but if you drop that down,

423
00:22:09,200 --> 00:22:11,290
you'll see where you
can pick other routes.

424
00:22:11,290 --> 00:22:12,890
I don't have any.

425
00:22:12,890 --> 00:22:17,183
I don't have any other route to pick from,
so I need to add that route in and that's

426
00:22:17,183 --> 00:22:21,166
where we go back to what I mentioned
earlier that we have the routing rules and

427
00:22:21,166 --> 00:22:24,370
we have the hosts that we need to
define to go in and set those.

428
00:22:24,370 --> 00:22:25,890
We'll get a chance to see
that in just a second,

429
00:22:25,890 --> 00:22:27,890
I'll have to come back and edit this rule.

430
00:22:27,890 --> 00:22:31,340
I'm gonna go and add the setting for
now with normal routing.

431
00:22:31,340 --> 00:22:33,870
And then, I can come back and
modify it in a moment.

432
00:22:33,870 --> 00:22:37,400
One word of advice for the exam is
you start to modify this stuff.

433
00:22:37,400 --> 00:22:40,220
This page right here, the Gmail page,

434
00:22:40,220 --> 00:22:45,200
there's something weird about it and
if you start making a bunch of changes,

435
00:22:45,200 --> 00:22:49,610
the odds of your changes failing
increase with each change you make.

436
00:22:49,610 --> 00:22:52,610
So, it's a good idea that
every time you make a change,

437
00:22:52,610 --> 00:22:54,400
you immediately hit save changes.

438
00:22:54,400 --> 00:22:58,240
So, I just made two changes at once,
and I haven't hit save, so

439
00:22:58,240 --> 00:23:01,130
the odds of this failing
is starting to go up.

440
00:23:01,130 --> 00:23:02,850
So, I need to make sure that I hit save,
and

441
00:23:02,850 --> 00:23:07,150
if you get an error here, well,
don't be surprised, first off [LAUGH], and

442
00:23:07,150 --> 00:23:11,130
then secondly, you'll need to go
back in and redo your changes.

443
00:23:11,130 --> 00:23:12,370
Remember, on the exam,

444
00:23:12,370 --> 00:23:16,440
they're grading you by checking
the end result, not how you did it.

445
00:23:16,440 --> 00:23:19,040
So, if you don't save the change,
you don't get the end result.

446
00:23:19,040 --> 00:23:20,520
You get the question wrong.

447
00:23:20,520 --> 00:23:23,040
So, make sure you save after each and
every change.

448
00:23:23,040 --> 00:23:25,210
And not just on the exam,
but even in real life land.

449
00:23:25,210 --> 00:23:27,580
You wanna make sure you save
after each and every change.

450
00:23:27,580 --> 00:23:30,900
There are just a lot of settings on
this page and so it's difficult for

451
00:23:30,900 --> 00:23:33,620
the system to track that and
it does get a little bit quirky.

452
00:23:35,600 --> 00:23:39,110
But I saved my changes, I can see
my reroutes are all right there, so

453
00:23:39,110 --> 00:23:42,750
I've got those if I have my vault settings
or whatever I could turn that on.

454
00:23:42,750 --> 00:23:48,610
So, you'll see some additional options
in here that are able to be manipulated,

455
00:23:48,610 --> 00:23:50,030
and you can change those.

456
00:23:50,030 --> 00:23:51,648
But I just created an entry and

457
00:23:51,648 --> 00:23:56,199
I couldn't change my routing because I
didn't have an additional route in there.

458
00:23:56,199 --> 00:23:58,800
So, I need to go and
get that squared away.

459
00:23:58,800 --> 00:24:02,747
If I go back to my settings for Gmail,
Right in here I'll see the hosts and

460
00:24:02,747 --> 00:24:06,800
default routing that I mentioned
way back in the beginning.

461
00:24:06,800 --> 00:24:08,550
Well, let's take a look at that.

462
00:24:08,550 --> 00:24:12,210
If I'm dealing with somebody,
let's say SendGrid.

463
00:24:12,210 --> 00:24:16,860
So, I'm using SendGrid as an outgoing
email service for my marketing email.

464
00:24:16,860 --> 00:24:19,650
They help make sure that you
don't violate any spam rules, and

465
00:24:19,650 --> 00:24:22,080
they do all sorts of bounce tracking and
stuff like that.

466
00:24:22,080 --> 00:24:24,890
I could send my emails
right from Google apps,

00:24:24,890 --> 00:24:29,930
but I don't get a lot of bounce
information and all the reporting and

00:24:29,930 --> 00:24:32,880
advanced analysis you get through
an actual marketing service.

469
00:24:32,880 --> 00:24:37,660
So I can go into hosts, and I can
define the SendGrid servers right here.

470
00:24:37,660 --> 00:24:40,410
I'm just gonna go up here to add route.

471
00:24:40,410 --> 00:24:44,640
And I can specify, so
these would be the SendGrid Servers.

472
00:24:44,640 --> 00:24:47,410
And I can specify a single host or
multiple hosts, and

473
00:24:47,410 --> 00:24:51,540
I'm pretty sure they used multiple ones,
right, so we'd punch in whatever.

474
00:24:51,540 --> 00:24:58,510
I'm making these addresses up, so don't
assume that I've got it actually correct.

475
00:24:58,510 --> 00:25:01,400
But we can punch in that information for
connecting to their servers.

476
00:25:01,400 --> 00:25:04,430
And if there's more than one server,
how we want the load to be distributed.

477
00:25:04,430 --> 00:25:08,650
So maybe I go 50/50 on these, and
you can add in as may servers as you need.

478
00:25:10,910 --> 00:25:12,100
All right.

479
00:25:12,100 --> 00:25:13,720
So, I've got those servers in.

480
00:25:13,720 --> 00:25:16,880
I can choose whether I wanna require TLS.

481
00:25:16,880 --> 00:25:19,480
TLS is Transport Layer Security.

482
00:25:19,480 --> 00:25:23,260
It basically uses SSL to encrypt
the communication between the two

483
00:25:23,260 --> 00:25:24,440
Google servers.

484
00:25:24,440 --> 00:25:26,610
I believe I talk about
that in another objective.

485
00:25:26,610 --> 00:25:28,140
So we'll see that a little bit later.

486
00:25:28,140 --> 00:25:30,660
But we can choose to
turn that on right here.

487
00:25:30,660 --> 00:25:33,880
There is this option Require
a CA signed certificate.

488
00:25:33,880 --> 00:25:39,290
And with that one, what we're saying is it
needs to be a public, actually registered,

489
00:25:39,290 --> 00:25:42,890
and trusted certification authority
that issued the certificate,

490
00:25:42,890 --> 00:25:45,060
not a self-signed certificate.

491
00:25:45,060 --> 00:25:48,540
If you uncheck that, they could have
a self-signed certificate where you might

492
00:25:48,540 --> 00:25:50,950
not trust the route, but
you'll still use it for encryption.

493
00:25:50,950 --> 00:25:54,310
That's weaker security, but
if you know you trust that cert,

494
00:25:54,310 --> 00:25:55,800
you can turn that option off.

495
00:25:55,800 --> 00:25:59,970
But if you don't know, you just leave
that checked, and you'll be covered.

496
00:25:59,970 --> 00:26:00,840
Oh, shoot, you know what?

497
00:26:00,840 --> 00:26:01,980
I made a mistake here.

498
00:26:01,980 --> 00:26:05,290

00:26:05,290 --> 00:26:07,650
What I did is I set these loads at 50%.

It's gonna use the primary's

502
00:26:12,740 --> 00:26:16,230
What I should have done if had more than

503
00:26:16,230 --> 00:26:18,820
And here you'll see where I

504
00:26:18,820 --> 00:26:21,840
So it red-flagged me because my
percentages didn't add up to 100.

505
00:26:21,840 --> 00:26:24,780
And that's what I really should've done.

506
00:26:24,780 --> 00:26:29,430
And maybe we've got
mail3.sendgrid as a backup, right?

507
00:26:29,430 --> 00:26:31,810
So if these guys aren't available,

00:26:31,810 --> 00:26:33,160
So I entered that wrong.

00:26:33,160 --> 00:26:34,450
All right.
So once we've got that in place,

510
00:26:34,450 --> 00:26:35,680
we can hit Save.

511
00:26:35,680 --> 00:26:39,050
And now I've got my SendGrid
servers to find as a host.

512
00:26:40,360 --> 00:26:43,330
Then, we can define our route.

513
00:26:43,330 --> 00:26:44,690
Now technically this is a route.

514
00:26:44,690 --> 00:26:48,160
See how it was the Add route
button here to get that specified.

515
00:26:48,160 --> 00:26:51,530
If I go back to my settings for
Gmail though, I can go down here to my

516
00:26:51,530 --> 00:26:55,230
default routing and this'll show
the routes that my emails followed.

517
00:26:55,230 --> 00:27:00,270
Now it looks empty, but what it's
actually doing is the default is to

518
00:27:00,270 --> 00:27:04,580
go through Google servers, and you can't
override that, so it doesn't even show up.

519
00:27:04,580 --> 00:27:08,080
We're adding in modifications
to the default.

520
00:27:08,080 --> 00:27:11,480
So I can hit Add setting, and
I can specify some information.

521
00:27:11,480 --> 00:27:13,720
Now notice this screen looks familiar,
right?

522
00:27:13,720 --> 00:27:18,253
This is the same as the routing rules
I was looking at a moment ago in

523
00:27:18,253 --> 00:27:19,994
the Advanced settings.

524
00:27:19,994 --> 00:27:21,194
And so, when we look here and

525
00:27:21,194 --> 00:27:24,320
see what we're doing,
we're specifying who the recipient is.

526
00:27:24,320 --> 00:27:26,760
And then down here,
we can hit Change route, and

527
00:27:26,760 --> 00:27:29,920
we can specify SendGrid Services
now on my list.

528
00:27:29,920 --> 00:27:32,470
But, we probably don't want to do it from
here because you'll notice this screen

00:27:32,470 --> 00:27:34,330
gives us less options.

530
00:27:34,330 --> 00:27:38,441
Notice down here for the options, I can't
really match on a particular address.

531
00:27:38,441 --> 00:27:40,410
So, this is a little bit more limited.

532
00:27:40,410 --> 00:27:43,880
And that's why I said we don't
normally like to use this screen, but

533
00:27:43,880 --> 00:27:47,810
instead if we go back to our settings for
Gmail and

534
00:27:47,810 --> 00:27:51,660
User settings, and
we'll scroll down to that routing section.

535
00:27:51,660 --> 00:27:55,150
We have a lot more power down
here in the routing section, and

536
00:27:55,150 --> 00:27:57,580
that's why we normally configure it here.

537
00:27:57,580 --> 00:27:59,360
So, I can go and
find that route that I put in.

538
00:27:59,360 --> 00:28:01,890
So here's my marketing email route.

539
00:28:01,890 --> 00:28:03,160
I'm gonna edit that route.

540
00:28:04,460 --> 00:28:08,093
And so here is where I matched, and you'll
see the advanced stuff down here where I'm

541
00:28:08,093 --> 00:28:10,734
matching just stuff coming
from marketing@itprotv.net.

542
00:28:10,734 --> 00:28:15,040
But the difference now is I can
go to change the route, and

543
00:28:15,040 --> 00:28:17,490
I can pick my SendGrid servers.

544
00:28:17,490 --> 00:28:20,741
So now, whenever the marketing
email address sends an email out to

545
00:28:20,741 --> 00:28:24,051
the Internet, instead of just going
straight out to the Internet,

546
00:28:24,051 --> 00:28:25,458
it'll send it to SendGrid.

547
00:28:25,458 --> 00:28:28,990
And SendGrid will take care of sending it
out to everybody else that's out there.

548
00:28:28,990 --> 00:28:32,600
So that is an example of
manipulating outbound routing.

549
00:28:34,020 --> 00:28:35,710
So, we've seen quite
a few different things.

550
00:28:35,710 --> 00:28:38,250
Let me just make sure I've just covered
each of the things I wanted to talk

551
00:28:38,250 --> 00:28:39,990
about, yeah.

552
00:28:39,990 --> 00:28:43,700
So, we got a chance to see some of
the things we can do with email routing.

553
00:28:43,700 --> 00:28:45,970
It's really powerful stuff.

554
00:28:45,970 --> 00:28:48,590
First, we could modify
emails that were coming in.

555
00:28:48,590 --> 00:28:50,840
Our incoming emails,
we could change where they go to,

556
00:28:50,840 --> 00:28:52,340
we could redirect them somewhere else.

557
00:28:52,340 --> 00:28:56,310
We can even rewrite their address,
rewrite the recipient.

558
00:28:56,310 --> 00:28:58,590
Bypass spam filtering, whatever we wanted.

559
00:28:58,590 --> 00:28:59,990
Our outbound routes,

560
00:28:59,990 --> 00:29:03,920
we can manipulate what servers were
being used to send those emails.

561
00:29:03,920 --> 00:29:06,400
And we also got to see
the outbound gateway setting,

562
00:29:06,400 --> 00:29:09,690
where we can just send all of our
outbound email to a particular host,

563
00:29:09,690 --> 00:29:12,440
which is great for
archival purposes and things like that.

564
00:29:12,440 --> 00:29:15,310
A lot of power to be had here and

565
00:29:15,310 --> 00:29:18,970
changing the way those emails pass in and
out of your organization.

566
00:29:18,970 --> 00:29:22,200
Now most companies aren't
gonna need this stuff, right?

567
00:29:22,200 --> 00:29:24,940
The Google services are perfectly good for
us and they'll meet the needs of most

568
00:29:24,940 --> 00:29:28,020
organizations, but I think I've kind of
laid out the scenarios for you guys where

569
00:29:28,020 --> 00:29:30,960
that might not be the case, where you
might want to take advantage of this and

570
00:29:30,960 --> 00:29:32,940
it's nice to know that power is there.

571
00:29:32,940 --> 00:29:35,930
So that pretty much takes
care of email routing.

572
00:29:35,930 --> 00:29:37,250
I hope you guys enjoyed it.

573
00:29:37,250 --> 00:29:39,332

We've got more Google apps coming up.

episodes.title: Manage Whitelists and Blacklists
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:07,958
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07,958 --> 00:00:10,092
Objective 4.2 covers allowing or

3
00:00:10,092 --> 00:00:13,960
blocking email addresses as
they pass through your system.

4
00:00:13,960 --> 00:00:18,515
The official name is demonstrate how to
manage approved or reject sender lists and

5
00:00:18,515 --> 00:00:22,450
whitelist senders by domain and
IP address.

6
00:00:22,450 --> 00:00:25,560
And really,
all we're talking about is making a list

7
00:00:25,560 --> 00:00:30,290
to say these people are allowed to come
in, don't bother scanning them for spam.

8
00:00:30,290 --> 00:00:32,430
Or these people are not
allowed to come in,

9
00:00:32,430 --> 00:00:34,480
don't bother scanning them for
spam either!

10
00:00:34,480 --> 00:00:37,583
Just chuck them, right,
[LAUGH] just ditch these emails.

11
00:00:37,583 --> 00:00:41,580
Whitelists and
blacklists are explicit lists.

12
00:00:41,580 --> 00:00:45,250
We specify, regardless of what
the content of the message is,

13
00:00:45,250 --> 00:00:46,740
to allow it or block it.

14
00:00:47,750 --> 00:00:52,260
If there's an email address or
an IP address of an SMTP server

15
00:00:52,260 --> 00:00:55,850
that you know is only going
to send you spam, that you

16
00:00:55,850 --> 00:00:59,550
know is not gonna send you anything of
value, you can create a blacklist entry.

17
00:00:59,550 --> 00:01:01,860
And any email generated by that server or

18
00:01:01,860 --> 00:01:06,020
any email sent from that
address will be blocked.

19
00:01:06,020 --> 00:01:09,380
Or if you know for a fact there's a system
out there that's going to be sending you

20
00:01:09,380 --> 00:01:11,860
good legitimate email, but

21
00:01:11,860 --> 00:01:16,780
might occasionally get flagged to spam
accidentally, you can create a whitelist,

00:13:29,895 --> 00:13:33,037
external email services that we're trying
to route all of our email through.

246
00:13:33,037 --> 00:13:37,192
We saw the Spam list,
which is really our whitelist,

247
00:13:37,192 --> 00:13:40,362
where we bypass the spam filter for
certain addresses.

248
00:13:40,362 --> 00:13:43,522
And lastly, we saw the Blocked senders,
which is our blacklist,

249
00:13:43,522 --> 00:13:48,262
where we explicitly block certain
people from sending email in, and

250
00:13:48,262 --> 00:13:50,992
we can create exceptions to it as needed,
all right?

251
00:13:50,992 --> 00:13:55,442
So that in a nutshell is our blacklist and
whitelist management, or

252
00:13:55,442 --> 00:13:57,944
our sender filtering.

253
00:13:57,944 --> 00:14:00,663
So that's about it.

254
00:14:01,840 --> 00:14:03,070
Sometimes I feel like I forget things.

255
00:14:03,070 --> 00:14:04,920
But I've got all my notes, so that's it.

256
00:14:04,920 --> 00:14:05,950
So, all right.

257
00:14:05,950 --> 00:14:07,270
I hope you guys enjoyed that segment.

258
00:14:07,270 --> 00:14:10,875
Stay tuned,
we've got more Google Apps coming up next.

259
00:14:10,875 --> 00:14:17,279
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Mail Security Best Practices
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:05,394
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:05,394 --> 00:00:10,605
[SOUND] Objective 4.3 covers some
of the security best practices for

3
00:00:10,605 --> 00:00:13,527
handling email inside of Google Apps.

4
00:00:13,527 --> 00:00:18,686
The official title is, Demonstrate How
to Apply Security Best Practices to

5
00:00:18,686 --> 00:00:24,510
Email Including Transmit Mail Via
a Secure Connection Based On System Rules.

6
00:00:24,510 --> 00:00:29,400
And what they're talking about is how
email is inherently non-secure, right?

7
00:00:29,400 --> 00:00:32,420
The entire email infrastructure
is built around SMTP,

8
00:00:32,420 --> 00:00:38,530
the simple mail transport protocol, and
SMTP sends everything in plain text.

9
00:00:38,530 --> 00:00:39,690
That's what it does.

10
00:00:39,690 --> 00:00:43,810
SMTP was developed in a more innocent
time, the early days of the internet,

11
00:00:43,810 --> 00:00:46,190
where people were nice and
friendly and behaved themselves.

12
00:00:46,190 --> 00:00:48,710
It didn't have security built into it.

13
00:00:48,710 --> 00:00:50,740
Really it was just the Wild West.

14
00:00:50,740 --> 00:00:54,200
Now we have to take precautions to try and
secure things.

15
00:00:54,200 --> 00:00:55,440
In the email world,

16
00:00:55,440 --> 00:00:59,550
there's really three legs of
the journey that have to be secured.

17
00:00:59,550 --> 00:01:03,588
There's the journey from your client
machine to Google's servers, right?

18
00:01:03,588 --> 00:01:06,780
So that would be like me firing up
a web browser and going to Gmail,

19
00:01:06,780 --> 00:01:08,940
logging in, and writing my email, right?

20
00:01:08,940 --> 00:01:10,600
So that's client to Google.

21
00:01:11,630 --> 00:01:15,730
Then, you've got the email
passing from Google servers

22
00:01:15,730 --> 00:01:18,110
to the destination server, right?

23
00:01:18,110 --> 00:01:21,600
So when it passes across the internet, by
default that's plain text, and so we need

24
00:01:21,600 --> 00:01:25,820
to secure that connection between Google
and whoever we're sending our email to.

25
00:01:25,820 --> 00:01:29,940
And then the third leg of that journey
is from that destination email server

26
00:01:29,940 --> 00:01:30,730
to the recipient.

27
00:01:30,730 --> 00:01:35,390
So the person who's receiving
the email and reading it, okay?

28
00:01:35,390 --> 00:01:40,700
We can actually control security on two
out of those three legs, all right.

29
00:01:40,700 --> 00:01:45,950
We can control security between our
clients and the Google servers and

30
00:01:45,950 --> 00:01:50,820
we can control security between the Google
server and the destination SMTP server.

31
00:01:50,820 --> 00:01:55,430
But we can't control security from the
destination email server to their client.

32
00:01:55,430 --> 00:01:57,590
It's up to them to configure that.

33
00:01:57,590 --> 00:02:02,550
So there's no real way with email to
provide end-to-end connection-based

34
00:02:02,550 --> 00:02:03,500
security.

35
00:02:03,500 --> 00:02:04,500
If you want that,

36
00:02:04,500 --> 00:02:08,620
you've got to use technologies like S/MIME
which are all client-based technologies,

37
00:02:08,620 --> 00:02:11,750
a little outside of the scope
of what Google Apps does.

38
00:02:11,750 --> 00:02:15,120
But on the server side, there's some
things we can do to help secure emails

39
00:02:15,120 --> 00:02:19,240
to at least ensure that the emails we're
sending internally are secure, all right?

40
00:02:19,240 --> 00:02:22,380
Step one, let's take a look
at the email client, right?

41
00:02:22,380 --> 00:02:25,480
Our end users are going to Gmail and
logging in and

42
00:02:25,480 --> 00:02:27,300
accessing their account, all right?

43
00:02:27,300 --> 00:02:28,770
Well, for

44
00:02:28,770 --> 00:02:34,090
the most part, Google has switched to
an SSL everywhere type configuration.

45
00:02:34,090 --> 00:02:37,940
So for most people, when they go to Gmail,
it's automatically going to be SSL.

46
00:02:37,940 --> 00:02:39,750
But it's not actually enforced.

47
00:02:39,750 --> 00:02:43,724
They could override it and do a non-secure
connection if they really wanted to.

48
00:02:43,724 --> 00:02:47,037
So we can configure that right
here in our admin console.

49
00:02:47,037 --> 00:02:51,902
If you go into your admin console and
go to More Controls and Security,

50
00:02:51,902 --> 00:02:57,360
inside of Security you've got basic
settings and you'll see right here.

51
00:02:57,360 --> 00:02:58,550
SSL.

52
00:02:58,550 --> 00:03:03,670
Automatically enforce SSL connections
when users sign into any Google Apps.

53
00:03:03,670 --> 00:03:08,985
Not just Gmail, but the add-in console,
it uses SSL anyway.

54
00:03:08,985 --> 00:03:12,525
But even the other services,
like Blogger and YouTube, and so

55
00:03:12,525 --> 00:03:15,245
on, it's gonna make sure
that we use SSL there, too.

56
00:03:15,245 --> 00:03:19,295
So we're protecting our clients Wwen
they connect up to a Google App service,

57
00:03:19,295 --> 00:03:20,815
they'll use SSL.

58
00:03:20,815 --> 00:03:23,555
So I'm gonna check that off
to ensure that's happening.

59
00:03:23,555 --> 00:03:26,525
Now, it's probably already happening for
your users,

60
00:03:26,525 --> 00:03:28,880
cuz it's kind of the default for
a lot of apps.

61
00:03:28,880 --> 00:03:31,630
But to prevent it from being overridden,
we can turn it on here and

62
00:03:31,630 --> 00:03:34,200
that'll make sure that it's enforced,
all right?

63
00:03:34,200 --> 00:03:38,080
You can even see where I was using HTTPS
up here already, even though I hadn't

64
00:03:38,080 --> 00:03:41,740
checked that option, and that's because
Google defaults to being secure.

65
00:03:41,740 --> 00:03:46,110
So, that's the client side or
end users connected to Gmail.

66
00:03:46,110 --> 00:03:47,740
What about server-to-server?

67
00:03:47,740 --> 00:03:51,470
So the Gmail servers connecting
to the third party email servers.

68
00:03:51,470 --> 00:03:54,100
Well, SMTP doesn't have
security built into it so

69
00:03:54,100 --> 00:03:58,365
there's not much we can do there,
but they have created

70
00:03:58,365 --> 00:04:03,100
add-ons to SMTP that allow us
to encrypt those communications,

71
00:04:03,100 --> 00:04:08,240
and the most common of them is called TLS,
or Transport Layer Security.

72
00:04:08,240 --> 00:04:13,000
What TLS does is it uses SSL, the same
security method that we're using to

73
00:04:13,000 --> 00:04:18,220
connect to the web pages, it uses SSL
with your email connection, with SMTP.

74
00:04:18,220 --> 00:04:21,840
So, if your server that you're reaching
out to, the destination server,

75
00:04:21,840 --> 00:04:26,060
if they have an SSL certificate
attached to their SMTP service,

76
00:04:26,060 --> 00:04:28,630
we can use that to encrypt communications.

77
00:04:28,630 --> 00:04:32,840
Most email providers have that these days,
but some don't, all right?

78
00:04:32,840 --> 00:04:35,450
There's some email systems where they
just don't care about security, or

79
00:04:35,450 --> 00:04:37,270
aren't worried about it or
whatever, and for

80
00:04:37,270 --> 00:04:39,360
whatever reason they don't
have the certificate.

81
00:04:39,360 --> 00:04:42,025
So what we can do is we can go into our
system and we can say, you know what?

82
00:04:42,025 --> 00:04:43,250
We require that.

83
00:04:43,250 --> 00:04:46,342
We require email communications
between Google and

84
00:04:46,342 --> 00:04:49,680
that destination server to have a cell,
to use TLS.

85
00:04:49,680 --> 00:04:50,940
And if they don't, we won't send.

86
00:04:52,010 --> 00:04:55,020
Or, you can do it on
a per domain basis and

87
00:04:55,020 --> 00:04:58,650
you can say emails going to this domain,
going to this server, we'll use TLS.

88
00:04:58,650 --> 00:05:02,580
The other ones, use it if you can,
don't use it if they don't have it, right?

89
00:05:02,580 --> 00:05:04,670
And that's kind of the default in Google.

90
00:05:04,670 --> 00:05:08,010
In the Google servers, they'll use
the certificates if they're there.

91
00:05:08,010 --> 00:05:10,230
So if it can use TLS, it'll do it.

92
00:05:10,230 --> 00:05:14,240
But if TLS fails, the default is to go
ahead and send it unencrypted, right?

93
00:05:14,240 --> 00:05:15,720
So that's what it's going to do.

94
00:05:15,720 --> 00:05:16,840
We can override that behavior.

95
00:05:17,920 --> 00:05:20,762
To override that behavior, we need
to go back into our Gmail settings.

96
00:05:20,762 --> 00:05:23,978
I'm in the general security settings here,
I need to go into Gmail.

97
00:05:23,978 --> 00:05:28,076
So, I'm gonna go to my admin console and
Google Apps, and

98
00:05:28,076 --> 00:05:33,782
then in here I'll go into Gmail, and
I'm gonna go down to my Advanced Settings.

99
00:05:36,623 --> 00:05:40,160
And in my Advanced Settings, I'm looking
for a section called Compliance.

100
00:05:41,630 --> 00:05:44,190
Now if you've watched some of our other
shows, you might have seen the segment

101
00:05:44,190 --> 00:05:48,130
where I talk about email routing, and
we can configure it in email routing, too.

102
00:05:48,130 --> 00:05:50,650
But if you want this to be general,
to affect all the servers,

103
00:05:50,650 --> 00:05:53,010
you're just looking for
the Compliance section.

104
00:05:53,010 --> 00:05:57,690
And down here I'll find Compliance,
and inside of Compliance you'll find

105
00:05:57,690 --> 00:06:03,160
a section about TLS,
Secure Transport Compliance, all right?

106
00:06:03,160 --> 00:06:05,940
And we can configure this and
see what it's described as.

107
00:06:05,940 --> 00:06:09,050
Require TLS when communicating
with the specific domains.

108
00:06:09,050 --> 00:06:10,900
So we can go into Configure, and

109
00:06:10,900 --> 00:06:15,870
we can add in servers that we want to
configure to communicate with securely.

110
00:06:15,870 --> 00:06:19,360
If you did this under the routing,
this is actually the same screen,

111
00:06:19,360 --> 00:06:23,640
except it's filtered out some of the
options that all I have is the TLS side.

112
00:06:23,640 --> 00:06:27,060
So we can enforce this for
inbound or outbound or both.

113
00:06:27,060 --> 00:06:29,022
So I could say all of my emails and

114
00:06:29,022 --> 00:06:33,020
then I could specify the servers
that I want to correspond with that.

115
00:06:33,020 --> 00:06:35,990
So, this is ITProTV.net.

116
00:06:35,990 --> 00:06:38,870
We've also got ITPro.tv,
and so maybe I wanna say,

117
00:06:38,870 --> 00:06:44,890
anytime I communicate to ITPro.tv,
we need to use TLS, all right?

118
00:06:44,890 --> 00:06:46,120
And, so I can come in and

119
00:06:46,120 --> 00:06:49,160
specify that, and so
I'm gonna put in here this is ITProTV.

120
00:06:49,160 --> 00:06:52,080
Any inbound and outbound messages
that are going to that domain.

121
00:06:52,080 --> 00:06:53,320
So I'll need do a list.

122
00:06:53,320 --> 00:06:55,135
So I'll hit, Use Existing or
Create a New One.

123
00:06:55,135 --> 00:06:58,660
And I've got a list from before, but
I don't remember what's in it, so

124
00:06:58,660 --> 00:06:59,810
I'm gonna create a new one.

125
00:07:02,780 --> 00:07:05,190
And I'll just call it the ITProTV Domain.

126
00:07:06,960 --> 00:07:13,400
And I'm gonna edit that and
I'll add in just the ITPro.tv domain.

127
00:07:13,400 --> 00:07:15,820
So any time I send an email or

128
00:07:15,820 --> 00:07:20,200
I receive an email from ITPro.tv,
I'm gonna require TLS.

129
00:07:20,200 --> 00:07:22,860
I've got it checked up here,
I'm gonna require TLS.

130
00:07:22,860 --> 00:07:25,750
The most important option though
is this one here at the bottom.

131
00:07:25,750 --> 00:07:29,650
Google is already going to
use TLS if it's supported.

132
00:07:29,650 --> 00:07:32,900
It's only if it fails,
that it'll switch to unencrypted.

133
00:07:32,900 --> 00:07:36,200
The bottom option is the one that says,
don't do that, right?

134
00:07:36,200 --> 00:07:38,470
If TLS fails, just don't accept the email.

135
00:07:38,470 --> 00:07:40,570
Don't allow it to come in.

136
00:07:40,570 --> 00:07:41,900
If you're not gonna set that,

137
00:07:41,900 --> 00:07:44,430
if you leave that off, you might
as well not even create the rule,

138
00:07:44,430 --> 00:07:47,350
because it's already behaving
the way that you're configuring it.

139
00:07:47,350 --> 00:07:49,260
So, it's kind of a waste of time.

140
00:07:49,260 --> 00:07:52,600
But, if you check that off,
now it'll require it.

141
00:07:52,600 --> 00:07:58,090
If we send to that server and TLS is not
supported, then we won't send the email.

142
00:07:58,090 --> 00:07:59,360
We'll stop and that's it.

143
00:07:59,360 --> 00:08:00,590
The email will bounce.

144
00:08:00,590 --> 00:08:05,430
And it's better to have it bounce than to
send it across the internet unencrypted.

145
00:08:05,430 --> 00:08:09,300
Now once it makes it to that other server,
they could be mishandling it over there.

146
00:08:09,300 --> 00:08:11,690
It could be sent unencrypted
on their network.

147
00:08:11,690 --> 00:08:12,860
Who knows, right?

148
00:08:12,860 --> 00:08:14,370
We don't have control over that.

149
00:08:14,370 --> 00:08:18,580
But for our side, we've done everything
we can to enforce that security.

150
00:08:18,580 --> 00:08:23,210
So when I add that setting in, now I've
got SSL being enforced for that domain.

151
00:08:23,210 --> 00:08:27,150
And I could add more domains in there, or
particular email addresses, whatever it is

152
00:08:27,150 --> 00:08:30,530
that I need, and that's gonna enforce
the TLS side of things there.

153
00:08:30,530 --> 00:08:32,630
So, setting up security.

154
00:08:32,630 --> 00:08:33,630
It's pretty easy, right?

155
00:08:33,630 --> 00:08:34,990
That wasn't very hard.

156
00:08:34,990 --> 00:08:36,260
But it's not perfect.

157
00:08:36,260 --> 00:08:40,590
It doesn't give you end-to-end,
client-to-client encryption.

158
00:08:40,590 --> 00:08:42,270
But it takes care of
everything that we can.

159
00:08:42,270 --> 00:08:45,590
Our client to the server,
our server to their server,

160
00:08:45,590 --> 00:08:48,890
and then it's up to them to protect
their server to their client.

161
00:08:48,890 --> 00:08:52,830
And again, if you need that, if you need
true end-to-end, you're gonna need to use

162
00:08:52,830 --> 00:08:58,150
something like S/MIMEor PGP, GPG,
any of those programs where your end

163
00:08:58,150 --> 00:09:02,030
user encrypts the message body and that
way the email can be sent in plain text.

164
00:09:02,030 --> 00:09:04,826
You don't care,
because the body is already encrypted.

165
00:09:04,826 --> 00:09:06,728
The servers don't have
anything to do with it, right?

166
00:09:06,728 --> 00:09:10,985
That's the only true way to
get good end-to-end security.

167
00:09:10,985 --> 00:09:15,571
All right, so in this segment we got a
chance to look at configuring required SSL

168
00:09:15,571 --> 00:09:19,882
for accessing our Google App services and
then we took a look at doing TLS for

169
00:09:19,882 --> 00:09:22,460
email server to email server encryption.

170
00:09:22,460 --> 00:09:25,609
Both great ideas,
things that we want running, and for

171
00:09:25,609 --> 00:09:28,023
the most part on by
default in Google Apps.

172
00:09:28,023 --> 00:09:29,636
All right,
I hope you guys enjoyed the segment.

173
00:09:29,636 --> 00:09:33,130
Stay tuned,
we have more Google Apps coming up.

174
00:09:33,130 --> 00:09:39,244
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Manage Compliance Settings
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,201 --> 00:00:07,321
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07,321 --> 00:00:11,804
Objective 4.4 focuses
on content compliance.

3
00:00:11,804 --> 00:00:15,149
The official title is demonstrate
how to filter messages

4
00:00:15,149 --> 00:00:19,940
based on general compliance settings,
content and attachment settings.

5
00:00:19,940 --> 00:00:24,490
And what that boils down to is looking
at the emails that are passing through

6
00:00:24,490 --> 00:00:26,420
your system, and determining whether or

7
00:00:26,420 --> 00:00:30,990
not they should be allowed through
based on certain criteria that you set.

8
00:00:30,990 --> 00:00:32,360
And we call that compliance.

9
00:00:32,360 --> 00:00:34,840
Is it complaint with
the policy you define?

10
00:00:34,840 --> 00:00:37,300
Now, where does that policy come from?

11
00:00:37,300 --> 00:00:38,270
It depends.

12
00:00:38,270 --> 00:00:42,300
A lot of organizations have,
city, state, government,

13
00:00:42,300 --> 00:00:47,190
national government regulations they have
to meet up to or just legal obligations,

14
00:00:47,190 --> 00:00:50,800
liabilities, and things of that nature,
that dictate whether or

15
00:00:50,800 --> 00:00:53,900
not certain contents should be
allowed to pass through your system.

16
00:00:53,900 --> 00:00:57,920
Now, a lot of companies don't
take any action on this,

17
00:00:57,920 --> 00:01:00,480
they just let it ride and that's fine.

18
00:01:00,480 --> 00:01:05,400
But for many organizations, they're very
proactive in preventing the transmittal

19
00:01:05,400 --> 00:01:10,400
of documents containing things like foul
language or personal details or whatever.

20
00:01:10,400 --> 00:01:14,180
And so you can modify the compliance
settings inside of Google Apps,

21
00:01:14,180 --> 00:01:15,370
to help control that.

22
00:01:15,370 --> 00:01:18,000
It's pretty neat, and
there's actually a lot of options.

23
00:01:18,000 --> 00:01:22,010
The objective itself really focuses on
the content filtering but I wanna show you

24
00:01:22,010 --> 00:01:25,305
guys each of the different compliance
settings that are in there.

25
00:01:25,305 --> 00:01:27,820
So what we're gonna do is we're
gonna take a look at that, and

26
00:01:27,820 --> 00:01:30,390
let me just get my desktop
shared out here real quick.

27
00:01:30,390 --> 00:01:32,720
There we go, all right, so we're
gonna take a look at that real quick.

28
00:01:32,720 --> 00:01:39,610
And what we'll do is we're gonna go
into Google Apps, and into our Gmail.

29
00:01:39,610 --> 00:01:43,090
And I need to get into compliance,
which is under Advanced Settings.

30
00:01:43,090 --> 00:01:45,530
And you can use the little link
down here at the bottom, or

31
00:01:45,530 --> 00:01:49,650
you can just hit User Settings at the top,
they actually go to the same screen.

32
00:01:49,650 --> 00:01:51,570
And once I'm in there,

33
00:01:51,570 --> 00:01:55,420
we can scroll down until we find
the section that says, Compliance.

34
00:01:55,420 --> 00:01:59,060
So we're just kind of keep looking,
there was user, end user settings,

35
00:01:59,060 --> 00:02:03,180
end user access, and spam, compliance.

36
00:02:03,180 --> 00:02:05,380

specify all sorts of things,

262
00:14:32,280 --> 00:14:35,540
like particular attachment types
that you wanna block or allow.

263
00:14:35,540 --> 00:14:40,380
They've got pre built ones in here, for
pictures, music, videos, and so on or

264
00:14:40,380 --> 00:14:42,830
you can type your own file extensions.

265
00:14:42,830 --> 00:14:46,465
The file type is just down
by an extension, though.

266
00:14:46,465 --> 00:14:48,735
And so
this can be a little easy to defeat.

267
00:14:48,735 --> 00:14:52,065
Somebody can just change the file
extension and they can get around it.

268
00:14:52,065 --> 00:14:56,125
For that, if we wanna be really detailed,
we need something like MIME types,

269
00:14:56,125 --> 00:14:57,690
which it doesn't do.

270
00:14:57,690 --> 00:15:01,680
But filename is another one we can
just look for particular filenames or

271
00:15:01,680 --> 00:15:02,940
message sizes.

272
00:15:02,940 --> 00:15:08,440
You could block emails that are over a
certain size and strip their attachments.

273
00:15:08,440 --> 00:15:10,020
Stripping the attachment
is what you normally do.

274
00:15:10,020 --> 00:15:11,840
If you look down here
in the modify options,

275
00:15:11,840 --> 00:15:14,630
you'll see attachments, remove attachment.

276
00:15:14,630 --> 00:15:18,050
So you can strip it out and put a little
note in here that it was Stripped out.

277
00:15:18,050 --> 00:15:21,840
That way the email still gets through,
but the attachment was stripped out.

278
00:15:21,840 --> 00:15:24,460
The alternative would be not
to strip the attachment but

279
00:15:24,460 --> 00:15:27,450
to reject the email as a whole.

280
00:15:27,450 --> 00:15:30,606
And so we could do that and
just not send it along or reroute it or

281
00:15:30,606 --> 00:15:33,062
whatever it was that we
wanted to do from there.

282
00:15:33,062 --> 00:15:40,200
All right, so those are the ones
that deal with content, right?

283
00:15:40,200 --> 00:15:42,040
Our content filtering.

284
00:15:42,040 --> 00:15:45,300
You'll notice that as I went into there,
there weren't any default settings.

285
00:15:45,300 --> 00:15:47,190
We have to put them in ourselves.

286
00:15:47,190 --> 00:15:49,520
So if you wanna create
an objectionable word list, or

287
00:15:49,520 --> 00:15:51,600
whatever- You're going to
need to make that list.

288
00:15:51,600 --> 00:15:55,680
Still to get with your HR department or
your CIO or whoever, and come up with

289
00:15:55,680 --> 00:15:59,160
that list of words that are going to be
banned will be to get them put in there.

290
00:15:59,160 --> 00:16:02,240
Same thing goes for any other criteria
here that we want to block on.

291
00:16:02,240 --> 00:16:04,910
We're basically just
acting on behest of our

292
00:16:04,910 --> 00:16:06,300
HR department is how it normally works.

293
00:16:06,300 --> 00:16:08,880
They tell us the criteria,
we set up the filter.

294
00:16:10,882 --> 00:16:14,670
All right so in this segment we got
a chance to see the compliance settings

295
00:16:14,670 --> 00:16:18,710
inside of Google apps and some of
the different filters that were available.

296
00:16:18,710 --> 00:16:21,380
Quite a few different things
from appending footers

297
00:16:21,380 --> 00:16:24,140
to restricting attachments,
quite a bit of stuff in there.

298
00:16:24,140 --> 00:16:25,521
It's really neat, really useful, and

299
00:16:25,521 --> 00:16:27,353
definitely something you
should take advantage of.

300
00:16:27,353 --> 00:16:29,338
All right,
well I hope you enjoyed the segment.

301
00:16:29,338 --> 00:16:32,742
Stay tuned we've got more
Google apps coming up.

302
00:16:32,742 --> 00:16:39,359
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Creating a Shared Calendar
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,008 --> 00:00:05,897
[SOUND] Objective 5.1 covers creating

2
00:00:05,897 --> 00:00:13,007
a shared calendar inside
of your organization.

3
00:00:13,007 --> 00:00:17,393
When you set up Google Apps and you start
creating your user accounts in there,

4
00:00:17,393 --> 00:00:20,660
a personal calendar is created for
every single account.

5
00:00:21,760 --> 00:00:23,940
That's fine, right,
if that's all you need, you're done.

6
00:00:23,940 --> 00:00:25,400
You actually don't have to lift a finger.

7
00:00:25,400 --> 00:00:28,230
The personal calendars are there and
you're in business.

8
00:00:28,230 --> 00:00:32,190
But the whole point of having
a collaboration platform like Google Apps

9
00:00:32,190 --> 00:00:33,880
is being able to share data.

10
00:00:33,880 --> 00:00:37,410
And so one of the common activities
of a company is to create a single

11
00:00:37,410 --> 00:00:39,160
centralized calendar.

12
00:00:39,160 --> 00:00:41,650
This been shared out
amongst the employees.

13
00:00:41,650 --> 00:00:44,080
That way they can all see
what each other is doing

14
00:00:44,080 --> 00:00:46,190
very easily right there
in one big calendar.

15
00:00:47,350 --> 00:00:48,260
That may not be for you,

16
00:00:48,260 --> 00:00:52,040
you may want to do a mixture where
people have their personal calendars.

17
00:00:52,040 --> 00:00:56,230
But then you have a company calendar that
manages various corporate wide events.

18
00:00:56,230 --> 00:00:59,800
Like days off and other company events.

19
00:00:59,800 --> 00:01:03,580
Or you might do like us at ITProTV,
we have countless number of calendars.

20
00:01:03,580 --> 00:01:06,000
So each employee has their own calendar.

21
00:01:06,000 --> 00:01:08,850
Then we have our company calendar
where we track events and

22
00:01:08,850 --> 00:01:11,320
vacations, sick days things like that.

23
00:01:11,320 --> 00:01:14,585
And then we have our show calendar
where we keep track of what show is on

24
00:01:14,585 --> 00:01:15,810
which days.

25
00:01:15,810 --> 00:01:20,680
Each calendar is separate so that we
can control the sharing aspect of it.

26
00:01:20,680 --> 00:01:25,180
So for example our episode calendar,
we share that out with the public, anybody

27
00:01:25,180 --> 00:01:28,890
can see that one cause we want you to know
what episodes we're filming and what days.

28
00:01:28,890 --> 00:01:33,110
But then our vacation calendar where
we check employee vacations we don't

29
00:01:33,110 --> 00:01:36,272
post that to everybody because
you guys don't care about that.

30
00:01:36,272 --> 00:01:38,030
[LAUGH].
And so we don't want to make that public.

31
00:01:38,030 --> 00:01:39,520
So it's on a private calendar.

32
00:01:39,520 --> 00:01:43,030
Creating multiple calendars allows you
to tweak the sharing aspect of it,

33
00:01:43,030 --> 00:01:46,750
and that's the real value of
a collaboration platform like Google Apps.

34
00:01:46,750 --> 00:01:48,160
All right.

35
00:01:48,160 --> 00:01:51,030
So before we get to
working with calendars,

36
00:01:51,030 --> 00:01:55,000
it's important that we adjust
the default sharing settings.

37
00:01:55,000 --> 00:01:57,560
In Google Apps, there's some default
sharing settings that are in place,

38
00:01:57,560 --> 00:02:00,250
and every time you create a new calendar,

39
00:02:00,250 --> 00:02:03,610
the sharing settings are copied
from this default kind of template.

40
00:02:03,610 --> 00:02:04,110
All right?

41
00:02:05,420 --> 00:02:10,270
If we go and change these settings after
the calendars are created, it's too late.

42
00:02:10,270 --> 00:02:14,640
The default settings only apply
when a new calendar is created.

43
00:02:14,640 --> 00:02:16,510
For existing calendars,
if we wanna go back and

44
00:02:16,510 --> 00:02:21,020
bulk update them, you've got to either do
it by hand or do it through API calls,

45
00:02:21,020 --> 00:02:28,080
the Advanced Program Interface to reach
in and make those changes in the system.

46
00:02:28,080 --> 00:02:30,560
So obviously that's not ideal for
a lot of people.

47
00:02:30,560 --> 00:02:34,310
We want to make sure we get the default
setting in place from the beginning.

48
00:02:34,310 --> 00:02:40,750
So in my admin console, I'm gonna go to
Google Apps and then I'll go to Calendar.

49
00:02:40,750 --> 00:02:43,980
And it's right here in the Calendar that
I'll see my sharing settings, right here,

50
00:02:43,980 --> 00:02:45,890
and that's what I want to work with.

51
00:02:45,890 --> 00:02:49,690
When we go into the sharing settings,
these are gonna be the default sharing

52
00:02:49,690 --> 00:02:53,070
settings for new calendars to
get created in my environment.

53
00:02:53,070 --> 00:02:56,110
So these settings right here we can tweak,

54
00:02:56,110 --> 00:03:00,110
they're not going to affect any calendar
I've already got, just the new ones.

55
00:03:00,110 --> 00:03:03,670
The first section or
the external sharing options, and

56
00:03:03,670 --> 00:03:07,940
notice how it says external sharing
options for primary calendars.

57
00:03:07,940 --> 00:03:10,440
What the heck is a primary calendar?

58
00:03:10,440 --> 00:03:13,240
Every time you create a user account,
they get,

59
00:03:13,240 --> 00:03:14,780
I called it a personal
account a minute ago,

60
00:03:14,780 --> 00:03:19,420
right, it's a calendar attached to their
account, that's their primary calendar.

61
00:03:19,420 --> 00:03:23,400
So for all of your users,
the default is, well,

62
00:03:23,400 --> 00:03:26,560
people outside of ITProTV,
that's my organization.

63
00:03:26,560 --> 00:03:32,680
So people outside of your organization can
just see free, busy data, and that's it.

64
00:03:32,680 --> 00:03:34,320
Free busy data and nothing else.

65
00:03:34,320 --> 00:03:38,580
So if I have an appointment
tomorrow from 3 PM to 4 PM and

66
00:03:38,580 --> 00:03:42,600
one of you out there in internet
land were to access my calendar,

67
00:03:42,600 --> 00:03:45,580
you would just see that I'm
busy between 3 and 4 PM.

68
00:03:45,580 --> 00:03:48,220
You wouldn't see what it was,
what I was doing.

69
00:03:48,220 --> 00:03:50,410
You would just that I was
busy during that time.

70
00:03:50,410 --> 00:03:51,720
That's the default.

71
00:03:51,720 --> 00:03:52,990
We may not want that.

72
00:03:52,990 --> 00:03:54,040
We may want to tweak that.

73
00:03:54,040 --> 00:03:56,700
Or, maybe I do want you
guys to be able to see it.

74
00:03:56,700 --> 00:03:58,750
We can kind of do various things.

75
00:03:58,750 --> 00:04:02,710
Like share all information, but
outsiders cannot change it.

76
00:04:02,710 --> 00:04:05,380
So now, you guys will be
able to see my calendar and

77
00:04:05,380 --> 00:04:07,110
you'd be able to see the appointment.

78
00:04:07,110 --> 00:04:09,420
But you wouldn't be able to modify it.

79
00:04:09,420 --> 00:04:14,010
Or we could say, you can see
the appointment and you can modify it.

80
00:04:14,010 --> 00:04:18,620
Now, why the heck would I want to
allow the internet to modify my own

81
00:04:18,620 --> 00:04:19,975
personal calendar?

82
00:04:19,975 --> 00:04:21,745
Normally you wouldn't, right.

83
00:04:21,745 --> 00:04:25,635
But, if you've got some kind of
an event and you're inviting people and

84
00:04:25,635 --> 00:04:29,005
allowing them to accept the invitation and
be listed on there as attending and

85
00:04:29,005 --> 00:04:31,845
you want them to put in notes, then
something like this becomes very handy.

86
00:04:33,165 --> 00:04:34,815
The last option is the most dangerous.

87
00:04:34,815 --> 00:04:38,415
It's share all information and
allow managing of calendars.

88
00:04:38,415 --> 00:04:40,935
So now, they could go in there and
change the calendar itself

89
00:04:40,935 --> 00:04:43,930
as far as changing who it's shared with or
even delete the calendar.

90
00:04:43,930 --> 00:04:45,980
And we're typically not
going to want that option.

91
00:04:48,560 --> 00:04:50,930
All right,
the next one is internal sharing,

92
00:04:50,930 --> 00:04:56,010
that was external sharing with people
outside of your Google Apps organization.

93
00:04:56,010 --> 00:04:59,990
But internal sharing, that's gonna be for
well, your internal employees, the people

94
00:04:59,990 --> 00:05:05,070
who have accounts in Google Apps and the
default here is to share all information.

95
00:05:05,070 --> 00:05:07,770
Other employees can see
exactly what I have scheduled

96
00:05:07,770 --> 00:05:10,790
from 3 to 4 PM tomorrow where
I'm going to be, all right?

97
00:05:10,790 --> 00:05:14,840
But we can change that to only free busy,
or to no sharing.

98
00:05:14,840 --> 00:05:16,900
Now remember, this is the default.

99
00:05:16,900 --> 00:05:20,010
Users can go and
change these after the fact if they want.

100
00:05:20,010 --> 00:05:22,180
They can modify the calendar
to whatever setting they want.

101
00:05:22,180 --> 00:05:25,460
So you usually want to set this
to be the most restrictive and

102
00:05:25,460 --> 00:05:27,000
allow people to open it up as desired.

103
00:05:29,080 --> 00:05:32,100
You've also got the ability to turn
on Video Calls and Calendar Labs.

104
00:05:32,100 --> 00:05:33,590
These are additional features.

105
00:05:33,590 --> 00:05:37,160
When you create an event on your calendar,
you can attach a Video Call to it.

106
00:05:37,160 --> 00:05:40,010
So when you invite people to it and
it's time for that meeting,

107
00:05:40,010 --> 00:05:43,480
they can all quickly fire up
a Google Hangout, a video conference.

108
00:05:43,480 --> 00:05:44,510
To carry off that meeting.

109
00:05:44,510 --> 00:05:47,350
It's a neat feature, but
you can disable that.

110
00:05:47,350 --> 00:05:48,990
Same thing with Calendar Labs.

111
00:05:48,990 --> 00:05:52,050
Those are labs features, the experimental
features for the calendar.

112
00:05:52,050 --> 00:05:55,150
You can choose whether you wanna turn
those on or off for your organization.

113
00:05:57,210 --> 00:06:01,500
All right, now notice how it
was our primary calendar.

114
00:06:01,500 --> 00:06:03,560
What about our secondary calendars?

115
00:06:03,560 --> 00:06:06,680
Secondary calendars are any
other calendar you create.

116
00:06:06,680 --> 00:06:10,710
If I wanna create a single calendar
that's shared across my entire company,

117
00:06:10,710 --> 00:06:13,890
I don't want that to be tied to my
account because, what if I get fired?

118
00:06:13,890 --> 00:06:15,390
Right?
Now my account goes away and

119
00:06:15,390 --> 00:06:16,740
that calendar goes away.

120
00:06:16,740 --> 00:06:20,320
So we wanna create a shared
calendar that everybody can get to.

121
00:06:20,320 --> 00:06:25,240
Well, any custom calendars that you
create are secondary calendars.

122
00:06:25,240 --> 00:06:27,822
And they're not covered by
the settings right here.

123
00:06:27,822 --> 00:06:28,870
All right?

124
00:06:28,870 --> 00:06:31,540
The settings here, and
remember how I got to this, right,

125
00:06:31,540 --> 00:06:36,480
I went from my admin panel and
I went to Google Apps,

126
00:06:36,480 --> 00:06:41,010
I went to Calendar, and
then I went in to Sharing settings, right?

127
00:06:41,010 --> 00:06:44,360
That's where I got in to
modify the primary calendar.

128
00:06:45,740 --> 00:06:49,820
For the secondary settings, I actually
have to go back to my calendar page.

129
00:06:49,820 --> 00:06:52,480
And that was under Sharing settings.

130
00:06:52,480 --> 00:06:55,850
Now I'm going to down
here to General settings.

131
00:06:55,850 --> 00:07:01,150
Under General settings, is where we'll
see options for our secondary calendars.

132
00:07:01,150 --> 00:07:02,310
And the options are the same.

133
00:07:02,310 --> 00:07:03,780
Let me move this over a little bit.

134
00:07:03,780 --> 00:07:05,960
You'll see external sharing options,
and then,

135
00:07:05,960 --> 00:07:09,340
here it is, Only free/busy,
share data and they can change.

136
00:07:09,340 --> 00:07:14,630
It's the same as the sharing for a primary
calendar, it's just in a different place.

137
00:07:14,630 --> 00:07:16,630
It's moved off to a different location,
and

138
00:07:16,630 --> 00:07:18,240
we can adjust the default values there.

139
00:07:20,600 --> 00:07:21,260
All right.

140
00:07:21,260 --> 00:07:23,600
So those are the settings
as far as my calendars.

141
00:07:23,600 --> 00:07:26,610
Now when I start to create them,
they're going to have those settings, and

142
00:07:26,610 --> 00:07:27,720
I can override them as needed.

143
00:07:29,630 --> 00:07:30,940
All right.
So next,

144
00:07:30,940 --> 00:07:36,360
let's take a look at actually
getting a shared calendar in place.

145
00:07:36,360 --> 00:07:37,000
Okay.

146
00:07:37,000 --> 00:07:38,701
If I want to create a shared calendar,

147
00:07:38,701 --> 00:07:41,316
the first thing I need to do is
to log into Google calendar.

148
00:07:41,316 --> 00:07:46,692
And you'll see right here it has
the URL that you can use, and it's

149
00:07:46,692 --> 00:07:51,698
just www.google.com/calendar/hosted/your
domain.

150
00:07:51,698 --> 00:07:52,302
All right.

151
00:07:52,302 --> 00:07:53,904
That's a long URL.

152
00:07:53,904 --> 00:07:57,100
You might want to change that,
and you can hit edit and

153
00:07:57,100 --> 00:08:00,950
modify what that URL is that your
users are going to be typing in.

154
00:08:00,950 --> 00:08:03,160
And you'll see where you
can set up a custom one,

155
00:08:03,160 --> 00:08:06,780
like I could do calendar.itprotv.net.

156
00:08:06,780 --> 00:08:10,435
Now, they don't mention it here, but
you actually get to it by just going to

157
00:08:10,435 --> 00:08:14,870
calendar.google.com, also, and
you'll go in and have access to it.

158
00:08:14,870 --> 00:08:19,620
But this is the official URL to be able
to browse in and gain access to that.

159
00:08:19,620 --> 00:08:24,620
If I set one of these shortcuts, I'll need
to go modify my DNS records to contain

160
00:08:24,620 --> 00:08:29,600
a record that will point
right back to this other URL.

161
00:08:29,600 --> 00:08:31,970
They give instructions
to that right there.

162
00:08:31,970 --> 00:08:34,300
But I'm gonna go ahead and
browse into my calendar.

163
00:08:37,060 --> 00:08:40,190
And when I get logged in,
I'm already authenticated, so

164
00:08:40,190 --> 00:08:41,480
I didn't get prompted in again.

165
00:08:41,480 --> 00:08:42,810
So it'll take me right in.

166
00:08:42,810 --> 00:08:46,280
And here I am, and under my calendars,
I'll see Don Pezet.

167
00:08:46,280 --> 00:08:47,589
That's my primary calendar.

168
00:08:48,590 --> 00:08:50,660
That's the personal calendar
that was created just for

169
00:08:50,660 --> 00:08:53,460
me when my user account was created.

170
00:08:53,460 --> 00:08:57,090
And so it's already got the various
settings copied from that default.

171
00:08:57,090 --> 00:08:59,100
Well not the ones we just
changed a minute ago, but

172
00:08:59,100 --> 00:09:02,910
from when it was set when my user
account was originally created.

173
00:09:02,910 --> 00:09:06,840
And you can always click on that and
you'll see Share this calendar.

174
00:09:08,240 --> 00:09:09,520
And when you go in to Share this calendar,

175
00:09:09,520 --> 00:09:12,860
you'll see where you can modify
how that calendar is handled.

176
00:09:12,860 --> 00:09:14,920
Right off,
it's share this calendar with others, and

177
00:09:14,920 --> 00:09:17,630
you can choose to make
the calendar public.

178
00:09:17,630 --> 00:09:20,860
You can allow external
people to see your calendar.

179
00:09:20,860 --> 00:09:25,180
And you can choose whether they just
see the free busy data or whatever.

180
00:09:25,180 --> 00:09:28,160
Same thing with share this calendar
with everyone in the organization.

181
00:09:28,160 --> 00:09:30,070
That's all the internal people.

182
00:09:30,070 --> 00:09:33,320
It's set to see all event details
because that was the default but

183
00:09:33,320 --> 00:09:36,051
I can change that to override
the settings if I desire.

184
00:09:38,978 --> 00:09:44,260
We'll also see in here where we can
delegate access for that calendar.

185
00:09:44,260 --> 00:09:47,210
Just because this is a personal
calendar doesn't mean I'm the only

186
00:09:47,210 --> 00:09:48,660
one that may need it.

187
00:09:48,660 --> 00:09:50,490
I may want, maybe I've got an assistant.

188
00:09:50,490 --> 00:09:53,190
I've been asking for
an assistant since this company started.

189

My other end users,

That's adding it by a URL.

So several different ways for them to

But once it's added,

So if we wanna get rid of it, you've
