episodes.title: Manage Calendar Resources
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,045 --> 00:00:05,292
[SOUND]

2
00:00:08,044 --> 00:00:10,731
Objective 5.2 covers Creating, and

3
00:00:10,731 --> 00:00:13,300
Managing Calendar Resources.

4
00:00:13,300 --> 00:00:15,570
Now, what is a Calendar Resource?

5
00:00:15,570 --> 00:00:18,300
When we create a Calendar, what we're
normally doing is we're scheduling

6
00:00:18,300 --> 00:00:22,050
events that we as a person
need to participate in.

7
00:00:22,050 --> 00:00:25,560
But often times there's objects,
equipment, rooms,

8
00:00:25,560 --> 00:00:29,270
facilities, things like that,
that are associated with the events also.

9
00:00:29,270 --> 00:00:30,970
For example, if I'm gonna have a meeting,

10
00:00:30,970 --> 00:00:33,890
I might invite five employees here
from the company to this meeting.

11
00:00:33,890 --> 00:00:35,750
I need all of them to get together.

12
00:00:35,750 --> 00:00:38,190
But where's the meeting going to be?

13
00:00:38,190 --> 00:00:41,380
Well, I've got Aware Field in the event,
I can plug it in there.

14
00:00:41,380 --> 00:00:45,680
But what if I scheduled two meetings
in the same room, at the same time?

15
00:00:45,680 --> 00:00:48,360
Maybe, I schedule a meeting
with our director, and

16
00:00:48,360 --> 00:00:51,530
meanwhile one of the other hosts
schedules a meeting with our producer,

17
00:00:51,530 --> 00:00:53,270
in the same room at the same time.

18
00:00:53,270 --> 00:00:54,680
We've double-booked.

19
00:00:54,680 --> 00:00:58,660
So, it's nice to be able
to track our resources too.

20
00:00:58,660 --> 00:01:01,090
We see this really commonly
with conference rooms.

21
00:01:01,090 --> 00:01:03,450
Which you can avoid
double-booking a conference room.

22
00:01:03,450 --> 00:01:07,521
But we also see it with equipment, things
like shared laptops, shared projectors, or

23
00:01:07,521 --> 00:01:08,950
things of that nature.

24
00:01:08,950 --> 00:01:13,570
We can use those as resources, so that
people can reserve them for certain times.

25
00:01:14,630 --> 00:01:20,090
Any kind of object that you want to have
reservations for, is a Calendar Resource.

26
00:01:20,090 --> 00:01:23,600
Now, when you set up Google Apps,
by default there are no resources.

27
00:01:23,600 --> 00:01:26,750
You don't even see the options for
it, but it's all just kind of hidden.

28
00:01:26,750 --> 00:01:30,730
We need to go in and define
the resources that our organization has.

29
00:01:30,730 --> 00:01:33,080
And then they'll become available for
us to use.

30
00:01:33,080 --> 00:01:34,720
Now, one word of advice.

31
00:01:34,720 --> 00:01:37,560
Now, I'm sure I'll run into it here,
when I set it up.

32
00:01:37,560 --> 00:01:42,050
When you set up your resource accounts,
they take a little while to synchronize,

33
00:01:42,050 --> 00:01:45,380
and allow Google Calendar
to see that they exist.

34
00:01:45,380 --> 00:01:48,530
And the problem is that they're tied to
these use accounts that you're not built

35
00:01:48,530 --> 00:01:53,060
for, and that means they have to be
created a slightly different way.

36
00:01:53,060 --> 00:01:56,330
So if you're in a hurry
to get something setup,

37
00:01:56,330 --> 00:02:00,800
don't rely on Google Resources right away,
or in your Calendar Resources right away.

38
00:02:00,800 --> 00:02:04,426
But if you're planning for this, and
you're setting your environment up,

39
00:02:04,426 --> 00:02:06,950
definitely [INAUDIBLE]
there are great thing.

40
00:02:06,950 --> 00:02:09,710
Just don't rush it,
it won't work quite right.

41
00:02:09,710 --> 00:02:12,350
And we'll see that here
cuz I am going to rush it.

42
00:02:12,350 --> 00:02:15,550
So [LAUGH] let's say,
I wanna create some resources.

43
00:02:15,550 --> 00:02:20,070
Well I'll go into my Admin console,
and into Google Apps.

44
00:02:20,070 --> 00:02:22,620
And I'll go into Calendar.

45
00:02:22,620 --> 00:02:26,260
And right here on my main Calendar page,
I'm gonna see Resources.

46
00:02:26,260 --> 00:02:29,820
And here's that chance for me to create
all these different resources for

47
00:02:29,820 --> 00:02:30,910
whatever it is that we need.

48
00:02:30,910 --> 00:02:33,310
Any kind of shared equipment.

49
00:02:33,310 --> 00:02:36,750
So, I'll go over here, and
choose to create a New rRsource,

50
00:02:36,750 --> 00:02:40,350
and we really just need to give it one
piece of information, which is a name.

51
00:02:40,350 --> 00:02:44,530
But, it's a good idea to give it a second
piece of information, which is a type.

52
00:02:44,530 --> 00:02:48,510
It's like a category,
an easy way to filter the resources.

53
00:02:48,510 --> 00:02:50,340
If you've just got two,
or three resources,

54
00:02:50,340 --> 00:02:52,630
you probably won't mess with the type,
it doesn't matter.

55
00:02:52,630 --> 00:02:54,530
But, if you've got hundreds of resources,

56
00:02:54,530 --> 00:02:57,181
your end-users will be able to
use the type to filter them out.

57
00:02:57,181 --> 00:03:00,012
So, I might have three conference rooms.

58
00:03:00,012 --> 00:03:03,405
So, I might have Room 201, and

59
00:03:03,405 --> 00:03:08,440
I'm gonna set that with
a type of Conference Room.

60
00:03:08,440 --> 00:03:12,877
So that one's gonna be a Conference Room,
and it's just Room 201.

61
00:03:12,877 --> 00:03:15,290
So I'll go ahead, and hit Save.

62
00:03:15,290 --> 00:03:18,790
And I'll go ahead, and create another
resource, and maybe this will be Room 108,

63
00:03:18,790 --> 00:03:22,410
which will also be a Conference Room.

64
00:03:24,340 --> 00:03:27,090
And then I'll go in, and
add some other room, Room 327,

65
00:03:27,090 --> 00:03:29,700
which will be a Conference Room.

66
00:03:31,840 --> 00:03:33,760
And then I'll just go ahead,
and add just one more.

67
00:03:33,760 --> 00:03:35,151
I'm gonna add Projector 1.

68
00:03:35,151 --> 00:03:38,750
Which I will just classify as Equipments.

69
00:03:41,990 --> 00:03:45,630
Now, if they don't show up right away,
don't sweat it.

70
00:03:45,630 --> 00:03:48,570
Just give it a moment,
it sometimes takes a moment to refresh.

71
00:03:48,570 --> 00:03:49,850
But there they go.

72
00:03:49,850 --> 00:03:52,430
So now, I've got my rooms.

73
00:03:52,430 --> 00:03:54,190
And my projector right there.

74
00:03:54,190 --> 00:03:57,410
So Room 108, Room 327,
Room 201, and Projector 1,

75
00:03:57,410 --> 00:03:59,880
and their Resource type right here.

76
00:04:01,060 --> 00:04:05,550
So now, that I've got those Resources,
I'm ready to book them.

77
00:04:05,550 --> 00:04:07,380
Well, not exactly.

78
00:04:07,380 --> 00:04:09,510
These resources that we just created.

79
00:04:09,510 --> 00:04:11,210
They're basically user accounts.

80
00:04:11,210 --> 00:04:13,080
They're user accounts that we don't see.

81
00:04:13,080 --> 00:04:18,890
If we go out here to our Users,
and we look at our User list.

82
00:04:18,890 --> 00:04:20,270
We'll see all the users,
and our employees.

83
00:04:20,270 --> 00:04:22,330
But we don't see those resource accounts,
do we?

84
00:04:22,330 --> 00:04:25,280
That's because they're special accounts,
they're hidden.

85
00:04:25,280 --> 00:04:28,190
But they've got a Calendar
attached to each one of them.

86
00:04:28,190 --> 00:04:30,790
And in order to use the Resource accounts.

87
00:04:30,790 --> 00:04:34,910
We have to share their Calendar, with
anybody we want to be able to book them.

88
00:04:34,910 --> 00:04:38,110
So, if I want somebody to
be able to book Room 201,

89
00:04:38,110 --> 00:04:40,870
I need to share Room
201's Calendar with them.

90
00:04:40,870 --> 00:04:43,070
I need to delegate out those privileges.

91
00:04:43,070 --> 00:04:46,080
If I don't do that,
if I don't share it out,

92
00:04:46,080 --> 00:04:50,740
when any user goes to book Room 201,
it will show as always being busy.

93
00:04:50,740 --> 00:04:54,390
24 hours a day, 7 days a week,
it'll always show as busy.

94
00:04:54,390 --> 00:04:57,830
So if I stop right here,
I kind of wasted my time.

95
00:04:57,830 --> 00:05:00,940
The resources exist, but
only I as a super-admin,

96
00:05:00,940 --> 00:05:02,830
will be able to schedule them.

97
00:05:02,830 --> 00:05:05,470
So my next step is gonna be
to delegate permissions to

98
00:05:05,470 --> 00:05:08,080
those resources to allow other
people to schedule them.

99
00:05:08,080 --> 00:05:12,973
And the way we do that is by enabling on
their Calendar to allow other people to

100
00:05:12,973 --> 00:05:14,511
see the event details.

101
00:05:14,511 --> 00:05:18,191
Not just see free busy data, but actually
see the event details on that resource.

102
00:05:18,191 --> 00:05:19,712
So, that's gonna be my next step.

103
00:05:19,712 --> 00:05:24,251
I'm gonna jump over to Google Calendar,
so I'm logged in here as my super-admin.

104
00:05:24,251 --> 00:05:28,578
And I need to add the Calendars for
each of those resources here, so

105
00:05:28,578 --> 00:05:30,830
I can then go, and delegate them.

106
00:05:30,830 --> 00:05:34,383
So down here under Other Calendars,
I'm gonna click that dropdown arrow, and

107
00:05:34,383 --> 00:05:36,200
choose Browse Interesting Calendars.

108
00:05:37,210 --> 00:05:39,360
And hopefully,
I've stalled enough that it shows up.

109
00:05:39,360 --> 00:05:41,130
It does take a minute to sync.

110
00:05:41,130 --> 00:05:44,078
I'm gonna go to More, and
I should see a new entry right there.

111
00:05:44,078 --> 00:05:46,353
Resources for itprotv.net.

112
00:05:46,353 --> 00:05:48,660
That's what I was hoping to see.

113
00:05:48,660 --> 00:05:50,160
And notice, there's no subscribe button.

114
00:05:50,160 --> 00:05:52,300
That's because there's
more than one resource.

115
00:05:52,300 --> 00:05:55,706
If I click on that,
it's gonna show me the resources, and

116
00:05:55,706 --> 00:05:58,290
I just need to subscribe
to each one of them.

117
00:05:58,290 --> 00:06:00,912
Subscribing to them is
gonna add them to my list.

118
00:06:00,912 --> 00:06:04,377
And looks like I have a little
problem there with 108,

119
00:06:04,377 --> 00:06:06,770
let me just subscribe to the other one.

120
00:06:06,770 --> 00:06:08,180
I might've clicked it too fast,

121
00:06:08,180 --> 00:06:11,280
there's a little loading blurb that pops
up there in the top-right corner, and

122
00:06:11,280 --> 00:06:14,850
if you click Subscribe while it's still up
there, it gets a little angry with you.

123
00:06:14,850 --> 00:06:16,170
So, let me try that one again.

124
00:06:16,170 --> 00:06:17,200
There we go.

125
00:06:17,200 --> 00:06:21,010
So, I'm subscribed to
each of those objects.

126
00:06:21,010 --> 00:06:25,880
If I go back to my Calendar,
I've now got Projector 1, Room 108, 201,

127
00:06:25,880 --> 00:06:27,300
327, all, right there.

128
00:06:28,690 --> 00:06:31,110
Now, I need to go, and
delegate out permissions.

129
00:06:31,110 --> 00:06:33,760
Once I've delegated permissions,
I can remove these Calendars from my list.

130
00:06:33,760 --> 00:06:36,610
I don't have to keep them attached,
but just to delegate them out,

131
00:06:36,610 --> 00:06:38,420
I need to add them in like this.

132
00:06:38,420 --> 00:06:41,373
So I can go to one of these,
so I'll go to this room, and

133
00:06:41,373 --> 00:06:43,380
I can choose to Share this calendar.

134
00:06:44,480 --> 00:06:47,500
And I'm gonna pick,
who I wanna share it with.

135
00:06:47,500 --> 00:06:49,730
Notice the room, it got an email address.

136
00:06:50,820 --> 00:06:52,080
It is a user account.

137
00:06:52,080 --> 00:06:55,130
It's got an email address, just like any
of us, and that's how it's being tracked.

138
00:06:55,130 --> 00:06:57,110
It just doesn't show up
as a user in my system.

139
00:06:58,220 --> 00:07:00,790
And right here I've got,
Share this calendar with others.

140
00:07:00,790 --> 00:07:04,130
And it sets the people can
see all the event details.

141
00:07:04,130 --> 00:07:06,080
That makes it seem like we're done.

142
00:07:06,080 --> 00:07:09,590
But you really got to share it with
specific people to get this to

143
00:07:09,590 --> 00:07:10,640
work properly.

144
00:07:10,640 --> 00:07:13,470
So, I'm gonna go down here, and
I'll pick some other people.

145
00:07:13,470 --> 00:07:16,780
And now, I don't have to put myself,
If I try, it'll get mad at me.

146
00:07:16,780 --> 00:07:20,580
But I do need to put other people so
I'm gonna give access, so

147
00:07:20,580 --> 00:07:24,910
I'll get him added, and you need to make
sure they have see all event details.

148
00:07:24,910 --> 00:07:28,550
You can give them more, like make changes
to event, and to make changes, and

149
00:07:28,550 --> 00:07:29,740
manage sharing.

150
00:07:29,740 --> 00:07:32,730
That will allow them to delegate
out to other people too.

151
00:07:32,730 --> 00:07:34,210
You might want them to have that access,

152
00:07:34,210 --> 00:07:36,930
you can specify whatever
it is you need right there.

153
00:07:39,160 --> 00:07:42,360
And basically, we just go down the line,
and do that for each of the resources.

154
00:07:42,360 --> 00:07:45,520
Every time you create a new resource,
you'll delegate it out.

155
00:07:45,520 --> 00:07:46,620
One trick I like to use,

156
00:07:46,620 --> 00:07:50,885
if you want everybody to be able to
reserve it, is you can create a group.

157
00:07:50,885 --> 00:07:54,225
And I know we haven't filmed our segment
on groups yet, we'll do that soon.

158
00:07:54,225 --> 00:07:57,405
But you can create a group for
all the employees.

159
00:07:57,405 --> 00:08:00,665
And when you delegate out, just delegate
it out to that all employees group.

160
00:08:00,665 --> 00:08:05,575
And that way all employees now, and in the
future when you hire them, will be added,

161
00:08:05,575 --> 00:08:07,685
and will have access to be able
to delegate out this resource,

162
00:08:07,685 --> 00:08:09,355
or be able to assign it to an event.

163
00:08:11,130 --> 00:08:13,480
Now, here's the part that may, or

164
00:08:13,480 --> 00:08:16,340
may not work right off,
because I haven't given it enough time.

165
00:08:16,340 --> 00:08:18,620
I've got an event here, like Don's event.

166
00:08:18,620 --> 00:08:21,330
And Don's event does not
currently have a Where.

167
00:08:21,330 --> 00:08:23,110
It doesn't have a location.

168
00:08:23,110 --> 00:08:26,470
And it doesn't have any
resources attached to it either.

169
00:08:26,470 --> 00:08:28,814
So, I don't know what room it's in,
or projector, or so on.

170
00:08:28,814 --> 00:08:33,350
Once those resources have time to
synchronize, over here where I've got Add

171
00:08:33,350 --> 00:08:37,347
guests, what you'll see is this
will actually turn into two tabs.

172
00:08:37,347 --> 00:08:40,333
You'll have a tab that says Add guests,
and

173
00:08:40,333 --> 00:08:45,440
you'll have another tab that'll say Rooms,
comma, et cetera, or etc.

174
00:08:45,440 --> 00:08:49,380
And you'll click on that rooms etc,
and then you'll be able to search, and

175
00:08:49,380 --> 00:08:50,040
find your rooms.

176
00:08:51,050 --> 00:08:52,813
Now, just because they
aren't showing up yet,

177
00:08:52,813 --> 00:08:54,770
it doesn't mean that you can't use them.

178
00:08:54,770 --> 00:08:57,250
You could actually click
here on Add guests, and

179
00:08:57,250 --> 00:08:59,080
if you start typing, there they are.

180
00:09:00,170 --> 00:09:02,870
So, I can see Room 201, 327, 108.

181
00:09:02,870 --> 00:09:04,780
They show up right here.

182
00:09:04,780 --> 00:09:07,740
It's just they haven't synchronized
the system to add that tab yet.

183
00:09:07,740 --> 00:09:10,450
It'll appear sometime
in the next 24 hours.

184
00:09:10,450 --> 00:09:12,060
But I'll pick Room 201.

185
00:09:12,060 --> 00:09:14,270
Now, it knows it's a room.

186
00:09:14,270 --> 00:09:15,380
See what it did?

187
00:09:15,380 --> 00:09:18,050
It just changed it to the Where.

188
00:09:18,050 --> 00:09:19,158
But look at that name.

189
00:09:19,158 --> 00:09:21,050
[LAUGH] That's a serious name.

190
00:09:21,050 --> 00:09:22,760
When it's properly
synchronized in the system,

191
00:09:22,760 --> 00:09:24,460
that'll actually show up as Room 201.

192
00:09:24,460 --> 00:09:26,510
It'll show up as the proper thing.

193
00:09:26,510 --> 00:09:29,660
But since, I'm forcing it along at
a faster rate than it's used to,

194
00:09:29,660 --> 00:09:31,660
that's why it's showing up
kind of strange like that.

195
00:09:32,910 --> 00:09:34,024
So now, I've got a room attached.

196
00:09:34,024 --> 00:09:37,189
When you've got the rooms comma etc tab,
you can click it, and

197
00:09:37,189 --> 00:09:39,294
you can choose the projector, and so on.

198
00:09:39,294 --> 00:09:44,720
And those will become Equipment Resources
that are attached to this meeting.

199
00:09:44,720 --> 00:09:47,450
And now, when people get this invitation,
when they see this meeting,

200
00:09:47,450 --> 00:09:49,750
they'll say oh this is in Room 201.

201
00:09:49,750 --> 00:09:53,160
And if somebody else tries to
book Room 201 for this meeting,

202
00:09:53,160 --> 00:09:56,400
or at the same time,
it'll say that that one is busy.

203
00:09:56,400 --> 00:09:57,760
That they won't be able to book it.

204
00:09:57,760 --> 00:10:00,140
And they'll say, all right,
let me pick one of the other rooms.

205
00:10:00,140 --> 00:10:00,810
I'll pick Room 327.

206
00:10:02,070 --> 00:10:03,480
Maybe that one's available.

207
00:10:03,480 --> 00:10:08,080
And they can pick, and choose based on
that, assuming they have that permission.

208
00:10:08,080 --> 00:10:09,690
We did the delegation.

209
00:10:09,690 --> 00:10:12,440
If not, those rooms will always show busy.

210
00:10:12,440 --> 00:10:13,770
They just wont be able to pick them.

211
00:10:15,380 --> 00:10:17,310
So, that's how the Resource accounts work.

212
00:10:17,310 --> 00:10:21,080
They're really cool, if you have any
kind of shared, or managed resource.

213
00:10:21,080 --> 00:10:25,610
The only limitation, is that if you do
something like share the permissions

214
00:10:25,610 --> 00:10:29,820
out with your whole company,
absolutely, anybody can book the room.

215
00:10:29,820 --> 00:10:32,450
So, even the lowliest employee

216
00:10:32,450 --> 00:10:36,110
versus the highest employee will
have the same amount of access.

217
00:10:36,110 --> 00:10:39,300
If me, as a IT guy,
I can go and book room 201.

218
00:10:39,300 --> 00:10:42,960
And then, the CEO wants to book Room 201.

219
00:10:42,960 --> 00:10:47,570
Well, Google Apps doesn't know
the political structure of your company.

220
00:10:47,570 --> 00:10:49,840
It just knows that, I booked it first, and

221
00:10:49,840 --> 00:10:52,700
the CEO is coming second,
CEO can't have access to that room.

222
00:10:53,940 --> 00:10:56,110
So, that's gonna make somebody mad.

223
00:10:56,110 --> 00:10:59,610
So as a super-admin,
you wanna make sure you keep that in mind.

224
00:10:59,610 --> 00:11:03,130
That you might need to go, and
override things from time to time, And

225
00:11:03,130 --> 00:11:06,250
that's where it is a good idea
to keep this Calendar linked.

226
00:11:06,250 --> 00:11:09,360
If we keep the Calendar linked,
we'll have it right here.

227
00:11:09,360 --> 00:11:14,410
And if I have a double-booking, I can go,
and pick a room, like Room 201.

228
00:11:14,410 --> 00:11:18,380
And when I go, and take a look at it,
notice in Room 201,

229
00:11:18,380 --> 00:11:21,580
let me change it's color to
something really vibrant.

230
00:11:21,580 --> 00:11:23,030
See, how I've got Don's event here.

231
00:11:23,030 --> 00:11:24,910
And Don's event is now twice.

232
00:11:24,910 --> 00:11:27,340
Don's event was actually added to Rm 201.

233
00:11:27,340 --> 00:11:29,940
So, that's how I know what's booked there.

234
00:11:29,940 --> 00:11:32,790
I could go, and remove Room 201 from it.

235
00:11:32,790 --> 00:11:35,100
And now, the CEO would go and
be able to book that room.

236
00:11:35,100 --> 00:11:38,200
And I'd need to contact who ever had it,
and say hey, guys I'm sorry.

237
00:11:38,200 --> 00:11:39,840
I've got to yank that room,
we need it for something else.

238
00:11:39,840 --> 00:11:41,620
You can book a different room.

239
00:11:41,620 --> 00:11:43,665
And then they can go, and
choose based on that.

240
00:11:43,665 --> 00:11:45,830
S,o Resources make that helpful.

241
00:11:45,830 --> 00:11:49,880
They really stop that
double-booking of conference rooms.

242
00:11:49,880 --> 00:11:53,770
And I didn't even do the equipment side,
like projectors, laptops,

243
00:11:53,770 --> 00:11:55,040
other equipment that's there.

244
00:11:55,040 --> 00:11:56,850
You can have nice little reservations,

245
00:11:56,850 --> 00:11:59,390
to ensure that people have
equal access to the equipment.

246
00:12:00,770 --> 00:12:05,450
So in this segment, we got a chance to see
creating shared resources in Google Apps.

247
00:12:05,450 --> 00:12:09,410
Delegating permissions out, so that people
will be able to assign them to events, and

248
00:12:09,410 --> 00:12:12,540
then actually assigning to an event,
and getting in place.

249
00:12:12,540 --> 00:12:13,660
It's a neat function.

250
00:12:13,660 --> 00:12:16,200
It's one that a lot of people overlook,
and don't use, but

251
00:12:16,200 --> 00:12:20,070
it is really cool, definitely something
you can take advantage of, and

252
00:12:20,070 --> 00:12:21,850
I only brushed the tip
of the iceberg here.

253
00:12:21,850 --> 00:12:26,780
You can track things like company cars,
and other resources like that,

254
00:12:26,780 --> 00:12:30,460
that aren't even related to a meeting, but
people need to book for certain times.

255
00:12:30,460 --> 00:12:35,020
There's a ton of power there, so
it's a neat feature to play around with.

256
00:12:35,020 --> 00:12:35,970
I hope you guys enjoyed this segment.

257
00:12:35,970 --> 00:12:38,850
Stay tuned,
more of Google Apps is coming up next.

258
00:12:38,850 --> 00:12:45,169
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Google Apps Mobile Management
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:04,701
[SOUND]

2
00:00:07,720 --> 00:00:10,710
Objective 6.1 covers managing Android and

3
00:00:10,710 --> 00:00:15,162
Google Sync devices that are connected
to your Google Apps account.

4
00:00:15,162 --> 00:00:16,522
Now when we talk about Android and

5
00:00:16,522 --> 00:00:19,390
Google Sync, what we're really
talking about are mobile devices and

6
00:00:19,390 --> 00:00:22,174
these might be tablets or cellphones,
they could be Chromebooks.

7
00:00:22,174 --> 00:00:23,566
Various things like that,

8
00:00:23,566 --> 00:00:28,210
that are using your Google Apps accounts
to connect to your Google Apps services.

9
00:00:28,210 --> 00:00:32,001
If one of these devices gets lost or
stolen or has data on it that gets leaked

10
00:00:32,001 --> 00:00:36,034
out, that's a problem and we need a way
to be able to manage and control that and

11
00:00:36,034 --> 00:00:39,606
we've got full functionality for
that right inside of Google Apps.

12
00:00:39,606 --> 00:00:43,020
Now, I find that this is one of
the most misunderstood features.

13
00:00:43,020 --> 00:00:46,418
A lot of people assume that this
device management is on by default and

14
00:00:46,418 --> 00:00:50,638
they'll have their end users connecting up
their Google accounts to their phones and

15
00:00:50,638 --> 00:00:54,522
then they'll come in and they'll find
that they're not able to manage them.

16
00:00:54,522 --> 00:00:57,840
The reason is in order to
truly manage the device,

17
00:00:57,840 --> 00:01:01,083
there's a couple of extra
steps we need to take.

18
00:01:01,083 --> 00:01:03,420
So we're gonna get a chance to see that.

19
00:01:03,420 --> 00:01:07,790
It's not uncommon to take a Google Apps
account like this one and go under device

20
00:01:07,790 --> 00:01:12,780
management and inside device
management to go to managed devices and

21
00:01:12,780 --> 00:01:16,870
not see anything, even though you know for
a fact that some of your end users

22
00:01:16,870 --> 00:01:18,859
are using their cellphone to
access their Google account.

23
00:01:20,030 --> 00:01:24,846
The reason is we need to connect one
of two ways not just for email and

24
00:01:24,846 --> 00:01:29,497
calendaring, but for actual MDM,
Mobile Device Management.

25
00:01:29,497 --> 00:01:34,443
When you log in to email,
you can log in with IMAP or POP3.

26
00:01:34,443 --> 00:01:37,473
When you connect to Google Calender,
you can connect directly to it.

27
00:01:37,473 --> 00:01:41,699
That doesn't give us the ability
to remotely erase a device.

28
00:01:41,699 --> 00:01:44,814
Believe it or not, they didn't build
that into the calendar protocol and

29
00:01:44,814 --> 00:01:46,620
IMAP definitely didn't have it.

30
00:01:46,620 --> 00:01:49,490
So a lot of the protocols we use for
communications,

31
00:01:49,490 --> 00:01:53,280
don't provide that support and that's why
the devices don't show up right here,

32
00:01:53,280 --> 00:01:55,200
cuz it's not built into those protocols.

33
00:01:56,450 --> 00:01:57,723
The old way to do this,

34
00:01:57,723 --> 00:02:01,813
to get the connectivity in place was
to use a technology from Microsoft.

35
00:02:01,813 --> 00:02:04,240
Microsoft had a technology
called ActiveSync.

36
00:02:04,240 --> 00:02:06,281
And when a device used ActiveSync,

37
00:02:06,281 --> 00:02:11,315
ActiveSync would give them access to their
email, to their calendar, to their notes,

38
00:02:11,315 --> 00:02:16,008
to all those various things and it would
also hook up the administration console,

39
00:02:16,008 --> 00:02:18,618
so that we could block and
erase the devices.

40
00:02:18,618 --> 00:02:21,637
All the little buttons up here
would light up, if we had that.

41
00:02:21,637 --> 00:02:25,282
Well, the problem it was
Microsoft technology.

42
00:02:25,282 --> 00:02:28,455
So Google, instead of reinventing
the wheel on the beginning,

43
00:02:28,455 --> 00:02:30,819
just licensed the technology
from Microsoft.

44
00:02:30,819 --> 00:02:36,416
They called it Google Sync, but it really
is Microsoft ActiveSync under the hood.

45
00:02:36,416 --> 00:02:38,860
So when we go to configure
device management,

46
00:02:38,860 --> 00:02:41,501
we'll see settings that
pertain to Google Sync.

47
00:02:41,501 --> 00:02:46,627
And the official exam for this one,
if you look is demonstrate how to use

48
00:02:46,627 --> 00:02:52,020
Google Apps Mobile Management to manage
Android and Google Sync devices.

49
00:02:52,020 --> 00:02:57,968
And a Google Sync device is really any
device that can run Microsoft Activesync

50
00:02:57,968 --> 00:03:03,569
and that's going to be iOS, iPhones and
iPads can do it, Windows Phone.

51
00:03:03,569 --> 00:03:07,057
So if you have a Windows mobile phone,
even the really old ones like

52
00:03:07,057 --> 00:03:11,315
Windows Phone 6, they can do it and
BlackBerries, BlackBerry 10 and above.

53
00:03:11,315 --> 00:03:12,198
They can do it.

54
00:03:12,198 --> 00:03:13,827
And you don't have to know it for
the exam,

55
00:03:13,827 --> 00:03:15,970
they're not going to give you
a mobile device to setup.

56
00:03:15,970 --> 00:03:19,375
But in the show notes for this episode,
I'll include links to how to

57
00:03:19,375 --> 00:03:23,099
configure each one of those,
if you're actually setting up the device.

58
00:03:23,099 --> 00:03:26,164
But basically, you just run through
their little ActiveSync wizard.

59
00:03:26,164 --> 00:03:29,469
You specify your server,
which is your Google Apps connection and

60
00:03:29,469 --> 00:03:32,608
they put in their user name and
password and it sets the rest up.

61
00:03:32,608 --> 00:03:36,104
They'll have email,
calendaring, notes, tasks,

62
00:03:36,104 --> 00:03:38,536
all that stuff will synchronize up and

63
00:03:38,536 --> 00:03:44,021
they'll now show up in our manage devices
screen, so we'll be able to control them.

64
00:03:44,021 --> 00:03:47,548
But Google Sync is built on
top of Microsoft ActiveSync,

65
00:03:47,548 --> 00:03:49,245
it's a licensed feature.

66
00:03:49,245 --> 00:03:53,679
And obviously, Google doesn't want you
to keep using that if there's something

67
00:03:53,679 --> 00:03:57,291
better and the something better
is the native Google Apps client.

68
00:03:57,291 --> 00:04:00,867
Many operating systems today,
actually have native support for

69
00:04:00,867 --> 00:04:02,240
Google Apps built-in.

70
00:04:02,240 --> 00:04:03,748
Android, obviously has it.

71
00:04:03,748 --> 00:04:08,446
As Google's flagship OS, you can expect
it to be there, but even iOS and

72
00:04:08,446 --> 00:04:12,154
some other phones are starting
to have it built-in too.

73
00:04:12,154 --> 00:04:15,245
So we don't necessarily
need Google Sync anymore,

74
00:04:15,245 --> 00:04:18,064
if we can make use of
a native Google connector.

75
00:04:18,064 --> 00:04:21,908
You can see this on like an iOS
device when you go to add an account.

76
00:04:21,908 --> 00:04:24,727
And actually, I think one of those
URLs I've got here shows it.

77
00:04:24,727 --> 00:04:29,232
Let me pull this one up and
I'll show you what I mean.

78
00:04:29,232 --> 00:04:33,110
When we go to add a device
like a iOS device, so

79
00:04:33,110 --> 00:04:36,385
they kinda show the step by step here.

80
00:04:36,385 --> 00:04:39,193
See, how they're going into
mail contacts and calendars.

81
00:04:39,193 --> 00:04:43,293
They're going into Add Accounts and
they're choosing Microsoft Exchange.

82
00:04:43,293 --> 00:04:46,403
Why are they choosing Microsoft Exchange,
if they're connecting to Google?

83
00:04:46,403 --> 00:04:49,412
Well, Microsoft Exchange uses ActiveSync.

84
00:04:49,412 --> 00:04:54,090
And so they're really saying, I wanna use
ActiveSync to connect up to Google Apps.

85
00:04:54,090 --> 00:04:56,349
And instead of specifying
an exchange server,

86
00:04:56,349 --> 00:04:58,777
they'll specify the Google Apps
server to do it and

87
00:04:58,777 --> 00:05:02,057
ActiveSync will give us the ability
to manage that device remotely.

88
00:05:02,057 --> 00:05:07,014
But you'll see, you don't actually
have to do it, beneath it is Google.

89
00:05:07,014 --> 00:05:09,185
I could choose Google, won't that do it?

90
00:05:09,185 --> 00:05:11,357
And sadly, the answer is no.

91
00:05:11,357 --> 00:05:12,005
No, it won't.

92
00:05:12,005 --> 00:05:16,997
When you choose Google right there, it's
actually setting up an IMAP connection and

93
00:05:16,997 --> 00:05:20,672
it's not doing a true remotely
managed system or connection,

94
00:05:20,672 --> 00:05:22,776
at least not in this version of iOS.

95
00:05:22,776 --> 00:05:23,982
This is iOS 6 here.

96
00:05:23,982 --> 00:05:26,854
But in newer versions of iOS,
like iOS 7 and 8,

97
00:05:26,854 --> 00:05:30,711
that Google option does include
the mobile device management and

98
00:05:30,711 --> 00:05:34,168
it will show up in the list and
you can remote wipe and so on.

99
00:05:34,168 --> 00:05:38,337
On older Android phones that didn't have
it, you can actually go in the App Store

100
00:05:38,337 --> 00:05:41,854
and get it, the Google Device
Management App, you'd install it.

101
00:05:41,854 --> 00:05:45,772
And that's what would connect the remote
wipe and other information, so

102
00:05:45,772 --> 00:05:49,813
that extra step to get the Google native
client on there to be able to manage it

103
00:05:49,813 --> 00:05:50,845
with Google apps.

104
00:05:50,845 --> 00:05:53,307
So, it's kind of important.

105
00:05:53,307 --> 00:05:58,737
Once we got that set on our client though,
the client will connect up and we'll

106
00:05:58,737 --> 00:06:04,186
see it right here in this list and I'll
just show you guys a quick example here.

107
00:06:04,186 --> 00:06:08,145
Like here is some of my old phones
connected to an account and so

108
00:06:08,145 --> 00:06:10,897
I've got my Asus PadFone X and Galaxy S3.

109
00:06:10,897 --> 00:06:12,453
Apparently, I've got two of them.

110
00:06:12,453 --> 00:06:14,392
I can see the devices here in the list.

111
00:06:14,392 --> 00:06:16,740
I've got them connected
not with Google Sync,

112
00:06:16,740 --> 00:06:19,036
I'm using the native
Google client on those.

113
00:06:19,036 --> 00:06:22,855
They're connected, I can see them, I see
the device IDs and I can manage them,

114
00:06:22,855 --> 00:06:25,363
because they're now
considered a managed device.

115
00:06:25,363 --> 00:06:31,408
Now the mobile device management piece of
Google Apps is super easy to configure,

116
00:06:31,408 --> 00:06:33,955
mostly because it's already on.

117
00:06:33,955 --> 00:06:36,056
It's turned on, we don't have to tweak it.

118
00:06:36,056 --> 00:06:37,694
We just need to connect the device.

119
00:06:37,694 --> 00:06:40,097
So connecting the device is
really the challenging part.

120
00:06:40,097 --> 00:06:43,336
We just need to make sure we use
the right settings and get that in place.

121
00:06:43,336 --> 00:06:46,610
But on the server, there are a few
things that you can adjust.

122
00:06:46,610 --> 00:06:49,238
You'll see the device
management settings and

123
00:06:49,238 --> 00:06:53,715
this is where we set our default policies
and there's a lot of good stuff in here.

124
00:06:53,715 --> 00:06:57,117
Things like,
whether we even want to allow Google Sync.

125
00:06:57,117 --> 00:07:00,891
You can choose to block that and
just allow the native sync or

126
00:07:00,891 --> 00:07:04,153
you can choose to leave it on and
have it available.

127
00:07:04,153 --> 00:07:07,973
You'll see Android has a native client and
iOS has native clients.

128
00:07:07,973 --> 00:07:09,412
So those are turned on by default.

129
00:07:09,412 --> 00:07:12,365
I didn't have to turn these on,
they're already on,

130
00:07:12,365 --> 00:07:14,755
then you can see some
of the other settings.

131
00:07:14,755 --> 00:07:16,914
Do you want to allow Google Glass?

132
00:07:16,914 --> 00:07:17,611
Maybe you don't.

133
00:07:17,611 --> 00:07:20,815
You've got the option to turn it on or
off and then your password settings.

134
00:07:20,815 --> 00:07:22,371
These are great.

135
00:07:22,371 --> 00:07:25,795
Many, many people don't bother
setting a pin number on their phone.

136
00:07:25,795 --> 00:07:27,734
And that means if anybody
finds their phone,

137
00:07:27,734 --> 00:07:31,322
they'll have access to that person's email
account and that's not a good thing.

138
00:07:31,322 --> 00:07:34,097
So here,
you can set to require a password.

139
00:07:34,097 --> 00:07:37,604
How many chances they can get to
enter it in before the phone locks.

140
00:07:37,604 --> 00:07:40,065
How often we require them to change it.

141
00:07:40,065 --> 00:07:43,742
You'll see other device settings,
like whether we can force encryption,

142
00:07:43,742 --> 00:07:45,810
whether we allow them to use their camera,

143
00:07:45,810 --> 00:07:48,866
we can turn that camera functionality
off and other settings.

144
00:07:48,866 --> 00:07:50,782
A lot of good stuff to be found in here.

145
00:07:50,782 --> 00:07:53,998
You will see notes throughout though, but

146
00:07:53,998 --> 00:07:57,399
some of these will say,
only applies to iOS.

147
00:07:57,399 --> 00:08:00,001
So, it doesn't apply to an Android phone.

148
00:08:00,001 --> 00:08:04,163
Or other ones, like this one here
is an Android setting, but it says,

149
00:08:04,163 --> 00:08:05,445
also applies to iOS.

150
00:08:05,445 --> 00:08:07,582
So, it applies to both Android and iOS.

151
00:08:07,582 --> 00:08:11,535
So just be aware that not every setting
is supported on every device and

152
00:08:11,535 --> 00:08:13,746
it'll always tell you which is which.

153
00:08:13,746 --> 00:08:17,635
Now you can browse through, there's a lot
of neat stuff in here that's useful.

154
00:08:17,635 --> 00:08:20,758
I like this one,
Add a Server Certificate Authority.

155
00:08:20,758 --> 00:08:25,266
If you have your own private CA, if you
have your own public key infrastructure,

156
00:08:25,266 --> 00:08:28,910
you can take the root cert of that CA and
push it out to the phones and

157
00:08:28,910 --> 00:08:31,925
now they'll trust
the certificates that you issue.

158
00:08:31,925 --> 00:08:35,650
That's super handy for a lot of this
technology, cuz it's using SSL under

159
00:08:35,650 --> 00:08:39,490
the hood to encrypt its data and you don't
necessarily wanna have to go out and

160
00:08:39,490 --> 00:08:43,292
buy public certificates for all this
stuff when you can just issue your own.

161
00:08:43,292 --> 00:08:46,949
These are all different things that
companies have to think about when they

162
00:08:46,949 --> 00:08:48,122
setup mobile devices.

163
00:08:48,122 --> 00:08:53,381
It is a dangerous area, cuz it's so easy
to lose these devices to misplace them.

164
00:08:53,381 --> 00:08:56,796
And now basically, a gateway into your
corporate network is released into

165
00:08:56,796 --> 00:08:58,919
the wild and
you definitely don't want that.

166
00:08:58,919 --> 00:09:01,733
But the use of the general
policy settings,

167
00:09:01,733 --> 00:09:06,687
if your clients are not running Google
Sync or the native Google Apps client.

168
00:09:06,687 --> 00:09:09,392
If they're not running it,
these settings do doing anything.

169
00:09:09,392 --> 00:09:10,971
You're wasting your time setting these.

170
00:09:10,971 --> 00:09:14,408
For devices that are managed,
the ones that show up on your list,

171
00:09:14,408 --> 00:09:15,664
these can be enforced.

172
00:09:15,664 --> 00:09:19,845
And you'll see that option right here
to enforce the policies to ensure that

173
00:09:19,845 --> 00:09:22,606
they take effect on those
devices no matter what.

174
00:09:22,606 --> 00:09:24,894
They're going to take effect and
be on there.

175
00:09:24,894 --> 00:09:30,363
Once we get everything set the way we
want, we go ahead and save our changes.

176
00:09:30,363 --> 00:09:35,296
And now the next time that phone checks
in, it'll receive this new policy.

177
00:09:35,296 --> 00:09:38,407
Phones do not get this instantaneously.

178
00:09:38,407 --> 00:09:40,927
The reason is we don't want
to consume their battery.

179
00:09:40,927 --> 00:09:42,923
It takes battery power to go and check in.

180
00:09:42,923 --> 00:09:47,178
The phones check in periodically,
I believe it's every 90 minutes for

181
00:09:47,178 --> 00:09:47,940
the policy.

182
00:09:47,940 --> 00:09:50,621
Let me see if it' s got it in here.

183
00:09:50,621 --> 00:09:53,153
I don't see the setting,
but it's in here somewhere.

184
00:09:53,153 --> 00:09:56,261
I believe it's every 90 minutes they
check to see if the policy is updated

185
00:09:56,261 --> 00:09:56,865
and refresh.

186
00:09:56,865 --> 00:10:01,117
Email is checked way more frequently, but
the policy is just check less frequently,

187
00:10:01,117 --> 00:10:03,436
cuz it's not something
we modify very often.

188
00:10:03,436 --> 00:10:07,859
But basically, you set your setting,
you define it and it's in place.

189
00:10:07,859 --> 00:10:11,455
Like I said, when I post the show notes,
I'll make sure to include

190
00:10:11,455 --> 00:10:15,777
these links to each of the different OSes,
iOS, Windows Phone, BlackBerry.

191
00:10:15,777 --> 00:10:17,288
For Android, you've got that client,

192
00:10:17,288 --> 00:10:19,786
you can just download it right out
of the App Store and it's got it.

193
00:10:19,786 --> 00:10:23,458
For iOS, you don't even need the client
anymore and this article shows ActiveSync,

194
00:10:23,458 --> 00:10:25,549
which you don't really
even need that anymore,

195
00:10:25,549 --> 00:10:28,610
you can just go through the regular
setup and that'll have it added in.

196
00:10:28,610 --> 00:10:30,733
So couple a neat things that are there and

197
00:10:30,733 --> 00:10:33,928
that's basically mobile device
management not much to it.

198
00:10:33,928 --> 00:10:38,374
It is popular enough that all
of this is turned on by default.

199
00:10:38,374 --> 00:10:43,092
So when you have a brand new Google Apps
account, when you go into your system,

200
00:10:43,092 --> 00:10:46,895
you'll have device management
right there and so, it's on.

201
00:10:46,895 --> 00:10:49,148
It's turned on,
you can turn it off if you don't want it.

202
00:10:49,148 --> 00:10:51,470
But otherwise, it's there and
it's in place.

203
00:10:51,470 --> 00:10:52,585
One quick note.

204
00:10:52,585 --> 00:10:55,276
If you're gonna use
the Apple iOS Sync piece,

205
00:10:55,276 --> 00:10:58,250
you do need to setup a push
certificate with Apple.

206
00:10:58,250 --> 00:11:02,295
The Apple phones, they won't check in for
their policies with Google,

207
00:11:02,295 --> 00:11:04,032
they'll check in with Apple.

208
00:11:04,032 --> 00:11:07,040
So they'll reach out to Apple first and
then we have to tell Google to check in

209
00:11:07,040 --> 00:11:08,930
with Apple too and
they both meet in the middle.

210
00:11:08,930 --> 00:11:11,570
Apple is like the middleman and
that doesn't work,

211
00:11:11,570 --> 00:11:13,795
unless you have an Apple Push certificate.

212
00:11:13,795 --> 00:11:15,501
So there's a little wizard,
you can run through.

213
00:11:15,501 --> 00:11:18,799
If you're supporting those iOS devices,
you'll want to do that.

214
00:11:18,799 --> 00:11:22,556
This is just a demo account for me,
so I'm not gonna set it up here, but

215
00:11:22,556 --> 00:11:24,360
it's pretty straightforward.

216
00:11:24,360 --> 00:11:26,182
You just walk through a little wizard and
it's done.

217
00:11:26,182 --> 00:11:29,832
So in this episode, we talked a little
bit about mobile device management,

218
00:11:29,832 --> 00:11:31,954
some of the things we
needed to think about.

219
00:11:31,954 --> 00:11:35,648
And we took a look at the policy settings
in there, all sorts of really good

220
00:11:35,648 --> 00:11:39,175
settings to help manage our devices and
keep our network more secure.

221
00:11:39,175 --> 00:11:42,387
Now, if you're asking yourself, gosh,
darn, you didn't show us to erase a phone,

222
00:11:42,387 --> 00:11:43,448
that's the awesome stuff.

223
00:11:43,448 --> 00:11:46,826
Well, I know,
[LAUGH] it's gonna be in the next segment.
