episodes.title: Managing Lost Devices
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:08,042
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08,042 --> 00:00:13,080
Objective 6.2 covers how
we respond to lost devices.

3
00:00:13,080 --> 00:00:17,880
The full title is, Demonstrate How to
Reset User Access and Prevent Access From

4
00:00:17,880 --> 00:00:23,870
a Lost Mobile Device Blocking, remote
people from being able to get in our data.

5
00:00:23,870 --> 00:00:28,430
Cellphones and Ipads and
Android tablets and so on, they've got so

6
00:00:28,430 --> 00:00:33,090
much of our personal and corporate data on
them, that if you leave them in a cab, or

7
00:00:33,090 --> 00:00:35,780
you leave them on the bus,
it's a big deal.

8
00:00:35,780 --> 00:00:38,190
Your entire email account
is accessible on there so

9
00:00:38,190 --> 00:00:40,140
at a minimum that's what you're giving up.

10
00:00:40,140 --> 00:00:44,010
But you may be logged into other things,
like Facebook and Twitter.

11
00:00:44,010 --> 00:00:47,220
I know a great example,
I use a product called Hootsuite, and

12
00:00:47,220 --> 00:00:51,580
Hootsuite lets me post to our
ITPro.TV Twitter page, and Facebook.

13
00:00:51,580 --> 00:00:54,520
I hate Facebook, so
I never log in to it, and so

14
00:00:54,520 --> 00:00:58,420
I told the guys, if you want me to
post anything, you've got to give me

15
00:00:58,420 --> 00:01:00,890
something other than FaceBook to use and
so they gave me Hootsuite.

16
00:01:00,890 --> 00:01:04,120
And so I'll log into that thing and post
and it goes out to the different areas.

17
00:01:04,120 --> 00:01:05,670
If I were to lose my cell phone and

18
00:01:05,670 --> 00:01:09,430
someone got ahold of it, they could start
posting to the ITPro.TV FaceBook page.

19
00:01:09,430 --> 00:01:11,870
That would be awesome, wouldn't it?

20
00:01:11,870 --> 00:01:14,650
So, these are the kind of things
that we put ourselves at risk by

21
00:01:14,650 --> 00:01:18,400
having these smart devices that have so
much functionality.

22
00:01:18,400 --> 00:01:22,650
So when a device gets lost,
we need a way to reel that back in.

23
00:01:22,650 --> 00:01:25,750
And one of the best ways to do
that is through an MDM solution,

24
00:01:25,750 --> 00:01:27,840
a mobile device management solution.

25
00:01:27,840 --> 00:01:30,160
And there's a ton of vendors
out there that do it, but

26
00:01:30,160 --> 00:01:32,560
fortunately Google Apps
has it all built in, so

27
00:01:32,560 --> 00:01:36,000
you shouldn't need any third-party
systems to make this happen.

28
00:01:36,000 --> 00:01:40,120
We covered in another segment how to get
our devices connected into Google Apps for

29
00:01:40,120 --> 00:01:41,540
device management.

30
00:01:41,540 --> 00:01:44,160
Once they're connected in,
people just run.

31
00:01:44,160 --> 00:01:48,470
They run and that's it, there's nothing
too exciting there, but the moment

32
00:01:48,470 --> 00:01:52,730
a device is lost, the moment that the
recognize it's gone, they can reach out to

33
00:01:52,730 --> 00:01:57,080
us as an administrator and say hey I lost
my device, can you do something about it.

34
00:01:57,080 --> 00:01:59,570
And we can reach out and
start to take action.

35
00:01:59,570 --> 00:02:04,000
Maybe they've got software on there like
the Google Locator, where they can go and

36
00:02:04,000 --> 00:02:07,150
find their device and figure out
where it went, or find my iPhone.

37
00:02:07,150 --> 00:02:11,100
But barring that, if it's just gone,
we need to at a minimum,

38
00:02:11,100 --> 00:02:13,860
prevent that phone from being
able to access our network again.

39
00:02:13,860 --> 00:02:15,710
And so we've got a few choices.

40
00:02:15,710 --> 00:02:18,850
When we go into our admin console,
you can go to device management.

41
00:02:19,940 --> 00:02:23,850
And inside of device management,
you'll see managed devices right there.

42
00:02:23,850 --> 00:02:26,530
And that's gonna pull up the list
of devices that your system is

43
00:02:26,530 --> 00:02:27,580
currently managed.

44
00:02:27,580 --> 00:02:28,440
I'm in my demo account.

45
00:02:28,440 --> 00:02:30,450
Let me switch over to an active account.

46
00:02:30,450 --> 00:02:31,270
Here we go.

47
00:02:31,270 --> 00:02:34,990
So here I've go a list of mobile phones
that are attached to my account.

48
00:02:34,990 --> 00:02:38,700
So I can see some of these different
phones, an Asus phone, and

49
00:02:38,700 --> 00:02:41,890
a couple of Samsung phones right there.

50
00:02:41,890 --> 00:02:46,840
If I've lost one of those phones,
like maybe I lost my pad phone, okay?

51
00:02:46,840 --> 00:02:48,780
Well, I can take action.

52
00:02:48,780 --> 00:02:50,630
Many systems out there
just have one action,

53
00:02:50,630 --> 00:02:53,880
which is to remote wipe the phone,
so I certainly could do that.

54
00:02:53,880 --> 00:02:57,660
I could check off the device and
then up here I can hit, remote wipe.

55
00:02:57,660 --> 00:03:02,250
When I remote wipe, that's going to erase
the phone and all of the data on it.

56
00:03:02,250 --> 00:03:04,580
All right?
So it's gonna be empty and blank, so

57
00:03:04,580 --> 00:03:07,790
whoever has the phone, sure they can
go sell it on Ebay or whatever, but

58
00:03:07,790 --> 00:03:08,920
at least they don't have my data.

59
00:03:08,920 --> 00:03:11,550
They can't get connected to
my corporate environment.

60
00:03:11,550 --> 00:03:13,860
They don't have access to my email,
it's on, it's erased.

61
00:03:15,270 --> 00:03:17,960
But what if I don't think it was stolen?

62
00:03:17,960 --> 00:03:20,990
What if it's just in my house
somewhere and I can't find it so,

63
00:03:20,990 --> 00:03:25,100
I reach out the IT guys and I'm like
look I'll probably find it tonight.

64
00:03:25,100 --> 00:03:26,350
I just don't know where my phone is.

65
00:03:27,480 --> 00:03:31,050
In that situation we might want to
something just a little less drastic.

66
00:03:31,050 --> 00:03:32,890
Right?
Not erase the phone, but

67
00:03:32,890 --> 00:03:35,940
take some other type of
action to protect us.

68
00:03:35,940 --> 00:03:40,180
And for that we have two other choices,
we've got block and wipe account.

69
00:03:40,180 --> 00:03:44,160
Okay, block is one of the least invasive.

70
00:03:44,160 --> 00:03:47,620
Block says leave the phone alone,
but don't let it connect anymore.

71
00:03:47,620 --> 00:03:49,860
Don't let it connect to our
Google Apps environment.

72
00:03:49,860 --> 00:03:54,380
So any emails or calendar items or
whatever that are cached on that phone,

73
00:03:54,380 --> 00:03:57,370
yeah whoever has the phone can
get at that, the data's there.

74
00:03:57,370 --> 00:03:59,710
But they won't be able to
connect up to send email or

75
00:03:59,710 --> 00:04:01,880
receive new emails or
create calendar items.

76
00:04:01,880 --> 00:04:05,650
They won't be able to do that stuff
because they're being blocked, or

77
00:04:05,650 --> 00:04:10,100
prohibited, from accessing
the environment, all right?

78
00:04:10,100 --> 00:04:14,280
Wipe account, what it does is
instead of wiping the whole phone,

79
00:04:14,280 --> 00:04:16,140
it just removes the Google Apps account.

80
00:04:17,190 --> 00:04:20,890
It'll knock out that Google Apps account
which is your email, your calendar,

81
00:04:20,890 --> 00:04:21,900
your tasks.

82
00:04:21,900 --> 00:04:23,800
That stuff gets wiped out.

83
00:04:23,800 --> 00:04:27,450
But it leaves all your apps,
your photos, your music.

84
00:04:27,450 --> 00:04:30,080
The other things that somebody
might have copied to that phone.

85
00:04:30,080 --> 00:04:32,860
That way you don't lose your personal
photos, or other things that might be

86
00:04:32,860 --> 00:04:35,360
there, and you just turn around and
find the phone the next day.

87
00:04:35,360 --> 00:04:35,980
All right.

88
00:04:35,980 --> 00:04:38,470
So those are kind of like a middle ground.

89
00:04:38,470 --> 00:04:41,220
Block doesn't remove
anything from the phone.

90
00:04:41,220 --> 00:04:43,370
It just stops it from connecting.

91
00:04:43,370 --> 00:04:48,470
Wipe account removes the account data from
the phone and leaves everything else.

92
00:04:48,470 --> 00:04:52,860
Remote wipe wipes the whole phone,
erases everything.

93
00:04:52,860 --> 00:04:55,370
Now all three of these
are really dependent

94
00:04:55,370 --> 00:04:57,900
upon the phone reconnecting again.

95
00:04:57,900 --> 00:05:02,800
If the phone is out there in the wild and
whoever got it actually stole it and

96
00:05:02,800 --> 00:05:05,480
quick turned the wireless off or
yanked the battery out of it.

97
00:05:05,480 --> 00:05:08,760
My remote wipe or my wipe account
are never gonna make it to the phone.

98
00:05:08,760 --> 00:05:11,990
It would have to come online and
have a network signal again.

99
00:05:11,990 --> 00:05:15,370
So I lost this in my backyard and
the battery died.

100
00:05:15,370 --> 00:05:17,350
Well it's never gonna phone back in.

101
00:05:17,350 --> 00:05:18,600
So it's never gonna check.

102
00:05:18,600 --> 00:05:21,690
But is somebody finds it,
charges it up and turns it on,

103
00:05:21,690 --> 00:05:24,790
the instant it checks in,
it'll do the remote wipe.

104
00:05:24,790 --> 00:05:27,450
So even if the phone has a dead battery,

105
00:05:27,450 --> 00:05:30,550
it's still a good idea
to send the remote wipe.

106
00:05:30,550 --> 00:05:33,710
That way, whenever it is powered on,
it'll get erased.

107
00:05:33,710 --> 00:05:36,560
Odds are whoever stole it wasn't
targeting your data anyway.

108
00:05:36,560 --> 00:05:39,110
And they're just gonna wipe it
themselves so they can sell it.

109
00:05:39,110 --> 00:05:39,650
Right?

110
00:05:39,650 --> 00:05:40,840
But if it was malicious.

111
00:05:40,840 --> 00:05:42,450
If they're actually after your data,

112
00:05:42,450 --> 00:05:45,290
when they bring it online that
remote wipe will be waiting for it.

113
00:05:45,290 --> 00:05:46,039
And it'll clear it out.

114
00:05:47,430 --> 00:05:50,520
So if I take my pad phone here and
I go ahead and

115
00:05:50,520 --> 00:05:53,200
do a remote wipe,
it's gonna say, are you sure?

116
00:05:53,200 --> 00:05:56,560
We're gonna send this remote wipe and
it's gonna erase the entire phone.

117
00:05:56,560 --> 00:06:02,540
Notice that it says it'll erase any apps
as well as any data on external storage,

118
00:06:02,540 --> 00:06:03,850
such as SD cards.

119
00:06:03,850 --> 00:06:08,310
So if I have an SD card in that device
it's going to erase that too, so I need to

120
00:06:08,310 --> 00:06:12,760
make sure that that's what I want and
if it is, I can go in and wipe device.

121
00:06:12,760 --> 00:06:15,110
And then it's gonna reach out
to that device and wipe it.

122
00:06:15,110 --> 00:06:18,290
Now, it's sent the wipe at this point.

123
00:06:18,290 --> 00:06:21,760
But the device, notice here,
it hasn't synced since 8/23.

124
00:06:21,760 --> 00:06:24,660
It's been over a month since
that device has synced in.

125
00:06:24,660 --> 00:06:27,560
All right, it's cuz it's sitting
in a box at my office at home.

126
00:06:27,560 --> 00:06:30,750
So, it's just sitting there dead.

127
00:06:30,750 --> 00:06:34,090
But if I were to go and
power it on the next time it synced,

128
00:06:34,090 --> 00:06:36,410
the next time it connected in,
it would wipe.

129
00:06:36,410 --> 00:06:39,960
And you'll get an email confirmation that
let's you know that the wipe happened,

130
00:06:39,960 --> 00:06:43,300
because otherwise you don't really
know that it wiped or didn't.

131
00:06:43,300 --> 00:06:44,780
But the wipe is in there, and

132
00:06:44,780 --> 00:06:48,500
you'll see as long as the wipe is in
place I've got a cancel wipe button.

133
00:06:48,500 --> 00:06:50,690
So if it hasn't actually wiped yet.

134
00:06:50,690 --> 00:06:54,760
I can cancel it so maybe they find the
phone, whoever lost it comes in and says,

135
00:06:54,760 --> 00:06:55,920
oh I found it.

136
00:06:55,920 --> 00:06:56,600
You can go ahead and

137
00:06:56,600 --> 00:06:59,296
cancel it before they turn it back on so
it doesn't lose the data.

138
00:06:59,296 --> 00:07:02,840
And when you cancel it you'll see
where you can switch it to block, or

139
00:07:02,840 --> 00:07:04,890
you can put it back to approve.

140
00:07:04,890 --> 00:07:07,758
So I'll cancel that wipe and
put it back to approve, and

141
00:07:07,758 --> 00:07:11,250
now it's an active phone that's up and
valid running on my system.

142
00:07:11,250 --> 00:07:13,160
Kind of a nice little feature,

143
00:07:13,160 --> 00:07:16,600
and you'll see my resolution is low enough
that I couldn't see the status here.

144
00:07:16,600 --> 00:07:17,930
All of them are showing as approved.

145
00:07:19,340 --> 00:07:21,660
If I do a remote wipe on that phone again.

146
00:07:21,660 --> 00:07:23,850
So now I'm remote wiping my pad phone.

147
00:07:23,850 --> 00:07:26,040
When I go over here,
you'll see the status says, wiping.

148
00:07:27,480 --> 00:07:30,630
When it actually does wipe,
it'll change it to say wiped, so

149
00:07:30,630 --> 00:07:33,280
that you'll know that it's
actually been wiped out.

150
00:07:33,280 --> 00:07:36,420
But we can just cancel that, I'll move
it back to, oh well here I'll move it to

151
00:07:36,420 --> 00:07:40,860
block this time, and now that status
will reflect the new blocked status.

152
00:07:40,860 --> 00:07:44,770
So, easy enough to change that stuff,
you can modify it however you want, and

153
00:07:44,770 --> 00:07:48,840
I can always come back and approve it
again if the phone has been found.

154
00:07:48,840 --> 00:07:49,620
All right.

155
00:07:49,620 --> 00:07:50,550
Pretty neat stuff there.

156
00:07:50,550 --> 00:07:55,150
Now, by default, we as an administrator
had to do this, right.

157
00:07:55,150 --> 00:07:58,060
So if an end user loses their phone they
have to contact an administrator and

158
00:07:58,060 --> 00:07:59,120
go in and do it.

159
00:07:59,120 --> 00:08:03,090
But you can make it for
the end user can wipe their own device.

160
00:08:03,090 --> 00:08:05,410
They would just log into
the admin console like we did.

161
00:08:05,410 --> 00:08:08,180
Now when a regular user logs into
the admin console they see something

162
00:08:08,180 --> 00:08:09,820
very different than us, right.

163
00:08:09,820 --> 00:08:12,850
They see,
that basically links to their Gmail, and

164
00:08:12,850 --> 00:08:14,160
links to their calendar, and so on.

165
00:08:14,160 --> 00:08:16,660
They don't see all
the management stuff that we do.

166
00:08:16,660 --> 00:08:20,350
But if we turn on their ability to remote
wipe, they'll see mobile devices, and

167
00:08:20,350 --> 00:08:22,340
they'll be able to go in and wipe things.

168
00:08:22,340 --> 00:08:25,170
If you wanna turn that on,
it's kinda buried away.

169
00:08:25,170 --> 00:08:30,780
I'm gonna go back to my device
management screen, right here,

170
00:08:30,780 --> 00:08:36,270
and if we go to device management
settings, and in here,

171
00:08:36,270 --> 00:08:41,440
if we go down to the advanced settings
portion right here, you'll see,

172
00:08:41,440 --> 00:08:44,810
allow user to remote wipe device.

173
00:08:44,810 --> 00:08:50,130
And you can check that, and when that's
turned on, now your users can browse

174
00:08:50,130 --> 00:08:53,690
that main admin panel and, in addition to
seeing links to their Gmail and calendar

175
00:08:53,690 --> 00:08:57,720
and stuff, they'll be able to manage their
remote devices, and choose to wipe them.

176
00:08:57,720 --> 00:08:59,900
That's nice if you want to
give them the power, so

177
00:08:59,900 --> 00:09:02,500
they don't have to reach out to
the help desk or whatever, to do it.

178
00:09:02,500 --> 00:09:04,760
So keep in mind that
that feature is there.

179
00:09:06,430 --> 00:09:08,040
All right.
So, in this segment,

180
00:09:08,040 --> 00:09:11,200
we got a chance to see the mobile
device management in action.

181
00:09:11,200 --> 00:09:16,000
How we can remote wipe, block, or wipe
an account from a device that has been

182
00:09:16,000 --> 00:09:19,240
lost or
stolen to protect our end user data.

183
00:09:19,240 --> 00:09:21,590
Very important because losing
these devices is so easy.

184
00:09:21,590 --> 00:09:24,340
They're so small and
they're great targets for thieves.

185
00:09:24,340 --> 00:09:28,160
So you do see a lot of people reaching
out specifically to get those.

186
00:09:28,160 --> 00:09:30,120
Alright well I hope you
guys enjoyed this segment.

187
00:09:30,120 --> 00:09:30,620
Stay tuned.

188
00:09:30,620 --> 00:09:33,458
We've got more Google Apps coming up next.

189
00:09:33,458 --> 00:09:40,149
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Using Groups to Manage Security
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,173 --> 00:00:08,264
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08,264 --> 00:00:11,336
Objective 7.1 covers using
groups to manage security

3
00:00:11,336 --> 00:00:15,240
settings within your organization and
when you hear that description,

4
00:00:15,240 --> 00:00:19,720
you kind of think to yourself, well we've
already got where we can manage security

5
00:00:19,720 --> 00:00:22,419
settings by our organization and
our sub-orgs.

6
00:00:22,419 --> 00:00:24,770
Right, so isn't that enough?

7
00:00:24,770 --> 00:00:28,360
Well, there are some little
exceptions to how we handle that.

8
00:00:28,360 --> 00:00:32,605
One of the big problems we have with using
our sub-organizations to manage security

9
00:00:32,605 --> 00:00:36,705
is that a user can only
be in one organization.

10
00:00:36,705 --> 00:00:41,095
So if I have them in one sub-org, I can't
have them simultaneously be in some

11
00:00:41,095 --> 00:00:44,375
other sub-org to get additional
permissions or whatever.

12
00:00:44,375 --> 00:00:48,485
So there are some scenarios where we can
use groups to start to influence that.

13
00:00:48,485 --> 00:00:53,530
Now, we'll cover groups in
a dedicated episode here in a bit but

14
00:00:53,530 --> 00:00:56,740
for right now I want to show
how we can use groups within

15
00:00:56,740 --> 00:01:01,270
a sub-org to kind of tailor
permissions that apply.

16
00:01:01,270 --> 00:01:06,860
And this is a fairly new feature to Google
apps and so it's not very wide spread yet.

17
00:01:06,860 --> 00:01:10,570
In fact, there's really only one
example that we can make use for now.

18
00:01:10,570 --> 00:01:11,840
Now that's all going to change.

19
00:01:11,840 --> 00:01:15,150
So if you're watching this live
right now while we record it,

20
00:01:15,150 --> 00:01:18,530
yeah, there's only one example but if
you're watching this six months from now,

21
00:01:18,530 --> 00:01:19,810
there might be many examples, all right.

22
00:01:20,890 --> 00:01:24,040
But the example I'm gonna use
today is 2-Step Verification.

23
00:01:25,080 --> 00:01:28,140
Google apps supports 2-Step
Verification for users.

24
00:01:28,140 --> 00:01:30,700
When a user logs in,
by default, they do one step.

25
00:01:30,700 --> 00:01:33,640
They provide a user name and
a password and they log in.

26
00:01:33,640 --> 00:01:36,320
But what if somebody gets
a hold of their password?

27
00:01:36,320 --> 00:01:39,040
Then, now their verification is ruined,
right?

28
00:01:39,040 --> 00:01:41,150
This other person can
authenticate as them.

29
00:01:41,150 --> 00:01:45,400
So what 2-Step does is it adds
a second factor of authentication.

30
00:01:45,400 --> 00:01:48,430
So when they login, you've got
a username and a password, sure.

31
00:01:48,430 --> 00:01:50,000
But you've also got a code,

32
00:01:50,000 --> 00:01:53,690
a code that's changing every
30 seconds that you punch in.

33
00:01:53,690 --> 00:01:57,870
And you'll use a device like a token or
usually

34
00:01:57,870 --> 00:02:01,750
the Google Authenticator app running on
your cell phone is a great way to do this.

35
00:02:01,750 --> 00:02:06,060
And you'll see what your code is,
you punch in that code, and you log in.

36
00:02:06,060 --> 00:02:09,910
That gives us a nice, higher level of
security and it prevents people from using

37
00:02:09,910 --> 00:02:12,860
things like key loggers to be able
to get somebody's password and

38
00:02:12,860 --> 00:02:14,600
authenticate as that user.

39
00:02:14,600 --> 00:02:17,190
So if we want to turn that on, great.

40
00:02:17,190 --> 00:02:18,600
Here's the challenge though.

41
00:02:18,600 --> 00:02:21,750
When you turn on 2-Step Verification,
you turn it on or

42
00:02:21,750 --> 00:02:25,310
off based on your organizational
structure, right?

43
00:02:25,310 --> 00:02:26,390
So let's take a look at that.

44
00:02:26,390 --> 00:02:33,340
So when I go into my organizational
structure, I can go into my Google apps.

45
00:02:33,340 --> 00:02:36,440
Actually, hang on,
I need to go into my security.

46
00:02:36,440 --> 00:02:38,594
So I'm gonna go into my Admin console and
I'll go into Security.

47
00:02:40,775 --> 00:02:45,139
And inside of Security, you'll see where
we've got things like our Basic settings,

48
00:02:45,139 --> 00:02:46,710
Single sign-on and all that.

49
00:02:46,710 --> 00:02:49,660
And here's the Enforce 2-Step
Verification right there.

50
00:02:49,660 --> 00:02:51,760
I'm gonna choose the Basic settings.

51
00:02:51,760 --> 00:02:53,660
And when I go in the Basic settings,

52
00:02:53,660 --> 00:02:58,120
you'll see where we can turn on
2-Step Verification, all right.

53
00:02:58,120 --> 00:03:00,470
Now when we turn it on here, well,
it's actually already on for

54
00:03:00,470 --> 00:03:03,710
me, Allow users to turn
on 2-Step Verification.

55
00:03:03,710 --> 00:03:05,130
Great, all right.

56
00:03:05,130 --> 00:03:08,359
But that's giving the users
the option to do it, right?

57
00:03:08,359 --> 00:03:09,300
They could choose not to do it.

58
00:03:09,300 --> 00:03:11,660
They could choose to ignore it.

59
00:03:11,660 --> 00:03:13,510
What if I want to enforce it?

60
00:03:13,510 --> 00:03:16,550
I wanna force my users to
use 2-Step Verification.

61
00:03:16,550 --> 00:03:19,060
Well for
that I have to go to my Advance settings.

62
00:03:19,060 --> 00:03:22,750
And in the advanced settings this is
the screen we've seen in other segments

63
00:03:22,750 --> 00:03:27,662
where we can choose our security settings
based on our organizational structure,

64
00:03:27,662 --> 00:03:28,760
all right.

65
00:03:28,760 --> 00:03:32,530
So it might be that I've
got contractors and

66
00:03:32,530 --> 00:03:36,640
I want my contractors to all
use 2-Step Verification, but

67
00:03:36,640 --> 00:03:41,310
I don't want my retired people to
have to use 2-Step Verification.

68
00:03:41,310 --> 00:03:42,550
Well, I can do that.

69
00:03:42,550 --> 00:03:46,220
When I go in here, if I choose ITProTV,
if I choose my parent organization,

70
00:03:46,220 --> 00:03:50,410
I'm affecting settings for the whole
company but if I choose just contractors,

71
00:03:50,410 --> 00:03:52,150
now I'm just affecting that sub-org.

72
00:03:52,150 --> 00:03:54,400
So we've seen that before,
that's not anything new.

73
00:03:55,410 --> 00:03:58,660
But here's the thing,
if I go into Contractors and

74
00:03:58,660 --> 00:04:03,120
I turn on enforcement, right,
it gives me a warning, this will

75
00:04:03,120 --> 00:04:07,832
force users to enter a verification code
each time they sign in, and I hit OK.

76
00:04:07,832 --> 00:04:09,830
All right, well when I do that,

77
00:04:09,830 --> 00:04:15,190
what happens to a user that hasn't
set up 2-Step Verification yet?

78
00:04:15,190 --> 00:04:19,540
If somebody hasn't set it up, I'm now
requiring it, they just got locked out.

79
00:04:19,540 --> 00:04:21,416
Now they can't log in, all right.

80
00:04:21,416 --> 00:04:25,742
So what we need to do when we set up
2-Step Verification is we need to turn it

81
00:04:25,742 --> 00:04:31,360
on, right, hit that allow users to use
2-Step and then give them time to enroll.

82
00:04:31,360 --> 00:04:34,500
And once they've enrolled,
then we can switch to enforcement, right?

83
00:04:34,500 --> 00:04:36,950
Now we're enforcing and
they'll have to use their code.

84
00:04:36,950 --> 00:04:39,190
But what happens when
you hire a new employee?

85
00:04:39,190 --> 00:04:42,580
When you hire somebody new,
you've gotta give them time to enroll.

86
00:04:42,580 --> 00:04:46,230
And if you're enforcing,
well, they don't have time.

87
00:04:46,230 --> 00:04:49,120
They're already required to put in
a code before they've even been able to

88
00:04:49,120 --> 00:04:50,990
set it up, so that creates a problem.

89
00:04:50,990 --> 00:04:54,550
And that's why Google
introduced group filters.

90
00:04:54,550 --> 00:04:57,540
And you'll see the group filter
right here down at the bottom left.

91
00:04:57,540 --> 00:05:01,220
Now this is not present on
most settings yet, all right.

92
00:05:01,220 --> 00:05:04,730
In the future we're gonna see this appear
more and more and you'll recognize it.

93
00:05:04,730 --> 00:05:07,380
You'll just see it as group filter
right down here at the bottom.

94
00:05:07,380 --> 00:05:12,080
And what we can do is we can use groups
to influence whether this applies or

95
00:05:12,080 --> 00:05:13,240
doesn't, all right.

96
00:05:13,240 --> 00:05:16,450
So it's an additional layer of
filtering we can do in addition

97
00:05:16,450 --> 00:05:19,780
to our organizational structure,
all right.

98
00:05:19,780 --> 00:05:22,400
So what I'm gonna do is I'm gonna
whip up two groups real quick.

99
00:05:23,430 --> 00:05:27,000
Or I guess I don't really need two groups,
I can create just an exception.

100
00:05:27,000 --> 00:05:33,250
But what we can do is we can go and
I'll just jump back to my Dashboard.

101
00:05:34,320 --> 00:05:36,145
And here I'm gonna go into my groups.

102
00:05:36,145 --> 00:05:42,757
So under More controls > Groups, I'm gonna
create a group here which I will call,

103
00:05:42,757 --> 00:05:47,481
maybe this is New Employee,
or On-Boarding Employee, or

104
00:05:47,481 --> 00:05:52,500
Non 2-Step Verification, or
something like that, right?

105
00:05:52,500 --> 00:05:55,130
So I'm just gonna call this one
New Employee is what I'll do.

106
00:05:55,130 --> 00:05:57,250
And you have to give it an address, so

107
00:05:57,250 --> 00:05:59,750
I'll just call it
newemployee@itvprotv.net.

108
00:05:59,750 --> 00:06:03,436
And in the description I'm gonna
put in here, users in this, or

109
00:06:03,436 --> 00:06:08,000
actually we can call it New Contractor,
if we wanna be a little more specific.

110
00:06:08,000 --> 00:06:09,110
We'll change that.

111
00:06:09,110 --> 00:06:11,900
So these'll be New Contractors, all right?

112
00:06:11,900 --> 00:06:20,250
And I'll say users in this group are not
required to use 2-Step Verification.

113
00:06:20,250 --> 00:06:22,620
All right?

114
00:06:22,620 --> 00:06:27,490
And so I'm gonna make it where people
in this group are an exception.

115
00:06:27,490 --> 00:06:29,710
They don't have to have
2-Step Verification,

116
00:06:29,710 --> 00:06:32,050
and this is where I'll put new people.

117
00:06:32,050 --> 00:06:35,860
This will give them a chance to log in and
enroll in 2-Step and

118
00:06:35,860 --> 00:06:38,430
get it set up, and
then I can take them out of this group.

119
00:06:38,430 --> 00:06:42,570
And when I take them out of the group, now
they are required to use 2-Step, right.

120
00:06:42,570 --> 00:06:46,650
So I can use this group to kind of
control that access, all right.

121
00:06:46,650 --> 00:06:50,460
And I'm gonna do it here with one
group where I've turned it on on

122
00:06:50,460 --> 00:06:54,390
the contractors' organization, and
these guys will be exceptions.

123
00:06:54,390 --> 00:06:59,340
But you could also create two groups,
one for pre-enrolled users and

124
00:06:59,340 --> 00:07:02,480
one for post-enrolled users and you can
just move them after they enroll so

125
00:07:02,480 --> 00:07:04,040
that they're now set to require that way.

126
00:07:04,040 --> 00:07:07,480
You can go either way, there's a lot
of flexibility here, all right.

127
00:07:07,480 --> 00:07:08,750
So I'm just gonna create this group.

128
00:07:08,750 --> 00:07:12,395
I'm not really worried about access levels
down here as far as what they can use,

129
00:07:12,395 --> 00:07:15,280
cuz I'm just using this
group as a security filter.

130
00:07:15,280 --> 00:07:18,820
I'm not using it as an email
mailing list or anything like that.

131
00:07:18,820 --> 00:07:20,720
So I'm not really gonna check
any other options here.

132
00:07:20,720 --> 00:07:25,890
I'm just gonna create the group
called New Contractor, all right.

133
00:07:25,890 --> 00:07:28,460
Then I can go back to
my Security settings.

134
00:07:28,460 --> 00:07:34,620
So back on my Dashboard I'll
go to More Controls>Security.

135
00:07:34,620 --> 00:07:39,260
And I'll go into my Basic
settings here where we set

136
00:07:39,260 --> 00:07:43,890
up our 2-Step, and actually need to
go into the Advanced settings anyway.

137
00:07:43,890 --> 00:07:44,724
So I'll go into Advanced settings.

138
00:07:47,451 --> 00:07:48,380
Or actually, you know what?

139
00:07:48,380 --> 00:07:49,560
I do need to go back to Basic settings.

140
00:07:49,560 --> 00:07:51,120
Let me go back to Basic settings and

141
00:07:51,120 --> 00:07:54,566
I need to go to the Advanced settings for
2-Step, so I'm just gonna go there.

142
00:07:54,566 --> 00:07:57,470
And inside of the Advanced settings for
2-Step, this is where I came in and

143
00:07:57,470 --> 00:08:00,380
went to Contractors and
I turned on enforcement.

144
00:08:00,380 --> 00:08:03,530
So when I hire a new employee or
bring on a new contractor and

145
00:08:03,530 --> 00:08:07,150
I create an account for them,
I'm gonna put them in this sub-org, and

146
00:08:07,150 --> 00:08:09,930
they'll be required to use 2-Step.

147
00:08:09,930 --> 00:08:13,190
But then down here I can
create a group filter.

148
00:08:13,190 --> 00:08:14,530
And I'm gonna create a filter for

149
00:08:14,530 --> 00:08:18,650
the New Contractor group that I just made,
all right.

150
00:08:18,650 --> 00:08:20,020
And notice what happens.

151
00:08:20,020 --> 00:08:24,100
When I've got Contractors chosen,
it says Turn on enforcement.

152
00:08:24,100 --> 00:08:28,310
When I click on New Contractor,
the screen updates.

153
00:08:28,310 --> 00:08:29,660
And it happens really fast, so

154
00:08:29,660 --> 00:08:33,220
you can't see it but
it's still saying Turn on enforcement,

155
00:08:33,220 --> 00:08:38,540
I'm gonna choose Turn off enforcement,
and hit Save changes, all right?

156
00:08:38,540 --> 00:08:43,690
Now what that just did,
is it applied to the New Contractor group.

157
00:08:43,690 --> 00:08:49,530
If I choose No admin group selected,
it says Turn on enforcement.

158
00:08:49,530 --> 00:08:53,760
If I choose New Contractor,
it says turn off enforcement.

159
00:08:53,760 --> 00:08:58,250
So now when I create my contractors, if
they're new accounts I stick them in that

160
00:08:58,250 --> 00:09:02,430
New Contractor group and
they won't have to have 2-Step.

161
00:09:02,430 --> 00:09:06,305
That'll give them a chance to log in
with the temporary password we set and

162
00:09:06,305 --> 00:09:08,693
enroll in the 2-Step process, all right.

163
00:09:08,693 --> 00:09:11,893
Once that's done, I can go and
take them out of this group,

164
00:09:11,893 --> 00:09:14,490
take them out of the New Contractor group.

165
00:09:14,490 --> 00:09:17,699
So now they'll be in this No
admin group selected, right.

166
00:09:17,699 --> 00:09:21,021
And now they will be
required to use enforcement.

167
00:09:21,021 --> 00:09:27,070
So this allows us to have different levels
of people within a single organization.

168
00:09:27,070 --> 00:09:28,990
Now there is another way I could do this.

169
00:09:28,990 --> 00:09:31,930
I could create multiple sub-orgs here.

170
00:09:31,930 --> 00:09:35,340
I could have a sub-org under
Contractors called New Contractors, and

171
00:09:35,340 --> 00:09:40,490
have that one not require 2-Step and then
move them to another org when they do.

172
00:09:40,490 --> 00:09:44,325
So you could go that route but the group
method is a little bit easier because we

173
00:09:44,325 --> 00:09:46,380
can also use this for communications.

174
00:09:46,380 --> 00:09:51,610
So, maybe we send an email out once
a day to the New Contractor group,

175
00:09:51,610 --> 00:09:56,370
saying you need to enroll in 2-Step,
all right.

176
00:09:56,370 --> 00:09:59,020
And that way, if they haven't done it,
they're getting this reminder,

177
00:09:59,020 --> 00:10:01,550
you need to enroll in 2-Step and
we can keep track of that and

178
00:10:01,550 --> 00:10:04,310
then see who's been enrolled, all right.

179
00:10:04,310 --> 00:10:08,570
We're gonna talk more about 2-Step in
another segment, but just as a little

180
00:10:08,570 --> 00:10:11,870
caveat here, if you want to figure out
which of your users have enrolled and

181
00:10:11,870 --> 00:10:15,760
which ones haven't, there's not
really a great way here in the GUI.

182
00:10:15,760 --> 00:10:20,210
If we go back to our Dashboard and
we go into the reporting subsystem.

183
00:10:20,210 --> 00:10:23,620
So I'll go to More controls > Reports.

184
00:10:23,620 --> 00:10:28,100
None of the reports show us whether
somebody is 2-Step enrolled or not.

185
00:10:28,100 --> 00:10:30,230
You don't see it here, all right.

186
00:10:30,230 --> 00:10:36,230
So, what you really need to do is,
if you go to Security, that's a good one.

187
00:10:36,230 --> 00:10:41,030
On the security screen you'll see
information about your users and

188
00:10:41,030 --> 00:10:42,930
you can use the Download button up here.

189
00:10:42,930 --> 00:10:46,420
And when you hit Download,
it'll export as a CSV and

190
00:10:46,420 --> 00:10:50,510
one of the columns in that CSV will
show whether they're 2-Step enrolled.

191
00:10:50,510 --> 00:10:53,870
And so you can use that to see quickly
how many people in your organization have

192
00:10:53,870 --> 00:10:55,780
actually 2-Step enrolled or not, and

193
00:10:55,780 --> 00:10:58,730
determine who needs to be in that
group and who doesn't, all right.

194
00:10:58,730 --> 00:11:00,750
But that's not the point of this segment.

195
00:11:00,750 --> 00:11:05,560
The point of this segment was to show that
we can create exceptions to the rule.

196
00:11:05,560 --> 00:11:07,520
And it's a fairly limited feature today so

197
00:11:07,520 --> 00:11:11,180
that's really the only example I can show
you, but expect to see it in the future.

198
00:11:11,180 --> 00:11:15,230
Expect to see areas where you go through
to configure settings especially with

199
00:11:15,230 --> 00:11:18,650
things like device management, where
you'll start to see exceptions there.

200
00:11:18,650 --> 00:11:21,300
And it's definitely something
you'll want to take advantage of,

201
00:11:21,300 --> 00:11:25,320
because you might not want certain things
to apply to administrators versus regular

202
00:11:25,320 --> 00:11:26,400
users and so on.

203
00:11:26,400 --> 00:11:31,260
So expect to see that admin group filter
start to appear down here in more and

204
00:11:31,260 --> 00:11:31,940
more areas.

205
00:11:33,320 --> 00:11:34,040
All right.

206
00:11:34,040 --> 00:11:38,510
So in this segment, we got a chance
to take a look at using groups

207
00:11:38,510 --> 00:11:42,220
to manage our security settings in
addition to sub-organizations, right, so

208
00:11:42,220 --> 00:11:46,100
that we can apply filters and change the
way that settings apply to different users

209
00:11:46,100 --> 00:11:47,940
at different points in our organization.

210
00:11:47,940 --> 00:11:54,328
I hope you guys enjoyed it, stay tuned,
we've got more Google apps coming up.

211
00:11:54,328 --> 00:11:58,729
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: SSO OAuth and 2-step
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,004 --> 00:00:05,850
[SOUND] Objective 7.2 is a mixed

2
00:00:05,850 --> 00:00:12,542
bag of security and authentication.

3
00:00:12,542 --> 00:00:17,334
The official title is,
Demonstrate How to Configure SSO, OAuth,

4
00:00:17,334 --> 00:00:19,454
and 2-step verification.

5
00:00:19,454 --> 00:00:21,515
It's a mouthful of acronyms.

6
00:00:21,515 --> 00:00:24,505
All right, so let's take a look at each
one of these, kinda see what they do, and

7
00:00:24,505 --> 00:00:26,385
how we go about configuring them.

8
00:00:26,385 --> 00:00:28,974
The first one they call out is SSO,
single sign-on.

9
00:00:28,974 --> 00:00:33,450
And single sign-on is, fortunately,
the easiest of the ones to configure,

10
00:00:33,450 --> 00:00:35,790
because it's already turned on.

11
00:00:35,790 --> 00:00:38,520
Google Apps uses a single sign on method.

12
00:00:38,520 --> 00:00:44,200
So when a user signs in to any one
of the various Google Apps services,

13
00:00:44,200 --> 00:00:46,400
they're given an authentication token.

14
00:00:46,400 --> 00:00:48,210
And that token is then valid for

15
00:00:48,210 --> 00:00:51,520
authenticating against any of
the other Google Apps services.

16
00:00:51,520 --> 00:00:56,540
So if I went to Gmail and
I logged in with my Google apps account,

17
00:00:56,540 --> 00:00:58,280
I'm now sitting on
an authentication token.

18
00:00:59,370 --> 00:01:03,210
If I turn around and go to YouTube,
I don't have to login a second time.

19
00:01:03,210 --> 00:01:04,680
I'm already logged in.

20
00:01:04,680 --> 00:01:08,800
YouTube will recognize me by my Google
apps authentication token and let me in.

21
00:01:08,800 --> 00:01:10,030
And I'll have my access.

22
00:01:10,030 --> 00:01:14,630
And if I jump over to Blogger or
a Google site, or

23
00:01:14,630 --> 00:01:18,840
any of the other various services,
again, I'm already logged in.

24
00:01:18,840 --> 00:01:21,200
So, it's really neat and,
as far as configuration,

25
00:01:21,200 --> 00:01:23,220
there's not really much to it.

26
00:01:23,220 --> 00:01:26,410
So, you might ask yourself
if it's on by default,

27
00:01:26,410 --> 00:01:29,290
how do I demonstrate how to configure it?

28
00:01:29,290 --> 00:01:32,120
Well there's not really much
to demonstrate on this one.

29
00:01:32,120 --> 00:01:34,040
We can see some of
the informations though.

30
00:01:34,040 --> 00:01:38,706
If we go into our Admin console,
and go into, Security.

31
00:01:40,541 --> 00:01:44,340
And I have to authenticate here,
my session has timed out.

32
00:01:44,340 --> 00:01:46,260
So let me authenticate real quick.

33
00:01:46,260 --> 00:01:49,830
So I'm in my Admin console and
I'm going into the security settings.

34
00:01:49,830 --> 00:01:54,130
You'll see right down here at the bottom,
set up single sign on, SSO.

35
00:01:54,130 --> 00:01:58,970
And if I click on that, we'll see some
basic options that are over here,

36
00:01:58,970 --> 00:02:04,050
and what these are doing is
modifying how single sign on works.

37
00:02:04,050 --> 00:02:10,390
By default, SSO is only within
the Google apps services.

38
00:02:10,390 --> 00:02:12,680
But what if you have
third party systems and

39
00:02:12,680 --> 00:02:14,890
you want to do a single
sign-on against them?

40
00:02:14,890 --> 00:02:19,470
So for example, maybe you have a Microsoft
Windows active directory in place.

41
00:02:19,470 --> 00:02:23,060
And all of your users already have
accounts in the active directory.

42
00:02:23,060 --> 00:02:26,300
And so,when somebody logs on into Google
Apps you don't wanna do a single sign

43
00:02:26,300 --> 00:02:27,120
on against Google Apps.

44
00:02:27,120 --> 00:02:29,900
You want to do a single sign on
against the active directory.

45
00:02:29,900 --> 00:02:34,000
You wanna have your users have
a true single user identity,

46
00:02:34,000 --> 00:02:36,350
that they use when they
login to whatever system.

47
00:02:36,350 --> 00:02:38,970
Be it Google Apps or
the desktop back at the office.

48
00:02:40,240 --> 00:02:44,250
Well, for that, you can override SSO.

49
00:02:44,250 --> 00:02:48,270
And say, instead of authenticating
straight up against Google apps,

50
00:02:48,270 --> 00:02:52,310
we can authenticate against your
existing SSO infrastructure.

51
00:02:52,310 --> 00:02:54,260
And so you can come in here and
specify that.

52
00:02:54,260 --> 00:02:57,970
Set up SSO with third
party identity provider.

53
00:02:57,970 --> 00:03:00,840
So SSO between Google app services.

54
00:03:00,840 --> 00:03:03,760
It's already on,
you don't have to configure it, it's done.

55
00:03:03,760 --> 00:03:06,350
The only time we have to do configuration
is if we want to change that to

56
00:03:06,350 --> 00:03:08,830
authenticate against a third party system.

57
00:03:08,830 --> 00:03:12,260
Now third party system's vary greatly, so

58
00:03:12,260 --> 00:03:15,180
I don't have one great
example that I can show you.

59
00:03:15,180 --> 00:03:19,500
Cuz you might be authenticating
against a Solaris NIS Plus domain.

60
00:03:19,500 --> 00:03:23,040
You might have a Windows Active Directory,
a Novel eDirectory.

61
00:03:23,040 --> 00:03:28,150
You might have a really advanced
identity system like Shebolith in place,

62
00:03:28,150 --> 00:03:31,660
and that one will let you do all sorts of
cross authentication for various things.

63
00:03:31,660 --> 00:03:36,530
And when you set those up, almost all
of the venders out there these days

64
00:03:36,530 --> 00:03:41,210
support SAML,
which is an authentication protocol.

65
00:03:41,210 --> 00:03:44,240
And that's exactly what
Google's SSO is doing.

66
00:03:44,240 --> 00:03:48,790
So you punch in the URL for
the sign-in page, or sign-out pages,

67
00:03:48,790 --> 00:03:53,660
where they go to change their password,
and you specify a certificate to

68
00:03:53,660 --> 00:03:56,580
use to authenticate the server,
their Google app servers.

69
00:03:56,580 --> 00:03:58,750
Talking to your authentication server.

70
00:03:58,750 --> 00:04:02,040
And when that's done, when the user
goes to log in, instead of issuing

71
00:04:02,040 --> 00:04:06,430
the certificate straight from Google apps,
it will send them to the sign-on page.

72
00:04:06,430 --> 00:04:09,460
And they'll sign in to your system,

73
00:04:09,460 --> 00:04:13,700
Which in turn will be issuing that token
and we'll receive that here on the server

74
00:04:13,700 --> 00:04:16,360
to continue cross authenticating
them across the other services.

75
00:04:16,360 --> 00:04:19,520
So here's where we go and
specify this information.

76
00:04:19,520 --> 00:04:22,685
And so if you're the Google Apps
administrator, you'll have to reach out to

77
00:04:22,685 --> 00:04:26,290
whoever your identity administrator is
to get this information to punch in.

78
00:04:27,640 --> 00:04:30,820
Now you can also specify
subnet masks down here.

79
00:04:30,820 --> 00:04:36,450
Which say only do SSO if the user's IP
address falls within a certain range.

80
00:04:36,450 --> 00:04:39,870
So you can specify that down here
to limit who's leveraging this SSO

81
00:04:39,870 --> 00:04:41,150
piece and who isn't.

82
00:04:41,150 --> 00:04:43,560
You might have external
users like contractors.

83
00:04:43,560 --> 00:04:45,570
That you don't want to use the SSOPs.

84
00:04:45,570 --> 00:04:47,880
But you have your internal
employees that you do.

85
00:04:47,880 --> 00:04:50,340
So you can specify that right here.

86
00:04:50,340 --> 00:04:53,000
Those are the only configuration
options we have for SSO and

87
00:04:53,000 --> 00:04:56,850
it looks deceptively simple like
I just punch in a few things.

88
00:04:56,850 --> 00:04:59,520
The hard work is on the SSO side.

89
00:04:59,520 --> 00:05:03,400
So whatever your single sign-on
system is if it's Shibboleth or

90
00:05:03,400 --> 00:05:06,150
Windows Active Directory
Federation Services or

91
00:05:06,150 --> 00:05:09,500
something like that,
you've got a lot of work to do on that end

92
00:05:09,500 --> 00:05:13,970
to get them set up to be ready to
receive these requests from Google apps.

93
00:05:13,970 --> 00:05:17,700
But on the Google apps side, it's really
just a matter of punching in URLs, and

So I'll put in my user name and my
password, and then it's gonna ask me for

320
00:17:21,227 --> 00:17:25,750
my code, so I'm gonna go up here and
log out, so I'm gonna sign out.

321
00:17:25,750 --> 00:17:28,894
I'm gonna close these other windows
that I've got open to Google just so

322
00:17:28,894 --> 00:17:30,190
I'm not signed in anywhere.

323
00:17:31,230 --> 00:17:32,110
All right.

324
00:17:32,110 --> 00:17:40,680
And I'm gonna go back to my admin console,
so let me just go to itprotv.net.

325
00:17:40,680 --> 00:17:43,960
All right, and it's gonna make me log in.

326
00:17:45,190 --> 00:17:48,260
And my authentication token should
be removed at this point, but

327
00:17:48,260 --> 00:17:50,390
if it isn't, there we go.

328
00:17:50,390 --> 00:17:53,260
Now I'm gonna log in and
it's asking me for my code.

329
00:17:53,260 --> 00:17:56,180
If somebody had my password,
it's not enough.

330
00:17:56,180 --> 00:17:59,180
They need my password and my code.

331
00:17:59,180 --> 00:18:03,060
And I can just look at my cell phone,
and the code that's on it right now, so

332
00:18:03,060 --> 00:18:09,090
I'm gonna punch in this code, and when
I hit Verify, now I log in and I'm in.

333
00:18:09,090 --> 00:18:11,990
I'm in, I'm able to work,
and we're in business.

334
00:18:11,990 --> 00:18:14,450
So that's two step verification.

335
00:18:14,450 --> 00:18:17,460
The only piece I'm leaving out right
now is that this is all optional,

336
00:18:17,460 --> 00:18:19,630
I made it optional for my end user.

337
00:18:19,630 --> 00:18:26,113
So I might want to enforce it, require my
end users to use two step authentication,

338
00:18:26,113 --> 00:18:31,020
and if that's the case,
I need to go back to my admin console and

339
00:18:31,020 --> 00:18:34,188
I need to change my enforcement policy.

340
00:18:34,188 --> 00:18:38,333
And we do that by going to More controls,
and Security,

341
00:18:38,333 --> 00:18:42,744
going into our Basic settings,
and in our Basic settings,

342
00:18:42,744 --> 00:18:45,940
if you scroll down, you'll see Two step.

343
00:18:45,940 --> 00:18:48,964
And there's a little text message
down there at the bottom that says,

344
00:18:48,964 --> 00:18:50,440
Go to advanced settings.

345
00:18:50,440 --> 00:18:53,140
We have to go to Advanced settings for
enforcement.

346
00:18:53,140 --> 00:18:55,980
And if we go to the Advanced settings

347
00:18:55,980 --> 00:19:00,560
we'll see the option in here to
require two step authentication.

348
00:19:00,560 --> 00:19:01,060
Right there.

349
00:19:02,070 --> 00:19:03,960
Now it's gonna give us a warning though.

350
00:19:03,960 --> 00:19:09,200
If anybody didn't enroll,
when I turn on enforcement, they're out.

351
00:19:09,200 --> 00:19:10,400
They can't log in.

352
00:19:10,400 --> 00:19:13,360
I've effectively locked
them out of the system.

353
00:19:13,360 --> 00:19:17,280
You have to be careful about this, if we
turn on enforcement anybody who is not

354
00:19:17,280 --> 00:19:20,170
enrolled in two step is
gonna be locked out.

355
00:19:20,170 --> 00:19:23,150
So when we turn on two step we
need to give our employees time.

356
00:19:23,150 --> 00:19:26,940
Let them enroll, and once they're
enrolled then we can turn it on.

357
00:19:26,940 --> 00:19:30,430
Now you can create exceptions and
I normally do this for new employees.

358
00:19:30,430 --> 00:19:33,810
For new employees, I put in an exception
so they don't have to enroll right away.

359
00:19:33,810 --> 00:19:35,510
They can get in and enroll on their own.

360
00:19:35,510 --> 00:19:37,920
And then,
I can take them out of the exception, and

361
00:19:37,920 --> 00:19:40,770
now they're enforced to use it.

362
00:19:40,770 --> 00:19:45,110
To do the exception,
we can use group filters down here.

363
00:19:45,110 --> 00:19:47,170
And we've recorded that
in another segment.

364
00:19:47,170 --> 00:19:49,050
Look for the objective that covers,
actually hang on.

365
00:19:49,050 --> 00:19:50,938
I think I know exactly
which objective it is.

366
00:19:50,938 --> 00:19:54,397
I wanna say it's 7.1 or
something like that.

367
00:19:54,397 --> 00:19:58,959
So you can jump over to, yes, 7.1,
objective 7.1 where I show how to use

368
00:19:58,959 --> 00:20:03,870
group filters to create that exception
group to say these people aren't enforced,

369
00:20:03,870 --> 00:20:05,980
but everybody else is, all right.

370
00:20:05,980 --> 00:20:06,950
So just be aware of that,

371
00:20:06,950 --> 00:20:10,360
if I turn this on right now
I'll be okay cuz I'm enrolled.

372
00:20:10,360 --> 00:20:14,130
But none of my other users are,
they're all gonna be locked out.

373
00:20:14,130 --> 00:20:16,130
When they log in it's gonna
force them to use a code but

374
00:20:16,130 --> 00:20:18,420
they won't have a code because
they haven't enrolled.

375
00:20:18,420 --> 00:20:21,290
So just be aware of that when
you go to configure this and

376
00:20:21,290 --> 00:20:22,920
make sure your employees
have time to enroll.

377
00:20:24,150 --> 00:20:28,646
All right so in this segment we got
a chance to see single sign on.

378
00:20:28,646 --> 00:20:30,111
We took a look at and

379
00:20:30,111 --> 00:20:33,950
kind of what it does and
allows multi-authentication between sites.

380
00:20:33,950 --> 00:20:38,623
And we wrapped up talking about two-step,
where we got a chance to see using

381
00:20:38,623 --> 00:20:43,808
a dynamic code that's in our possession as
a second step of authentication to ensure

382
00:20:43,808 --> 00:20:49,120
that key loggers and attacks of that
nature are not viable in our environment.

383
00:20:49,120 --> 00:20:50,370
They're all great technologies.

384
00:20:50,370 --> 00:20:52,780
You definitely want to
take advantage of those.

385
00:20:52,780 --> 00:20:54,470
All right,
well I hope you guys enjoyed the segment.

386
00:20:54,470 --> 00:20:58,063
Stay tuned,
we've got more Google Apps coming up next.

387
00:20:58,063 --> 00:21:05,063
[MUSIC]

388
00:21:05,063 --> 00:21:06,813
Can you like blur that out on the screen?

389
00:21:06,813 --> 00:21:08,460
>> [INAUDIBLE]
>> Okay.

episodes.title: Google Groups for Business
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:08,240 --> 00:00:11,180
Objective 8.1 is one of my favorites.

2
00:00:11,180 --> 00:00:15,650
The Google Groups system inside of Google
Apps at first looks really limited, but

3
00:00:15,650 --> 00:00:19,830
there's this secret side of Google Groups
that's hidden underneath the hood.

4
00:00:19,830 --> 00:00:24,200
We can turn on a lot of power and
that's what this objective is all about.

5
00:00:24,200 --> 00:00:28,320
The official name is Create a Group that
will be used as a shared mailbox for

6
00:00:28,320 --> 00:00:32,024
a group of users, Q & A forums and
distribution lists.

7
00:00:32,024 --> 00:00:33,828
That's quite a mouthful.

8
00:00:33,828 --> 00:00:37,580
A normal Google group can't
do half of that stuff right.

9
00:00:37,580 --> 00:00:39,610
But let's take a look at
a normal group first and

10
00:00:39,610 --> 00:00:41,780
then we'll see how we can
kind of improve upon this.

11
00:00:41,780 --> 00:00:46,380
When you set up a Google Apps account,
there's a Groups service built into it.

12
00:00:46,380 --> 00:00:49,930
If we go down here to more controls,
you'll see Groups right here, and

13
00:00:49,930 --> 00:00:55,405
these are your normal, what they call
them are admin console Groups, all right?

14
00:00:55,405 --> 00:00:58,920
It' just Groups that we create that
are typically used for one of two things.

15
00:00:58,920 --> 00:01:01,160
They're either used for one, permissions.

16
00:01:01,160 --> 00:01:03,800
Giving people permissions to
access various resources.

17
00:01:03,800 --> 00:01:08,970
Like I might share a document,
or share a site, share a folder

18
00:01:08,970 --> 00:01:13,420
in Google Drive with one of these groups
so it's really controlling permissions.

19
00:01:13,420 --> 00:01:17,020
Or two,
using them as email distribution list.

20
00:01:17,020 --> 00:01:20,680
So for example maybe I've got
a sales department in my company.

21
00:01:20,680 --> 00:01:25,413
And when somebody inquires about
a sale with my organization they send

22
00:01:25,413 --> 00:01:27,667
an email sales@itprotv.net.

23
00:01:27,667 --> 00:01:33,520
Well, I could add sales at ITProTV.net
as an alias to a user, right.

24
00:01:33,520 --> 00:01:35,360
I could go into my users and

25
00:01:35,360 --> 00:01:40,480
I could pick, we'll make
Marty Friedman our manager of sales.

26
00:01:40,480 --> 00:01:44,630
So I could go into old Marty Friedman
here, I could go into his account and

27
00:01:44,630 --> 00:01:48,050
I could add an alias for him right here.

28
00:01:48,050 --> 00:01:53,150
And I could say that his alias
was sales@itprotv.net alright.

29
00:01:54,580 --> 00:01:58,130
So now anytime somebody sends an email
to sales he would get it all right.

30
00:01:58,130 --> 00:02:00,980
The problem with that is,
what if Marty is out sick?

31
00:02:00,980 --> 00:02:02,280
If he's out sick tomorrow,

32
00:02:02,280 --> 00:02:06,260
I get all these sales emails coming in and
nobody answers them all right.

33
00:02:06,260 --> 00:02:10,530
So that's not really a great option for
a shared email address.

34
00:02:10,530 --> 00:02:13,680
Instead, we could use one of
our admin console groups.

35
00:02:13,680 --> 00:02:18,200
I can go back to my Dashboard and
go under More Controls>Groups.

36
00:02:18,200 --> 00:02:21,420
And Groups is one of the ones that I
almost always pin to my admin console.

37
00:02:21,420 --> 00:02:23,880
So I'm gonna hit the little
plus mark there to pin it.

38
00:02:23,880 --> 00:02:25,510
There we go.
So that way I don't have to go to

39
00:02:25,510 --> 00:02:26,900
More Controls every time.

40
00:02:26,900 --> 00:02:31,100
But I'll go into Groups and
I can create a Group called ales, and

41
00:02:31,100 --> 00:02:34,320
I can put multiple people in that group so

42
00:02:34,320 --> 00:02:38,640
they'll all get the emails that
go to sales, not just one person.

43
00:02:38,640 --> 00:02:40,940
And that's really handy,
cuz if I hire new people,

44
00:02:40,940 --> 00:02:43,970
I can put them in the sales group or
take them out of the sales group.

45
00:02:43,970 --> 00:02:46,080
Depending on whether or
not I want them to get those emails.

46
00:02:47,130 --> 00:02:49,600
So it works as a good way
of setting permissions,

47
00:02:49,600 --> 00:02:52,130
as well as a distribution list for email.

48
00:02:52,130 --> 00:02:53,620
So I'll just whip one up here real quick.

49
00:02:53,620 --> 00:02:56,081
I'm gonna call this my Sales group, and

50
00:02:56,081 --> 00:03:00,190
I'll give it the email
address of sales@itprotv.net.

51
00:03:00,190 --> 00:03:02,320
If I wanted to have more
addresses I can do that.

52
00:03:02,320 --> 00:03:05,720
Not on this screen, but after
the group is created I can edit it and

53
00:03:05,720 --> 00:03:08,330
you aliases on a group just
like you do on a users.

54
00:03:08,330 --> 00:03:13,530
So I can add more aliases if you've
got more than one domain name, right?

55
00:03:13,530 --> 00:03:15,820
Down here I can pick the access level and

56
00:03:15,820 --> 00:03:20,670
the access level this is kind of our level
of permissions for the group itself.

57
00:03:20,670 --> 00:03:22,760
You'll see the default is team.

58
00:03:22,760 --> 00:03:26,650
And that means that anyone that's in
this group can send emails to group.

59
00:03:26,650 --> 00:03:28,830
They can send an email and
it'll go to all the other guys.

60
00:03:28,830 --> 00:03:30,980
And they can also view the member list.

61
00:03:30,980 --> 00:03:32,810
They can see who's in the group.

62
00:03:32,810 --> 00:03:34,020
And that's the default option.

63
00:03:34,020 --> 00:03:36,850
We want visibility inside
of our organization.

64
00:03:36,850 --> 00:03:38,350
Another options, though,
is announcement only.

65
00:03:38,350 --> 00:03:44,550
And with announcement only, your members
will receive emails sent to the list,

66
00:03:44,550 --> 00:03:48,030
but they can't actually
email the list themselves.

67
00:03:48,030 --> 00:03:50,490
This is useful if you want,
well, announcements.

68
00:03:50,490 --> 00:03:53,770
You want your administrators to be able to
send messages out to the whole company.

69
00:03:53,770 --> 00:03:56,480
But you don't want everybody else in
the company to be able to use that

70
00:03:56,480 --> 00:03:57,810
address list.

71
00:03:57,810 --> 00:03:59,530
And then there's restricted.

72
00:03:59,530 --> 00:04:02,540
Restricted effectively
makes this list private, so

73
00:04:02,540 --> 00:04:04,710
that only members even know it exists.

74
00:04:04,710 --> 00:04:09,340
And then the owners can email and post
messages into it, and go on from there.

75
00:04:09,340 --> 00:04:11,510
So the restricted ones are kind
of private and hidden.

76
00:04:11,510 --> 00:04:14,430
I'm gonna stick with team on this one,
though.

77
00:04:14,430 --> 00:04:18,500
And you'll see, allow anyone on
the internet to post messages.

78
00:04:18,500 --> 00:04:20,660
Notice that's not checked by default.

79
00:04:20,660 --> 00:04:23,750
When you create a group,
by default it's a distribution list for

80
00:04:23,750 --> 00:04:27,750
people inside of your organization and
that's it.

81
00:04:27,750 --> 00:04:30,530
But, if this is sales at ITProTV and

82
00:04:30,530 --> 00:04:33,160
I want people on the internet
to be able to email to it.

83
00:04:33,160 --> 00:04:36,820
So, I'll need to check that off so
that the general public can use it.

84
00:04:37,960 --> 00:04:42,420
Then we've got add all users
within ITProTV.net to this group.

85
00:04:42,420 --> 00:04:44,520
This is a really cool option.

86
00:04:44,520 --> 00:04:47,982
Right now I don't want all
of my users in this group.

87
00:04:47,982 --> 00:04:51,140
If somebody emails I just need
it to go to the sales people.

88
00:04:51,140 --> 00:04:55,860
But if I was creating a more generic
group, like an all employees group so

89
00:04:55,860 --> 00:04:57,990
I could use it for
announcements to the company.

90
00:04:57,990 --> 00:05:02,770
I might want to choose that so
that all current and new employees get

91
00:05:02,770 --> 00:05:05,820
added to this list so that when I send
the email out it will get to them.

92
00:05:05,820 --> 00:05:08,160
We actually use something
like that here at ITProTV.

93
00:05:08,160 --> 00:05:14,470
I'm gonna hit create to turn this group on
and then I'm gonna create one more group.

94
00:05:14,470 --> 00:05:16,550
I'll just go right back up
here to create group and

95
00:05:16,550 --> 00:05:19,390
I'm gonna call this one all employees.

96
00:05:19,390 --> 00:05:20,010
All right.

97
00:05:20,010 --> 00:05:23,370
And I'll call this one
everyone at ITProTV.net and

98
00:05:23,370 --> 00:05:26,630
down here I'm going to change
that to announcement only.

99
00:05:26,630 --> 00:05:30,480
I don't want employees using this like,
hey, I've got a refrigerator for sale,

100
00:05:30,480 --> 00:05:31,340
anybody interested?

101
00:05:31,340 --> 00:05:33,680
I don't want that kind of stuff going on.

102
00:05:33,680 --> 00:05:34,950
So, I'll set it to announcement only, so

103
00:05:34,950 --> 00:05:38,520
that only the owners of
this group can email to it.

104
00:05:38,520 --> 00:05:43,060
And then I'll choose to add all
users within ITProTV.net to it.

105
00:05:43,060 --> 00:05:46,430
Now any time I add new employees
they're going to automatically be

106
00:05:46,430 --> 00:05:47,780
part of this list.

107
00:05:47,780 --> 00:05:52,615
But when I chose announcement only
notice that Internet option is gone.

108
00:05:52,615 --> 00:05:56,355
I can't choose to allow the people
on the internet to email to it.

109
00:05:56,355 --> 00:05:59,665
That's not what this list would be used
for, so that's perfectly fine for me.

110
00:06:00,845 --> 00:06:03,705
There's one more warning down
here that says if groups for

111
00:06:03,705 --> 00:06:05,955
business is activated later,
blah blah blah.

112
00:06:05,955 --> 00:06:07,135
What's that talking about?

113
00:06:07,135 --> 00:06:08,735
Well I'll talk about that in a minute.

114
00:06:08,735 --> 00:06:12,050
Right now we'll work through with
what are called Admin Console Groups.

115
00:06:12,050 --> 00:06:14,550
Groups for
business are the other type of group.

116
00:06:14,550 --> 00:06:18,090
They're the really advanced group
that gives us a lot more features.

117
00:06:18,090 --> 00:06:21,350
So it's just letting me know that if
we set this, and we turn Groups for

118
00:06:21,350 --> 00:06:25,040
business on later, we'll be okay,
this group will actually be converted and

119
00:06:25,040 --> 00:06:27,010
brought into Groups for business.

120
00:06:27,010 --> 00:06:31,662
I'll go ahead and hit create though and
now, I've got this other mailing list.

121
00:06:31,662 --> 00:06:35,980
Now, these lists aren't very
useful just like they are.

122
00:06:35,980 --> 00:06:38,180
We typically need to go and
add some members to them.

123
00:06:38,180 --> 00:06:40,380
So, you'll see manage users,
and we can go and

124
00:06:40,380 --> 00:06:42,960
start to add users in there,
based on what we need.

125
00:06:42,960 --> 00:06:44,320
Right?
People are going to be owners or

126
00:06:44,320 --> 00:06:47,240
managers and
people are just going to be inside of it.

127
00:06:47,240 --> 00:06:51,553
And we'll see more of
that in another segment.

128
00:06:51,553 --> 00:06:55,297
Some of the other things that we can do
once we're in here, well we create these

129
00:06:55,297 --> 00:06:58,532
groups, now we can go and
start sharing resources with the groups or

130
00:06:58,532 --> 00:07:02,433
assigning permissions to areas, we can
use them as group filters for security.

131
00:07:02,433 --> 00:07:05,330
There's all sorts of stuff you can use
with the group Once they're created.

132
00:07:05,330 --> 00:07:07,090
But there are some things you can't do,

133
00:07:07,090 --> 00:07:10,200
and unfortunately some of those things
are right here in our exam objective.

134
00:07:10,200 --> 00:07:14,790
For example, I can't use one of these
Groups as a shared mailbox, right.

135
00:07:14,790 --> 00:07:17,745
The objective said shared mailbox for
a group of users.

136
00:07:17,745 --> 00:07:20,825
Well if I add more than one
person to that sales list, so

137
00:07:20,825 --> 00:07:23,105
let me go back to my sales list.

138
00:07:23,105 --> 00:07:24,515
So when I go to the sales list and

139
00:07:24,515 --> 00:07:27,875
I go to manage users,
there's nobody in here right now.

140
00:07:27,875 --> 00:07:31,885
I'll go and add some people, so I'm
gonna add Marty, and I'll add Nick, and

141
00:07:31,885 --> 00:07:35,795
I'll add Dave.

142
00:07:35,795 --> 00:07:37,095
All right, so
I'm adding these three people.

143
00:07:37,095 --> 00:07:39,920
They're gonna be my sales people so
I'm punching them right in there.

144
00:07:39,920 --> 00:07:41,380
They're now my sales people.

145
00:07:41,380 --> 00:07:43,590
And I guess I should add David too,
I don't wanna leave him out.

146
00:07:44,690 --> 00:07:45,470
There we go.

147
00:07:45,470 --> 00:07:46,600
So we got the good lineup.

148
00:07:46,600 --> 00:07:49,160
So we got them right in there,
they're gonna be my salespeople.

149
00:07:49,160 --> 00:07:50,872
And I'm gonna add them as a member.

150
00:07:50,872 --> 00:07:51,604
All right.

151
00:07:51,604 --> 00:07:56,521
So that means if we send an email
to sales@itprotv.net All four

152
00:07:56,521 --> 00:07:59,081
of these guys are going to get it.

153
00:07:59,081 --> 00:07:59,732
Okay.

154
00:07:59,732 --> 00:08:01,479
And you'll see that they're all members.

155
00:08:01,479 --> 00:08:05,093
Now, I might wanna make
